name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 11 June 2015.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Mr President! These days, the third freedom flotilla again sails to Gaza for the incarcerated people there. I would like to call on everyone to support this peaceful demonstration, so that we can also show the people of Gaza that they are not forgotten by the international community and that we will also strongly denounce Israel's threat to attack again a non-violent action, as they did five years ago, in which several people were killed. I would also like to say to the Council that action must now be taken so that we have a chance to change direction in this unfortunate region.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The final draft agenda as set by the Conference of Presidents pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure was distributed at its meeting on Thursday 11 June 2015. I would like to inform you that the Committee on Legal Affairs has approved the following two reports on immunity: A8-0191/2015 (Hon. Ferrara) and A8-0192/2015 (Hon. Zwiefka). Pursuant to Rule 9(8) of Parliament's Rules of Procedure, these reports will be put to the vote during today's vote. With regard to the Statements by the Council and the Commission on the preparation of the European Council meeting of 25 and 26 June, the Group of the Greens/European Free Party has requested that the speaking time of speakers from the political groups be replaced by an in-depth debate.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, you have been pleased to present our proposal very faithfully. Its justification is simple. We know that the European Union, in particular the Eurozone, is living absolutely decisive hours for its future. We believe that the inclusion on the agenda of this session of a topic such as the Berès report on the future of European economic governance, in addition to the discussion and adoption of the Juncker investment plan, justifies giving more time. Mr Weber, I know that sometimes the Brussels sessions are not very busy, but this time it is rather too much. I therefore believe that this House must be given the means to play its part in public debate at times critical for the future of the European Union.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the On behalf of my group, I would like to support the motion made by Philippe Lamberts for the Greens. It is indeed important that, in view of this discussion and the situation in which we find ourselves, we do not reduce the debate we are having here in Parliament to a debate that can only be had by the group spokesmen with regard to the discussion on Greece. We need more time, and we need more speaking time to do so. It would be a democratic signal and also a signal that we are taking ourselves seriously if we also give other Members the opportunity to speak on this issue.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the preparation of the European Council meeting (25 and 26 June 2015)(2015/2629(RSP)). I would remind you that there is no catch-the-eye procedure for this point, nor will 'blue card' applications be accepted.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Dear President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. Honourable Members, Before turning to the agenda, I would like to note that this is the last plenary session of the European Parliament during the Latvian Presidency. It falls on a day when my country celebrates a very important holiday, a real folk holiday— Lio or the summer solstice. In honor of this celebration and the fact that this is the final plenary session of our Presidency, I will speak in Latvian today.  The Latvian Presidency concludes its participation in the European Parliament plenary session with this very important debate on the preparation of the European Council, the most important event for the European Semester.  The forthcoming Agenda of the European Council is very saturated. The Heads of State or Government of the European Union will discuss migration, security and economic issues. However, before I address these issues, I would like to brief you on the informal meeting of the Heads of State and Government of the euro area on Monday, which was convened at the initiative of the President of the European Council, Mr Tusk. Its aim was to dispel the dangerous ambiguity with regard to Greece. The Heads of State or Government of the Eurogroup exchanged views on the situation in Greece and discussed the progress of negotiations between Greece and international lenders. With this meeting, President Tusk wanted to change the dynamics of the negotiations so far, giving them a new positive momentum. Monday's meeting did indeed give a positive boost. As President Tusk has already pointed out, according to the initial assessment of international lenders, the new proposals by the Greek Government are a positive step in the right direction. At the moment, it is important not to dwell on action. Prime Minister Cipr and international lenders are already working to achieve results at tonight's eurogroup meeting by concluding work on elements of the Greek reform plan that will be presented to the Heads of State and Government tomorrow.  Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. Returning to the European Council's agenda, I would like to begin with the issue of migration. This will undoubtedly be one of the most important items on the agenda of tomorrow's European Council.  As we all know very well, already in April 2015 the European Council decided on emergency measures to prevent further deaths at sea and to find new ways to address smugglers. Many - including the European Parliament - felt that the outcome of the April European Council was insufficient. I will immediately say that the role of the April European Council was not, and could not, be, an immediate resolution of all the problems in the area of migration. There are no quick solutions in this very difficult situation. A sustainable solution can only be possible within the framework of a targeted, comprehensive and balanced approach, which is systematically implemented step by step. Tomorrow's European Council discussion will be another step towards implementing such an approach.  In the few months that have passed since the April European Council, the Council and the Commission have made a valuable contribution to finding a solution. The Presidency, together with the European Commission and the European External Action Service, presented to the President of the European Council a renewed action plan for the implementation decided by the April European Council.  The Commission, as we know, has also published its communication on the European Agenda on Migration. The Council has immediately started to work on the various aspects of the Communication, as well as on the Commission's concrete proposals for the implementation of the measures contained in the European Agenda on Migration. Tomorrow, the European Council will focus on three important elements of this policy: (1) relocation, resettlement, reintegration, (2) return, readmission and (3) cooperation with countries of origin and transit.  These elements are closely interlinked and their effective implementation will best protect those in need. However, safeguards in themselves will not be sufficient. They must go hand in hand with an effective system for returning irregular migrants. It is no secret that the most recent discussions in the Council have now been the result of the Commission's proposal to relocate asylum seekers between the Member States of the European Union. Yesterday's General Affairs Council debate confirmed the unanimity of a common European Union response to the challenge of migration. A balance must be found between solidarity and responsibility, which are an essential part of the European Union's migration policy.  Ministers also expressed their willingness to show solidarity and to find a solution to this emergency caused by migration flows. There is a common understanding that there is a need for an appropriate mechanism to allow an adequate response to this emergency situation and to support the so-called frontline Member States.  However, before that, a number of very important political and technical issues will have to be resolved. Member States differ in the views of the Member States, which exactly the European Union's response should be and how it will refer to each individual EU Member State. This is therefore all the more necessary for the involvement of the European Council and guidance to decisions to take into the future. The issue of migration is very complex and politically sensitive. This requires a smart and balanced approach and does not take solutions "on a fast hand".  What is worrying is the information that has been made today that Hungary is unilaterally planning to suspend the Dublin system. Unilateral action by individual Member States is not an option; only in dialogue and joint action, through the consistent implementation of the existing package, it is possible to respond to the existing challenges.  Therefore, as I said, it is precisely a comprehensive approach that is consistently put into practice and thus provides the necessary support for the short and sustainable solution in the future. It is already clear that the challenges of migration will be at the forefront of our common agenda for a long time and intensive work will continue even after the European Council.  Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. The next item on the agenda of the European Council is the security challenges. The European Union's internal and external security has faced very high challenges over the last year. Europe and the world have undergone dramatic changes, so we are now living in a very different geopolitical situation. The European Council will look at the work being done on internal security and it should be noted that, during the Latvian Presidency, the Council has indeed done a great deal to strengthen security in the European Union. It should be noted that on 16 June the Council approved the renewed Internal Security Strategy of the European Union, which also took into account the european Parliament's contribution. We have made progress on a number of issues, such as a significant increase in the exchange of information between the competent authorities of the Member States, and from 1 July the European Union's internet reporting unit will become operational.  At the same time, however, we must continue to work towards intensified checks at the External Borders of the European Union. The Passenger Name Record Directive should also be agreed before the end of the year. The Council therefore calls on the European Parliament to confirm its position so that we have the opportunity to continue working together when we start a trialogue. As in the area of migration, the Presidency, in cooperation with the European External Action Service, has prepared and will present to the President of the European Council an overview of the progress made in the fight against terrorism.  On the other hand, on the external aspects of security, the European Council will discuss security and defence policy and will assess the progress made in this area since the European Council conclusions of December 2013. This discussion will take place in a situation where there is a new and significantly different internal and external security environment with new types of security challenges.  In this context, it is important to note that the Council has agreed on the launch of the Common Security and Defence Policy Operation (EUNAVFOR MED) in the Mediterranean. At the same time, the European Union needs a new strategy, which the European Council will ask the High Representative to prepare. The Presidency also particularly welcomes the action plan on strategic communication prepared under the leadership of the High Representative. This is an important step in coordinating and strengthening the European Union's capacity to resist disinformation campaigns by third parties. Yesterday, ministers continued discussions in the General Affairs Council on the possibilities of further strengthening the European Union's strategic communication. The new security challenges have also made it clear that the European Union must strengthen its capabilities against hybrid threats. I therefore welcome the decision of the Foreign Affairs Council of 18 May to draw up proposals for the European Union to combat hybrid threats by the end of 2015. We also expect the European Council to stress the need to mobilise European Union instruments to help better counter the hybrid threat. As a Presidency, we welcomed the plan to keep security and defence policy issues on the European Council's agenda on a regular basis. Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. Of course, economic issues will also be on the agenda of this European Council. The European Union's growth figures show that the economic recovery has stabilised in the EU Member States. The EU economy is expected to grow by 1.8% this year and accelerate to 2.1% next year. Unemployment continues to fall. Both external factors and policy measures have contributed to a positive turnaround. This encourages, but growth rates are low, and there is really a lot of work to be done to ensure that economic growth is long-term and sustainable.  The three priorities of the annual cycle of economic policy coordination, or European semester, have just been: firstly, to encourage investment, secondly, to implement structural reforms and, thirdly, to develop responsible fiscal policies. In line with these priorities, recommendations have been made to each Member State of the European Union and the euro area as a whole, which were adopted yesterday by the General Affairs Council and will be approved by the European Council tomorrow. (The speaker indicated that there were problems with interpretation and expressed the hope that they would be resolved.)  Continuing on the economy, it should be stressed that ...  (Technical the speaker interrupted the speech due to problems.)  In the area of economic governance, one priority for the Presidency was to ensure the success of the European Semester in its new, improved form.  (Due to technical problems, the speaker interrupted the speech.)  Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. As I said, one of the priorities of the Presidency in the area of economic governance was to ensure the success of the European Semester in its new, improved form. The early publication of national analyses and greater attention to country-specific recommendations has a positive impact on the sense of responsibility at national level. This, in turn, contributes to the implementation of structural reforms. These reforms are essential for improving Europe's competitiveness and for boosting our economic recovery. The Latvian Presidency has laid good foundations for regular discussions on the most important structural reforms that are currently in place and in the near future. The Council has also done a great deal to create the conditions for long-term and sustainable economic growth.  I will give only three examples. Firstly, we have managed to reach an agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments in record time. I would like to sincerely thank the European Parliament and the European Commission for their intensive work, which I hope will culminate in a positive vote by the European Parliament tonight. Secondly, the Council has focused much in developing the potential of the European Union's single market this month, including through a detailed discussion of obstacles and priorities for the development of the Digital Single Market.  We all know that without reassuring our society to the digital age, we will lose in all areas – employment, growth, competitiveness. The importance of digital technologies for innovation, economic growth and job creation was also particularly noted yesterday by ministers at the General Affairs Council. That is why, in the light of the Commission's Digital Single Market strategy, the European Council intends to set priorities for further work. This work will affect a wider area and not just barriers to a well-functioning digital single market. We expect the European Council to provide further impetus to work on the approval of the legislation essential to the completion of the Digital Single Market. The Latvian Presidency has made every effort to ensure the progress of the Data Protection Regulation, the Telecommunications Single Market and the Network and Information Security Directive.  Finally, when it comes to the economy, the European Council will focus on the development of Europe's economic and monetary union.  On 22 June, a report by five presidents on the development of Europe's economic and monetary union was published. The President of the European Parliament has also participated in its development, as we know.  The European Council provides for the first exchange of views on the five Presidents' report and will continue to work on the issues outlined in the report in all relevant Council formats. The report makes a number of recommendations for better management of Economic and Monetary Union (EMU), which will be examined by the European Heads of State and Government at the June European Council. I don't want to judge their assessment too early. In my opinion, the report contains ideas to gradually make economic and monetary union more effective in the short term and also to complete this structure in the longer term.  I would like to stress that every effort must be made to promote convergence. The differences between euro area Member States may jeopardise the future and economic development of the Union as a whole. Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. As we can see, the agenda of the forthcoming European Council is saturated with a great many topical and important issues. I would like to hear your comments and opinions and I expect an interesting and intense discussion. Thank you very much for your attention!

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. Mr President, Madam Secretary of State, ladies and gentlemen.  When President Juncker addressed this Parliament on 15 July last year, he told you that his primary mission is to rebuild bridges in Europe. In fact, building bridges in Europe, and beyond Europe, is an eminently European task and that is why it is not here today. He would have wanted to be here, among you, now, but he is trying to build bridges with Greece right now.  This is what we have done all these last months, in recent days with Greece: build bridges! Because the European Union is not meant to exclude, but to include, and in Europe, everything is about a permanent dialogue that must be based on understanding and mutual respect. It's not always easy, it's not a long, quiet river, but you get there when everyone is ready to build their own part of the bridge. And we have to find an agreement this week on Greece. Time is running out and we have to get straight to the point. There is no extension. It is imperative to meet the expectations of the suffering Greeks. They are the ones the Commission and President Juncker are thinking about. It is for them that we work, to help them fight unemployment and social insecurity and to build their future on a sound and solid foundation. This means that we must all take responsibility: the Greek government, the Eurogroup, the IMF, the European Parliament and the European Commission.  We must all commit ourselves to a fresh start for jobs, growth and investment through the reforms it will implement, but also through the European Funds.  As soon as all the necessary conditions for an agreement are met, the Commission is ready to activate or rather, reactivate, 35 billion euros of the European budget to support Greece.  President Juncker will propose solutions to facilitate the absorption of the European Structural and Investment Funds and immediately mobilise large sums of money to start investment projects in the real economy.  It is only after joint efforts that we will find an agreement acceptable to all, and we are convinced that this will be the case at the end of the European Council over the next two days.  Building bridges is once again what we must devote our efforts to throughout this European Council. First of all, of course, on the issue of immigration, the Council has mentioned, because if there is one area in which European solidarity can manifest itself, it is immigration.  I attended the Council yesterday and we are sometimes surprised by the ease with which some Member States ask for solidarity, and by their silence when they are asked for solidarity.  We all agree that there is an urgent need to respond to the migration and humanitarian crisis facing all our countries. We have to do it one way or another, because everyone will be confronted with it sooner or later. Having said that, and it is good to have said so, the urgency now is to agree on what needs to be done, so that European solidarity is not a vain word, or a tear to be shed with every tragedy in the Mediterranean, and Europe remains true to its values and interests. The minute's silence at the European Council should not be followed by months of silence when answers are needed. (Applause) What we need to do is reach out to those unfortunates who, at the risk of their lives, leave their conflict-torn country in search of international protection to which they are entitled. It is a matter of respect for human dignity.  We must also express our solidarity with the Member States which are facing a high migratory pressure. Today it is Italy and Greece. Tomorrow it could be other countries.  In any case, solidarity mechanisms are needed, and it is now that we must put them in place, acting together and not against each other. It's now, not tomorrow, because people are still dying in the Mediterranean.  Let us be clear, we are not talking about quotas when we are talking about human beings. It's a misunderstanding. We are talking about a redistribution key and we are not talking about quotas on the right to asylum. We all have an obligation to stand in solidarity. President Juncker will therefore strongly defend the Commission's proposals on relocation and resettlement, because these proposals are necessary and ensure a good balance between solidarity and responsibility. No Member State has presented us with better solutions. (Applause) We are told has said several times, "We don't want that," but we have not been offered any other solution. And I stress, the division between Member States must be done on an effective basis, because experience has shown us that if it is voluntary, it does not work.  We will therefore have to agree, by the end of July, on the practical modalities of a solidarity and equitable distribution between the Member States in order to implement these measures as soon as possible.  The cost of our inaction today would be just as great for migrants as it would be for Europe, where solidarity must be shared. We have to take this step together. To do nothing now would be to deny our values, the values to which we are strongly attached. (Applause) We know very well that some countries have opt-ins, others opt out, but Europe is all the more credible when it supports those who are most vulnerable and when it acts united and united. And I am pleased that Ireland, but also Norway, Switzerland and Liechtenstein have made known their intention to participate in this relocation mechanism. We invite other countries to follow their example. On the other hand, if we are to be generous to those in need of international protection, we must be firm towards those who have no reason to stay in Europe, nor any need for international protection. That is why we have put forward proposals to strengthen our return and readmission policies. It is clear that our people's support for a human asylum policy decreases when people feel that those who are not entitled to asylum are abusing that asylum to stay anyway. We really need to look at this issue on both sides. And since it is not enough to combat the symptoms of the crisis, we must also strengthen our cooperation with the countries of origin and transit to address the causes of the crisis. We are well aware of these causes. These are instability, war and poverty in Libya, Syria, Iraq and across Africa. Here, too, we need to build bridges and develop more shared responsibilities and cooperation with our African partners. Member States must increase their development aid at all costs. It's a must. We need 0.7% now, not tomorrow, not next year, but now! In terms of defence, from Ukraine to Syria, through the Middle East and North Africa, our neighbourhood is increasingly fragile and unstable. One would have to be naïve to think that Europe could only be a soft power. There can be no durable soft power without hard power, without built-in defense capabilities. Again, it is a question of credibility. It is not a question of building a European army overnight. It is an old European project, a long-term project. Nor is it a question of making the European Union a counter-project to NATO. We are not competitors, but partners, we must work together and be in sync.  What we need in the area of defence is enhanced cooperation, as the Lisbon Treaty provides. We need to do more together and refrain from taking separate and divided initiatives at the national level.  Today, in the European Union, more than 80% of investment in defence equipment is spent at the national level. So, if only for budgetary reasons, there is also a need to build bridges and cooperate more in defence markets, in research and innovation to meet common needs and challenges.  Finally, we must build bridges to the future and achieve economic and monetary union while preserving the integrity of the single market.  The crisis has shown us that the euro protects us. He brought us monetary stability. Without the euro, we would have had very unpleasant moments of unwinding of national selfishness. But the protective virtues of the euro do not fall from the sky: they are directly linked to our ability to implement policies focused on stability, on balanced economic growth, on a competitive social market economy in the service of full employment, social progress and prosperity of citizens. This is precisely the objective of the report's proposals - I see that the English interpretation is working well - that has become that of the five presidents, since President Juncker was also keen to involve President Schulz in it.  The report includes a roadmap for achieving economic and monetary union, which is ambitious and nevertheless pragmatic. Some of the proposed initiatives can and should be be put in place without delay. The first measures should be launched by the institutions as early as 1 July 2015; others require more time. Above all, this report offers a clear direction, essential for citizens and economic actors and for confidence in the single currency. The first phase, or deepening through practice, begins today until June 2017. It builds on existing instruments and existing treaties to boost competitiveness and convergence, ensure responsible fiscal policies, complete financial union and strengthen the democratic accountability of economic and monetary union. The second phase of the completion of the economic and monetary union will allow us to take greater action to make the convergence process more binding and create a euro area treasure. The final phase by 2015 will provide a stable and prosperous framework for all EU Member States that have adopted the single currency and an attractive environment for others.  To build intelligently and serenely in stages, as we propose, an economic union, a financial union, a fiscal union and a political union, is not an end in itself, but a means of meeting the expectations of the citizens and preparing the Union for future global challenges. Because Europe is more than the single market and the single currency, Europe, it is a broad, vast and ambitious project for its citizens, but not just for its citizens. Ik wil eindigen in mijn moedertaal. Vandaag is in Nederland een zeer bekende en geliefde zanger en muzikant overleden, Tea Lau, en ik wil hem aan het slot van mijn betoog citeren, omdat zijn meest beroemde vers van zeer grote toepassing is op de Europese Raad en op de geest die zich, naar ik hoop, meester zal maken van de leden van de Europese Raad. Ik quote: "Iedereen is van de wereld en de wereld is van iedereen".

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr Vice-President, representative of the European Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work and for the work she has said. I would like to confine myself today to two points which are certainly being discussed at the forefront of the Council and which are the ones that are most perplexing and moving us all. One is firstly our eurozone, our currency in the European Union, and above all, of course, Greece. The European People's Party wants Greece to stay in the euro. We feel that the situation is serious these days, that difficult decisions need to be made. Jean-Claude Juncker, in particular, has the full support of his group for his negotiations, which he is now leading. I would also like to say that, whether we are experiencing the crisis we experienced with the economic and financial crisis five years ago, we Europeans can also be a little proud of what we have achieved in other countries. Portugal, Spain, Ireland and Cyprus are four countries that have been programme countries and have already left the programme behind, and are again on their own. Now this week Greece remains as a big question to be resolved. First of all, I would like to express frustration at the fact that an enormous amount of time has been wasted. We have now been discussing the matter at technical level for months, there has been talk, it has been shaded. Nothing has come out, we have wasted time without end because Greece – the new Greek Government – has not been able to put concrete proposals on the table. On Monday, thank God, we have at least received at least one text. After the first five months of a communist government, I think it is worth taking a look at what these new politicians have achieved, what has been moved. It was also said that they had taken over a broken country and would now dare to build it. I take a look at this balance sheet. In January, we had a situation where there was a slight surplus in Greece's state budget. Now this surplus has melted down, there is again a deficit in the budget. Pensions can no longer be paid at the end of the month. It was in January that we had slight growth. After years of very difficult and catastrophic economic development, we had slight growth in January. What do we have now? A severe recession: no one is investing in Greece anymore. We had banks that were reasonably stable. Today, Greek banks are facing a bank run. Billions are withdrawn almost every day because their own citizens no longer have confidence in the financial institutions there. The biggest promise was that the rich in Greece must finally pay. I think that, after five months, we can ask what has become of this promise. Can the rich finally be asked to pay? We have a communist government that has destroyed this country in recent months, and that must be said.  That is the record we are facing after five months of Tsipras. Nevertheless, we are trying, but negotiations are still taking place. As the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, conditionality is an important point for us, because Greece needs a plan to get out of this negative spiral that can be observed there. That is why we are calling for a programme on which the lenders agree, together with Greece, which, at the end of the day, also offers a perspective for Greece. I would like to say explicitly that the ball is in Athens. We need proposals from Athens on how to solve the problems. We will also need a parliamentary majority in Athens for this programme. Simple signatures from Tsipras and Varoufakis will no longer be enough to win the trust of Europeans. That is the situation we are in. You feel that many in our group are frustrated by the behaviour of our Greek partner. In spite of all this, we will support all efforts to keep Greece in the euro. We owe that to the people of Greece – not to the government, but to the people. Thousands have demonstrated on the streets of Athens over the last few days who want to stay in the euro and want the help of Europeans. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats stand by these people. I would like to pick up on a second point, namely the migration issue, which has been discussed. We need legal routes for those who come to Europe, especially those who need our protection. The European Commission's proposal, particularly on the distribution of Syrian refugees, is a good proposal. A proposal that no one usually rejects Can. That is why we support the Commission to remain stubborn and to really demand help from the states for Syrian refugees – refugees defined by the UNHCR. However, on the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I also say that we must remember the figures and the abuses. Last year, two thirds of all applicants in the European Union were rejected. If we look at this, we must also make it clear that Europe must work to secure the external border better. Even on the external border of a continent, one can say: you are allowed in. And you can also say to someone who has no legal reason: you have to stay outside. From our point of view, it is not acceptable for refugees to come from countries that are candidates for EU membership with which we are negotiating, such as Serbia, for example. We need clarification that these are safe third countries. Incidentally, also in the case of Turkey, which should also take over the repatriation of rejected applicants. I also believe that, mr Vice-President, on the return policy, the Commission should talk more intensively with the African and Asian countries of origin, so that these return agreements can finally be concluded. We need a balanced proposal: aid on the one hand, demarcation from the extreme forces that we have in Europe, which, unfortunately, all foreigners are lumping together, and, on the other hand, proper border security and the fight against abuse.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the Latvian Presidency for its work. Today I sincerely wanted to comment on the final outcome of the negotiations on Greece, but we are still discussing 'if'.  I remember that in February it was said that agreement had been reached; in April the same thing was said. Last Monday, it seemed that agreement had finally been reached. I believe that this is the right time, but I still hear critical voices: members of the International Monetary Fund, some figures on the European right... And I am sorry that someone I hold in high regard, such as Mr Weber, still says today at 3 p.m. that the Greek Government still has to make proposals.  The agreement is there, it is on the table, and it has been achieved mainly thanks to the efforts of President Juncker and the European Commission, who must be given the opportunity to acknowledge that they have behaved with balance and responsibility. But if the deal is there, why wait? What should we wait for?  I dare not imagine... We would be ludicrous if, for some point of VAT on Greek catering, the integrity of the euro area and the future of Europe were to be jeopardised. What game are we playing? If anyone wants to stretch the time to humiliate the Greek people, we tell them that they are wrong.  The governments – and we are not in the Tsipras government – change with the citizens' vote. And now there is no question of the Tsipras government, nor of the judgment on the Tsipras government: the salvation of the Greek people and the salvation and integrity of the eurozone are now under discussion.  The exhausting continuation of technical discussions reveals the danger of a bureaucratic Europe without vision, including on immigration.  I would like to thank President Timmermans for making a robust, firm and vision-taking speech. But it is not the same in the Council. I must say this with great sincerity and also with great sadness.  On the one hand there are countries like Italy that are committed to doing everything possible to save lives in the Mediterranean, on the other there are governments such as the Hungarian government that unilaterally raise walls of protection against migrants. And I have to say that I am very sad that it is precisely a country like Hungary, which has suffered in its own skin from the Iron Curtain, that is building new walls against migrants.  The European Commission's strategy has been right and seems to be partly accepted by the Member States, only in part. Well the confirmation of the forty thousand migrants who will be welcomed in Europe. Well the establishment of hotspots. But that is not enough. I understand diplomacy, but we cannot reduce everything to an ambiguous lexical exercise.  I hear that some States are in favour of solidarity but are against compulsory mechanisms. What does that mean? I must explain to you what it means that they must not be compulsory mechanisms. Explain to me in concrete terms what that means. And do we want, faced with such a huge theme, to take refuge in the lexical exercise of a distinction of words? Or do we have to go into substance and show the attributes and show that we are up to being the leader of a Europe? If we are not the leader of a Europe... I say this to the governments.  Why do we get scared and complain about the populist drift? The populist drift is anti-European; is the result of a lack of attributes if Orbán does those things. If one state sets itself against another state, it is because there is no European decision. If there is and if there is a European vision, these things will end.  That is why the European Parliament has every right to make its voice heard. This House – despite some minorities that I respect, but whose position I do not share – has always expressed strong positions on this issue, which I would like to reiterate in my speech.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would also like to thank the Latvian Presidency for their time in office. I know this is their last part-session. One of the problems holding back competitiveness in the EU is that, whatever the problem, the solutions proposed here seem to be more Europe and more regulation; and while we in the ECR campaign against red tape that holds back businesses from creating jobs, as we consider the issues to be discussed at the summit – Greece and the Mediterranean crisis – the solution seems to be not more red tape, but more sticking plaster, more Band-Aid. Consider the patient that is the Greek economy. Each time we approach another Greek crisis, rather than sticking to the medicine, we propose more sticking plaster. The solution is yet again more expensive sticking plaster in the form of a bailout, until the next Greek crisis when the solution is yet again more sticking plaster – bailout or restructuring – until the next Greek crisis, and so on. If and when we reach another deal, how long will it be before we are back here again in this Chamber debating the same issues? How long until the eurozone runs out of sticking plaster? How long will this blame game go on between the Member States, with northern eurozone countries arguing that they can afford to keep Greece in the euro but not being honest with their taxpayers that a currency union requires fiscal transfers from the richer countries to the poorer countries – probably for ever? The Greek Government has to play its role and also behave responsibly, as other group leaders have said. It is time to stop the sticking plaster. It is time to start sticking to the rules. If we look at the crisis in the Mediterranean, there is no easy answer, despite what many people claim. We cannot let no one in, yet we cannot let everyone in. But until we have a strategy, we will simply be providing lifeboats, plucking unfortunate desperate people from the sea. The Commission’s plan raises some important issues – targeting traffickers, processing applications and returning those not fleeing persecution; helping those in failing states on the front line. But while some EU countries could probably do more to help, proposing a quota system was a mistake because, instead of cooperation, the Commission has proposed coercion. So instead of solidarity, we now have polarity. Instead of countries working with each other, we have countries arguing with each other. Let us come together in a spirit of cooperation to alleviate the suffering of those in countries from which people flee, to process genuine applications before they make that hazardous journey, and to target the people traffickers who sell a false hope – not another sticking plaster solution until a future summit. And on security and defence, cooperation on coordination, not coercion, should be the principle that we will abide by. In country after country, election after election, the voters are saying what the ECR has been saying: Europe cannot go on as it, Europe has to change. So as the British Prime Minister David Cameron introduces ideas for reform, do not see it as simply a shopping list for Britain, but seize it as a chance for genuine reform of the EU. Then, maybe, all of us in the EU will be better placed to face the challenges: the challenges within our borders, the challenges at our borders, and the challenges beyond our borders.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –  Mr President, first of all, I want to say to Mr Timmermans – I thought you were singing at the end but you were not – that I fully agree with what you said on migration and with the proposals that you have made. The only point that I would like to make is that you have to follow through on what you said. What you said is true, but what we see now in Hungary – and Mr Pittella referred to this – is a scandal in itself, because it goes against the acquis communautaire. It goes against the common and solidarity-based approach that you have defended here in this House. So I hope that, at the end of your second intervention and in the coming days, the Commission will be clear that what Mr Orbán is doing is against the rules of Europe and that it will not go through. That is what I accept with regard to both the wall and the other issues. My second point is on Greece. I think that we will have a deal. I do not think there is any other choice than to make a deal. There is no other choice, because a Grexit would be the worst thing for everybody: the worst thing for the Greek people, because the first thing that would happen would be a devaluation and another loss of their purchasing power of 30—40% on top of all the efforts of the past; and it would be a bad thing for Europe and for the eurozone, because it would in fact be indicating that the euro is not a stable currency, as you can come in and go out. It would be like a party where you enter when you have money and you go out when you no longer have any money. So I think we are going to find a solution – but will it be long-lasting solution? Let us be honest. What we are talking about is EUR 7 billion in the second package. We are not talking about a solution for Greece, but about how to give these last EUR 7 billion of the second package. Everybody knows – and everybody is writing – that we will discuss a third package in the future and that it is absolutely necessary to have a fundamental solution for Greece. What we are talking about is not a fundamental solution. A fundamental solution for Greece would be based on two elements. The first element is that in Greece they would really start to end the clientelistic and corrupt systems, the oversized public sector and the non—opening of the private markets. That has not been done. It is not about picking a little at low pensions or low wages but about changing the social system that exists. That is not happening – not with the deal that they are making at the moment. A second point is that we must have a structural solution for governing the debt in Europe. I think it would have been far better if they had listened to Parliament and if we had started three years ago with the redemption contract. That should have solved the problem. But now we are dealing with a country like Greece, which is asking for money, and the others say: ‘We will not give money to Greece because what have we received? Why did we not receive the same help?’ With the redemption fund, everybody could have the same help in the future. That was the right way to do it. Finally, on the report: I am pleased with the report by the five Presidents on completing Europe’s economic and monetary union, Mr Timmermans. I think it is a good basis. It is not complete – for example, the redemption fund is not in it – but it is a good basis to start. I hope that we in Parliament can support this approach. Having said that, I have to tell you something – and I am saying this directly to Mr Pittella and Mr Weber: we are going to vote in four or five hours from now on a report – the Berès report. What are we talking about? We are going to vote on the Berès report, and it has less ambition than the paper by the five Presidents. What are we doing? This Parliament, which has always been ahead in economic governance in the European Union, is now going to vote on a report which does not even deal with all these problems. Mr Weber, I know how it works and that you have made a little deal downsizing the whole thing and saying that it is an own initiative report. I can tell you that I have seen better reports from Pervenche Berès. It is not a question of the intelligence of Pervenche Berès, but it is not the best that you have ever done. Having said that, I think that we are going to ask to have it sent back to committee before the start of the vote, because it is completely crazy and completely useless. I say to all my colleagues – and certainly to the EPP – that you will now start voting now on a report that has already been taken off the table due to a good proposal from President Juncker.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, on Monday I saw communications which saw the solution to the Greek problem at the door. The Eurogroup communication considered it very good, the Commission welcomed it as a very good basis, at the summit everyone said that we were very close to the agreement and, suddenly, internal undermining began.  The International Monetary Fund and some conservative governments, which are a minority within Europe, seem not to want a deal, even though that is in the common interest of both Greece and Europe. On the contrary, they want to undermine it and they want to humiliate the Greek people, to question the need to respect not only the rules, but also the Republic.  The Greek government, in cooperation with the Commission services, has tabled a proposal that ensures settled public finances with primary surpluses, that promotes reforms to combat bureaucracy, corruption, the client state. Which puts an end to the shame of early retirements of people aged forty and fifty, that your political friends, Mr Weber, have voted and implemented in Greece for decades and not SYRIZA, and please let go of intolerance.  It is time for everyone to contribute to solutions to remove the word Grexit from the vocabulary of the European debate, to put the Greek people and Greece on the path to development. So don't finger us, gentlemen of the Conservative party, because you have implemented along with the troika - in violation of European Union rules - a policy that has caused thirty per cent pay and pension cuts, tripled unemployment, brought a twenty-five per cent recession and soared debt from one hundred and twenty-five per cent, to one hundred and eighty per cent of GDP.  We need settled public finances, but also growth as well as sustainable debt and this is a European, political problem and must be solved with shared responsibility.  We have tabled proposals, we have tabled equivalents and now some people from the International Monetary Fund say we do not like equivalents. I don't know. Because we tax the rich, because we tax those who have an income of more than fifty thousand euros a year, those who make profits of more than five hundred thousand euros a year in a country that has one and a half million unemployed and that nine out of ten unemployed do not get a single euro.  The message from my group is clear: a solution is needed, an urgent solution is needed, it is perfectly possible, it is ready on the basis of what was tabled and considered a basis for discussion on Monday.  Mr Timmermans, work on them, the International Monetary Fund does not have to be at the heart of Europe, Europe has the mechanisms and institutions to respond to them.  Respecting democracy, Greece, and the Greek government, is ready to agree, but the Greek people are not ready to kneel and be humiliated, and everyone must understand that.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the ingredients for an exit from the crisis for Greece are known. First of all, these are structural reforms that would allow Greece to recover. I am thinking, in particular, of the establishment of a socially fair, economically efficient and environmentally friendly tax system. The aim is to reform the pension system to make it financially bearable, while respecting the rights of the most vulnerable and insecure pensioners. This includes reducing the military spending that makes Greece one of THE champions, I am sorry to say, of NATO. It is about putting in place an effective administration. It is a matter of effectively combating corruption and clientelism. First element. On all these points, the Greek government, elected in January, may have sometimes belatedly, sometimes clumsily, proved that it was ready to commit.  The second element is investment. Everyone knows that today investing in Greece is out of reach of the Greek economy. I thank the Commission which, through Commissioner Timmermans, has shown that it is ready to commit itself. I would like the Council to be prepared to target the Juncker plan, in particular on the countries that need it most, first and foremost Greece.  The third element is to make Greek debt sustainable. The latter was unsustainable in 2010. It was in 2012 after the first aid plan for Greece. It is still after the second aid plan for Greece, and I would add that the structural reforms that have been imposed on Greece have aggravated the situation. Those who refused to consider a restructuring of the Greek debt have demonstrated, and still show today, either grime economic incompetence, a denial of guilty reality, or an ideological obsession with trying to make borrowers pay the price of irresponsibility alone, leaving the creditors, equally irresponsible, in complete freedom. Today, the restructuring of the Greek debt must be on the agenda and firm commitments must be made on this subject.  Albert Einstein said that madness is about doing, redoing and doing the same thing again, hoping for different results. I hope that instead of madness, collective intelligence will prevail in the Council. I know that some in some creditor governments, within the European Central Bank - even within the European Central Bank! - want to fail and want Greece to leave the eurozone. I know it and I hear it, because they have told me about it personally. I think that is irresponsible. I can fully understand that the emergence of political forces and political options that stand out from single thinking can annoy or unsupportant some. However, I believe that it would be politically irresponsible to refuse this option, because this would be tantamount to paving the way for those in this House who are fearing, stigmatifying and rejecting the other their trade fund.

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, during last year’s European elections we in UKIP were told that we were mad – crazy – when we spoke about a European army. Now Mr Timmermans has just said – and I quote – ‘a European army is a long-term European objective’. So thank you very much, Mr Timmermans, for clarifying that position before the referendum. It is clear to me that the three most important issues at this European Council are: how the European Union will deal with the issue of immigration; the controversial TTIP deal; and, of course, Greece. Firstly, the problems surrounding migration were brought home to MEPs yesterday, because a number of British representatives could not get here because of the chaos in Calais, where a workers’ strike resulted in migrants running amok and boarding lorries and cars trying to make their way to the UK, and as a consequence, the Channel Tunnel was closed. But this is nothing compared to what is to come. There are half a million migrants in the Mediterranean waiting to make their way through Europe, and frighteningly, there are another half a million making their way through Africa and the Middle East – and what is worse is that we do not know who these people really are. We are told that ISIS is using this chaos to import their wicked and warped ideology onto our continent, which makes the next terrorist attack not a case of if, but when and where. The answer is not a common EU asylum policy. Mr Timmermans, I have a better suggestion. The answer is an Australian-style ring of steel, which protects our borders and sends out a clear message that Europe is not a soft touch. Now, let us move on to TTIP. We all know how worried you lot are about TTIP by the way you behaved in Strasbourg earlier this month. You cancelled the vote on TTIP; you silenced any debate on the issue; you ignored millions of citizens across Europe who have legitimate concerns. Let me make this clear: TTIP is a corporatist scam which will hurt workers, consumers, pensions, farmers and small businesses. It gives an unfair advantage to large corporations. It is a lobbyist’s dream. There are 30 000 lobbyists here in Brussels – that is over 40 per MEP. There are more lobbyists here than there are in Washington DC, and therefore it is no surprise to me that the Commission and the big groups in this Parliament support TTIP. People are concerned about the damaging effects of TTIP. We should put aside our political differences and stand united against this secretive stitch-up. On a final note, my heart goes out to the people of Greece, who are being impoverished by the European Union. To witness the cradle of democracy being threatened by the Brussels bully-boys is a truly sickening sight. So let us stand together against TTIP and stand united in our support of the people of Greece.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: For the sake of information, President Schulz had decided to postpone the vote and the sovereign plenary decided to postpone the debate. So the vote has not been cancelled or the debate cancelled. They've just been postponed.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, you were looking for me in the front row, I suppose? But democracy is struggling to move forward in this Parliament, as we knew. So it has already come down from a few bleachers, it has five left, but I have no doubt that this Parliament, which is so committed to democracy and respect for all groups, will manage to find a solution and put an end to what appears to all to be a terrifying discrimination.  So, Members, the current negotiations between the European Union and Greece are fierce. Brussels does not want to give up anything and tries to impose on the Greeks the pursuit of hyper-austerity that destroys their country. The reduction of pensions and the minimum wage and the increase in VAT have already destroyed the Greek economy and make no sense, even from a financial point of view. Yet you are asking the Greeks to leave for a tour of this deadly scenario. Everyone knows that Greece, burdened by a debt equal to 180% of its GDP, cannot repay its creditors, but you are asking the Greek people to continue to carry the burden of an absolutely unsustainable public debt. You thus practice slavery for debt against this people, the same debt slavery that had been abolished by Solon in 500 BC. Let me tell you that this is a nice step backwards. If Tsipras refuses your implacable terms, the Greek state will default on its public debt on June 30. As a result, Greece's fragile banks will go bankrupt. We all know that the text voted in 2014 by this Parliament, which we have dubbed 'the wall': a single resolution mechanism, should apply. You will then send all Greek savers into this wall. Have you told the people of Europe that this text requires the seizure of all their deposits and savings bank accounts above EUR 100,000, if their failing banks are to be recapitalised? No? You have carefully hidden it from your constituents? Did you say that Article 6 of this text allows the European Commission to lower this threshold of disposing of savings by 100,000 euros, to what, 20,000, 10,000, 5,000 or zero euros? I will quickly read Article 6 to refresh your memory, the amount covered - the 100,000 euros therefore - is subject to periodic review, taking into account in particular the evolution of the banking sector and the economic and monetary situation in the Union. This review will not take place until July 3, 2020. Phew! Unless unforeseen events make it necessary at a later date. This rule is not only tyrannical, but it is also stupid. When the citizens of European countries understand your manoeuvres, depositors' confidence in their banking system will be destroyed, which will speed up Bank Runs in crisis situations. But you have no choice, to try to save once again, the euro, even at the cost of confiscating the bank deposits of your citizens. You have therefore shamefully voted for this text and then hidden from all savers that you will be able to steal their savings in the event of the bankruptcy of their bank. Gentlemen, it is time to get rid of the golden calf that is the euro and stop these follies, it is time to return to democracy and give back to every people its national currency!

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Mr President, the agreement being prepared by the government and lenders, in front of the summit, leads to the carmaniola of the working-class family in Greece, while providing for new unpopular measures, while maintaining the harsh measures of previous governments. From the so-called tearing up of the memorandums promised by the SYRIZA/ANEL government, it is now recommending to the lenders a new memorandum to serve in full the unbearable debt of plutocracy that the people do not owe. With increases in indirect taxes, privatisations, abolition of insurance rights, an increase in insurance contributions bring new unbearable losses to the already slashed popular income. The Communist Party of Greece calls on the people, without waiting, to reject blackmail, to reject the government's calls for submission to the realism of the Euro-one-way street and the capitalist path of development that brings misery and poverty. Oppose the new unpopular agreement and block unpopular measures by denying debt. To demand the abolition of the Memorandums and the recovery of all losses in the path of real rupture with the European Union, their capital and their power.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before giving the floor to the First Vice-President of the Commission and Mrs Kalnièa-Lukashevica, I have the great pleasure of informing you that a delegation from the Indian Parliament has taken its seat in the gallery of official visitors. I can extend a warm welcome to the Indian delegation led by the President of lok Sabha, Mr Sabha. Sumitra Mahajan.  The delegation is here today at the invitation of the President to strengthen the ties between our two parliaments. Meetings between the Indian Parliament and the European Parliament have been held since 1981. India's importance to the European Union is growing as a reflection of the strategic partnership established in 2004, and our delegation for relations with India undertook a series of visits to india, most recently in March this year, when the President had the pleasure of inviting the honourable President of the Indian Parliament to Brussels. It is a pleasure to welcome our friends and colleagues from Lok Sabha here today. We hope that your visit to the European Parliament, which began earlier this week and ends today, has been positive and will help to increase friendship and communication between our parliaments in the coming years. I now give the floor for a very brief greeting to Mr Beazley. Mr Van Orden, Chairman of the EU-India Parliamentary Delegation.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: – Mr President, I shall be brief. It is indeed a great honour and pleasure to have the speaker of a parliament that represents over a billion people in India, the largest democracy in the world, and it is the first time we have had the Speaker of the Lok Sabha here in 16 years, so it is a particular honour and pleasure. I did say in our discussions earlier that there were many views about the future of Europe, and I think listening to the discussion in the last few minutes she will have had a flavour of some of that variety of views. Parliamentarians can be extremely helpful in pushing forward the relationship with a great country like India. We do need the summit which now is going to take place in November, we do need to make progress on the Free Trade Agreement, and thanks to the efforts of parliamentarians on both sides, I hope that will now go forward at a more accelerated pace. I would just share two very brief words that the Speaker of the Lok Sabha mentioned in her discussion with us earlier today: ‘Nurture nature’ was one of the things that she mentioned to us, and the other was that we should take less, and give more. I think these were very wise words and ones that we could all remember. You are very welcome.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I would like to extend a warm greeting to the representatives of the Indian Parliament. You will always be welcome in Europe.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me react to some of the remarks and comments made. First, on Greece, I insist the Commission will continue its efforts to find a compromise which is acceptable to everyone, which is based on the idea that we should not let the Greek people suffer more, and find a way out of this problem. Those of you who have argued – I refer especially to Mr Nuttall and Ms Le Pen – that that they are great friends of the Greek people and are arguing against the euro and saying that we should leave the euro, should perhaps reconsider their friendship or their position, because the Greek people by a vast majority do not want to get rid of the euro. They want to find a solution within the euro and, if you declare yourselves to be such great friends of the Greek people, you might perhaps even follow their wisdom in that. Now I can see somebody sitting next to Ms Le Pen making a signal as though you are completely crazy. So your friends call you crazy. (Interjection from the floor: ‘The euro is a disaster, Sir’) Sir, with friends like you, I would rather have enemies. (Interjection from the floor: ‘Better than the Eurozone’) Another subject that surprised me is that Mr Nuttall complained about the fact that his MEPs could not reach the European Parliament yesterday because of a strike. I was under the impression that his party did everything possible to get rid of the European Parliament. You cannot have it both ways, Mr Nuttall. (Interjections from the floor: ‘No, he said British MEPs’; ‘They are all trying to enter Britain, Sir, they are all trying to flee Europe’) I would hope that not all British MEPs forgot about their wonderful, wonderful legacy of being open to the world, of being self-confident enough not to be thinking in terms of building gates along the borders of Europe. This brings me immediately to my second point, which is on migration. Either we will find European solutions, or we will not find solutions and keep on working with the problems we have today. That is my deep conviction. I think to create the impression that, by keeping people out, we will solve the problem is not only morally suspect but is politically impossible. It will not happen. We are not Australia. We are not located in the middle of an ocean. We cannot apply the same solutions. By the way, what are you going to say to the family fleeing war in Damascus, or in other places in Syria or elsewhere? ‘You have no right to asylum, you should stay there, you should be killed there? No, you should stay in the region.’ Yes, go and say that to countries like Jordan. Go and say that to a country like Lebanon, where one quarter of the population are refugees. Sir, I think you need to rethink this idea that, by simply keeping people out, we will solve the problem. Europe will need to take its responsibility to find a sustainable solution based on our values. If we compromise our values on this issue, we will compromise our values on all other issues that we need to deal with, including issues pertaining to our own citizens. (Applause) So I plead with the Council to follow the Commission’s reasoning tomorrow. Give us better reasoning, give us better solutions or follow our reasoning. The Commission will stick to its proposition. I feel reinforced today by the position of the majority of this Parliament to stick to this proposition. We have tried before with voluntary schemes. They have failed. I think it is an issue of political and moral integrity to see that and to draw the right conclusions from that. I wish the members of the European Council the inspiration to take this seriously. On the specific issue raised by Mr Verhofstadt on Hungary, the Commission is now in close consultation with the Hungarian Government to know what these technical reasons are; why, etc. We are not even sure that there is a suspension. There are all sorts of rumours, so we are trying to find out exactly what has happened. We will certainly demand of all Member States that they apply the rules and, if there is an emergency situation – there are indications that Hungary is facing a sudden enormous surge of refugees; that can be an emergency situation – we have instruments at our disposal to assist Member States to address that emergency situation. But simply stopping admission is not one of the instruments allowed by European rules. We are there to assist Member States and we are also fully committed to assisting Hungary in this. We are in the process of talking to them about this, but we do urge all Member States to simply respect the rules we have agreed jointly. We will certainly continue to follow this very closely with Hungary. Finally, I want to reiterate, on behalf of the Commission, that this European Council needs to take bold steps forward in terms of the migration issue. If we do not decide today, more people will die and we will not be able to start implementing the rules and the necessary measures we will need to discuss in July. The Commission will appeal – Jean-Claude Juncker will appeal – to all other members of the European Council to take responsibility on the basis of the Commission’s proposal, with strong support from the European Parliament. (Interjection from the floor: ‘Grexit followed by Brexit’)

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Dear President, representative of the Commission, honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. Thank you for this very dynamic, accurate, specific discussion! About migration. As I said, the Council is looking for a comprehensive, balanced and long-term solution. I understand that the European Commission is determined to defend its proposal, but the Council is not yet convinced that this is the best way to solve the causes of the problem, rather than simply combating the consequences of the crisis.  Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. If there is a flood at any point, it is necessary to build a dam instead of squealing water with a bucket. I would stress (if I did not say enough clearly at first) that no one in the Council has any doubts about the need to help those who really need help. No one in the Council has any doubts about the need to strengthen development cooperation. No one has any doubts about cooperation with countries of origin and assistance to 'frontline countries' about the need to combat people smugglers. But we still need to discuss the best way to achieve a smart, sustainable solution, a real and effective solution.  At the same time, the Council has always been ready to react. The Council has been actively working to implement the measures approved by the April Extraordinary European Council and to prevent the loss of life in the Mediterranean. I would remind you that the Council has supported a triple increase in the frontex agency's budget. Member States have provided additional technical and human resources for Frontex. And this has already allowed people to be saved lives in the Mediterranean and prevented the april tragedy from happening again. Secondly, as I said, the Council has agreed to launch a common security and defence policy operation in the Mediterranean. Thirdly, the Council is actively working on preventive and comprehensive cooperation with countries of origin and transit. The Council will find a solution and agreement on truly comprehensive solutions to migration policy as a whole. About Greece. I understand the impatience of the European Parliament. We are all looking impatiently towards Greece, and I agree that the situation is not straightforward. However, we must allow Greece to show us all that it is able to offer and implement a reform plan. And tomorrow's meeting, I hope, will bring positive news.  A man doesn't drown because he ever falls into the water. A man drowns because he stays in the water. We must give Greece a chance to get out of this pit. We can only hope that the outcome of the negotiations will be sustainable. Reforms and consolidation are always painful. However, from our national experience, we can also say that voters are able to appreciate positively the courage of the government and the ability to make difficult decisions operationally, to do the necessary work to ensure stability, prosperity and security for their citizens. Therefore, a solution is needed, not prolonged agony and stagnation. I think it is in all our interests to see a strong, united, economically prosperous European Union, a single euro area, a stable economy. We must therefore be able to overcome its difficulties, be able to act boldly and do the necessary work, and issues relating to the common economy of the European Union, on national-specific recommendations, on the five presidents' report, and also the question of strengthening the European Union's internal and external security, are equally important on the European Council's agenda. These are all very, very closely related to each other.  Thanks for today's discussion! Let me take this opportunity to thank the European Parliament very much for the very fruitful cooperation of these six months with the Latvian Presidency. We have had dynamic discussions, we have sought solutions to many difficulties, and important issues have been agreed. Thank you great for that! And I would like to wish not only the next Luxembourg Presidency, but the European Union as a whole, that the next semester be calmer, so that there is less crisis, but more stability, security and growth. Thanks great!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Parliament also thanks the outgoing Presidency for the work and excellent cooperation that has taken place over the past six months. Thank you again. The debate is closed.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, I did not ask you to speak on a point of order. I asked for the floor for the previous debate. The bureau promised me he'd give me the floor, and he didn't give it to me. That's the problem. I asked for a minute to speak on the previous topic, he said yes, he sent me a representative to speak and finally he didn't give me the floor, what should I do now?

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The problem, as I understand it, is that, at the debate, it was about the heads of political groups. From this point of view, no other member could take the word. But this formula was found, so that you would now receive the word and say what you had to say at the time. You can take the floor.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, I would like to ask and I wanted to ask all my colleagues a question. It is a question which I consider crucial for the course of Europe if it wants to be democratic. The question is: will we respect the will of a people, yes or no? The Greek people decided with the elections that they do not want loans, they do not want this path, they want their own path. He wants to build his own future. Are we going to respect that? Yes or no?  It's not a matter for the Greek people, it's a matter of democracy. Will we respect the will of a people whoever it is? Yes or no? That's the problem. The Greek people have decided and are building their present and future and do not want their lenders to drown them. The negotiations have led nowhere. There's only one solution. No rupture, no submission. After a year, come and discuss whether we owe to pay, if we don't owe, not to pay.  That is what I wanted to say and please, because I am leaving the European Parliament in twenty days' time, I want every Member to answer this question with his conscience and know that you will be being chased by my opinion, wherever you go, wherever I go.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: – The debate has been closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. Today we are talking about the European Council summit that will meet here in Brussels in the next few hours. The agenda contains central issues such as immigration and the Greek crisis. These are questions that require urgent answers. The solutions that this Council is preparing to discuss challenge all of us about the future of Europe, urging us on the very foundations of the Union. It is precisely for this reason that it becomes imperative that common commitment, shared responsibility and solidarity be the guidelines for the coming days. We must restore its soul to a Europe that is now generating fear. Going beyond technicality and parameters to bring to light the community of people we want and who hold us together. The answer to immigration cannot be that the problem does not concern us, just as the response to the economic difficulties of the Member States cannot be just any exit. We have heard the difficulty of taking rapid decisions in these situations again today in this House. I do not agree, and I would like to thank Vice-President Timmermans for reiterating on the contrary that 'Time is short and we must get straight to the point'.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. The Greek crisis is clearly demonstrating the limitations and negative consequences of austerity policies applied in times of crisis. Fiscal austerity measures to cut services and the welfare state only exacerbate the conditions of those in need. What Greece and Europe as a whole need is a paradigm shift that focuses not on cuts but on growth, through investments to promote competitiveness and restore oxygen to workers and small and medium-sized enterprises. In addition, the Greek case highlights the need for a Union that is not merely monetary, but economic and social, acting with the aim of full employment and the defence of citizens' rights.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – The measures put forward by the five-chairpersons' report go in the right direction, although the report is less ambitious than that of the European Parliament on the economic governance framework. Beyond what the document contains, it is necessary to take into account what is not yet being raised. In particular, it is worth noting the absence of key proposals from the PSOE: mutualization of the public debt of the Member States (Eurobonds); launch of the Debt Repayment Fund on the basis of the EESM, a particularly important element in definitively resolving the Greek public debt crisis; issuance of European public debt; European unemployment insurance. Nor is it defined how the proposed fiscal capacity of the euro area/European Treasury would be financed. Finally, in the context of the debate on the future of Economic and Monetary Union, there is no reference to the need to strengthen the euro area horizontally, that is to say, to extend it to Member States which have a legal obligation to adopt the single currency. In this way, Economic and Monetary Union would be politically strengthened while reducing the democratic deficit, as the European Parliament would truly be the euro Parliament.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – The measures put forward by the five-chairpersons' report go in the right direction, although the report is less ambitious than that of the European Parliament on the economic governance framework. Beyond what the document contains, it is necessary to take into account what is not yet being raised. In particular, it is worth noting the absence of key proposals from the PSOE: mutualization of the public debt of the Member States (Eurobonds); launch of the Debt Repayment Fund on the basis of the EESM, a particularly important element in definitively resolving the Greek public debt crisis; issuance of European public debt; European unemployment insurance. Nor is it defined how the proposed fiscal capacity of the euro area/European Treasury would be financed. Finally, in the context of the debate on the future of Economic and Monetary Union, there is no reference to the need to strengthen the euro area horizontally, that is to say, to extend it to Member States which have a legal obligation to adopt the single currency. In this way, Economic and Monetary Union would be politically strengthened while reducing the democratic deficit, as the European Parliament would truly be the euro Parliament.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
