text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Vladimir Putin's Russia has been striving for years to maintain its influence in Eastern Europe in a wide range of areas, from politics to the economy. Russia's actions in this area have repeatedly been aggressive. Raw material blockades were used, gas prices were inflated and increased activity by Russian special services was maintained. I consider it absolutely necessary and right for the Council to extend economic sanctions against Russia for military aggression in eastern Ukraine. Financial and visa sanctions should also be extended and strengthened, as recent reports have shown that Russia's actions clearly show that it is determined to further escalate tensions on Ukrainian territory. The annexation of Crimea and the outbreak of war in Ukraine, and the demonstration of Russia's military forces, including at the border with Poland, the EU's external border, followed by Vladimir Putin's attempt to tell Europe that Russia was not taking part in these events, have challenged the existing European peace deal. In the context of the forthcoming Council meeting, I expect a detailed review of the European Security Strategy from the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. The war that is taking place in Ukraine is not only a threat to the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, but to the european Union as a whole. The new security strategy should therefore be based on the solidarity and consistency of the Member States.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. – The measures put forward by the five-chairpersons' report go in the right direction, although the report is less ambitious than that of the European Parliament on the economic governance framework. Beyond what the document contains, it is necessary to take into account what is not yet being raised. In particular, it is worth noting the absence of key proposals from the PSOE: mutualization of the public debt of the Member States (Eurobonds); launch of the Debt Repayment Fund on the basis of the EESM, a particularly important element in definitively resolving the Greek public debt crisis; issuance of European public debt; European unemployment insurance. Nor is it defined how the proposed fiscal capacity of the euro area/European Treasury would be financed. Finally, in the context of the debate on the future of Economic and Monetary Union, there is no reference to the need to strengthen the euro area horizontally, that is to say, to extend it to Member States which have a legal obligation to adopt the single currency. In this way, Economic and Monetary Union would be politically strengthened while reducing the democratic deficit, as the European Parliament would truly be the euro Parliament.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – The key to the development of the single market is to end the fragmentation of markets. To this end, harmonisation of legislation, network development and the establishment of an appropriate regulatory and investment environment should be accelerated in order to develop the most modern services possible. Market consolidation does not clearly result in better service and prices, so there should be room for other players: competition has a place on the market. Improving the investment environment, which is particularly important for start-ups and SMEs, is part of promoting competitiveness. While ensuring the free movement of products and services, portability of copyrighted content in Europe and even around the world is essential. Ensuring a level playing field is a necessary precondition for competition.  The debate is partly about over-the-top (OTT) operators, which have a significantly different operating and business model from traditional telecommunications operators, so that the voice and content services of OTT operators cannot be incorporated into the role of traditional telecommunications companies. The debate must hear the voice of telecommunications operators that regulation, in its current form, results in an unfair competitive advantage for OTT operators. However, let us not forget that we must also take the interests of consumers into account.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - The soon-to-be-held European Council will discuss important topics relevant to the future of European unity.  First, the eurozone issue and Greece's participation in its follow-up are sure to dominate the session. I think it is important for the future of the European Union for Greece to remain in the eurozone, but there is no doubt that the Greek Government must assume some of its responsibility.  Secondly, I also strongly support the effort to create a single European Capital Union, and to strengthen the linking of the European banking system.  Thirdly, we also need a common, much stronger, cooperation in the field of integrated defence capabilities. The European Union needs to develop its defence forces in synergy with NATO forces.  Fourth, on the issue of a lot of pressure on immigrants to enter the territory of the European Union, I believe that the solution to setting quotas by country for those refugees who are indeed refugees. All those who wish to exploit other people's tragedies for their unsubted interests should be disabled in their intentions.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In the context of the future Council, I wanted to address two issues: the fight against terrorism and migration. In recent times, many events, including the terrorist attacks in France and Denmark and the migration crisis in the Mediterranean, have made Eu citizens feel anxious and concerned about the effectiveness of policies and the functioning of the European Union. Such social and economic uncertainty makes it difficult for us to concentrate on finding solutions to today's challenges and problems together. This is a huge mistake, because only by acting together, in a spirit of loyalty, can we ensure that the citizens of the Union are safe and that their rights are respected. I therefore hope that at the Council you will be able to reach a compromise on a common asylum and migration policy. I also hope that, following the common system on migration, we will focus on a common system of integration of migrants. In the context of the fight against terrorism and the Joint Declaration of Education Ministers adopted in Paris on 17 March on strengthening the theme of building civil society and respect for fundamental values in national education systems, I ask that the priorities of this declaration be taken into account in the EU counter-terrorism strategy.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – The grey economy in Greece is at 22.4% of GDP and is the highest of oecd countries. By comparison, the lowest gray economy in the U.S. is at 5.9%, of the countries of Europe is the lowest in Switzerland at 6.5%. Here, too, it is necessary to look for the reserves that Greece has. Under the former government, Greece managed to achieve a primary surplus and modest growth back in 2014. Now that the new government has taken office, there is a recession and economic indicators are deteriorating. It is therefore important for Greece to demonstrate that it is able to adopt solutions that will lead to a recovery of the economy and show that Greece is able to repay its debts. Meanwhile, what greece's new leadership is showing has not convinced anyone that they are capable of handling it. Alexis Tsipras and his SYRIZA party are newcomers to high EU policy. They found out late that they would either agree to the terms of their creditors or give up the euro. On the other hand, we need to know whether the conditions for the discharge of the country are clearly laid down.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Writing. – The 76th Interparliamentary meeting between Members of the US Congress and the European Parliament will take place in Riga from 26 to 28 June. As at the next European Council, the common security and defence policy is on the agenda. The European Council will focus in particular on the implementation of its decisions taken in February in response to the attacks in Paris. These include the concrete protection of citizens, measures against radicalisation and cooperation with our international partners. The United States is our most important partner in this respect. Together, we must ensure that the internal and external dimensions of European security policy and the approaches of the United States are meaningfully intertwined. After all, the serious crises in North Africa, the Middle East and Ukraine will be easier to deal with if we all act together. When the European Council adopts a new strategy on internal security and takes stock of the common security and defence policy, it is expressly not in competition, but in a conscious and clear complement to NATO.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – The IOM reports that more than 100 000 migrants have arrived by sea in Europe this year so far. We are clearly dealing with an unprecedented humanitarian crisis situation in the Mediterranean, which raises the question for governments about appropriate measures of response at European and national level. How can we call ourselves European if we refuse to help others in need, whether a Member State on the periphery of Europe dealing with the influx of migrants, or a refugee or asylum seeker wanting international protection? We have an ethical and moral obligation to act, save human lives and help people who have fled war and persecution to find stability and the chance to improve their lives with dignity.  I welcome the Council agreement on a migrant relocation system, but I strongly criticise the governments who opposed the mandatory relocation mechanism. Europe and Member States can no longer merely observe the situation, but need to provide strong political leadership, take ownership of the migration debate and fully endorse the Commission Agenda on Migration. Europe needs a comprehensive European migration and asylum policy based on solidarity and respect for human rights, dignity and the values upon which the European Union is built.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – The Hungarian Government crossed the Rubicon this week: because of its inciterative, xenophobic policies, Hungary could again lose billions of pounds of the EU, even if we could be excluded from the Schengen area. This is thanks to the government's decision this week to suspend the application of the Dublin Regulation on the readmission of refugees, citing technical difficulties. The Hungarian government, which has a flag of Christian values, is persecuting rather than protecting refugees. Orban and his government have turned their backs on European solidarity, denying their most basic responsibility to asylum seekers. We find it inconceivable to have a European Union where Member States only hold their hands on EU aid and denounce obligations they do not like.  At the moment, the Government is clearly seeking to violate EU law: it is not possible to suspend the Dublin Regulation: if a crisis a situation a develops, a common solution must be found with the Commission. The Hungarian government's anti-foreigner immigration policy does not offer a solution to the refugee wave, but is at the root of the problem itself. By violating EU law, building barbed wire fences and launching a poster campaign, we can only lose EU funds, and refugees will not be short of refugees. Viktor Orban and his government have finally wiped themselves out of Europe, but the Hungary drink the juice.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Negotiations between the European Union and Greece will be at the centre of this next Council. The hyper-austerity imposed by Brussels has finally brought the Greek people to their knees. Falling pensions, record unemployment, public debt exploding to 180% of GDP, Greece is now at the throat and the Greek economy is totally suffocated. To avoid the bankruptcy of Greek banks, Brussels plans to launch a mechanism to attack the savings of Greeks. Thus, the ceiling of 100,000 euros could even be lowered (Article 6 - MRU). To save the euro, the Eurobenates are decidedly ready for anything, including confiscating the bank deposits of individuals. We urgently need to return to democracy, to the sovereignty of nations and peoples.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. For years, Parliament has called for greater involvement of the European Union as a whole in dealing with the phenomenon of waves of migration from countries in Africa and the Middle East burdened by devastating political, social and economic conditions. Very often, unfortunately, the attention paid to these requests was only ignited in the event of huge human tragedies, only to fade a few days later without any proposals for concrete solutions. This time, Parliament has demanded a different reaction, and the Commission must be recognised as initiating extensive and detailed work, which has ended with proposals based on the fair distribution of burdens and responsibilities between all European countries. A proposal, perhaps for the first time, truly European and not just aid to those States that, for geographical reasons, are faced with the phenomenon directly and on the front line. It is therefore important to emphasise that this time 'Europe', as it is generally quoted in many media, has been equal to its role, making proposals that we consider to be an important step in the right direction. It is now up to the Member States, meeting today and tomorrow in the European Council, to demonstrate that their membership of the European Union is much more than an economic union and is based on deep and shared values.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. - The issue of the Greek financial crisis has emerged as a major topic of discussion. This is not just about the crisis of functioning of one country - but about the crisis of relations within the EU and the IMF. The nature of the attitude towards the Greek crisis is the best indication of how the system needs to be revised, as those not currently affected by the financial crisis could also become subject to future discussions.  As for the issue of migrants and the distribution of quotas, it is quite clear that the European Union has recognised the problem, but in seeking a way out of what really is a disaster, it has remained halfway there. The question arises as to what kind of profile the EU wants to have in the first two decades of the 21st century: whether it will be the "EU of the privileged or the EU oppressed", but also that the answer probably needs to be sought somewhere in the middle.  At the moment, 70% of all refugees in the EU are disposed of by five European countries. The rest are very little or in no way participation and are not interested in this program, especially Eastern Europe, especially the Baltic countries, and unfortunately Croatia is also involved. Therefore, we are only at the beginning of a process that I hope will bring a far more serious solution than before.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. The European strategy on immigration is lacking in ambition, but it is a first step in the right direction. In order to reach a lasting solution, this issue can no longer be a matter of subsidiarity. It must be a European policy in its own right. All Member States must abandon the logic of everyone for themselves and finally agree to translate into action the calls for solidarity and responsibility, first and foremost on proposals to relocate and resettle 60,000 migrants. Solidarity applies not only between us, but also and above all to those thousands of people in need of protection or in search of a better life. Responsibility applies through a realistic and positive approach to immigration, which does not amount to systematically driving migrants out of Europe. To have a realistic vision is to act to establish legal channels of immigration, both for migrants and for asylum seekers. Faced with the reluctance of some states and those who wish to raise barriers to their borders, let us answer loud and clear that immigration is not a problem. This is a reality to which ambitious, humane, and open solutions must be provided.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – I consider the European Council of 25-26 June 2015 to be very crucial. National leaders will address migration, security and economic governance issues. Uncontrolled migration from Syria, Iraq and other African states is causing an increase in resistance in European states, with groups promoting xenophobia, intolerance and discrimination coming to the fore. Although Zanda Kalnina-Lukashevic spoke on behalf of the EU Council, saying that there are no urgent solutions to the migration crisis and that only a long-term solution will help us achieve a targeted, holistic and balanced approach, which we will apply systematically, step by step, the European Council will have to take very concrete measures. Measures to help migrants in their difficult situation and calm the wave of fear and dissatisfaction among EU citizens.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – The European Union's immigration policy needs to be changed. The leaders of the Member States face the task of combining the need for security, mutual solidarity and humanities, which are one of the pillars of our civilisation. Solutions must not be accepted under the influence of emotions, but must be systemic and permanent. The problem of immigration needs to be tackled comprehensively and preventively. First of all, steps to protect the EU's coastline need to be better coordinated, as well as cooperation in the search for and arresting people who make money from human misfortune. It is estimated that the annual profit from such crime is up to EUR 20 billion, and this money is often spent precisely in Europe. First of all, the causes need to be addressed, not the consequences of this situation. The causes must be addressed where they originated, i.e. in the countries of origin of migrants. Both the European institutions and individual Member States should therefore reflect on a common strategy to stop illegal migrants already in their country of origin. To that end, development programmes should serve the countries concerned. The emerging Energy Union can also help, as it is the north African and Middle East regions that should be one of the sources from which the EU will increasingly pump oil and gas. By improving the economic level, one of the reasons for mass emigration will also fall.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – I recognise the need to treat those fleeing imminent danger to life differently from the masses of migrants arriving at the EU's borders for economic reasons, mostly those who are also at risk of starvation. However, they all have the right to assistance based on European solidarity. Instead, it exacerbates the problem and causes almost irreparable political damage when the government of a Member State is setting all refugees as potential criminals and terrorists in front of a wide public. This is at the same time destroying eu solidarity and cooperation, which is already difficult to develop on the subject, and is eroding the chances of a more effective international action and an international fight against terrorism. Unfortunately, this is exactly what the Orban government is doing when it is inciting refugees in a PR campaign, while simply desecrateing the Commission's Migration Agenda and quota proposal as 'madness'. This EiT meeting is precisely the right level, forum and opportunity to curb this dangerous populist policy before it can further undermine the chances of a more effective common European policy on migration and foreign and security – I ask that both the EiT and the President of the Commission use all their influence.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The Summit of 25 and 26 June 2015 has an ambitious programme. Among other things, the situation in the Mediterranean, the Digital Single Market and major economic policy issues will be addressed. At the same time, we feel that the EU is barely finding strength on all these issues, because the eternal bailout of Greece continues. The bailout Europeans want a fig leaf from Greece so that they can continue to lie to their voters at home, and the Greeks do not even deliver that. They admit that they are bankrupt and that the borrowed money is gone, and they are constantly calling for new breaches of the law in the euro zone. The euro countries continue to play a part. They violated the law on the deficit criteria, the non-assistance clause, the allocation keys for cash or the granting of ELA loans. In a recent question to the ECB, I found that there is no longer any parliamentary control here, because the ECB's response amounts to a refusal to provide information. I ask you, how is the EU supposed to function in the face of the many breaches of the law? The problem does not only include the euro, but also, for example, the Dublin Treaties on migration. Now huge regulatory systems are to be built for economic government. If the law in the EU obviously counts little, then there is no hope of respecting the legal bases of new systems either.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. – The measures put forward by the five-chairpersons' report go in the right direction, although the report is less ambitious than that of the European Parliament on the economic governance framework. Beyond what the document contains, it is necessary to take into account what is not yet being raised. In particular, it is worth noting the absence of key proposals from the PSOE: mutualization of the public debt of the Member States (Eurobonds); launch of the Debt Repayment Fund on the basis of the EESM, a particularly important element in definitively resolving the Greek public debt crisis; issuance of European public debt; European unemployment insurance. Nor is it defined how the proposed fiscal capacity of the euro area/European Treasury would be financed. Finally, in the context of the debate on the future of Economic and Monetary Union, there is no reference to the need to strengthen the euro area horizontally, that is to say, to extend it to Member States which have a legal obligation to adopt the single currency. In this way, Economic and Monetary Union would be politically strengthened while reducing the democratic deficit, as the European Parliament would truly be the euro Parliament.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – As over 100 000 migrants came to Europe this year, and 2 000 are missing or dead in the Mediterranean, there can be no question but that this is a most pressing problem. It will always be necessary to provide asylum for people who are persecuted. Immigrants and refugees must be treated on the basis of respect for human rights, and we can no longer rely on temporary measures to alleviate this problem. We must stand in solidarity as a Union to find a comprehensive, viable solution to this crisis. Solidarity is a responsibility in this Union, but nonetheless we have a responsibility to our own citizens as well. Migrants seek asylum in Europe not only from the other side of the Mediterranean, but also from other conflict zones. An agreement must be reached that allows for all Member States to ensure that migrant workers and asylum seekers can be integrated into society, but on a voluntary basis. To respect the diversity of the situation for Member States across the Union, mandatory quotas should not be implemented. However, I am confident that a solution can be reached that will ensure the continued security and stability of Member States as well as the health of all those seeking aid.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. The Greek pantomime is clearly and once and for all demonstrating both the structural problems constitutive of the euro and the short-sightedness of the economic policies of the European institutions. How can we expect further fiscal austerity measures to grow again? There will never be any growth and the measures that are being discussed at the Eurogroup are absolutely insane, on all the increase in VAT and the increase in corporate taxation.  We must be aware that austerity is intrinsic to the structure of the euro: there is no euro without austerity, as the recent document of the five Presidents explained, perhaps unk knowingly. In the euro, the only instrument available to deal with a crisis is internal devaluation: wage cuts, job insecurity and the dismantling of rights.  The European institutions have a great responsibility in the Greek affair and are proposing the same solutions that led Greece to this socially and economically unsustainable situation. A serious debate is opening on a debt renegotiation: Greece needs to exit the euro in order to recover its instruments and hope to return to growth. But this is frightening to the Eurocrats, they have the only objective of saving the wrong currency, even at the cost of sacrificing people's lives.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "More dynamism, efficiency and consistency are needed. A slight optimism before the Council meeting of 25-26 June is becoming a reality. It welcomes both the importance of a better flow of information and a stronger approach to the subject in the trilogue on the transfer of air passenger data. It is important that this system is compatible, undispersed and at the same time protects passenger data from unwanted interference. Just to make it tight, well protected. A little worried is still quite superficial and vague about the subject of a common EU army, but, as I understand it, it is still far from the decision itself. I would add, by the way, that I therefore do not trust too much the assurances that this is a viable project. Today, it is much more necessary to enrich the tools of persuasion, defense, security than to strengthen often rather outdated tools of one kind. If we are dealing with hybrid conflicts and the same armed conflicts, let us create more complex response tools.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the report of Mr José Manuel Fernandes and Mr Udo Bullmann on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Strategic Investment Fund and amending Regulations (EU) No 1493/1999 and (EC) No 1493/1999. 1291/2013 and (EU) No 1291/2013. 1316/2013 (COM(2015)0010 - C8-0007/2015 - 2015/0009(COD))(A8-0139/2015).

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Rapporteur. – I would like to begin by congratulating the Commission and, in particular, on the President of the Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, for coming with this legislative initiative. I would also like to welcome the competent action of the Presidency of the Council, of the Lithuanian Presidency, which has made it possible for us to reach a good port, and of course to thank all colleagues, all the rapporteurs, all the shadow rapporteurs, all the officials, officials not only of the political groups but also officials of the secretariats of the Committee on Budgets and the Economy, who have proven that we have great competence in this House. A special word for co-rapporteur Udo Bullmann: we both had hours and hours of meeting, hours and hours of meetings, more than two hundred hours of work, but we can say it was worth it.  It was worth it because we have a fund that will enable growth and jobs. It was worth it because this is a new fund, an innovative fund, a fund that also provokes and is challenging, a fund that does not allocate either by regions, nor by themes. And so everyone will have to do their job, everyone will have to look and those interested will have to do so, the beneficiaries, to take advantage of this fund.  A fund that says something like this: I am here to support viable projects that the current funds, that current programmes, which financial markets do not support at the moment and, in this sense, this additional nature, this complementarity, is extremely important.  A fund that will therefore, with its EUR 315 billion, EUR 240 billion for investments, EUR 75 billion for businesses and, in particular, for small and medium-sized enterprises, help growth, help the competitiveness of our economy.  A fund also proves that it is not politicians who create jobs, but must do everything to provide conditions for job creation. A fund also open, from research, through broadband, energy efficiency, but also education, health, tourism, infrastructure. A fund that will enable a stronger recovery in the European Union.  A fund also that we want to continue and therefore the action we have had to make sure that if it goes well, but if it does not go as well as that the Commission will come up with a new proposal so that it can continue and obviously if it is a disaster it would not make sense for it to continue. But it's not going to be a disaster.  We also provided transparency to the decision, we gave democratic legitimacy to this fund and we were able to reduce the impact it had on two important funding programmes. I am referring to Horizon 2020 and the Connect Europe Facility, where we have reduced an impact by EUR 1 billion on these programmes. But here I want to tell the Commission that this work will continue and in every budgetary procedure we will continue to do everything we can to reduce the impact on these funds. And, as I said, we will try to minimise as much as possible the impact that the guarantee of this fund has on these two programmes.  A fund which is also a fund which demonstrates that sharing is important and based on a Guarantee of the European Union, a common guarantee, a guarantee also from the Member States, an EIB guarantee.  I am confident that we all want growth, we all want jobs and so we will vote for this fund. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Mr Fernandes, who has done an excellent job, thanked the Commission for this fund. Parliament's role was decisive. Without Parliament, this fund would not be in the Commission's programme. You should recognize him. Secondly, he said there are no priorities for either locations or projects. Mr. Congressman is Portuguese. You dropped cohesion? Do you intend to drop cohesion?

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Rapporteur, reply according to the "blue card" procedure. – (2) I note that my colleague Carlos Zorrinho has not read the regulation, because territorial cohesion is contained in the compromise, which is contained in the text of the Regulation, is in the recitals. It has an eligibility criterion, and by the way it is now known that I myself proposed this eligibility criterion with regard to territorial cohesion, and that is an important criterion. But what I have said is that cohesion policy, cohesion policy, this has another objective, and this fund has no geographical allocations or thematic allocations, but it must also contribute to improving territorial cohesion in Europe. And it is clear that Parliament played an important role in before and after, as I have underlined.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. No wonder we're excited. It's about big things, it's about important things. Europe does indeed have a massive investment gap: 200, 300 billion a year – these are the lower figures that the Commission gives us. An investment gap that lacks schools, transport links, networks, broadband in the regions – broadband for all, so that value can get to where people are. There are many things that we urgently need in the fight against climate change: building renovation, energy efficiency – these are our big issues. That is why it was right for Jean-Claude Juncker to take up a proposal from the political debate, from the election campaign, and said: if I become President of the Commission – and he has kept his word – I will make a proposal to that effect. This is a question of our performance and viability, our sustainability, our economic and social systems. We have welcomed this proposal, not because we say that it is already sufficient in volume, but because we say that it is a step in the right direction if we do it right. Not all reactions made us feel good at the beginning. Member States, I say it, have been very reluctant to say whether they are participating in this fund. I would like to ask: what kind of European consciousness is this, if you only take part in a project where there is an immediate juste return? This is not the spirit in which we can work in the long term. There should be some discussion on this issue on the Council bench. We need the European Investment Bank, but it, too, may have thought that it could simply carry on as before. That, too, would not be a sufficient attitude. And private investors should know that it can't be about takeaway effects, it's about additionality. We want to open up markets, we want to give small and medium-sized enterprises a chance, we want new employment to be created. That is why it has been consistent that Parliament has cooperated excellently across party lines and that we have set ourselves clear objectives. We want to invest in the future, not in the past. That is why: clear guidelines with investment criteria, investment guidelines, codecision – and a scoreboard to ensure that the right priorities are met. The volume is not enough. That is why we want to enable the regions, the Member States, the promotional banks and the platforms to invest. Yes, they should! The Commission will make a statement today to ensure that this does not become even more complicated. And we need a clear level of leadership, clear responsibilities, the appointment of a senior executive, in which Parliament is centrally involved. For this successful project, which can be the beginning of something great, I would like to thank all the rapporteurs from 15 committees in this House who have worked in the shortest possible time, all the staff, the services and the good cooperation with the institutions. I believe that this Parliament has shown that it is capable of doing good in the shortest possible time, too important, and in a great way. We will continue to accompany the project.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, let me first express my gratitude to this House – the European Parliament – and especially the Chairs, Mr Gualtieri and Mr Arthuis, and of course the two co-rapporteurs, Mr Bullmann and Mr Fernandes, for your excellent support and your excellent work on this very specific and important file. I also want to thank the other rapporteurs who were working on this issue. I have to say that these people were very tough negotiators but also very result-oriented negotiators, and it meant that in record time we managed to pass such a difficult and detailed piece of legislation. It was only possible because of the political will, because we share the same view: Europe needs investment, and we have to deliver fast in order to create a better atmosphere and environment for private investors to invest in this continent. As I said, these people were very tough negotiators, and I even owe my first sunrise in this building to them! The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) is a very important tool to address market failures – market failures which partially originate from regulatory changes. We have regulated in good faith, but it has had some negative impact, which we are now ready to address. Europe is not primarily lacking in liquidity: there is plenty of money, plenty of liquidity in the private sector, but there are also plenty of reasons why this liquidity is not used for productive investment in the real economy. One of the reasons is lack of risk financing, and that is exactly what EFSI is providing now. We want to provide risk financing for small and medium-sized enterprises, for innovative companies, for start-ups, but at the same time for larger companies and public-private partnership projects in order to get productive investment and create jobs. EFSI will not change the whole world. We also need other measures to get more investment. We need measures at international level, which means structural reforms in order to strengthen external competitiveness, and this is what our Member States are doing at the moment. We also need other measures at European level, and that is exactly why the Commission will also concentrate on the third pillar of the Investment Plan, which means widening and deepening of the internal market. So I would like to spread the same spirit of delivering fast to those areas in which we are talking about the deepening and widening of the single market. Why do we not deliver as fast on those proposals which will harmonise the Digital Single Market or create the Digital Single Market or those proposals coming from the Commission which are dealing with the Energy Market Union or Capital Markets Union? These proposals will have an even bigger impact on investment and job creation. According to the European Parliament’s own assessment, if we had a Digital Single Market, its impact on our economy would be something like EUR 415 billion per year. That is why we have to deliver as fast with these proposals as we did with EFSI. The Commission is already working on the various documents and actions which are needed for implementation. In less than a month, the Commission will be in a position to decide to extend the EU guarantees to the projects warehoused by the EIB and the European Investment Fund, to appoint the members of the Steering Board alongside the EIB, and to issue the Scoreboard under a Delegated Act. The process for recruiting the members of the Investment Committee will be launched within two weeks, and we aim to have them in place by September. In September, honourable Members, you will have the occasion to hear and, hopefully, approve the candidates for the position of Managing Director and Deputy Managing Director, and we plan to have the European Investment Advisory Hub up and running after the summer, and the European Investment Project Portal by the end of the year. So we are really delivering fast. In this context, and on behalf of the Commission, allow me to make the following statement on our assessment of one-off contributions within the context of the EFSI initiative for the purpose of implementing the Stability and Growth Pact: ‘Without prejudice to the prerogatives of the Council in the implementation of the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP), one-off contributions by Member States, either by a Member State or by national promotional banks classified in the general government sector or acting on behalf of the Member State, into the EFSI or thematic or multi-country investment platforms established for the implementation of the Investment Plan, should in principle qualify as one-off measures within the meaning of Article 5 of Council Regulation (EC) No 1466/97 and Article 3 of Council Regulation (EC) No 1467/97.’

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first I want to join my colleague, Jyrki Katainen, in thanking the Chairs, Mr Gualtieri and Mr Arthuis, and the two rapporteurs, Mr Bullmann and Mr Fernandes, and also many others sitting in this room, such as Mrs Van Brempt, who have worked so hard with us to make the Fund happen. The negotiations were tough for a reason. We faced a very tall order: to find space to fund the aspiration that this Commission brought, with Parliament and with the Council, to unleash the confidence and courage of our investors for the benefit of our people, and to do so in a very tight budgetary environment. It was not because we had different objectives. We had the same objective, which was to make the best use of our people’s sacrifice. But this objective had to be achieved by making very tough trade-offs between well-performing programmes – Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility – and the margin we need so that we can face the challenges of today and tomorrow. We made this choice together, and now the tough job begins. Institutionalising the Fund is only the first step. From here on, we have to make sure that it delivers on the promises that we have outlined. From my position, as the person you have trusted with the EU budget, I pledged to you that we would look very carefully every year at the possibilities the budget may offer so that we can further ease the impact we have had on Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility. We know that you expect no less from us than to leave no stone unturned and to look at every angle so that we can make the best use of our people’s money. I also want to tell you, from the bottom of my heart, that it made me feel proud to be a European and proud to be serving the European institutions when we, together, got this done in line with the schedule we promised our people we would follow.

name: Michael THEURER
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The Committee on Budgetary Control, all my colleagues, have worked over the last period to achieve better spending, more money for research and development, more money for trans-European networks. That is why– And I do not hide it – we were naturally very concerned at the beginning that EFSI would call into question precisely this priority. We are therefore pleased that improvements have been made through tough negotiations. We, as the Committee on Budgetary Control, have also fought very hard to ensure that democratic control of expenditure – auditing, economic auditing – is also ensured. It is a great success that the negotiations have succeeded in ensringing the European Court of Auditors, the right for the Court of Auditors to look into the books, in order to ensure that the funds are spent efficiently and also in the right place. It is now important that the investments are made in the right place. It is important for us, as guarantors, that Parliament's right of discharge is also guaranteed. Thank you very much to the rapporteurs, to the Vice-President, to Mrs Georgieva and to the Council for this compromise.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: , author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. - (C) Mr President, I would like to begin by thank Dear! After the necessary period of saving and restoring the sustainability of public finances, it is time to invest in the European economy and create new jobs. In this context, the creation of a European Fund for Strategic Investments and the creation of a business-friendly environment deserve great support.  As rapporteur for the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I assessed the European Commission's proposal with shadow rapporteurs on its impact on job creation in Europe. I am very pleased that the final version of the regulation contains clear indications that one of the main objectives of the Fund is precisely to promote employment and to invest in sectors with great potential for job creation. The Fund will also support broadly understood social investments, i.e. education, research and development, human resources training. A very important provision in the final version of the Regulation is the assessment of the social impact of the Fund and its impact on job creation, carried out in the framework of reporting to the Institutions of the European Union and in the framework of the review procedure.  I am convinced that this will allow more informed and responsible decisions to be made in the future. The fund's support is estimated to generate 1,300,000 jobs. I hope that European companies are ready to take on the challenge and we will soon feel the positive effects of the recovery in investment in Europe.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Rapporteur ta' opinjoni tal-Kumitat għall-Ambjent, is-Saħħa Pubblika u s-Sigurtà tal-Ikel. – Sodisfatta li dan il-Fond jirrikonoxxi li jekk verament rridu nagħmlu differenza fil-ħajja tagħna u fil-ħajja tat-tfal tagħna rridu nibdew ninvestu, minn issa, f'dawk il proġetti u inizjattivi li huma ambjentalment u so大jalment sostjalblili. M'għadux iż-żmien li naħsbu li t-tkabbir ekonomiku u l-protezzjoni ambjentali i jmorrux id f'id. Min jaħseb hedge huwa għalkollox żbaljat. Għaliex qegħdin ngħixu f'era feġetti innovattivi u sostenibbli li ja大大ertaw ekonomija resource efficient u anki low-carbon, iva, għand jingħataw prijorità. Bħala rapporteur għall-Kumitat tal-Ambjent nistenna li nara issa proġetti b'teknoloġija rinnovabbli, enerġija nadifa, trasport elettriku u ekonomija 大irkolari, b'mod partikolari f'dawk il-pajjiżi fejn dan it-tip ta' investiment huwa nieqes. Huma dawn il-proġetti li għandna bżonn biex nagħmlu qabża 'l quddiem. Tkabbir ekonomiku u impjiegi ġodda jridu jaslu għand i大-ikeittadini ta' kull pajjiż tal-Unjoni Ewropea, mill-ikbar sal-iżgħar, għaliex l-awsterità waħedha ma tħallix riżultati fit-tul u hija ekonomija li tħares lejn tkabbir sostenibbli li tagmelħ id-differenza.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – As a Social Democrat, I hope that the whole group will approve this in the near future, not only because we have been negotiating for a very long time and the two chief negotiators have my full admiration for the biting into this dossier, but also because this is the point at which we in the European Union are moving from a policy that focuses on savings to a policy that can be reinvested.  As rapporteur for ITRE, I would like to emphasise two points and both points are about money. First of all, where does the money in this fund come from and secondly, where are we going to invest the money? Let me start with that last point. In the ITRE Commission, but also in other committees, it has been defended with gusto that it is important that we invest in the future and not in the past. In other words, investing in anything is not good enough for Parliament. We have clear policies in this Parliament, but also in the European Union, with the support of the Commission. We have policies on climate, energy, the Energy Union, the digital union. We know where we want to go and this money needs to be invested in it. That is crucial for us. I am very pleased with the final compromise that we have reached around the scoreboard, around the investment guidelines, around the criteria.  The first point: where does the money come from? It was a very difficult point for the European Parliament, Commissioner. We talked about it for a long time, sometimes we had difficult moments. This Parliament is very attached to the programmes that deal with the future, in particular investment in research and development, in energy and transport. It was very painful to see that the money was being taken from that very well.  We have reached a compromise, let us be clear. Do I think that's great? Am I super content with it? No, I would have liked the fact that no euro would be taken out of these programmes. But we have reached a compromise that is an honourable compromise, Commissioner. But you should know, the forthcoming negotiations, year after year, on the budget - and here I count on all my colleagues in the Committee on Budgets - will be tough negotiations, because in the end we want our money back.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Mr President, what a sad waste. Again, Europe is not going to be there. Once again, Europe will be unable to send a strong signal to its citizens and to the rest of the world. Once again, Europe will illustrate the inability of its leaders - and I regret it - to imagine the 21st century and to respond to the new challenges it offers us in terms of production, consumption, displacement, energy and resources. Like all environmentalists, of course, I am defending an investment plan, but a real one, which would really revive Europe, give young people hope, give them work, respond to the issue of unemployment and address the environmental and social challenges that arise. Unfortunately, the Juncker plan is not an investment plan; it's a communication plan. I am very concerned that its announced failure will create even more recoil and despair in Europe, and that in the end, far more than the Eurosceptics, we are all the gravediggers of the Europe we are defending.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Drafts member of the Opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Mr President, my deep gratitude and appreciation to the two rapporteurs, Mr Fernandes and Mr Bullmann, for their patience, as well as to the team of the European Parliament as a whole and to the other actors in this agreement, is ahead of the way. The EIE offers us two essential general virtues, from my point of view, for our discourse with the citizens. Firstly, it has restored the lyrics of the European anthem, so that it may return to the "Hymn to Joy", after these terrible seven years of skinny cows, suffering, poverty and recoil of Europe. The virtue of the Juncker Plan is to have regained the original momentum of common Europe. After a crisis like a war, it's time to grow back: employment, employment, employment. The second virtue is more complex - and two-sided currency - and opens the debate on coexistence between normative framework and growth. One part, those in the surplus, are calling for the flexibility of State aid rules. On the other hand, those in the deficit, we seek that investments in European programmes, clearly and clearly European, such as the EIE, do not penalize public debt. If the first virtue is to be acknowledged to the Commission, to President Juncker, supported from the minute minus zero by this Parliament, the second belongs to an intensive negotiation, nocturnity by, in a trilogue which was somewhat strange at the beginning, because in Parliament we start by confronting the Council and the Commission forming an adversary bloc, and I must thank in particular - and is present - Vice-President Georgieva , for opening the door to the solution by making the Commission recover its interinstitutional role of helping us and therefore helping citizens to find the solution. And this solution, after hours and hours of intensive negotiation as few, has resulted in the transport sector taking EUR 500 million out of the Council's mouth or pocket, which is back to the CEF, and we have even been able to advance another 500 million coming out in the form of direct subsidies, which is what our transport sector needs most. We have also ensured that the lever effect of the 1 x 15 EIE guarantee is consistent with the principles and values of the trans-European network programme, thus being complementary and with an emphasis precisely on the sectors in which the Commission encountered the most difficulties: urban mobility, accessibility, safety, pollution reduction, accidents , etc. and also expanding the basic and global networks through possible new nodes, but always with reference to the Connecting Europe Facility, its principles and its objectives and values, further ensuring the presence of transport experts in all the necessary areas of programme governance. In Parliament we have now fulfilled our task of improving the agreement. It is now up to the Commission and the European Investment Bank, together with private initiative, Member States, regions, civil society, etc. to launch it to have the effect of job creation and growth in this employment-intensive sector as ours. Yesterday in Riga, representatives of the sector agreed on their satisfaction and hope.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Mr President, Commissioner, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to welcome the great cohesion in Parliament between the various rapporteurs, which has enabled us to defend our positions, to underline the personal involvement of Mrs Georgieva and Mr Katainen, who have been involved at length in our sleepless nights, and to welcome the very pugnacious position of our budget rapporteur. , my friend José Manuel Fernandes, who has improved the proposals, in the face of an intransigent Council and determined to sacrifice programmes on growth and employment, rather than using those margins which Member States no doubt hope to make better use of.  I welcome the adoption of this much-needed investment support mechanism for Europe. The projects supported, and this is what I would like to emphasize, must have a real additionality, that is, have a high risk profile and support where the market does not support. These projects must be in line with the Union's political objectives, including, of course, transport, energy, telecoms and research. The improvement we are experiencing for cyclical reasons should not exempt our governments from making progress towards structural reforms as well.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Policy. – The Committee on Regional Policy strongly supports this new fund. We already have EUR 460 billion available for this period in the renewed regional funds, the so-called European structural and investment funds, with the co-financing of the Member States. If you now take into account a multiplier one in four, then we have a real investment amount of around 1.5 trillion euros. With the addition of the EFSI fund of some EUR 315 billion for high risk capital, we will receive a wonderful package. Europe lacks high-risk investment.  Our companies, our start-ups, the pilot projects in new technology, in smart industry have a real need for risk capital. The fund foresees this gap. Now let's follow it in the implementation with each other, together with the rapporteurs, to see if we can see that synergy in the ... investment and jobs.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education – Culture, but also in the area of education, this is not the best area to seek funding for new projects. It is also not a good area to seek any savings, because it is a source of pride and success for the whole of Europe.  However, if this is the case, according to the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education, which I represent, everything must be done to ensure that these savings are minimal. Secondly, there must indeed be a situation where the cultural area and the area of education can participate in this project, in short.  I stress on behalf of the committee: we supported the Juncker project, we supported the creation of a fund to improve Europe's economic situation, but the most important thing is that both culture and education also have a chance to take place in this project.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Mr President, I would now like to see the EFSI moving at the highest possible speed from legal framework to reality. It is a long-term mechanism and it can reduce the investment gap – but the EFSI is not only about investment funding. The creation of an investment climate will also depend on whether the Commission acts promptly to eliminate barriers existing in the single market and in financial sector relations, and on whether establishing a Capital Market Union will quickly address inefficiencies in capital markets. Bringing private investment in will not be achieved overnight, but getting it done is still, to a large extent, in the hands of the European institutions.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, Vice-Presidents, I would like to thank the commissioners for their excellent work and for their excellent work. As chairman of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I do not want to add anything in substance. I would just like to go to the lectern to say thank you to those who have contributed to the success of this project: the Commission, with Jean-Claude Juncker at the helm, but also Vice-Presidents Katainen and Georgieva, who are here today. I would like to thank our rapporteurs for their leadership. The fact that we have kept to the timetable is a great success for all of us as institutions. We have shown that we can give answers to the citizens. And the idea that investments are necessary, as Mr Bullmann has said, is a key element of this plan. Millions of people in Europe may not be so enthusiastic about the technology we are adopting today. But i hope in a few years' time they will say that this technology has led to jobs, investment and the future for this continent. That is the hope that surrounds us all. However, I would also like to emphasise once again that this will certainly not be enough on its own. The Commission has also pointed out on several occasions that, in order to create jobs, money is needed, that investment is needed, but, on the other hand, structural reforms and budgetary discipline, that this triad of Europe's reform efforts must always be seen. I would have a political wish at the end. I had heard that this project, this programme, has now been adopted by a large majority in the advisory committees and that both left and right in the House, the extremes in our Parliament, this project, have rejected this plan. In other words, the extremes are against us doing this. Then I would have a wish, if I may say so: that in future, when motorway projects are inaugurated, when infrastructure projects are initiated in Europe, because we are putting this in place, every speech will say that the democrats in Europe have made this possible and that Le Pen and the left were opposed to this infrastructure being built. You have to communicate that sometimes. It is political majorities that want something that is positive. It is a good day for Europe, and we have done it together.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the fact that we are here today, debating an investment plan, shows that things in the European Union are changing. Finally, we are abandoning this passion for austerity, so harmful to Europe. Because cutting policies neither create growth nor create jobs nor, of course, help European citizens. But in recent months we are seeing changes in economic policy. It may not yet be too evident in the day-to-day life, but that change is the change that society has demanded and which this group has asked the European Commission to make. First we have seen how this Commission has revised the pact for flexibility, stability and growth, giving more flexibility and more scope for action to implement growth-oriented policies. We have also seen a change in fiscal policy, decisively pursuing fraud and evasion and also giving a new approach to European corporation tax; and we also just saw, a few days ago, the report of the five presidents reinforcing economic and monetary union. And today we are here talking about this Juncker Plan, an investment plan that wants to mobilize 315 billion euros to be invested in the real economy, which is what really touches people. Commission, Council and Parliament negotiate tomorrow, afternoon and night — literally – to reach an agreement that can be approved today, because the need to give an urgent impetus to investment in Europe has made us work against time but the urgent has not prevented us from working on what is important, because we tabled more than 1,400 amendments to this plan, because we believed that the proposal could be improved , and the outcome of the Agreement demonstrates this. With our work we have improved funding. We've got 1 billion euros more. And, therefore, we do not affect so much programmes that already existed and which also invest in the future of the European Union, such as Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility. Our funding proposal was more appropriate and more ambitious, but it was a pity that the Council did not have the courage to give the necessary financial support to such an important project. In fact, it is a pity that the Council is not even in this debate today. But in any case, the last word on funding is not said. In September we will negotiate the 2016 budget and we are also on the eve of negotiating a review of the Financial Framework and look forward to more resources for the Plan. But not only has the funding been changed, but there has not been a single article of the Regulation that we have not improved. And I'm done. I would like to thank the rapporteurs, Mr José Manuel Fernandes and Mr Udo Bullmann, for being able to lead and negotiate a good agreement for Europe. And now, probably, we should start working on a second Juncker Plan.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. –  Mr President, our priority is jobs, growth and competitiveness. It is unfortunate that Europe has endured very low levels of investment since 2007. I therefore welcome EFSI. It is a responsible and ambitious programme that will maximise use of public finance and, at the same time, encourage investment from the private sector. I am pleased to note that the fund will be managed by the European Investment Bank, and I am also content that the multiannual financial framework (MFF) remains unaltered. That means no additional call on taxpayers’ money. But I do have concerns: first that, in application, this really is a new financial instrument doing a new job, not just an extension of current schemes; second, it is important that additionality really does mean spreading excellence and widening participation. I also have concerns about whether smaller businesses and research facilities will be sufficiently aware that the funding is available and whether it will be readily accessible. Finally, I have a warning to Member States. The measures being taken by the Investment Bank, the Central Bank and the Commission will go a long way towards injecting life back into the European economy. I commend the Commissioners for that, and they have my full support. But I have to stress that EFSI is not a substitute for structural reforms and sound public finances in the Member States, nor can it be an excuse for a lack of urgency in single market reform.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to say a big thank you to my colleagues, Mr Bullman and Mr Fernandes, and I would also like to extend that thank you to the Co-chairs, Mr Arthuis and Mr Gualtieri. They have done a tremendous job, and I can assure everybody that spending the night here together with the Commission and the Council is not a very great erotic experience. Commissioner Katainen and Georgieva have said that we share the same values and the same objectives. That is probably true for the Commission and for Parliament, but it is not true for the Council. Commissioner Georgieva said that she is going to turn every stone to find new money, and I believe her. She is going turn every stone, and as soon as she finds something under that stone, the greedy hand of the Council will try to get that money. That is the problem we have. We have a Council which is counter-productive and which does not stand for European values. Moreover, we are not negotiating with the Member States – we are negotiating with COREPER, and they are not able actually to move. We have a deep problem, a structural problem here, and we have to address it. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Mr Torvalds, I could say that the outcome of the negotiations represents a great success for us, Socialists and Democrats in Europe. At the same time, I understand what you said. What is your opinion on a budgetary solution for financing a guarantee fund for the European Fund for Strategic Investments? It will not be able to function without a guarantee fund.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: blue-card answer. – The very first problem we had with the process was that there was no new money and no way of getting the Member States out of their corner. And that is the problem we are going to have in the future: with each annual budget we are going to have the same fight about getting some money just to repair what we could not fix during the negotiations. Thank you for a very good question.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Austerity policy has choked off investment. Therefore, those who want investment, including private ones, must bury the policy of cuts. I expressly recognise the efforts of the rapporteurs to improve the EFSI. However, EFSI is a placebo for the sick man Europe. In any case, planned investments are being used by private investors. This is expensive nonsense because taxpayers pay the return of investors. This solves the backlog of returns for banks and insurance companies, but not the investment backlog. Addressed to Mr Weber, the great Bavarian democrats: the next time he inaugurates the motorway in Bavaria together with Allianz Insurance and adopts his anti-European car toll, he should please mention that I was not part of this project. The EFSI aims to make €21 billion in guarantees €315 billion of investments over three years. Even if the Juncker voodoo works, this represents only 0.8% of the EU's economic power annually. Europe needs a public investment programme of at least 2% of gross domestic product. The European Investment Bank could already finance this today without any risk to its triple-A rating, for example by buying its bonds in an emergency, rather than aimlessly pumping liquidity into financial markets. EIB bonds are not subject to the stupid Stability and Growth Pact, which neuters growth, not debt. 1 euro of public investment generates 1.60 euro income. They create wealth for future generations. We do not need a Juncker placebo, but a Roosevelt in Europe.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all I too would like to thank all those working on this file, but especially the co-rapporteurs, who have made sure that we as a parliament put up a very good fight on this one. I also want to thank the Commissioners, who it was indeed interesting to spend the nights with: something I never expected to endeavour that early on. Nevertheless, after these thanks, and where it is also very clear that investments are needed and that there is finally room now for an investment programme and not only an austerity programme – which is something, indeed, that Parliament can compliment itself on – we need to be honest: this is not the investment programme yet. This is just the start of a beginning. We have just been discussing the sum of EUR 8 billion. Of course, we know that in the projections and with all kinds of leverage factors it will come in the end to EUR 300 billion. Let us see whether we achieve that. But in the end we have been discussing only EUR 8 billion, and it is also EUR 8 billion we took away from the existing EU budget, an existing well-functioning EU budget. And why those budget lines? Because they are for the EU; because the Member States did not want to touch any of their own budget lines. We know that, and let us be honest about that: we cannot sell this as ‘the’ start, as ‘the revolution’ of Europe. Nevertheless – and of course, given these circumstances, we had a huge discussion in the Group – from a Green perspective, we do see a very clear direction for sustainability, for jobs, and that is what is needed. That is also what we will hold the Commission and the EIB – I see the EIB there at the back as well – accountable for: that these projects will really deliver change and not business as usual. We think we have enough in place so that the Greens can support this programme, but on the scoreboard, for example, work needs to be done. This is the beginning. Let us really make this a successful programme where we can say this was the start of a new Europe instead of business as usual.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not believe that this agreement is as useful for lifting the European economy as the supporters of the Juncker Commission would have us believe. Firstly, this plan relies too much on private investment, which only comes for their own personal benefit, and where there are risks they always have the guarantee of the EU, and therefore of taxpayers, to cover them. It never changes anything. Profits are privatised and losses socialised.  In addition, the projects that are to be supported are always the same, starting with large and useless infrastructures, to continue with relifiers and gas storage plants. Are these the new, alternative projects with great added value? Moreover, it is clear that EFSI is just a complete fiction artfully constructed. The EIB has already identified the projects it wants to finance for months. Nor did it wait for the end of the parliamentary process to make its decisions public. He has probably rightly realised that he is dealing with a Parliament that passively suffers choices that have fallen from above and decided elsewhere. I believe that the citizens of us want more, but you are also rejoithering for this umpteenth gift to the usual well-known.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – The time has come, the countries of the European Union are going to provide guarantees of more than EUR 300 billion, ostensed to make investments. We are talking about projects that are explicitly considered risky and are not funded by mainstream markets. The banking crisis arose at the time after risky projects were funded for people who could not afford it. As a solution to the crisis, you are now coming up with risky projects funded by governments that, given their debt mountain, cannot afford it. I will explain to all my constituents why I will have voted against this crazy Juncker Fund, but I wonder how you will be told by your children and grandchildren later that you did approve of this project and have saddled them with even more public debt, with the only argument being that you believed that, despite the straitjacket of the euro, you did. , would nevertheless result in economic revival.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, if something does not achieve its objective, it is corrected or abolished. A basic rule which in the European Union is not respected. We see that the European Investment Fund is unable to cope with the ongoing economic crisis in Europe and lead to growth. We are not making the necessary changes to meet the new challenges, and we are not removing it as a failed model. But we are creating a new fund and we call it the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Another flashy title of a ghost fund that we fund from European Union funds to bring results over a three-year horizon.  I get the impression that we're going to create a virtual reality that we just wish would succeed. This fund is rather more a means of manipulating public opinion, and a perfect trick by Mr Juncker to succeed in setting up a committee, rather than solving the problem. The Treaties, the euro, the Stability Pact, the reforms, the corrective funds have failed. The European Union produces poverty, unemployment and Euroscepticism.  Mr. Younger, growth is not coming, making Luxembourg a tax haven for multinationals. Growth will come in a way. Abolition of the wrong policies and reconstitution of the European Union in favour of the peoples and not of plutocracy.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which This is a good day for this House and for Europe. I am very grateful that I was able to be part of the negotiating team. The European Parliament has improved the Financial and Financial Security Fund for Strategic Investments financially and in terms of content and strengthened democratic legitimacy and parliamentary control. We have made the Commission's initiative our concern. Unfortunately, to date, we have not been able to make it a concern for the Member States. The absence of the Council on this important day speaks volumes. We must get the Member States on board! Today, we are launching investments of EUR 315 billion, opening up the opportunity for 2.1 million new jobs. These investments are urgently needed for Europe and for new jobs and the economy: we currently have 430 billion fewer investments than in 2007. The European Parliament has set a clear line: the fund must act independently, the selection of projects must be free of political cries, and the funds must be made available unconditionally and irrevocably. The largest projects that have not yet been implemented must be supported. There must be no business as usual, and the fund is not an EIB ATM, but support for global players in investment. With the new platforms, we have ensured that investment and research platforms become a separate structure in this fund, opening doors for cooperation with the ideas of the world. I am campaigning for a broad majority. (The speaker agreed to answer two questions under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: "blue card question." – Mr Karas, you mentioned that we have not yet sought the opinion of the Member States. Indeed, it's factual, it's still a future task. But do you not think that it is even more important to seek the views of the social groups, organisations, local cooperative associations and trade unions concerned?

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Firstly, we have negotiated with the Member States, we have spoken to the regions – the Council is part of the outcome of the trialogue. What we want is for the Member States to invest in the fund, to initiate them more in projects and to increase their participation through the promotional banks through the possibility of participating and extending the guarantee. In addition to the scoreboard, we also discussed and integrated the issue of the involvement of the social partners and civil society in the trialogue.

name: Neena GILL
text: blue-card question. –  Mr Karas, I agree with you that this is a good day for the European Parliament, because this fund is an important opportunity to boost investment and growth in the EU. But on the financing side of the fund, I am still concerned that important parts of it will be taken out of Horizon 2020, cutting into a very important R&D budget. I would like to ask you what you think about that. Are you also concerned about the limited time-frame of the fund? Does it not put at risk the objectives?

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. In particular, the rapporteurs Fernandes and Bullmann and us, together with the Commission, have succeeded in greatly reducing the share of Horizon and Connecting Europe, at least by EUR 1 billion. And there is the Commission's commitment that everything will be done, that no existing projects will be jeopardised by this: that is a clear message to the market. We do not want to touch anything, we need our own money, which is available. The second thing you asked me is that we clarified in the trialogue that for us, Parliament, this fund should be a long-term institution and have included evaluation periods. He has no expiration date if he works well.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are going to approve the most important initiative taken so far by the Juncker Commission, an initiative that is part of a macroeconomic strategy that finally has significant elements of innovation compared to the past.  It was a nice page of parliamentary democracy. We will all remember forever the long nights of negotiation. I would, of course, like to thank Vice-President Georgieva, Vice-President Katainen, Council representative Mihails Kozlovs and the entire negotiating team, starting, of course, with Udo Bullmann and José Manuel Fernandes. A beautiful page of parliamentary democracy which has shown how the Union method can be an efficient system of decision-making, which has enabled us to significantly improve the text by building what still seems to be a broad political consensus, which has been built not in an abstract way, but in practice in the process of improving the legislative text.  I do not need to remind you of the many points where the text has been improved thanks to Parliament's work: the selection and appointment process, accountability, governance, the setting of objectives for investment guidelines, the evaluation system, the scoreboard. I would particularly like to stress how we have helped to clarify and strengthen a concept of effective additionality of investments, that is, a real capacity of the plan to help overcome market failures, financial fragmentation, showing that, while we need to work – Vice-President Katainen is right – just as quickly and concretely on the digital single market, on the capital market union, at the same time it is an important recognition that the market needs public policies , without which investments do not get where they should go. And then, very importantly, I would like to thank Vice-President Katainen for the statement he has formally read here today: this is another important piece in overcoming a rigid and bureaucratic interpretation of the Stability Pact towards an interpretation that allows and encourages Member States to contribute on the ground of national platforms and to strengthening the fund's investment capacity. We therefore have a good basis and Parliament will certainly continue to exercise its prerogatives to the full in order to contribute to the effective implementation of the investment plan.

name: Sander LOONES
text: – Will this investment plan have an impact on the site? Yes. Is this the sustainable solution to our problems? Of course not! Only structural solutions with strong structural reforms can bring sustainable solutions. The ECR Group had a number of basic red lines. We are pleased that they can also be found in the final text to a large extent. For example, not politicians but independent experts will decide which projects are funded and that is a good thing.  It is also a good thing that we are talking about a temporary project. Only when we see that the results of the project are good and successful can a new project be considered. But there remains, it has been said repeatedly, a major blemish on this project and that is the fact that resources for scientific research, the resources of Horizon and SEF are being cut. Then I hear it said, here in this House, that Parliament is saving one billion less on these funds and that this is a good thing.  This is not a victory, this is not enough!
