This is not an honourable compromise. This is, I think, a disgrace. Horizon and SEF are still saving $5 billion. The answer I get is that fundamental research is safeguarded. Yes, three projects are safeguarded, but that does not mean that all basic research is protected. The innovative aspect of Horizon is precisely that fundamental research and applied research are intertwined. It's a shame that's not being respected.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: – Mr President, I think that the agreement reached during the trilogues was the best possible one, taking into account the position of the Council and the Commission. At many moments they were completely united against Parliament. I do not think that the Juncker Plan is the cure for all our economic problems, but I do think it can be useful and that it goes in the right direction. The Juncker Plan can help to build the European infrastructure still needed to enhance our growth and deepen the single market. In particular, the EFSI can be of great help in those countries which face more problems raising private capital in the financial markets. Moreover, a personal objective was – from the beginning – to include provisions that ensure that the EFSI will not be used to build ‘ghost airports’ without planes or high-speed trains without passengers. Only projects with the capacity to attract private investors will be able to be part of the fund. The inclusion of the TEN-T corridors is a very good piece of news too, as is the inclusion of regional promotional banks in the plan. In Barcelona (where I come from), the Catalan Finance Institute – a historic collaborator with the European Investment Bank – has been for years a key institution for reaching many innovative SMEs.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, aontaím agus aithním go bhfuil gá ann d’infheistíocht, ach caithfimid béim a chuir ar infheistíocht phoiblí. Ní hé sin atá sa phlean seo; a mhalairt atá i gceist. Ní théann sé fada a dhóthain agus ní sholáthraíonn sé aon infheistíocht don earnáil phoiblí. An sprioc atá leis ná príobháidiú de réimsí tábhachtacha a neartú. Beidh tionchar damáisteach aige seo ar na daoine agus na tíortha is boichte inár sochaí. Ní chreidim go ndearnadh go leor iniúchta maidir leis an tionchar a bheas aige ar ghnáthshaoránaigh na hEorpa. Mar aon leis sin, samhlaím go mbeadh sé tábhachtach go mbeadh soiléireacht agus cuntasacht ag croílár an phlean seo – ach níl ar ndóigh. Creidim go gcaithfidh sé a bheith soiléir an tslí go ndéantar na cinntí agus ba chóir monatóireacht leanúnach a dhéanamh ar éifeacht na hinfheistíochta. É sin ráite, is dócha gur céim dhearfach é go pointe go bhfuil cinneadh déanta gan an EUR 500 milliún a thógaint ón nuálaíocht agus taighde. Cuirim fáilte roimhe seo. Chuireas féin chun tosaigh leasuithe maithe a chinnteoidh go mbeidh maoiniú agus infheistíocht ar fáil le haghaidh fiontair shóisialta agus comharchumainn. Agus tá siad sin, mar is eol dúinn ar fad, mar chroílár d’aon phobal; tá siad thar a bheith tábhachtach do gach geilleagar áitiúil. Impím ar gach duine tacú leis sin. Ní hé go bhfuilimid i gcoinne infheistíochta; táimid ar fad i bhfabhar infheistíochta. Ach caithfimid féachaint ar an bplean seo mar go dtugann sé tosaíocht do phríobháidiú agus sin é an rud atáimid in aghaidh.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Mr President, today we are witnessing a certain ceremony of exaltation, a certain understandable self-referential triumphalism. How could we dissent, in any case, from a proposal aimed at growth at last and not the obsession with austerity, in any case in force today in other areas? That's why it's more necessary, I think, the critical counterpoint that I'm going to try. We have a new investment fund, but we don't have an investment plan. We have a powerful financial instrument, with some elements of management and selection of projects entirely interesting, but we have no clear and verifiable objectives beyond the wishful thinking perhaps to mobilise EUR 315 million. We have, however, some realities consolidated in the negative, such as the impact on the best European programmes under Horizon 2020. Perhaps the best expression of EIEA's real ambition is this famous expression 'in particular through', used to escape any real commitment to the coherence of the projects selected with the explicit objectives of European strategies. Mr Katainen said that we had to deal with the market failure that characterises the current situation, a much larger private investment gap, by the way, than the fund wants to generate. Once again, everything at the service of the market and only at the service of the market. The general interest, at best, will be a desirable second derivative. All right, we'll work to get reality to demise our critical concerns. We will try, I will try, from our social and economic reality, from my own country, to bring up the projects justifying the decision to be adopted by this Parliament today. But, as we will see in the votes, this debate is completely overflowing geographical or ideological boundaries. I will vote against, as a best sign of my commitment to a real policy, aimed at sustainable growth and reducing inequalities, objectives that this Plan does not even intend to achieve.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: –  Mr President, I admit I have got serious concerns about this project’s ability to deliver value for money and whether it will actually help small and medium-sized businesses or merely become an avalanche of paperwork. My colleague Marco Zanni put it very well when he said that we are socialising losses and privatising profit. If you want a case study of why this kind of thing does not work, you have only got to look at the British Labour Party and the disastrous PFI (private finance initiative) that was introduced, part-privatising our British NHS. When we voted on this matter in committee, the words used by one of the rapporteurs about the aims of this project were particularly telling. He said: ‘We asked the question: would you use your own plastic, your own personal credit card to pay for a project like this?’ Then after all the negotiations, he said at the end, ‘Well, I am not sure whether people would still use their plastic on this project’. Well, I have got news for you: when you spend money it is your credit card we are using, but it is also mine, and everybody else’s credit card across the whole of Europe, and that is what we need to think of before spending taxpayers’ money.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: Mr President, the European Fund for Strategic Investments seems to be the last road to an impossible recovery. The Juncker plan makes a lot of noise for nothing in reality. This report once again deplores the dramatic fall in private investment, even though it is only the result of the disastrous austerity policies demanded by Brussels.  In the face of this, the Commission is promising us, with a great deal of communication, 315 billion euros of investment created from a guarantee of only 21 billion euros. This leverage, deliberately overestimated, will suffer the same fate as the pact for growth and jobs, which is supposed to bring in 60 billion euros of additional investment to actually reach 20 billion euros. The counterparties demanded are still the same, the smoky structural reforms that can no longer even find thanks to the eyes of IMF economists, who recently admitted that it brings no further growth. In reality, this plan will accelerate territorial disparities by retaining only the most profitable projects, and this obviously for the benefit of a few large metropolises and agglomerations. Finally, and this is the most scandalous, it will strengthen the bottom line, the privatization of infrastructure through partnerships more... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker.)

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Mr President, the European Fund for Strategic Investments is not an autonomous project, but part of the €315 billion investment package, the Juncker Plan. The EU has a commitment of EUR 16 billion, with EUR 5 billion from the European Investment Bank. We expect private investors to spend 15 times this 21 billion. This isn't going to be the expected economic miracle weapon, it's going to be a miracle. And what could be tempting for investors? The fact that states have to take responsibility for high-risk investments is public money. I quote the report: its capital requires an additional significant contribution from the Member States, which is essential. In fact, it is a European PPP construction of gigabytes. We in Hungary have very negative experiences with this type of cooperation.  The Member States, the Council representing them, will have no say in the decisions. They will not have a representative on either the Steering Committee or the Investment Committee. And if the report emphasises that the investment fund can only work well if Member States continue structural reforms, which is known to mean austerity. Real positive change can only be achieved by the re-creation of neoliberal economic policies and the Community solution to the debt crisis.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteurs in the European Parliament who led these negotiations, because it was an extremely difficult mission for all those who participated. It was a difficult negotiation, with four committees, with many rapporteurs, and at the same time on the other side, it was a kind of union between the Council and the Commission – and I hope that this will not happen again in the future. I think they have done a very good job, they have succeeded in diminishing the effects on the two Connecting Facility and Horizon 2020 programmes, and I think this will be seen in the future.  Now we have the legal framework. It was a project that had been expected for a long time. Now let's see what the Member States are doing, what projects they are presenting and hope that all other eligible entities will present projects that cannot be financed by other means and projects leading to economic development, jobs.  At the same time, I ask the Commission to ensure that, in the 2016 budget, in the same negotiation with Colleague Fernandes, it tries to put back the money for the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020.  Thank you very much.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, it is really a collective achievement to launch these funds for strategic investments at such short notice, but we all know this is just the beginning of a very long process to relaunch growth and investment and job creation in Europe. I would like to put a specific question to Vice—President Katainen on job creation. My question is: how do you now intend to use this investment plan to foster job creation? I would like to share with you my own thoughts about this. In order to use the plan to foster job creation, we need, first of all, to use the best of these investment guidelines to put a strong focus on the creation of high-quality jobs. The criteria for selecting the projects should be to create a strong path to job creation. The Advisory Hub should encourage job-rich projects. Investment platforms can play a central role if they become engines for innovation, skills and job creation. That is why it is very important that all Member States and all regions have real opportunities to participate in such investment platforms. I notice your final declaration on how to make a correct interpretation of one-off measures, so I would like to have your thoughts on this.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is undisputed that the EFSI will trigger investment and create jobs for the EU. The question is what investments, what jobs, and for how long they will last. Who will ensure that we create added value for EU citizens? There is an intractable conflict of objectives here. After all, how can it be that we identify new, profitable projects that have not yet been realised? Why haven't they been realised so far? I think that is a very obvious question, and the Commission has not been able to answer that question, because I do not think there can be a meaningful answer either. Instead, we will create a great deal of bureaucracy. If we only imagine that we want to finance each project with an average of EUR 10 million, then we must support 31 500 projects in order to obtain EUR 315 billion in volume. Which authority is to do this, should it do better than the many thousands of company leaders who already have it?

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Mr President, I am pleased that so good work has been done in such a short period of time. The EFSI is a new financial instrument available to private investors, but in order for them to seize and engage, two brakes and two risks must be lifted. The fragmentation of the internal market is the first obstacle: investors in the economic field demand uniqueness and stability of the rules, that is to say the urgent need to accelerate the removal of the barriers that still clutter the European market. The second brake is monetary: the lasting settlement of the Greek crisis and the establishment of a credible eurozone government must put an end to questions and doubts about the euro. Finally, while it is true that the EFSI is a guarantee given to investors in return for risk not borne by the markets, I want to warn against two risks associated with its implementation. The first risk is not to ensure the partnership expected by SMEs, contrary to the requirement of additionality introduced in our regulation, and the second risk is to pave the way for a de-establishment of public investment expenditure and consequent debts.

name: Claude TURMES
text: Mr President, the new financial instrument is a first step towards a Europe that is reinvesting in its infrastructure to create a better future. It is a victory for a progressive party in Parliament over the ideologues of austerity. It was a victory for the Progressive Party of Parliament to steer investments into the future and not to business as usual.  There will be no investment in nuclear and coal, but in energy efficiency. Personally, I fought for a $50 billion energy efficiency fund. Now the ball is in the European Investment Bank's court. It is up to it to provide cities and private investors in Europe with technical assistance on energy efficiency and to advance investments in energy efficiency. Your challenge is to go further than the $50 billion, otherwise it would have been better to take my idea of a dedicated $50 billion fund.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Juncker Fund will trigger investment, it will encourage innovation in businesses, it will improve transport infrastructure, the EFSI will make a difference in terms of broadband. These are all positive aspects. I am all the more annoyed that the money for the guarantees comes from research and transport pots of all things. We get something valuable, but we give up something valuable. With Horizon and CEF, the money comes from the policy areas of all places, where we have struggled to find European competences. Yes, the Juncker Fund will receive a great deal of support, but I do not understand why the Commission has made it so easy to finance. It has not even tried to get close to agricultural or structural funds. We all know that billions of these funds are being used unused and are often not being used efficiently. The fear of the Member States must not go so far as to allow for sub-optimal solutions. That is why we will make every effort to ensure that research and transport funds are returned in the coming years. The Commission is here in its word - Parliament will take it at its word!

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Mr President, Madam and Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to join in the congratulations expressed to the negotiators, particularly to my parliamentary colleagues who have sometimes fought against the rigidity of the Council and, more surprisingly, a certain hostility, initially, from the Commission. This investment fund, we dreamed it, we did it and we will vote for it! I hope that everyone today recognises the added value of the progress that Parliament has made, for example on the budget. While research and transport infrastructure budgets have regained $1 billion of the initial $6 billion cut, the choice to provide the Fund for these programs is weakening them. A greater use of margins would have been less counterproductive and this debate once again confirms the handicap of an undersized European budget. I also want to stress the importance of the clarifications we have made to ensure real additionality: investing where neither the EIB nor the Structural Funds can do so, investing in projects that meet the need for energy transition and job creation, and I welcome the guidelines and scoreboard that will guide investment priorities. I would also like to highlight the clarifications obtained on the co-financing of Member States and public investment banks with regard to the Stability Pact. These one-off measures may be excluded from the deficit calculation in order to loosen the stranglehold of austerity.  But what we are voting on today is only one step. We do not grant a blank-seing to either the EIB or the Commission. That researchers, universities and regions can be assured that we will continue our efforts to preserve horizon 2020 and CEF funding through all the levers, Mrs Georgieva, and even the margins. If we socialists and democrats have put so much emphasis on issues of governance and democratic control, it is because we see Parliament as the watchdog of the use of the budget. We will defend investments that will serve the goals of job creation and sustainable growth.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: – Mr President, dear colleagues, many of you will know that EFSI is not a new concept for the EIB. They successfully carried out a programme of pilot project bonds in the last mandate, which demonstrated investor interest in their projects. They also showed the ability of the EIB to utilise leverage responsibly and transparently in order to facilitate private sector investment in European projects. A similar investment vehicle has recently been utilised by Switzerland, and it seems that long-term investor groups are keen to participate in well-chosen and well—implemented investment opportunities. We should be under no illusion that EUR 315 billion is only the first tranche of investments which the EU needs to collectively mobilise to achieve growth in its economies. However, this fund should facilitate billions of euros of private sector capital, from within the EU and across the world, to finance infrastructure, business and innovation. It seems that the Member States have already put forward more projects than can be funded using this project. I therefore welcome the new EU investment portal, as it enables long-term investors to identify further investment opportunities independent of EFSI.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Mr President, I have welcomed and supported the Juncker plan from the beginning. I had and still have three reasons to do so.  The first reason is that everyone knows that the level of private investment in Europe is far too low, even lower than it was before the 2008 crisis. I am convinced that the plan, using private capital, with the share of the European Investment Bank and the guarantee granted to it, by the multiplier effect I believe in, will be the first step in reviving private investment in Europe.  I am convinced, secondly, of the need for an effective instrument in the European Union to help finance investments with potential high added value, but also at significantly higher risk than others.  Finally, I am convinced that the Fund's management structures, thanks to their professionalism and therefore their independence from haggling between Member States, are a guarantee of success in selecting projects with a future.  To innovate, you have to do something new and dare to get out of corporatism. That is the challenge of the Fund. I think he'll make it.

name: Christian EHLER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Fernandes has already been rightly praised by everyone. However, I would like to express my thanks to Kathleen Van Brempt, who negotiated for the Committee on Industry, for the gender balance and also for personal merits. It is significant that the Council is not here today. This discussion has given the impression that it is more right to support the EFSI than to invest in research and development or infrastructure. This was never an economic issue, I believe, for all those who have some sense of reason. The issue is that the Council was not prepared to give any money in the investments from the national envelopes or from other programmes, and that we were in the emergency situation to support a real political, economic sign – basically, to cannibalise one in order to get the other. In this respect, I would like to make it clear once again that this is a good day today, and I am not putting it in opposition to research, development and transport. Hopes are pinned that the Fund will also be successful in this way. But I would like to make one thing clear, and we should remember this: we once decided to spend three per cent of Europe's gross national product on research and development, and we are now below two per cent. In this respect, I would ask that this situation, which was perhaps necessary politically and economically, be rectified so that we still stand by the old commitment and try to increase these very funds again in the annual budgetary procedure. Otherwise – and I call on Mr Katainen to do so – he may still experience many early hours of the morning in this Parliament.

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Mr President, firstly I would just like to say that I very much welcome the creation of EFSI and the opportunity that it provides in the UK as well as in all the other European Union countries for investment in infrastructure, SMEs and green growth. Just this morning I had a meeting with people from my region who were talking about EFSI as being a vital source of funding for the significant energy infrastructure gap that we have, which is a promising sign of where it can be used. However, additionality is absolutely the key, and that is why the source of the funding for EFSI is a challenge, and it is a challenge that we are going to have to keep coming back to. Taking the money from Horizon 2020, which is already a successful means of support for our economy, was the wrong source, and we need to keep going back to this – and we will do so in the 2016 budget negotiations.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Mr President, Commissioners, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Speaking in the debate on the European Fund for Strategic Investments, I would like to express my hope that it will be a real and not a paper instrument for reducing the investment gap created in the Union as a result of the economic crisis that began in 2008. The creation of a EUR 21 billion guarantee fund is expected to trigger investments of eur 315 billion over the next three years, mainly by the private sector. This means that projects financed by this fund are expected to have an average leverage of 15 times. It's a very high bar. In this situation, the weakness of the fund may be that most of the investment projects submitted so far are for infrastructure or energy, and these have long rates of return. Finally, I would like to express my hope that the Investment Committee, when deciding on the investments that will be guaranteed by the Fund, will take into account the late investment of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe and projects from this part of Europe will, however, have additional support.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: – Mr President, Commissioners, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. I would like to stress that today we are dealing with a new chapter, a new stage in the functioning of the European Union, because an attempt has been made to create an instrument that is intended to fundamentally change investment measures. The way in which this fund is introduced is important. If it is accompanied by the argument that it is the answer to the fact that other policies are working badly, this will be a very bad sign for the functioning of the Union. The idea is to show that other policies are in other sectors, and this fund is going to work in a completely different area. It will therefore be extremely important to clarify the relationship between the Structural Funds and the ESI Funds. This is not yet fully explained – I therefore report the urgent need for complementarity in this area.  Finally, I will just say that we are dealing with a rather risky experience. Namely, if Parliament works at this pace with the Commission and with the Council – and this is an example of how we can work quickly – this will be a good example, but undoubtedly a serious challenge, because it was indeed, as the Commissioner said, meeting the deadline and working in a very short time. The question is whether we will be able to work like this in the future.

name: Eva KAILI
text: S&D). Mr President, I too would like to welcome this excellent effort by everyone, but also by Kathleen Van Brempt and, of course, by all the rapporteurs for EFSI, because the expectations that have now been created are too great for the whole of the European Union. But the concerns are just as great about how leverage will ultimately work to achieve the EUR 300 15 billion target. It concerns us, of course, whether this objective can be achieved without further burdening the Horizon programme. The debate is therefore also about the fact that there is money available for investment, but it is also important that projects in the Union, which really have a public interest, are also profitable.  If there is one dimension that I could mention, it is that in countries where the crisis has hit the most there are significant opportunities to invest in efficient projects and infrastructure projects, but there is not enough incentive to finance them from the private sector to achieve the necessary leverage. As you can see, the issue for us is worrying as you understand that the procedures for selecting these projects...  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you very much to the Commission for what you have to say. I agree with you that we need more investment for Europe. With the trilogue agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments, we have certainly created a very good basis. However, I would like to pick up a few points briefly. First of all, it is very positive that there will be no political impact on the EFSI's project selection. Investment decisions must remain investment decisions. And we need a selection process for the projects that is geared to quality, sustainability and legal certainty. This includes a concrete examination of the real added value of each project application. I also welcome the fact that the agreement lays down the principle of risk diversification. This means that all regions and sectors can benefit from this fund. And that also means that not only large-scale projects can benefit, but above all small and medium-sized enterprises. We do not want to create a new bureaucratic fund, but a stable and attractive framework for investors. Only in this way can we also promote growth in Europe. Investment and forward-looking economic policy are two sides of the same coin. Europe must continue its efforts in this regard. Investment in projects alone will not be enough, and we must continue to invest in our reform efforts, in our competitiveness. Only in this way can the investment plan become a success at the end of the day. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr President, you mentioned in your speech that it would be important to see how we can also provide SMEs with funds, and at the same time you said that you are sure that there will be no political influence. Can you explain how you are sure there will be no political influence?

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you very much for the question. I believe that we have ensured, with the framework conditions for this fund, that decisions can indeed be taken here independently of direct political influence. I am very confident about that; that is why I raised this point. I am also very confident that, in the end, really small or medium-sized enterprises can benefit from this fund. I believe that the conditions have been created; we have discussed and seen this on several occasions in the negotiations. That is why I believe that we have got this off to a really good place.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: – We have focused too much on austerity in Europe in recent years. We have invested too little in areas that deliver growth and jobs. If we were to stay on this path, we would enter a long period of low economic growth, low inflation and unemployment. I therefore welcome a project that attracts private and public funding for those viable investment projects that would not otherwise have been implemented. However, we must necessarily link the project to measures to combat tax evasion and tax fraud, to Eu funds to finance projects with high added value, to better access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises, to the ECB's money-issuing measures, to the continuation of structural reforms in the Member States, but also to the digital market mentioned by Commissioner Katainen. We need to help the younger generation get a job. If we can revive the positive moods of the population, it will help us to kick-start growth, employment, living standards throughout Europe.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: I think that with the European Fund for Strategic Investments we have created a beautiful baby at the European firmament, but after a difficult birth! The question is also whether this baby will grow up to be a full-fledged and mature youngster. We'll see.  As transport coordinator of the EPP, I have been greatly hurt by the SEF funds that the European Commission has withdrawn from my fund. I had an extra EUR 2.8 billion in subsidies, which I am now losing to the European Fund for Strategic Investments. I think that is fine in itself, but to speak to Mrs Van Brempt: I do want my money back at the end of this operation. And whether I get that money back in loans or in subsidies or in roads, waterways, railways or airports, I don't care that much.  In transport, we do have a problem that road and air are more powerful than rail and inland waterways, and I hope that the European Commission will look into this in the years to come. The mid-term evaluation of the Multiannal Financial Framework gives us a good time to look back with you.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D). Mr President, Europe needs investment, against one-sided austerity, in order to have growth and close the investment gap. That is why the contributors to this programme deserve congratulations, and in particular to the two rapporteurs, Mr Bullmann and Mr Fernandes. At the same time, this is an innovative tool.  It is also innovative for ideological reasons, because it finally combines public intervention with money and guarantees and private initiative. I wonder, would some in this European Parliament take the same view if Mr Juncker did not adopt and promote it? I come to the third, perhaps most important, point of my own intervention. It has been rightly said that this text has created a framework which excludes political criteria in the selection of investment projects. I know a country, our Member State, Cyprus which is threatened by a third country and has energy resources. So we'll see in practice if they're not really politically influenced... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: – Dear colleagues, Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. We often live in clichés in this house. We say things like "now is not the time for words, now is the time for deeds". But what is our job? Our job is to create the conditions so that the economic growth that we all want emerges. And this European Fund for Strategic Investments is, in fact, one of our visible works. What have we done? We take a small part of the European Union budget so that it works as a guarantee that private investment is invested in the economy, not in your accounts, but in the economy. We have done our job : there are proposals. Now there is a question and hope that the private sector will seize the opportunity, make money and create the jobs that we as legislators want. Thanks for the attention!

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as everywhere in Europe, the citizens of my constituency are waiting for the economic recovery and are well aware that it requires a massive plan of public and private investment for that matter. The EFSI will clearly be an asset to this relaunch thanks to the guarantee it provides to project owners. I would like to express my satisfaction with what Parliament has done and the project it has been able to develop on this regulation. For my part, I stressed two particular points: firstly, the involvement of regional levels, which I think is very important, because the regions are intended to carry projects and to support them financially, in particular, in the most fragile territories; secondly, the opportunity for SMEs to participate in the work generated by this plan, which I believe will enable them, I hope, to create jobs.  I regret, however, that the Council has not agreed to provide guarantee funding and I will be extremely vigilant on the budgetary issue, in particular on the MIE and on Horizon 2020.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has What is now in Article 14 of the regulation – namely transparency, the European Parliament's rights of control, the control rights of the European Court of Auditors – have already been very important points for us, and I am really grateful to the rapporteur for them. José Manuel, the invitation to dinner. I would like to tell you that you must always disclose to us the question of how much private capital we actually attract with the fund. We know that there will be a large amount of taxpayers' money, including through the purchase of second bonds by the European Central Bank. That is why I believe that what we are now making of it in the coming months and years – what you, as the Commission, but also we as a Parliament, make of how we are bringing this agreement to life – is crucial. I would like to encourage you to provide us with as much information as possible and as transparently as possible. With the EFSI, we encounter the same administrative procedures, the same administrations, the lack of authorisations, objections, long legal proceedings. Perhaps we must now take up the point in a second wave as well. Otherwise, the first step may not have gone long and not far enough.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President, Mr Vice-President, adopting this Strategic Investment Fund means first of all restoring confidence and proving its effectiveness.  We have already won the race against time, because five months have passed since the Juncker proposal, and we have already taken on a great challenge. Proving effectiveness means that when we vote for investment support, we must immediately bring down the disbursement to make it useful.  The challenge we face with this Investment Fund is above all job creation. And behind the European Social Fund, it is clear that it is strategic investment that can create wealth, create research and innovation, mobilize public and private funds, so that full employment is our main objective that restores the confidence of our fellow citizens. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: the blue card. – In fact, there are many problems in individual countries: unemployment, income, economic growth. This plan is presented on a case-by-case basis precisely as a plan to address all these issues. I am fundamentally in favour of the need for a plan, but how do you think what percentage of the problems that this plan will solve?

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, of course you are asking for the age of the captain, I am not escaping it! What I want through this plan is to restore the confidence of citizens, because, inevitably, strategic investment restores and creates jobs and that, behind this job, it is young people entering the labour market, it is unemployed people who return and it is certainly also working lives that are lengthening. So there is no place here, in this Chamber, for doubt: yes, strategic investment is essential!

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the adoption of the Juncker Plan is undoubtedly proof that, with political will, Europe is moving forward and citizens are winning. I would therefore like to congratulate the rapporteurs, Mr Fernandes and Mr Bullmann, and, of course, Vice-President Katainen, on the great work they have done. Because, without a doubt, this plan will contribute to the objective that we all have in this room: growth and job creation. But let us not forget that this will not solve Europe's big problem. It is undoubtedly part of the solution, but not the solution. As Vice-President Katainen said, we need to continue to make progress on reforms at national level, but also, at European level, we need to encourage the single capital market, the single energy market and the digital single market to boost growth and job creation. But, without a doubt, today what we are going to approve is great news.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Mr President, first of all, very warm congratulations to our two Vice-Presidents today, Mr Katainen and Ms Georgieva, for their strong leadership and commitment that led us through this process – and that is why we are here today – as well as to my colleagues Mr Karas and Mr Fernandes and many others, who worked tirelessly to match this very tight schedule. On very key and important projects such as this, citizens expect us to deliver, and this is what we did in the most efficient way possible. But if we only worked in such a swift and efficient way on other projects such as the Digital Single Market or the Energy Union, Europe would probably blossom not only through springtime but throughout the entire year. Yet, as Commissioner Georgieva mentioned earlier, the tough part of the job is ahead of us now, so we need to get EFSI to function in an efficient and cohesive manner. What I would like to see – and what we need to help with  – is business ideas becoming quality operational projects with high returns, by providing the necessary assistance. This means that technical and advisory support should be readily available to get projects off the ground, especially in states with less experience and expertise. This is why I very much welcome – and I think it is a very good thing – to have the European Investment Advisory Hub. But charging business for the use of its services might create a barrier for those in greater need of assistance. With the political will and the right incentives for projects to be realised, this Investment Plan can be … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: For the catch-the-eye procedure that follows, I would like to begin by pointing out that I have almost four times as many requests to speak as I can. I will therefore not take into account colleagues who are still on the list of speakers elsewhere today. I have tried to strike a certain balance according to the political groups and also by the Member States in which colleagues are elected. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, I would also like to congratulate Commissioners Katai and Georgiava, as well as all parliament's negotiators, for having achieved a very satisfactory outcome for all parties on this important EFS. As we know, the European Parliament has been very strong in its support all along for the creation of this Fund for Strategic Investments. But the main concern was that there were fears that these funds would pinch out Horizon 2020 funding, which is important for basic research, and, on the other hand, the financing of important transport projects. In these negotiations, those main concerns were certainly allayed. It is excellent that now EFSI is really getting off the ground and we are gaining momentum for investment in Europe. In my region, Finland, for example, EFSI has already proactively decided to lend a large part of the very significant investment of EUR 1 billion in the forest industry, which is directed precisely at clean technologies, and we need more of this kind of investment in Europe.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the pillar of the Juncker Plan, we are finally talking about investment and growth in Europe and no longer about austerity. The European Parliament must be credited with making improvements to the commission's initial proposal, and congratulations to the rapporteurs. I am thinking, for example, of the changes towards greater transparency in the work of the Steering Committee and the reduction of the cut in two key programmes such as Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020 compared to the Commission's initial proposal, with greater protection for the research sector. It is therefore a positive step, some have called it a good day, but it is to be hoped that the Fund will retain the objective of actually exerting leverage over private investment. It goes without saying that, in order to strengthen confidence in the Union's economy, Member States should continue to undertake effective and economically and socially sustainable structural reforms in order to establish a virtuous circle in which investment projects contribute to job creation and the reduction of macroeconomic imbalances in the Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, this report recognises well the growing need to invest in education and the development of skills in the field of new technologies, and I would particularly commend the emphasis placed on making money more accessible for SMEs that suffered the most in the crisis and whose recovery is crucial for our economies. But I must say that I am concerned about the very character of this Fund because it is too reminiscent of a central planning political project. Further concerns in this regard are also raised by the proposed composition of the management board, as 75 % of its members are appointed by the Commission, while Member States are prevented from appointing members.  I can see that the report also calls for the achievement of the Union's political objectives through funding from the Fund, and from this place I would like to invite all stakeholders to first of all be guided by a clear economic calculation so that taxpayers who finance all this profit to the maximum.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the European Fund for Strategic Investments will mark our mandate. Its success or failure will be part of what will be part of our work and in particular the Commission's work. In this context, I want to strongly support the establishment of this fund, I also want to strongly support the intentions to invest in infrastructure, in energy, I also want to strongly support the fact that it wants to talk about risky investments, support risky investments, start-ups, that it wants to foster a public-private partnership.  But what I want to specifically warn about is: let's not forget our traditional industries. This Parliament and the Commission talk too little about tourism, and I think tourism is a great opportunity for us, especially in Mediterranean countries, and we talk too little about shipbuilding, and the ship is a real European product. And I think there is a lot of room for improvement and the opportunity to strengthen our European competitiveness.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the European Fund for Strategic Investments remains an incomplete project. A firework that, instead of promoting growth and public investment in the real economy, transfers the risk of investment to the already austere state budget, even to taxpayers, by leveraged profits for private capital. Thus, while guarantees and losses will be socialised, profit will be privatised. Even these scarce public investments will be financed by cuts to other projects. Three parties three billion euros from the Connecting Europe project, two parties seven billion from Horizon 2020.  The GUE disagreed and disagreed with this logic. The peoples of Europe need purely public investment in the real economy, which will ensure new, decent and secure jobs, but also social and economic growth. The peoples of Europe need to stop the austerity policies, the policies of the memorandums.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Many hopes are being put to this fund, and of course many questions are raised. Many hope because the possibility of creating new jobs in many areas is also envisaged. But, of course, there are many questions, because it's a relatively... important novelty in this capital market as well. And above all, it is clear that we also have the right to demand the best possible and greater transparency and transparency of resources. It would therefore be a good thing to consider once again whether this fund should, of course, become a financial instrument and therefore become subject, on the one hand, to greater control by the European Court of Auditors, so that we can also be calm about assessing the effectiveness of the use of funds in this part and achieving the objectives themselves. On the other hand, it is also possible to discharge the European Parliament, because this also strengthens the European Parliament's concrete role towards this fund.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: –  Mr President, following the sharp drop of investments in the EU in the aftermath of the financial and economic crisis, the setting up of the European Fund for Strategic Investments could be one of the answers to the provision of stimulus the European economy needs. I am hopeful that through a well-managed fund we can efficiently attract leveraged private investment in order to achieve the goal of creating more than a million new medium- and long-term jobs. The fact that, during the negotiations with the Commission and the Council, Parliament succeeded in minimising the budget cuts in the Connecting Europe facility and the Horizon 2020 programmes is also a great achievement, which ensures that vital financing for energy and transport infrastructures and research and development projects is secured.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, committee chairmen, Mr Gualtieri and fellow rapporteurs, I think that today we can be very satisfied with the result achieved on the nature, financing, operation and governance of the EFSI, with objectives that are very important to the European Parliament.  In particular, as chairman of the Committee on Culture and Education, I would particularly like to thank Mr Bullmann and my fellow rapporteurs for having not only confirmed the role of education and training as a growth strategy and funding commitment within the seven strategic objectives, but also the cultural sector, which was strangely forgotten. I would remind you, however, that in the field of so-called digitalisation, new technologies, the issue of e-learning and e-teaching platforms, connected schools and all those projects that really serve to make human capital a great strategic resource, and not just structures, must also be considered. I'm just going to close by saying it's very important.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, after my conclusion, my colleague Georgieva would like to issue a statement on behalf of the Commission. Thank you very much, dear colleagues, for your opinions and advice. Now we are turning to the implementation phase, and it is very important that we all pass the message on in our Member States – first of all to companies. If you have a plan to invest in something which is considered a high-risk project, or if it is difficult to get financing purely from the private financial sector, you can call on the European Investment Bank and ask if they could help get financing. Nobody can guarantee this, but companies do not need any governmental approval; they can contact the EIB today or tomorrow. There are lots of hardworking people at the EIB, and they are willing to help the companies in their investment plans. The second message, which I hope we all could pass on in our Member States, is that we need a local intermediary for SME financing. I have visited 24 Member States since the beginning of the year, and in every single country I have heard the same message. In most cases, SMEs can get financing from the banks, but venture capital is a very scarce resource. There is a lack of equity financing everywhere. So, if countries are interested in improving SME financing, it is your duty to establish a local intermediary. It can, of course, be a commercial bank, but in many cases national development banks or promotional banks can be an intermediary for SMEs. Private venture capital funds can also apply for resources from the EFSI and serve their clients. This is the message I am constantly passing on when visiting Member States, and I hope everybody here does the same. The final comment is that we strongly encourage Member States, as well as the regions of Member States, to establish national or regional – and sometimes cross-border – investment platforms. It basically means a special-purpose vehicle into which public money can be put. National promotional banks can finance those vehicles and pension money can go there. Insurance companies can chip in and apply risk financing from the EFSI and opt to protect themselves and finance those high-risk private sector or public-private partnership projects. Implementation is very important. The EU cannot implement this beyond what we have done already. We need an SME intermediary, we need a message to bigger companies that you can contact the EIB already today, and we need national or regional investment platforms. This is the way, Madam Rodrigues, in which the EFSI can help to create new jobs.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, during the negotiations, we in the Commission made a commitment to make a declaration on the 2016 draft budget. I would like, for the record, to read the text of this declaration: ‘The Commission will analyse the potential impact of the contributions to EFSI of the different budget lines of Horizon 2020 on the effective implementation of the respective programmes, and will, if appropriate, propose an amending letter to draft budget 2016 to adjust the breakdown of the Horizon 2020 budget lines’. I would also like to assure Parliament that Commissioner Moedas and his services have been working on this task. In conclusion, I would like to confirm that we are determined, in the annual budget procedure, to look for any opportunity to reduce the impact on the two programmes which are, together with the margins, the foundation for us to be able to move forward.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to welcome this debate, to thank Vice-President Cattani and Vice-President Georgieva, and to say that job creation cannot be conditioned by ideological prejudice or a poor agenda against the integration of the European Union. In job creation, investment is positive whether it is public or private, and that is not the way - to be public or private - to measure good or bad investment.  With this plan, which we have here and which will be approved, we need to mention another positive point which is the advisory platform that has been approved. An advisory platform to help structure projects, a advisory platform that will be free for public entities and where small and medium-sized enterprises will only pay a third of the costs. A platform that will help this plan move forward and now get to work with this plan.  We also have a portal, a portal that will give visibility to investments. There are also platforms: they can be regional, they can be national, they can be thematic, where third countries can also be present, using the guarantee; and can contribute to the Energy Union, they can also contribute, for example, to the Digital Union.  This is a fund that believes in private initiative, which believes in small and medium-sized enterprises. It is a fund that is also strengthening confidence, which is giving the European Union more competitiveness and, as has already been said here, that it is additional and complementary.  I hope that it will be a success for it to continue from the outforce and that another fund like this can then continue.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very Three comments so that we know that there is still work to be done tomorrow. First of all, I think that in future we should not let the Member States and the Council get away with it – little to no ownership, at the same time red lines, which must not happen, and the hope that everything will pass as quickly as possible, as long as only the money from the European budget is used, is not an attitude that we, the European Chamber of Citizens, will accept. In view of the plight in Europe, this institution must find a different awareness. My appeal to the next presidencies: we will make this point clear! I would like to thank both Commissioners for the clarity and correctness with which the agreements have been implemented again today, together with a warning to their address as well as to the European Investment Bank: what we have negotiated is what we mean. This applies to the agreement on the content. We in the Steering Board will blame the EIB and the Commission for the fact that there are good products, for good results, and this also applies to the selection of people. We will insist that the best are taken and not make room for anything else. My final comment is on my colleagues and their staff. The rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs have done an excellent job, especially, of course, those who have worked excellently for them in the services, in the personal offices and in the group offices, as always. I would like to express my thanks for the way in which they have done so, which has brought the European spirit back to life in this House. Finally, José Manuel Fernandes, my co-rapporteur, is a big thank you not only for fighting like a lion to defend the European budget and also to bring it into the future, but also for allowing the greatest possible coalition possible in this House.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, 24 June, in the evening. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The progress made between the final text and the initial announcement of the stimulus package should be noted. I am pleased that the social sector, education and health are finally among the possible areas of intervention. In addition, the Juncker Plan will primarily benefit SMEs, the main source of economic recovery in many EU countries, including Belgium, and promote regional participation. These advances achieved through the work of left-wing forces in the European Parliament fully justify full support, although it will be necessary to remain vigilant about the extent of effective job creation by the selected projects. Thus, the public guarantee granted to private investment must have as an imperative corollary to create growth and employment. The Fund's tracking scoreboard, another significant improvement, will be crucial in this regard in assessing job creation, the impact on growth, the volume of private investment and respect for leverage. Finally, while we can welcome the forthcoming implementation of the Juncker Plan, European decision-makers must be bold and courageous in abandoning the austerity in force in many countries, a policy that is humanly dramatic and economically inefficient.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I welcome the Commission's proposal for a European Fund for Strategic Investments, which aims to lift Europe out of recession. The aim of this fund is to create new jobs, increase long-term employment, attract private capital and investment. New incentives to increase investment – investment will be supported by EU guarantees – can restore investor, public authorities and industry to confidence in future growth. Attracting new investment, the European Fund for Strategic Investments can become a key factor in a new investment cycle that creates new jobs and opportunities. These new investments are needed not only to rebuild the EU economy, but also to restore a social Europe that our citizens can trust and believe in. Thus, in order to increase employment, the number and quality of jobs created by the Fund need to be assessed, with a particular focus on working conditions in jobs created. Member States should promote active labour market policies in order to ensure that their workers have the capacity to adapt to the needs of sectors with high investment potential. The success of this fund will depend on the extent to which the private sector is willing to invest, so incentives for the private sector should be maximising. In addition, in order to maximise the job creation potential of these financial instruments, the European Structural Funds should be used to contribute to project financing.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – The Juncker investment package would mobilise EUR 315 billion in capital for European transport, energy, digital and social investment and help companies with a maximum of 3 000 employees, mainly SMEs, to access finance through venture capital loans. The three pillars of the package are, on the one hand, the setting up of a new fund, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, on the other hand, the creation of a list of feasible developments and the adoption of an internal market roadmap that removes administrative obstacles. The European Union and the European Investment Bank (EIB) contribute a total of EUR 21 billion to its capital. Of this, EUR 16 billion is provided by the EU and an additional EUR 5 billion is added by the EIB. On the basis of EUR 21 billion, it is estimated that the EIB will issue AAA-rated bonds worth EUR 60 billion at triple leverage. This generates approximately EUR 315 billion in capital investment, calculated on an additional fivefold leverage. This could provide a good basis for a new, economically sound boost for the economies of the Member States of the European Union to overcome the crisis.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. Our efforts to fill the investment gaps created by the economic and financial crisis must not be allowed to slacken. As MEPs, it is our duty to adopt measures that break the ever-increasing inequalities between regions and restore people's confidence in the Union's economy. We can only bring about real change if we effectively drive economic recovery in the Member States. And economic recovery requires new investment. I particularly welcome the fact that a large part of the money goes to small and medium-sized enterprises, the backbone of our economy.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – The European Union needs further investment in the real economy over the next three years, and the European Fund for Strategic Investments can and must support higher-risk projects that can contribute to job creation and growth in the Member States. By maximising the impact of public spending and unlocking the financing of privately investment projects, Europe can make progress in Member States and in sectors where job creation and growth are most needed.  We can only hope that there will be favourable treatment under the Stability and Growth Pact for national contributions to the European Fund for Strategic Investments, but also that the specificities of the Member States will be taken into account.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. President Juncker announced last December that a European fund would be set up by the summer to boost investment on our continent. This project, an essential element of European economic policy along with fiscal consolidation and structural reforms, was aimed at supporting the development of SMEs, creating jobs and financing growth projects in the fields of agri-food, transport, digital, energy, research and innovation. The appointment with the opinion was made. Today, I am pleased that the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission have agreed on this European Fund for Strategic Investments, which will eventually mobilise EUR 315 billion over three years towards the real economy. I am also pleased that the European Parliament, on behalf of project owners in our territories, has been able to impose a reduction of one billion in the planned contributions of the Horizon 2020 programmes and the interconnection mechanism in Europe to the fund. In order to achieve the desired results, it is now necessary that this fund be put in place as quickly as possible.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the proposal for the establishment of a European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) comes at a vital time as the EU struggles to emerge from the economic crisis, resulting in a 15% decrease in investment in the Union. I was very concerned by the Commission's initial proposal, as in its view the approval of the projects financed by this Fund would have depended entirely on their economic returns and support for economic growth without any geographical distribution. My concern was that with this type of criteria, EFSI-funded projects would concentrate in better developed REGIONS of the EU, further widening the gap with the least developed regions, such as those in Bulgaria. Thanks to the proposals made in the EP, it is of great importance to me that among the main objectives and indicators for measuring progress made under efsi should be to include the achievement of economic and social cohesion objectives, and that projects must contribute to ensuring inclusive and sustainable growth. The EP's proposals radically change the Commission's original text, namely that they give less developed regions, such as those in Bulgaria, the chance to apply for EFSI funding projects.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – In my opinion, the Juncker package will also open up serious opportunities for private investment in agriculture with an EU bank guarantee. However, only more competitive and larger agricultural undertakings should be able to access investments. I therefore agree with the view of the Committee on Agriculture that the investment promotion programme should be focused mainly on small and medium-sized enterprises. In particular, they are capable of creating jobs. Hungary good experience in this field, since the Hungarian Government has a successful policy in terms of job creation. On the other hand, I would remind colleagues that EU agricultural policy is primarily based on subsidies and will not change in the future. It is in our interest that the current Common Agricultural Policy be maintained and not replaced, even in part, by a system of EU investment promotion instruments. Such an instrument can only complement the current cap system.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – I welcome the outcome of the negotiations on the establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which is in line with the objectives of the Hungarian economy, as it will provide a new kind of financing opportunity for domestic financial service providers and companies. The Fund will also support risk finance for SMEs and mid-caps across Europe. It will help to bridge the capital gap by means of larger direct capital investments and additional guarantees for high-quality securitisation of SME loans. SMEs will be able to benefit from pre-financing grants before efsi is fully set up.  It is estimated that the investment package could increase the European Union's GDP by up to EUR 330-410 billion over the next three years and create between 1 and 1.3 million new jobs, so the estimates are very impressive. From a Hungarian point of view, of course, the greatest success is that the investment package is completely separate from the resources of cohesion policy. The eur 5 billion redeployment will amount to EUR 2.8 billion for the CEF and EUR 2.2 billion for Horizon 2020, which finances R&D. From the point of view of horizon 2020, which finances R&D projects, it is a success that the proposed reduction is being reduced compared to the Commission's original proposal. It should be noted that, in the case of Horizon 2020, the core research lines that are our priority are not affected by the redeployment, including the programme to broaden the participation of the new Member States.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. Today is an important day for the European Parliament: after months of hard work by the rapporteurs, also thanks to the contribution of the other committees, including my group's EMPL, a much better regulation will be adopted than the initial EC proposal. The strategic investment plan will now have the financial instrument to implement it.  It is time to combine growth and the creation of quality jobs that the EU as a whole needs in a concrete way. Firstly, the countries which have so far paid the highest price for the economic and social crisis. The main objective of EFSI must be growth and the creation of adequate and high-quality jobs. That can only be the guiding principle of the whole regulation. However, in order to prevent job creation from being hampered, Member States need to promote active labour market policies to ensure that workforce skills are adaptable to the needs of sectors with the highest investment potential.  The success of EFSI will depend very much on its ability to ensure cohesion with other European financial instruments, such as the Structural and Investment Funds, and to strengthen them concretely.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. – This initiative by the European Commission is very welcome. This European Strategic Investment Fund must finance high-risk projects that Member States will never assume. At the same time, we must avoid competition between Member States. The expertise is totally different, the ability to attract funds and invest is different. It is very important to support SMEs, which can have great advantages for the EU if they manage to gain a large scale and manage to start the engine of the economy.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – It was only after lengthy consultations that the EU institutions were able to agree on the rules of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), which should be set up as a matter of urgency, and the end result is very worrying: there are no guarantees that the new fund will be used exclusively for long-term sustainable developments that are coherent with existing EU policies, such as projects for the green economy and energy savings. Although Parliament has had partial success in the negotiations, the new fund still draws a significant part of its money from the EU Horizon 2020 Framework Programme for Research and Innovation and the European Network Development Facility (CEF).  The way in which the project is selected is also problematic – although a scoreboard will help to assess the expected impacts, much more would be needed: full transparency and consistent enforcement of sustainability criteria – as set out in the opinion of the ENVI Committee. The selection should be based on the EU's environmental, energy and climate objectives. The new fund does not reflect decades of experience in development policy, lacks precise selection criteria, detailed objectives and conditions for the involvement of stakeholders. We should not allow efsi to be spent on environmentally and socially damaging or unsustainable developments that have been left out of the Cohesion Fund. Some Member States should not be allowed to fund the capture of expensive infrastructures based on conventional energy sources or outdated technology and thus make them uncompetitive with EU public money.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. - The European Fund for Strategic Investments, known as EFSI, is the Juncker Commission's flagship investment policy project. With the help of the EFSI, the Commission wanted to mobilise €315 billion and invest in European projects within three years. With the aim of significantly reducing the crisis-related investment gap in Europe of around EUR 400 billion and subsequently creating growth and employment – a good project in itself! However, there has been scepticism about this project from the outset. For many experts, the leverage effect of 1:15 was far too high and incomprehensible, although the European Investment Bank, the parent company of the EFSI, has repeatedly asserted that leverage on this scale is common practice in its sphere of activity. To this day, the return expectations of private investors to participate in EFSI projects remain largely unclear. And then there are also problems in identifying potential projects, because only those that are highly risky and therefore not supported by private investors can be supported – all in all, anything but good conditions for the fund! Ten projects have been identified which can be co-financed by EFSI. The extent to which these projects will have strategic benefits for Europe will be revealed.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. – The economic crisis has left a deep imprint on citizens' and business's confidence in Europe's ability to create the right conditions for growth and employment. In recent years, we have approved many legislative measures and they are already bearing positive results, but the psychological effect of the crisis remains an obstacle to Europe's return to the trajectory of sustainable economic growth. With the adoption of the Juncker Plan, today we send a strong signal that the Union institutions are committed to the problems of their citizens and are working to solve them. As politicians, we have a responsibility to create the right environment and ensure that vital investment will focus on these projects in member states that will improve citizens' living standards and create a better perspective for the young. I believe that the distribution of investments to be mobilised through the European Fund for Strategic Investments must be geographically balanced and not lead to deepening regional disparities. At the moment, this is also of huge geopolitical importance, given the instability and security challenges in the eastern part of the continent. The Fund is also an additional guarantee to counter attempts at separation between Member States through various external economic, energy, cultural projects and financial incentives from third countries.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. – As much as they insist otherwise, the Juncker Plan is not an investment plan. It is an insurance plan for large private investors, who see how their speculative projects are subsidized by the state, which guarantees their losses in the event of bankruptcy. Once again, the neoliberal framework is imposed on the definition of public policies. Where criteria of cohesion and vertebration of the European economy, of productive convergence of its less developed regions, were necessary, we find ourselves deepening the liberalizing trends of recent decades: in infrastructure, in energy; even in public services, as governance itself pushes States to cut back and resort to such plans. There is a need for a public investment programme, in which the State takes care of technological development and economic diversification, especially in foreign trade. And there is also budgetary scope for this, if the EI directly supports the States and the ECB acts on the secondary market, if genuine fiscal harmonisation is carried out: proposals which its Commission rejects, delving into the crisis of the European project and economy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. – While we are discussing the Juncker Fund, the troika continues to suffocate credit towards Greece. It is pushing for continued austerity, violent fiscal adjustment and a reduction in public funds as well as the Public Investment Programme that could be a lever for investment in Greece.  With regard to the Juncker Fund, as we have already pointed out in our previous speeches to the plenary of the European Parliament, investments are not made with an 'air of bang', but with funds which the 'Juncker Plan' does not have. Moreover, investments in the European South will not be made unless the problem of public debt is solved.  For this reason, the shameful debt in Greece must be erased and the public debt cut in the other countries of the European South must be cut. Only in this way will public funds be released which, instead of going into the pockets of loan lenders, will be invested in development.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Mr President, I would like to thank the The Commission and other supporters of the EFSI are already praising this controversial fund in such a way that it must be assumed that it has already solved Europe's problems! And yet it is still not known how high the capital stock must be, which is supposed to attract more investors. External estimates assume that this must be between EUR 20 and 50 billion! Whether this lever works at all and attracts private investors is currently completely open! Another point of criticism is the lack of planning for the use of the money. Precise advance planning would be the key with such a large capital and therefore urgently needed! Socialists and Social Democrats called for new money for the initiative. I say that the Member States must be prevented from being burdened more. Does such a high-risk investment make sense if, at the same time, the 'fund for unforeseeable expenditure' is more than exhausted, thus showing that the Union's financial planning is not stable and therefore safe?

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: in writing. –  I see the European Fund for Strategic Investments as a key instrument for risk finance for SMEs and a driver for the future competitiveness of the European economy. Though I am satisfied with what we were able to achieve so far – namely: less to be taken from the existing programmes, CEF and Horizon 2020; for countries which are still progressing in the R&D area and finalising their modern infrastructure, EUR 1 billion less cuts will give them an equal chance to prosper; the steering board would not be politically influenced, and Member States and third parties as contributors in the guarantee fund will not intervene in the decisions; the principle of additionally has been supported, which means that similar projects may not be cofinanced with other EU funding opportunities; and technical assistance is provided – nevertheless I would like to stress that many projects have already been announced as approved for financing, before the final agreement being reached. I think this practice should be abandoned because it confuses the beneficiaries and it is not fair towards them. Finally, I put my hopes that the EFSI will give young entrepreneurs the courage to realise their brave and innovative ideas in the European and global markets.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. – I support the agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments. I am pleased that, as early as 2015, riskier projects will be supported and investment has begun in the countries and sectors where the need for jobs and growth is most affected. I am pleased that, despite the difficult negotiations, Parliament has succeeded in reducing the cuts in the budget allocated to Horizon 2020 research programmes and the Connecting Europe Facility. I fully agree with the need to promote investment through various measures in the context of economic recovery, job creation and industrial competitiveness, but this should not be done at the expense of other viable and well-functioning programmes. It is therefore now necessary to ensure that the Fund supports future-oriented projects that will have the greatest impact on economic growth and will help Europe achieve its objectives in the areas of energy, climate and digital market. We must ensure that the fund operates transparently and democratically. The aim must be to attract as much private and public investment as possible at a later stage, to encourage all Member States to contribute to the fund and thus to ensure its stable growth. Whether juncker's plan will be able to generate the desired impetus for the European economy will tell us the time, but it must not be forgotten that this fund, like others, is an additional incentive alongside other European initiatives and the necessary structural reforms.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. – I have serious doubts about the clout and the focus on change of EFSI. It is said that this fund represents a change of direction, away from the savings policy towards a serious investment policy.  It is very unclear to me how EFSI and the Juncker Plan ensure a better return on social, economic and environmental transition. We are not providing new public funds and are even taking 5 billion out of Horizon2020 and CEF. What signal do we send to our R&D world? What guarantee is there that these funds will be better used through the EFSI than in the regular budget? Moreover, the compromise saves 4.1% on climate action and energy R&D resources.  I also have big questions about the so-called multiplier effect x15. This is voodo politics. What certainty is there that the mechanisms in this plan will also work in politically uncertain countries? Will investors be willing to step in? EFSI opts for public-private partnerships; it is invariably more expensive for taxpayers than direct public investment. This concept ensures the socialization of possible losses and the privatization of profits. Or will the richest regions still benefit the most from this initiative? I am not convinced and therefore vote against.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. The European Fund for Strategic Investments must be strengthened in order to create good and sustainable jobs. The announcement that he wants to get a "triple social a rating" for Europe must now be followed by action by President Juncker. It must not be the case that the funds of the Investment Fund create precarious job conditions. There must be no investment for the sake of investment.
