Care must be taken to ensure that the European-funded projects have a sustainable effect and that good quality jobs are created as a result. The selection of projects must take into account not only how quickly the project can be implemented, but also that it creates high-quality jobs. Investment in social and nursing professions is urgently needed in view of demographic change and an ageing population. More attention must be paid to regions affected by the crisis. It is important to ensure that the money arrives where it is most needed. We will only regain the confidence of the citizens in the European project if we succeed in making Europe fairer.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – The European Parliament and the Council have demonstrated that, by using the Community method, it is possible to set up a European fund outside the Union budget - in this case, for strategic investments. This success once again confirms that, when there is political will, the European Union is able to progress towards common objectives. In this respect, I hope that we can achieve more quickly the formation of a fiscal capacity at Union level so that we achieve a true Economic and Monetary Union, in line with the principles set out in the recent report of the Presidents of the European institutions.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: In writing. Estonia is one of the countries whose largest national holidays, including Victory Day and St. John's Day (June 23 and 24, respectively), are not observed by the European Union. The twentieth century saw several wars contribute to the formation of European countries as we know them now. Estonia is the only one of these countries, in its pursuit of independence and peace, to have achieved victory on two different fronts: against the Red Army and against the Baltische Landeswehr. However, we understand that it is important to continue working, and we refrain from asking for days off during the Estonian holidays, or that the European Parliament does not organise a plenary session on the very day of one of these great celebrations. On the contrary, let us work effectively to achieve our desired objectives, for example by unanimously demanding that Russia release the Estonian policeman Eston Kohver who was kidnapped more than six months ago from Estonian territory and who is still illegally detained in prison by the Russian authorities.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) is at the heart of the plan to rekindle growth in the EU. It is the main tool for mobilising €315 billion in new investment in the real sector of the economy over the next three years. The ambitious plan represents an excellent opportunity for the Member States, I really hope so for Slovenia as well. This is also an opportunity for investors who will see an opportunity for yield in this fund. These additional investments will focus on infrastructure, broadband, energy networks and transport infrastructure in industrial centres, education, research and innovation, renewable energy and energy efficiency. All of this is what Europe needs now.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. The EFSI has been presented to us as the key to lifting the European economy and directing private capital towards the long-term financing of the real economy. But the deceptive propaganda on the Juncker plan hides many doubts, not least about the ability to mobilise EUR 315 billion in a few years thanks to a miraculous and unrealistic multiplier effect, and many questionable choices. Starting from the decision to cut billions in investment in research and innovation, to divert funds destined for "Horizon 2020" and "Connecting Europe Facility" to EFSI, to that of still betting on private capital in search of short-term profits and on infrastructure with no added value, including projects with high environmental impact such as relifiers and gas storage; and the choice to use public money to cover potential losses on high-risk projects. I believe that Europe needs a major public investment plan to stimulate the real economy and employment, not major works built through public-private partnerships with a very poor cost-benefit ratio for the community, which have all too often fuelled clientele systems, corruption and mafia infiltration. It is public investment in research and innovation that will make the greatest contribution to economic growth in the long term.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Pervenche Berés on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the review of the economic governance framework: stocktaking and challenges (2014/2145(INI)) (A8-0190/2015).

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, we have known for a long time that economic and monetary union is unfinished. In this Parliament, under the previous Parliament, we have taken a position with the report of our former colleague Mrs Thyssen. I welcome this report and hope that it will continue to inspire the work of the Commission and the Council.  But unfortunately since then, this urgency has still not happened and when we look at the level of unemployment, low inflation, too low growth in the European Union, let alone Greece, we realize that there is an urgent need to look again at this issue of economic and monetary union. On the eve of a European Council which will be referred to the report of the five presidents, to which our President has made a contribution which I welcome, we, as the European Parliament, must have the courage to take a stand on issues that divide us. If this urgent issue is so dragging on, it is because it is a subject that divides us. However, I say here, the balance we have found around this report shows that there is a possible path, that there is progress that is possible, with or without treaty revision. And we're demonstrating that we can move the lines.  We also say that the first step that has been taken by the European Commission with the 'flexibility' communication is a useful step that needs to be stabilised. It allows us to reaffirm that the issue of investment in the European Union, beyond the EFSI, is an issue that must be dealt with constantly and have in the crosshairs. We cannot settle for an EFSI and consider it to be a one-time measure. The issue of investment must become a key indicator to ensure that we are conducting the right economic policy at the level of each Member State and at the aggregate level.  We say that structural reform is a demanding reform, which must be evaluated over time in terms of results, not only in terms of labour costs, but also by integrating social, environmental and economic criteria. We also say that the troika system cannot be repeated, that more needs to be done and that is probably the most important message of this report. The European semester must enable us to pursue better economic policies for the whole of the European Union. And where it needs to be done, we will have to have the courage, because it will probably be necessary to correct the rules to make them simpler and more complete and to improve economic governance. There is also a need to focus, much more than the report of the five presidents, on the issue of convergence, let us admit. I have a deep conviction that convergence will not wait too long, as we know that our economic and monetary union suffers from our differences.  Macroeconomic imbalances between Member States and also within some Member States should be considered. That is something that needs to be emphasized.  We will have to have an approach that goes beyond the rules to have an economic policy, to be able to assess the situation and the perspective of the euro area and to articulate economic policies according to this diagnosis. We also say in this report that the debt rule needs to be examined more closely, because clearly it does not correspond to the reality of the European economies.  And then beyond that, in a revision of the treaties that will have to be anticipated, because I am convinced, and I will conclude, Mr President, that, as far as economic and monetary union is concerned, we will have to show the same political will that we have been able to mobilise to complete the banking union. It seems to me... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for giving me this opportunity to address you today on this very topical issue. I would like to start by congratulating you on tabling this draft report. Let me briefly recall where we have come from. The Commission published its communication on the six- and two-pack review last year as a basis for debate. With this report you have responded to our invitation to the debate, for which I thank you, in particular as the report is the outcome of thorough and long discussions in this House. It proves that the issues at stake are important and of concern to all of us. For this reason, I am particularly glad to know that our views largely converge. We all share the common objective of an efficient and effective economic governance framework. The reform introduced by the six- and two-pack legislation has gone a long way towards this goal. The reform has strengthened the governance framework and has made it deeper, broader and more effective. Here I can assure you that the Commission is resolved to follow both the letter and the spirit of the six- and two-pack reform in its entirety. It is not without challenges, however. While the governance framework is no smarter, it is also more complex, which creates challenges for transparency and ownership, which in turn affects the enforcement and implementation of reforms. This Commission has taken measures to improve the transparency and effectiveness of the framework. This concerns, in particular, the streamlining of the European Semester and clarification of the flexibility in the Stability and Growth Pact. We all view the European Semester as an important vehicle to coordinate economic policies and deliver reforms, and we all agree that national ownership built on wide consultation of national stakeholders and supported by democratic oversight is key for implementation of reforms. For this reason, the new European Semester places so much focus on prioritising consultations and debates. Discussions in the European Parliament, in particular in the context of the economic dialogue, are important elements in guaranteeing the transparency and legitimacy of the European Semester. In the same spirit of transparency and clarity, the Commission presented its communication on flexibility in the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP), and I am glad that you recognised our efforts. We are going to have a debate on SGP later today, so, for the sake of brevity, let me only emphasise that the flexibility communication was an important step towards better aligning fiscal and economic surveillance, towards creating stronger incentives for reforms and towards ensuring consistency between EDP recommendations and the CSRs. The flexibility communication was one of the components of the economic policy strategy this Commission presented in the Annual Growth Survey (AGS). With their strengthened governance framework with the Commission’s AGS priorities, we are on the right path to overcome the legacy of the crisis. However, our ambition must go further. In particular, the euro area needs a framework which is resilient and robust to any future crises, so that any doubts about the stability of the euro area are removed. I can see there is full agreement on this point among us. Tomorrow, EU leaders, including the President of the European Parliament, will discuss the next steps towards better economic governance in the euro area, based on the Five Presidents’ Report. The report you are adopting today will be a valuable contribution to further improvements in the governance framework. The Commission is fully committed to take forward the initiative to strengthen EMU, and we hope we can count on your support.

name: Anne SANDER
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mr President, Commissioner, as rapporteur of the opinion given by the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I propose three lines of action to deepen European economic governance. We must first ensure that the specific country-specific recommendations are implemented better, and I appeal here to the responsibility of the Member States. This also requires greater association with national parliaments, social partners and European citizens. Finally, more visibility must be given to the social situation of the Member States.  The return to growth, and above all to employment, will only take place with genuine labour market reforms, at least in a number of Member States. This return to growth will also require less taxation of the labour market. Finally, I think we need a more favourable environment. (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Mr President, Commissioner, strengthening the governance of the single market is very closely linked to concrete ideas for the creation of economic governance, including a targeted pillar of the European Semester. As an opinion-giveer to the IMCO Committee, I focused on the areas, the key areas that most promote economic growth and support convergence. I am convinced that the governance of the single market must be strengthened in order to achieve our objectives. However, this requires avoiding discrimination between measures at EU and Member State level, so that we can develop more effective instruments. On the one hand, it is necessary to create further development and better synergy of existing ones, and on the other hand, a system of guidance numbers capable of measuring this integrity. However, I am extremely sorry that these proposals have only been partially incorporated, and I hope that this will change in the future.

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. Mr President, we are coming to the end of a long process in which, in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, we have tried to project ourselves a little bit into the future and to make proposals that are a little more innovative. I deeply regret, for my part, that a number of the elements which had been adopted in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs and for which there had been a gentleman's agreement between the AFCO Committee and the ECON Committee were not included in this report. One of the things I am thinking about is how we are making the rules more respected.  One of the institutions that played an extremely important role in the consolidation of the European Community at the time and the European Union, then, is the Court of Justice. It has just made an extremely important decision on the UNWTO and it seemed interesting to us to consider, of course in the distant event of a treaty change, the possibility of increasing the role of the Court, which is of course the body that is supposed to ensure compliance with the rules. This provision has not been repeated. I believe that, given the current lack of confidence in the legal and political framework of the governance of the euro area, this is extremely regrettable. That is why our group has very deep doubts about this report.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. –  Mr President, it is no secret of course that this report has taken quite a long time to be ready for plenary, and given the differences between political groups that is no surprise. For the EPP, credible economic governance is first and foremost also implementing what you have agreed to do. In our view our economic governance framework is not the cause of the economic difficulties that Europe finds itself in, it is an instrument for addressing imbalances within Member States early on and making sure that we do not run up unsustainable debts. Is this framework then perfect? Surely not. Procedures can be streamlined, as has been said by the Commissioner; they can be better timed. We clearly need a more transparent democratic debate about the key points of our economic policy agenda and we need increased ownership and involvement by national parliaments. For the longer term everyone can see that our monetary union is not perfect or complete, but for steps to be taken to deepen our monetary union we first need to make sure that the current system actually works. In our view the economic governance framework needs to watch over – do I dare say it as a Christian Democrat? – the Holy Trinity of responsible public finances, structural reforms to improve competitiveness, and investments that can create growth and jobs – investments that are attracted by stability and competitiveness, not by running up debt. This will help make our economy stronger, making the eurozone as a whole stronger and more convergent. Then, and only then, can we take the next step that we should take in deepening EMU. It is a question of doing things in the right order, and this order I also see reflected in the Five Presidents’ report. I am glad that in the end we found some groups taking the responsibility, overcoming their differences and actually coming up with a report that gives us the element for the future agenda in the short and in the long term. And now let us get to work.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is the only major bloc which, seven years after the 2008 crisis, has yet to emerge from it. When you leave, you will be with deep scars: unemployment has doubled, skilled young people from the less competitive regions have emigrated, and investment has dropped to historic lows. The conditions for growing up together have never been more difficult. We must be aware that the greater the divergences, the less viable the single currency will be.  That is why the Juncker Commission's option to finally apply the flexibility contained in the Stability and Growth Pact makes perfect sense. Accommodating strategic investment and structural reforms in the rules, reconciling these rules with the economic cycle is a matter of pure common sense.  The Berès report touches on some of these aspects, but it is important to remember here that the single currency will not survive if we do not revise the concept of structural reforms, selecting those that promote a genuine convergence of competitiveness. It will not survive if we do not create minimum social rights at European level; if we do not stabilise the markets, fulfilling the promise of creating a common deposit guarantee of up to EUR 100,000 in the banking union; if we do not put the Troikas, the European Stability Mechanism and the Budgetary Treaty under the Community method; if we do not find a common solution to the sovereign debt problem; if we do not create a European instrument capable of relaunching economies in crisis without causing a recession; if we do not end the practice in which countries steal tax matters from each other while at the same time sanctioning themselves when their budgets are not balanced.  There is an agenda underway, the Berès report is just one step, an important step but an important step, but the fundamental reforms that are partly covered in the Five Presidents Report must be, in combination with the Berès report, carried out with the greatest urgency if we are to truly save the European project.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I cannot share the optimism that has been expressed here from many speeches. With the Berés report, we are taking a further step towards fiscal union, just as we are with the five-president report, a further step towards communitarising risks and burdens. But responsibility for these risks and for these burdens remains at the national level, where it belongs. But nations do not necessarily have to bear their consequences. We see new mechanisms being introduced, such as fiscal capacity. We see that minimum wage legislation is now being required in all the countries of the European Union. We see massive interference with the economic autonomy of the individual Member States of the European Union. All because you think you have to steer economic policy. And why do we have to steer economic policy? Well, the plight has just been adequately described by my colleague, Mrs Ferreira: because the euro and because economic governance has not yet worked, because the system, which is now to be improved further and further, has failed. But it is not being improved, it is proceeding in the wrong direction. We should return to the original principles of the Maastricht Treaty, we should return to the clear and simple rule that there is a principle of non-assistance and that each state is responsible for its own actions and has to pay its own debts. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: blue card question. – Thank you very much, Fellow Lucke, for accepting the question. You have contrasted, in your speech, with national sovereignty, the ability of States to direct their economic policy, and I would like to ask you if you do not believe that it is worthy to represent the sovereignty of your fellow citizens, of German citizens, as we are all in this House, worthy of representing European citizenship and sovereignty.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. It is a question of sovereign rights and not so much sovereignty. It is a question of the competences laid down in the European Treaties. And it is precisely economic policy and fiscal policy that are a national competence, not a European one. The use of the vehicle of monetary union to build a fiscal union is an abuse of the possibilities that the European Commission, the Council and Parliament have, which is precisely not properly respecting the rights of the nation states.

name: Michael THEURER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The current situation in the euro area on the ground calls for a responsible policy, it requires more commitment and more commitment and commitment in the Member States. It requires compliance with the rules in our treaties. It requires a shift towards a social market economy and a market economy policy. Unfortunately, this report makes no mention of this. The report is not a great report, it lacks perspective. While the five Presidents have made a forward-looking mark-up aimed at renovating public budgets, stimulating growth and creating jobs, this report does not mention this. It falls behind positions that we have believed we have already overcome in the past. There is no merger of the country-specific recommendations with the EDP and the macroeconomic imbalance. There is no clear commitment to the rules, there is no verifiability by the European Court of Justice, there is no insolvency procedure for states, there is no uniform external representation of the euro. We consider it totally unacceptable, downright dangerous, that we call for the six-pack to be put on hold at the expense of fiscal discipline. The Communication by the European Commission on flexibility, which we consider to be partially in breach of the Treaty, is explicitly praised here. We reject that! It is not enough for the mere announcement of structural reforms to be taken into account in the examination of the EU Commission without parliamentary decisions and without their implementation. No, we need more, not less commitment, more, no less regularity, more, not less implementation and support for reform policy by national parliaments and governments. None of this is what this report does. On the contrary, it opens the door to the weakening of the Stability and Growth Pact. That is why the ALDE Group cannot agree to this. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" question. Mr Theurer, you spoke of respect for the rules, obviously, of economic governance. Do you think that these rules include fundamental rights, in particular social rights or not?  When the troika demands that Greece, for example, demolish all pensioners' rights and leave no room for decent living for pensioners in order, supposedly, to reduce the excessive budget deficit, which is actually widening even further, is it or is this not a violation of social rights?

name: Michael THEURER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The crucial point is that the troika does not specify exactly what to do. And when Mr Moscovici of the Commission points out that Greece spends 17.5% of gross domestic product on pensions, but only 13% is spent on pensions on average in the euro, it is an indication that action is needed. The old principle applies: it cannot be spent more than is generated. I therefore simply call for the economic problems in Greece to be tackled. Together we can do this: through a market economy, not through planned state economics.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: gue/NGL Group. Mr President! Now you might think that the seriousness of the situation would make an impression. The fact that millions of people live in poverty, including too many children, that we have excessive ly high unemployment and, in particular, excessive youth unemployment, which is almost like the invincible, would have made such an impression that this Parliament will point to new avenues. But if you were so naïve, you have to be disappointed! With this report, Parliament alone points out that we need to do more of the same. We need to cut public spending more, we need to dismantle welfare and we have to take the money from the poorest. It's just not good enough! My group tried to focus on the imbalances in the euro structure. For example, on the problem of the fact that balance of payments surpluses are not only good if, for example, it comes from wage retention and dumping of other countries' domestic markets. But the majority refused to see the problem. The peoples of Europe need - yes, they want - a different path. They must have a say in their country's economy and not see it governed by the European Union, and they must have solutions to poverty and unemployment, not more of the same. It was a new answer that we should have given them. With hope and with the future, with new frameworks and opportunities to develop welfare instead of dismantling it. Unfortunately, they must be disappointed once again, neither the majority in this House nor the rest of the EU elite want to listen to them. It is sad both for welfare and for democracy, which is why the report must of course also be rejected. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Kari, I would like to thank Mrs Kari for her work You mentioned current account surpluses and linked them to wage dumping. I would like to know whether you believe that wage dumping is taking place in Germany, because Germany has large current account surpluses. Or is it not more likely that we are finding that those countries in Europe that pay high wages tend to have current-account surpluses?

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: Blue-card response. Mr President! I believe that the problem with looking only at payment surpluses – the balance of payments – is that you are blinded and that you do not find that if there is talk of wage restraint among the employees in the country, then they are hit very hard, and then you see in reality that the economy is weakening. At the same time, I think it is a problem if that surplus comes because it has failed in comparison with other countries' domestic markets. It wasn't just wage dumping, but wage restraint, I was talking about.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Good afternoon. Thank you very much, dear colleagues. The first thing is a thank you to the rapporteur, who I think has made us have had a good collaboration. However, I have to say that my group's vote is going to be negative, not least because I believe that the right of this Parliament has wanted to impose a report that is timid, not ambitious and extremely conservative, and clear and clear support for what is the current governance framework. And I think it's a mistake; and I, in any case, have to regret that, since the Social Democratic Group, this pressure has been ceded. Look, the Marco has failed. The objectives sought by the Framework itself that we have approved go against exactly the rules we have given ourselves; among other things because, with the rules we have applied to ourselves, today we have more deficits, more indebtedness and more recession and, therefore, it is clear that this does not allow the European Union to reach the path of well-being. Let us therefore assume that the Framework has failed and assume that we need legal reform. Many groups have been calling for Parliament to call for legal reform of the Framework to open up a perspective on many things that are currently essential, whether it is having its own budgetary capacity, strong enough taxation, a revision of the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, what kind of reforms we are doing and the debt issue. It is timid very much the reference on the question of debt in the report and we know that we have a serious problem, even though there are many groups that have made amendments in this regard so that there is a reference. And I would like to say that, in some of these things, this report is a step backwards, because on debt and other issues we have had, for example, in the Troika report of the previous mandate, much more advanced references. I therefore believe that, at the moment, my group cannot support this report and I would also like to say - and I do this as a call to all Members on the left of this Parliament - that it is not putting a couple of commas in an absolutely ideological neoliberal framework, which is not ours, as we must move forward. We must come up with a real alternative to reform the euro area, which is the urgent thing right now.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report is totally unsatisfactory because it starts from a misguided reading of the eurozone crisis, which is essentially due to the inability or unwillingness of The Member States to implement reforms and to respect budgetary rules. The only concern of the report, which we will vote against, is the failure to respect the current framework of economic governance and not the devastating repercussions that austerity policies and the obsession with budgetary constraints have had on the European economy and citizens.  By making a mistake, of course, the cure is also wrong. The aim of the report is to strengthen the existing rules and enforce them, without in any way questioning the need to immediately review the treaties and rules, austerity policies and absurd and unsustainable budgetary constraints. We do not see the vital need to increase flexibility for public investment by exempting it from deficit and debt calculations. We do not look at the macroeconomic imbalances generated by the single currency. There is no roadmap that proposes real solutions to break with the bankruptcy strategy adopted so far, an impossible compromise between those who persist in stating, against all the evidence, that Europe needs more austerity, stricter budgetary constraints, lower wages and less welfare state, and those who, in the election campaign, proclaimed that they wanted to change course and change the existing rules because they were unsustainable and now do not have the political strength to fulfil that commitment.  And I appeal to the Socialists, who have a political commitment to respect with their electors: with this report they absolutely cannot respect it. You have taken millions of votes for change and the fight against austerity and now you support these positions. We have tabled an alternative motion for a resolution to increase the fiscal area and productive investment and to enable the Member States to face up to the problems that we are facing now, namely unemployment and poverty. If we do not solve these problems, Europe will not go ahead. We need to review the budgetary rules, therefore, and above all introduce a withdrawal clause from the eurozone, extending the opt-out granted to some countries to allow all Member States to choose their currency democratically and therefore monetary policy. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Michael THEURER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Valli, the euro is neither the cause nor the solution to the problems, but the problems lie in the real economy. Do you agree with me that we cannot combat excessive public debt by creating even higher public debt and that jobs cannot be created by means of credit-financed stimulus programmes at pump, but only through innovation, products that can be sold to world markets, that is, through the real economy, and, above all, of course, through better conditions for small and medium-sized enterprises that create jobs?

name: Marco VALLI
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Thank you, Mrs Theurer. The major crises have always been defined by forward-looking plans, not six months or a year long, with budgetary constraints of this kind. We need long and public planning in order to have the means to revive the economy and to get out of this crisis situation; otherwise, with the budget accounts, and as long as we have the accountants manage the budget, we will not emerge from the crisis – that is the problem – and therefore we will not be able to make any forward-looking economic manoeuvres over time. Since you are a German colleague, I appeal to you not to respect the constraints.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the tone of this report, which seems to respond in a bad way to the cries of pain and suffering that are currently being heard by the Greek people who are suffering because of you, sounds grotesque. It is a report that is a commercial in favour of the euro and the regulations that support it; it does not contain any serious criticism of the austerity recipes which are the natural consequence of the euro and which today weigh so heavily, as we see, particularly on the Greeks. The path of convergence towards rigid parameters enshrined in the Maastricht Treaty, taken up by the Stability and Growth Pact and reiterated in the fiscal compact, is incompatible with the sharing of a common European political project, a prerequisite for the single currency. You want to integrate EU law, the ESF, the fiscal compact just to secure from popular reaction the instruments that have devastated Europe, leaving only a few countries to compete on the market and relegating others such as my own, Italy, to the role of extras, as the market for the former. But now, with the Europe of Nations and Freedom Group, there is the voice of a people's Europe.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Mr President, it has been shown in practice that the European Union is turning against the people and beating labour rights in order to serve the interests of monopolistic economic circles. Deepening Economic Monetary Union means strengthening the mechanisms of the unpopular capital strategy and the European Union. With measures such as the Fiscal Council, the strengthening of the Eurogroup and others, supervision of the implementation of sustainable austerity for peoples is strengthened, for the sake of the competitiveness and profitability of business groups.  Common objective of the Eu-Union monopolies, the further reduction of the price of labour. No matter how much you take action, no matter how much you talk about convergence, inequality and the capitalist crisis, you cannot prevent it.  In this unpopular strategy the peoples have an answer. Organize and attack to meet their own needs, disengagement from the European Union with the economy and power in their hands.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The rules on economic governance were revised and significantly strengthened in 2011. Why? Because a previous weakening of the rules had led to Member States living beyond their means, delays in reforms and delays in the future. At that time, we ended up in the very debt spiral that decisively fuelled the economic and financial crisis. That is why strengthening economic governance in 2011 was so important and right. That is why we are firmly opposed to a role backwards. That is why we do not accept any softening of the rules. We agree with the own-initiative report that has been presented only because it makes it clear that no legislative changes are required. That is our clear message to the Commission. And the Commission is being asked to apply the existing rules, with the possibilities and within the clear limits that the rules set equally for all Member States. National responsibility and participation must be given greater prominence. Europe cannot be the scapegoat for wrong decisions that lie within the national competence. We very much welcome the fact that the rules were extended in 2011 to include the procedures on macroeconomic imbalances. Contrary to legend, macroeconomic imbalances arise within Member States. An early discovery of such imbalances and their correction through structural reforms is a prerequisite for preventing future sovereign-debt crises. Economic and monetary union must become more resilient. But this can only be done if we look bluntly at the cause of today's crisis. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Marco ZANNI
text: "blue card" question. Mr Balz, I would like to ask you a question: can you tell me how you think Greece will pay its huge debt within the euro? That is, will it pay its huge debt in a hard currency, with an internal industrial system completely destroyed by austerity policies?

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. One should think that Greece has certainly lived beyond its means in recent decades, has been unsound and, of course, that is the problem. I believe that the finance ministers, Heads of State or Government are making a very serious effort to find solutions. I also hope that we will come to solutions. But one thing must be clear: a lot has gone wrong in the past. And simply to say that we can cancel debts here or to cancel debt here cannot be the solution in the end.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with this report, Parliament is making an important and very important contribution to the process of reforming economic and monetary union.  There is strong and bipartisan support for the Commission's communication on flexibility, which is fully in line with the Treaties and the Stability Pact, and there is an ambitious and credible path to improving the governance of the eurozone by strengthening the coordination of economic policies, more binding co-decision objectives at European level and at the same time greater recognition of national margins for defining the means of implementing these objectives. , with the involvement of national parliaments, the indication of fiscal capacity to encourage convergence and reforms. It is good that these elements have been incorporated into the report of the five Presidents, and it is also important to specify certain institutional elements. The report is very clear: the development of eurozone governance must take place within the legal framework of the Union using the Community method. The economic governance of the euro is the European Commission; the Minister for Economic Affairs, the European Treasury is the European Commission. We are not convinced by this idea of a fiscal board and it is good that it has been made clear that it is only advisory.  And the eurozone Parliament is the European Parliament, which is perfectly organised to carry out this task and is ready to start negotiations for an interinstitutional agreement to strengthen its role within the European Semester. This is a clear path, this is a credible path and that is why, because it is credible, it is also ambitious. We therefore call on the European Council, on the other Presidents, to take full account of the Berès report and we are ready to play our full role.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Parliament's response to the Commission's report on the application of the current economic governance framework and to the Commission Communication on the flexibility of the governance framework are not in line with both the position of the Polish Delegation of Law and Justice and the ECR Group as a whole. Although we agree with some general statements, such as highlighting the need for job creation, especially for young people, improving access to finance, especially for SMEs, we cannot support increasing fiscal, economic or political integration in the European Union. In my opinion, measures to deepen economic and monetary union are simply not right, especially in the context of the current situation in Greece. In my opinion, some provisions go far beyond the rational principles of the functioning of the economy: such as the provision on greater resilience to crises in countries with high-quality jobs or better social protection. For these reasons, the Polish delegation is clearly not in favour of both the majority of the provisions and the report as a whole.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: – We are meeting today on a very important issue, namely how the European Parliament sees the future of the euro area and the rules we have agreed with each other to make the euro area economically and fiscally sound again.  Unfortunately, the proposed report of these agreements makes a hole cheese. It calls for more flexibility for the Commission in applying budget agreements, when we have seen just how catastrophic the loose enforcement of rules can end. The lesson from this should have been that rules should be applied rigorously and rigorously to all countries and not that we should create any more space for political horse-trading. Instead of undermining the rules, Parliament should be in favour of a euro area in which all countries abide by the agreements and all countries take measures to strengthen their economies. If countries do not, they will come across themselves. For this reason, european money should only be available to countries that comply with budgetary rules, implement economic reforms and implement the annual country-specific recommendations. That would really help the eurozone move forward. (The speaker shall respond to a "blue card" question in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: "blue card" question. Mr van Nieuwenhuizen, thank you for accepting the blue card question. Frankly, I have a perplexity. You spoke of full acceptance of the rules by countries: I would like to know what you think of the fact that Greece has cut a billion in health spending over the last three years, that infant mortality has increased by 43%, that malaria has also returned? What do you think of these devastating tragedies and social consequences that brought the country to its knees? Do you still have the courage to say that the rules must be applied, whatever the cost, bypassing the lives and dignity of millions of citizens?

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: "blue card" answer. – Of course I am aware of the very difficult situation of many people in Greece. I deeply regret that. But that does not change the fact that we do think that the rules should be enforced and it is up to the Greek administrators themselves to make the right choices and to achieve austerity in other places than where they might be doing it now. The choice of how to cut back really lies with the Greeks themselves. They simply have to stick to the agreement just as well as other countries that have also had to make difficult choices, because Greece is really not the only country where sacrifices have been made. (The speaker shall respond to a "blue card" question in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Marco VALLI
text: "blue card" question. Mr van Nieuwenhuizen, this is not a relentlessness, I had not seen my colleague's card. You say that the rules must be respected, but they must also be respected in the case of the Netherlands and Germany, for example, which break the rules when they show a trade surplus of more than 6%: Germany has done so for several years, and so has the Netherlands. So I want to know if you think the rules should be applied here too.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: "blue card" answer. – The rules should certainly be applied in all cases. The Netherlands has also taken advantage of the flexibility provided for by the Stability and Growth Pact. After that, we followed the rules. So there is sufficient flexibility in the Stability and Growth Pact and we see no reason to add any more flexibility to that now. Because again, countries are already being looked at very well, and countries are being given time to make the adjustments at the right pace.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Mr President, we had a simple but important task here: the task of reviewing the economic governance package. And for what? To bring Parliament's position to the governments and even that Parliament has failed.  Despite all the efforts of the rapporteur, the People's Party boycotted, blackmailed, played, postponed as many times as it could, and we now have here a situation in which the Socialists gave in at the last minute.  What we have here today is nothing new. In fact, it is the behind-the-scenes agreements, far from democratic control, that have been littering all the work we have done over many months. What we have here today is, unfortunately, something we know very well. It is the grand coalition of the right with the Socialists, the same one that governs Europe with the results we know, the same one that governs Germany, the same one that ruled greece until the total disaster.  But in this case, the problem is not only that of the unacceptable proposals of the grand coalition, the problem is also that they have rendered the role of Parliament useless and the document we are going to vote on today is obsolete. This resolution will not serve for the strictly nothing and the ridicule is such that a document made by five presidents will have more weight than the document made by the direct representatives of five hundred million citizens. Shame is the proper word. This is a disgrace and is, above all, a great lack of respect for those who elected you.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, the wise Roman philosopher Marcus Cicero once said: ‘Any man makes mistakes, but only an idiot persists in his error’. Europe has faced economic tragedy for nearly a decade. Tragically, we see this played out in Greece on a daily basis – youth unemployment at 51% and the highest rates of suicide in any Western civilised nation. This economic misery is not confined only to Greece – it is in Portugal, Italy, Spain, and Croatia. The common factor of this misery is their membership of the European Union, its bureaucratic controls, over-regulation and lack of democratic accountability. There is a feeling that people do not matter, only the EU matters. Instead of recognising its mistake – that it is the EU state that is the problem, not the nation state – instead of looking at countries that are succeeding in the global economy, like China, India, Australia and Brazil, the EU persists in its error by issuing reports such as this from the Socialist MEP Madame Berès. Instead of freeing people, it states that the EU must take control of all the countries’ economic, financial and fiscal affairs. Instead of looking to the future, you look to the past with a ‘command economy’ ideology. Instead of unleashing economic liberalism – looking outwards and trading globally – you continue to make the same mistakes. In the words of Cicero, Europe can no longer afford to allow the idiots to persist in their errors. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. I'm not going to mention the word idiot because that's why I lost my immunity here in this Parliament, so I'm not going to mention that word. But, sir, I ask you, why do you mention Croatia when you clearly do not understand the situation in our country. You can speak and you have the right to talk about your country, you have the right to talk about Croatia, but please inform yourself. And I ask you, so that you can still answer the question, do you really know well the situation in Croatia and what has been done well for Croatia by joining the European Union?

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: blue-card answer. – Indeed, your country has faced economic problems. I cannot think that you would disagree that you have high rates of unemployment and that you experienced a drop in GDP upon the immediate connection with the European Union. This is my point: the very fact is that once you joined the European Union, your GDP, unemployment and inflation were impacted by the overregulation and undemocratic control of this place. That is why I am suggesting that you would have been better off outside the European Union, not shackled to the euro and its devastating effect on the people of your country.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Mr President, this report is the subject of a compromise. A compromise always makes people unhappy, and this text is no exception. However, it must still be remembered that at the end of a long negotiation which has been quite difficult and painful, we manage to maintain a number of principles which seem particularly important to our group, the EPP. First of all, the Six Pack and the Two Pack should not be revised and we are not reopening the debate on the Stability and Growth Pact, it was essential for us. Secondly, we remind you that the rules in force must be respected. In reality, the dysfunctions that many of our colleagues are talking about in the Member States are dysfunctions that are simply due to non-compliance and non-application of the rules. The report of the five presidents makes it clear that we need to strengthen our system of economic governance and that this requires the application of existing rules. I urge the European Commission to stand firm on this point in order to maintain and strengthen our internal market and strengthen our environmental and industrial policy. Finally, it must be recognised that some Member States, more than others, need to make structural reforms to adapt their economies to the changing world, and I recognise that this is a step forward that has been taken by rapporteur Mrs Berès and I hope that Commissioner Moscovici will be able to convey the right messages to Paris.  Maintaining the existing rules, rigorous application of the rules, structural reforms, these are the reasons why we will vote in favour of this report.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, we are on the eve of a very important European Council where the Five Presidents’ Report will be presented, and we have started discussion on Economic and Monetary Union reform. That is why we need to adopt the Berès report today, because this is a very valuable contribution to this discussion, which is crucial in order for us to address a central problem of the European Union and of the eurozone. The fact of the matter is that the eurozone is working not as a process of convergence, but rather as a process of divergence, and this is recognised by the Five Presidents’ Report. And if you want to overcome this – because this is undermining the political support for European integration – we need to come up with clear proposals. First of all, yes, we need a reform agenda, but a reform agenda turned to the future, building on a competitive turn to the future, and supporting advanced social standards; and yes, we need to have a powerful investment initiative. We now have EFSI, but we need to build a fiscal capacity supporting Member States in what they can no longer do, because they are committed to a common fiscal discipline. More than that, we need a proper economic coordination of our policies based on the fiscal stance and reducing the macroeconomic imbalances we have, which are undermining the total growth we can achieve as a continent. Finally, we need to bring more democracy to all these decisions and to give a stronger role to the European Parliament. This is a clear agenda for reforming and improving the economic governance of the European Union, and I believe this is a strong reason why we need to support Pervenche Berès’s report today.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the figures and figures show that the current economic governance framework has failed, because social and regional disparities have increased, because the euro area economy is doing much worse than the United States economy, because unemployment and poverty have increased, because the debt of fifteen of the nineteen Euro area Member States is above the provisions of the Treaties and has increased particularly in recent years, and because investment has fallen.  Changes are therefore needed, and these changes are not proposed in the Berès report. Changes in taxation, investment, strengthening cohesion policies, the distorted architecture of the euro area.  This is because the rapporteur did not want them and did not propose them initially, even insufficiently, but because she accepted, in a bad compromise, the pressure of the European right, which wants a Eurozone à la carte, to suit only the rich and the powerful.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has This European Union is a Union of solidarity. Every year, with the Structural Funds, we have a redistribution to weaker groups and regions. EUR 50 billion, that is several times the Marshall Plan every year. That is in response to the previous speaker, as far as he is still listening. I think that the Presidents' report and the Berés report go hand in hand. Many flower dreams that we have had, sometimes different flower dreams, have not come true. But I believe that it is important that, firstly, we make it clear that the European Parliament must play a role and have codecision rights here – in the case of conversions, in the guidelines – and that, therefore, the institutional agreement is important, just as a decision has been established by the national parliaments. Many of the reform measures are subject to national competence, and that is why there must be such a combination. I believe that both reports go into a development that makes clear the decisions we have taken so far, which we have with Sixpack and much more, that there is an internal link between fiscal soundness and structural reforms. Structural reforms are the condition for growth to emerge. Growth can only be done with competitive structures. And for that we must provide European solidarity, through the Structural Funds, through a eurozone budget or whatever – with the participation of the European Parliament, in order to further promote growth from it. In particular, it is a time for support and support to be given to countries that are doing so in a positive way. I believe that we should remember that the agreements with the Fiscal Compact and the like, which are intergovernemental, must be incorporated into Community law in accordance with the obligation.

name: Jakob von WEIZSÄCKER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work. You probably know the story of the three little pigs: the first piglet builds his house out of straw, and when the wolf comes, he can just blow the house away. The house of straw is the euro of the Maastricht Treaty. The idea was excellent, but the implementation was not yet very resilient. The second piglet builds his house out of wood, which is already more stable. This is the euro with the ESM, with the banking union. But also with the very complicated rules of the two- and the six-pack. In our picture one can imagine the new rules as very complicated cross-measures within the house, which should make the house more stable. Unfortunately, they also make the house a bit uninhabitable. You have to be constantly afraid that you stumble over a strut in the house or stumble on it. What do you not do to be prepared against the wolf in the wooden house! But if the wolf actually came, he could still blow the wooden house over. So the question arises: when will we finally rely on the stone house? Congratulations to Pervenche Berés and the Five Presidents' Report, which call for the House of Stone. We must finally get serious about a new architecture for the euro, because we do not know when the wolf would actually come. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Lord von Weizsäcker, who is the wolf?

name: Jakob von WEIZSÄCKER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Of course, it is not Mr Woolfe, who has just left the room, but the wolf, that is the crisis. The wolf, in the case of the straw house, was the financial market crisis, which in fact made the rules that we had devised in the Maastricht Treaty at that time seem non-crisis-proof. Today, for example, the wolf is the great crisis in Greece, from which we have not yet found a way out. And the next wolf could also be another financial market crisis. But it could also be a political crisis, where Euroscepticism is growing. So we should not wait too long: if the house becomes uninhabitable, support for Europe will be smaller and smaller.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: " Herr Präsident, Lieber Kollege! In der Originalgeschichte war es nicht der Wolf, sondern das Wetter, das schlechte Wetter. Mr President, first of all, I would like to make a political remark. I've seen a lot of people here over the course of the afternoon saying that the left has caved in to the right. Well, what it seems is that these Members forget that here are people who represent the voters and therefore have the right to speak out and give influence to their constituents. And so the text we have reached is the result of a compromise between centre-left voters and centre-right voters. All that was left was that center-left voters and left-wing voters had more rights than center-right voters who, on top of that, cast more votes for the center-right than the center-left and the left. This is the first thing that has to be said here. Therefore, the product of this Parliament is the product of the will of the electorate.  Secondly, I think that this report, as it appears after the negotiation, is going in the right direction, which is the meaning that we have had here. There was a crisis in which a crisis of confidence between states and public opinion was created. It was necessary to strengthen the state of the state the trust. That's what you want to do here.  We want to go further, we want to deepen integration, we want to go much further (I have no doubts about that), but for that we have to trust each other and be able to bring each country into convergence with each other so that there is no mistrust and so that we can create a real political union as the final stage of our project.

name: Paul TANG
text: Let me not start with Mrs Berès's report, but with the report of the five Presidents, because that report reads like an admission of guilt, for the good reader.  The admission is that rules do not yet add up to policies, certainly not to policies that allow for economic stabilisation and the fight against unemployment, nor to policies that are democratically supported. Instead of bringing Member States together, tackling the euro crisis has led to divergence between countries and within countries, and at last we dare to admit it and there is movement.  The present report by Mrs Berès and the others shows more than movement. It also gives direction and also deals with the steps that need to be taken to strengthen the architecture of the euro area. For example, the idea that fiscal policy is important for stabilisation and convergence, including for the fight against unemployment, is central.  Finally, a note. The countries have transferred sovereignty, but with the introduction of the euro, with a stronger democratic eurozone, sovereignty is reclaimed, not for a country in itself but for all of us.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Mr President, there seems to be a broad consensus on the need to strengthen the EMU’s democratic legitimacy. This democratic legitimacy could get a boost from the accountability coming from better—orchestrated cooperation between the European Parliament and the national parliaments. However, this need for accountability comes also from the fact that several intergovernmental arrangements were created during the crisis, and there is a commitment to incorporating them into the legal framework of the European Union, to which Elmar Brok alluded. We will have to look beyond what is in the Berès report, and the five Presidents’ report reminds us, in particular, that the fiscal compact will have to be incorporated into Union law, and that a Treaty change will be required for some of the provisions. It seems to be the case, with regard to the Member States’ obligations, that they provide for a balanced budget golden rule of a binding and permanent character. This is also the case for reverse qualified majority voting and the excessive deficit procedure, and for formalising the euro summits. I believe that this type of accountability cannot come through the back door in Treaty-stretching exercises.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D). Mr President, my congratulations to the rapporteur on the difficult effort she has made and I am sure she has worked very hard because it is a text with many compromises.  So it is a question of some common rules. In the text there are some very positive elements, which leave us satisfied, such as enhanced mechanisms of democratic accountability, such as the social dimension of the European economy. But there is also a great deal that does not leave us satisfied and because, today here, I have heard too many of my colleagues talk about rules that had to be applied and must be applied, I will talk to you for the rest of my time, about rules that have not been applied and let us be honest.  Was the way the deposit haircut was implemented in Cyprus in 2013 impartial? Was the way in which the restructuring of Greece's public debt was implemented to rescue some of the big banks in Germany and France? And finally, is it impartial that we do not have a common, pan-European deposit guarantee scheme?

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we must not create a dichotomy: because when we talk about economic governance, when we talk about financial policy and rehabilitation, we are talking about one pillar, but we also have the other pillar, which is the pillar of the real economy, growth and competitiveness, and we must not necessarily contradict them.  On the contrary, I believe that when we support the real economy, we also help economic and financial recovery, because clearly an economy that is good gets more money into the coffers, makes the citizens feel good, but also goes to reduce debt, rebalances imbalances.  So we are talking about flexibility, and I am pleased about that, Commissioner Katainen has also spoken about it so much. I would like to point out that flexibility has already been applied by our Vice-President Tajani, when it was precisely with regard to the Public Administration Payments Directive that he succeeded with Rehn in putting this flexibility into play, just as he put the target of 20% to 2020 with regard to the GDP generated by the real economy. Let's talk about the real economy. We are talking about a Europe that is closer to its citizens. A Europe that is close to the real economy is a Europe that is closer to its citizens and that is better understood.

name: Olle LUDVIGSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The development of EMU needs to have a clearer focus on creating a better and functioning labour market. This is a key key to building stable public finances and a stable monetary union. Social dumping must be stopped. Everyone wins on fair terms and fair competition. Active labour market policies need to be stepped up. The match is too poor in many places today. Health and safety at work needs to be upgraded. In this area, too little has happened in the last year. In this, the social partners must be given a central role. Their rights and independence must be respected. They must be more actively involved – at both national and European level – at all stages of the European Semester.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, having listened to this debate, it is striking that so very many in this Chamber believe that you can solve the problem of a deficit crisis and the debt crisis by increasing the deficits and the debts. If we look around, in reality it is very easy to see that, where you have allowed the deficits to increase, you have undermined employment, growth and investment. This is the true reality, and still some here believe that you have to finance investments with the money you do not have, instead of having budgets applied using the money you do have. I say this because the rules we possess have value and credibility if we follow them, and if we follow them we will allow for the investments and the growth we need. That is why this report is good: it means that we can follow the rules that we have agreed upon. That makes the European Union strong.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). Mr President, strengthening economic governance is necessary to address the imbalance within the euro area, to increase stability and competitiveness.  It is the lack of stability that is currently undermining my country, Greece, and that is why it is necessary in the next few hours for white smoke to come to an agreement.  It is also necessary for creditors to make a gesture of goodwill and bring back to the table the November 2012 commitment to settle greek debt servicing.  It is also necessary to look at the recipe of the next day. The Greek government cannot raise taxes and limit structural changes. It is necessary not to put Greece back into the cycle of recession, because this will have an impact on the entire economic governance of the euro area.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Mr President, I have heard many critical voices in this debate and I would like to point out that the merit of this report and the presidents' report is that it gives us the opportunity to open a debate on the reforms that our economic and monetary organisation needs. This is the value of this report. It's not perfect, obviously. It's a necessary pact. It is an opportunity to be able to work on the necessary reforms in the fiscal union, in social union, in labour mobility, in political organization, in the political reforms that have to be made in the Treaty, including for better governance. It's very easy to say no. I understand many of those who say no, but today I want to vindicate the importance of the pact, the importance of agreeing. Because Europe, in large part, is done like this: agreeing and addressing problems as we are going to do this afternoon.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, while we are discussing the future of Economic and Monetary Union, the troika continues to suffocate credit towards Greece. It is pushing for continued austerity, violent fiscal adjustment and a reduction in public funds and the public investment programme. And all this to pay the lenders.  Mr Katainen, the memorandum failed in Greece. Government debt of one hundred and twenty-seven per cent of GDP reached one hundred and eighty per cent of GDP. The troika has given loans of two hundred and fourteen billion euros to Greece in the last five years. And yet we have one and a half million unemployed people in Greece. So where did the money go, Mr Katainen? Because if they had been invested in Greece, then the economy would have taken off and we would not have armies of unemployed people.  So in order to relieve Greece and stop the humanitarian crisis, the memoranda must be abolished, the troika must leave Greece, the shameful debt must be erased, the eurozone must learn to respect the democratic will of the Greek people who in the elections of 25 January decided to throw the troika out of Greece.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, it is certain that more Europe is not the solution for everyone, but more Europe when it comes to monetary union is certainly a good solution. More Europe when it comes to the Energy Union is surely a good solution. More Europe when it comes to the digital union is also a surely good solution.  That is why we need an ambitious report and that is why our Club will not support this report because we believe that we need stronger and faster reforms, we believe that with these reforms there should be clear rules, because without clear rules that everyone will stick to there is no common Europe and no common success, and only joint success will guarantee the satisfaction of our citizens. However we are spoken to here and whatever we are calling for here, I am sure that more Europe in the cases I have cited can only help the betterment of our citizens living in the European Union.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, so-called economic governance leads to the de facto imposition of a state of emergency not foreseen by the European Treaties. European institutions behave as if the rules on excessive budget deficits take precedence over rules that guarantee fundamental and, in particular, social rights. However, the European institutions themselves undermine the basis of the European Union, namely respect for people's fundamental rights.  At a time when millions of people in Greece, but also in other European states, are hungry or unable to secure heating for their homes in winter, the Frankfurt stock exchange records one historical record after another. At the same time, the Commission is blackmailing the Greek government into abolishing the meager heating allowance for the poor.  If Europe does not change course, if it is not fortified through social redistribution from the economically strongest to the weakest - and not the other way around as it is today - it risks collapsing. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Elmar BROK
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I have listened to this a few times now. We are prepared by a large majority to help Greece. Do you not think, however, that you should start the reform processes there now, so that your country, such as Spain, Portugal and Ireland, becomes competitive, so that the money that others give you can lead to growth in you? Or do you think you don't have to do anything about it, and it's already going to work when the others give their money?

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" answer. Mr President, of course we are ready for reforms and the great reform, the real reform, is the fight against tax evasion. But this requires time and help from the other European states in order to be able to organise ourselves.  Instead, the Commission is demanding, like the European Central Bank, so-called reforms which lead to the further violent poverty of people who are already on the verge of survival or even below them. This is not reform. This is a violation of the European Treaties.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for this very lively debate. As you certainly understand, it is not possible to comment on or address all the ideas which were raised during this very good debate. I just want to assert that the Commission is fully committed to implementing the current surveillance framework and to further improving it and building a deep and strong architecture for the EMU. To do that, we are committed to cooperating with Parliament and the Council, and we are ready to translate the conclusions that will come from the debates on the five Presidents’ report on completing the EMU into practical steps. The strategy for jobs and growth presented in the AGS remains valid – fiscal responsibility, investment and structural reforms. We have taken important steps towards implementing it, for instance the investment plan and STB flexibility. We now call for all stakeholders, Member States and institutions to do their part to implement this strategy. We recall the importance of structural reforms for growth and the responsibility of Member States in this regard. Honourable Members, Mr President, I thank you very much for this debate. We have to continue this debate, because the five Presidents’ report has just presented a good basis for further work. Before adopting any official lines, we need very lively discussions to try to find the best way while showing solidarity and underlining the need for national responsibility.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, if it were necessary to demonstrate the difficulty and tensions surrounding this issue, I think this debate illustrated it well. But I want to draw the attention of my colleagues to what we have been able to say in this report, because in some speeches I have not read the same thing.  It is not true that this report does not concern itself with the social dimension of economic and monetary union. It is not true that this report does not concern the situation of the unemployed and those who do not have a job in Europe today. It is not true that this report does not say anything about the urgency, in terms of smarter investments and structural reforms. It is not true that this report does not say anything about reforming the rules of economic governance. This report explicitly states that the rules of economic governance will need to be completed, amended and corrected.  It is now up to us to convince the Council and the Commission to move. Of course, more debates are needed, but we must also act and, in this direction towards reforming economic and monetary governance, it seems to me that this European Parliament can now give a signal: there is a possible majority between the right and the left to move forward on the basis of the proposals which I hope will be supported by this House in a moment.  Finally, as everyone knows, this negotiation has been very difficult, but I want, with courtesy and respect, to thank the contributions of each of the shadow rapporteurs and the negotiating team, even though I can see that at the end of this long and common history, we do not share the same assessment of all the work done.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: . – I close the debate. The vote will take place today, in half an hour. Written declarations (Article 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Compliance with the rules of economic governance is a duty for euro area Member States. Let us stop asking ourselves whether we need more or less flexibility. The rules of the Stability and Growth Pact provide for flexibility. It also leaves a considerable room for investment. To demand more flexibility is to give false hope to European citizens. Let us not hide behind this false debate on flexibility and address the real issue: the urgent need to converge our fiscal and social policies. We have created a borderless single market in which people, goods and capital move freely. We have also created a single currency that has put an end to monetary competition. These are not sustainable without harmonizing national social and fiscal policies. On the one hand, we want fair tax competition and on the other we do not want to bring national tax policies together. We want to end social dumping, but we do not want social coordination. This is economic and political nonsense. Member States must understand that their interest is not in ever more competition between them, but in more cohesion.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. – The economic dynamics and complexity of their governance are, as is evident in the text before us, in the budgetary phase by each institutional operator. This verification cannot overlook the ambitious targets not yet on the horizon. European monetary union is in fact at the centre of a ford: so much has been achieved for the correction of macroeconomic imbalances, much more needs to be done to strengthen governance, coordinate economic policies and make effective use of the Stability and Growth Pact.  It is not allowed to underestimate the consequences of Greece's economic fragility and the risk of global depression that its default would entail, now that the ECB has once again raised the emergency liquidity provided to Greek institutions and that, at this time, the issue of debt and the new Greek proposals is under consideration. This episode is teaching us. Macroeconomic imbalances must be prevented, first and foremost by strengthening governance and by addressing, with a holistic and truly pro-European method, the growing divergences between the economies of the euro area.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. – I welcome the Beres report on the review of the economic governance framework. The recent crisis in Greece demonstrates that it is high time we reform this framework. This report acknowledges the need to address the lack of investment and the long-lasting low inflation situation within the euro area, and to improve the current economic framework. Furthermore, it stresses the need to make better use of flexibility within the Stability and Growth Pact, insisting on the added value of flexibility to bridge the investment gap and ensure better implementation of the rules regarding growth. It further underlines that macroeconomic imbalances need to be tackled and the role of national parliaments and the European Parliament needs to be strengthened.
