Finally, I believe we should reinforce the Five Presidents Report on the future of the economic union in the coming months in order to make the economic governance structure in the euro area more effective.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – The Stability and Growth Pact is an important instrument for ensuring fiscal discipline in the Member States, and for its credibility it is necessary that the application of the rules in the Member States is transparent, fair, timely and based on proper economic analysis.  In light of the recently presented report on the completion of the Economic and Monetary Union, it should be noted that the increasing interdequity of eurozone Member States, particularly visible in times of crises, requires a more efficient and fair institutional system, which on the one hand will ensure solidarity, but at the same time adhere to common agreed rules.  Furthermore, the European Semester significantly strengthened economic policy coordination. However, I consider it necessary to pay sufficient attention to the recommendations to individual Member States as well as to compliance with the rules, otherwise the credibility and sustainability of the fiscal policy framework, which has been significantly improved by the adoption of the six-pack package of legislation, is at risk. We have set ambitious targets for the coming period, and to achieve them, it is more than clear that we need clear guidance and even clearer political will.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. – The recent economic crisis has clearly demonstrated that the current economic governance framework in the European Union is not optimal. One cannot ignore the fact that the Euro area is unable to meet its objectives and ensure sustainable growth, high employment, social progress and stability. Similarly, we must not ignore the serious economic inequality between Member States, manifested by varying levels of economic growth, unemployment rates or current account balance of payments values. It is unimaginable that we should wait for the next crisis and delay steps to reform the current ineffective system. Member States' heads of state cannot close their eyes to this problem and must start to consider a long-term solution. We need a stronger economic and fiscal union based on democratic principles. In this context, I would like to stress that it is very important to stimulate debate not only at the top level of the European Union. National parliaments, as well as other stakeholders, need to be invited to discuss reform of the current system. Moreover, the debate must also be open to non-euro area countries. Under the Treaty of Lisbon, all member states of the European Union are to enter the euro area, with exceptions. The time is right to turn the current system into a model that is more democratic, transparent and much simpler. Unless fundamental reform is made, the Union will never become what it has set out to do, with competitive, solidarity-based, sustainable and democratic groupings.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. –  An essential problem of the Eurozone has become the increasing economic divergence between its different parts (north vs. south and so on). The benchmarks that are being used to stabilise and run the system – which are fully endorsed in this resolution – attack only the symptoms but not the economic fundamentals that are producing this result. Indeed, the discipline being followed on the basis of the set benchmarks might be contributing further to the divergences. Partial deepening of the existing arrangements could actually serve to further widen the divergences even within a steady state, stabilised context for the Eurozone as a whole. The report emphasizes the coordination of economic policies of Member States rather than a convergence of economic performance and outcomes. It supports the partial deepening of Eurozone structures without making this dependent on progress in efforts to achieve greater economic convergence. It proposes to harmonise tax structures when this will further serve to reduce the flexibility of those economies which, in order to boost their competitiveness and performance, given their limited endowments, will need to differentiate their tax profiles, naturally under conditions of full transparency. For these reasons, I cannot therefore support the report.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. – Seven years after the start of the global financial and economic crisis, many Member States are still facing recession, low inflation and high unemployment. According to Eurostat, in June this year the unemployment rate in the euro area was 11.1% and the inflation rate in May was 0.3%. In order to overcome these challenges, the European Union has established an economic governance framework based on enhanced economic planning through closer supervision by the EU, safeguarding the stability of the euro area and measures to rebuild the financial sector. I am surprised that the report on the review of the economic governance framework considers the current framework and the policies resulting there from it to be appropriate. In the future, the framework should only need a few amendments, but only after the existing requirements of the economic governance framework have been properly implemented by the Member States. Unfortunately, however, the report underscores some of the important positions adopted by Parliament in this area in the past, such as the requirement to adopt convergence guidelines under the codecision procedure to better coordinate economic policies and place greater emphasis on the social aspect of EMU, while completely bypassing some important aspects, such as the demand for a more democratic EMU and a more ambitious European tax policy and the promotion of investment with long-term positive effects on society and the environment.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I continue to wonder if the magic will work and bring out this 300 billion euros. Worse still, I can only understand that in one of the paragraphs some rejoice in the 2packs and 6 packs! Therefore, I cannot accept the text.  However, I must highlight the work done by the ECON Committee, in particular by my colleagues Berès and Bayet. The progress made between the final text and the initial announcement of the stimulus package should be highlighted. I am pleased that the social sector, education and health are finally among the possible areas of intervention. In addition, the Juncker plan will primarily benefit SMEs, the main source of economic recovery in many EU countries, including Belgium, and promote regional participation. In this regard, I agree with the aforementioned colleagues of the group that the public guarantee for private investment must have the imperative of creating growth and jobs. The Fund's tracking scoreboard, another significant improvement, will be crucial in this regard in assessing job creation, the impact on growth, the volume of private investment and respect for leverage.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is Question Time to the Council and the Commission. The theme is the transparent application of the Stability and Growth Pact (2015/2731 (RSP)).

name: Sander LOONES
text: Author. – The Stability and Growth Pact is one of the foundations of economic and monetary union. Unfortunately, several Member States have not complied with the rules. Yet no real sanction was ever handed out. We have built the euro on too weak foundations.  1. Not only this week, but actually for the last five years, European politicians have been gritling their teeth on the Greek crisis. The Greek crisis affecting not only Greek citizens, but all citizens in Europe. It is our democratic duty to expose all causes and responsibilities and to learn lessons. We need to find out what's happened in the last few years, what interests who have served. We do not need yet another non-committal resolution or report. We do need a thorough investigation, which mentions man and horse.  2. How can we ensure that the agreements on the budget and on the national debt are finally respected? If we want to strengthen European and monetary union, we must start from the grassroots. There is no point in building on shaky foundations, so the budgetary rules must finally be applied transparently, consistently and rigorously, and so we must also determine how we can develop a system with more independent controls and more automatic sanctions. How can we strengthen the foundations of the currency union? That's the question. I am very curious about the answers from the European Commission and the Council.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In 2011, the Stability and Growth Pact was significantly strengthened. The European Parliament and the European Commission have achieved collectively that the Member States can no longer decide on their own. Now that the Commission has more rights, we must be able to rely on the Commission to take it correctly. The lessons of the sovereign debt crisis show that proper compliance with the rules of economic and monetary union is vital. The crisis was a shot at the bow, and we absolutely have to learn from it. The Commission has a particularly high level of responsibility. We want to remind the Commission of this responsibility today. The rules of the Stability and Growth Pact must apply equally to all Member States. There is no big thing, and there is no small thing when it comes to debt levels and deficits. Numbers are numbers. They remain so, even if you turn them upside down. We do not accept that economic analyses should be misappropriated or reinterpreted as they see fit. We want to make a comprehensive publication of the assessments that the Commission and the Council are making to the Member States. We want an independent chief economic analyst whose analysis we can read. We want the analyses to be carried out equally independently for all Member States. We therefore appeal to the Commission to do justice to your role as a neutral auditor. It is about nothing less than the credibility of the Stability and Growth Pact and, therefore, about the foundation and sustainability of our economic and monetary union.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Author. – Madam President, my group is also very interested in knowing exactly what the criteria are for the implementation of the Stability Pact and transparency measures. Obviously, there's a problem here. I know that there are many groups that are raising this question because they want a much stricter application of the rules of the Covenant; But you know what's going on? the problem is that, in many circumstances, the rules go against one's own objectives and are often unfulfillable. I therefore believe that there is also a whole reflection here to make on the extent to which the flexibility incorporated by the Stability and Growth Pact itself is sufficient or not, because, in recent years, what has happened is that flexibility has simply been used to be able to legalize de facto situations; that is, when a state no longer complied with the rules, flexibility allowed that legal vacuum to be filled. But of course that is not done for that and, in any event, obviously with the Commission's Flexibility Notice, we hope that this can improve. For us, equally and obviously, the rules must be clear. The Commission must explain exactly how it applies these criteria and, therefore, we are also interested in asking it some questions, for example what methodology is used to develop its economic analyses within the framework of the Covenant itself. That's a very important issue. And, if the Commission can explain, too, its choice between a downward or an upward economic analysis when assessing the reform efforts of the Member States. We'd like to know, too. Third question: what kind of analysis has served as the basis for the Council's recommendations since the entry into force of the six-pack governance package. Also let them clear that up for us. And finally, my last question — and with this I conclude — when the Commission will make public its legal opinion on the coherence of Communication 12/2015 with the provisions of the Stability and Growth Pact, in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001 on public access to documents, which is a repeated issue in many debates and which we also think is important.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start with a premise and an analysis which, although it is not mine, I fully agree with.  In December, I gave all my colleagues a short but well-considered essay in which a university professor and former Italian minister, Professor Guarino, listed many reasons and causes of the current crisis in Europe. One of these causes lies precisely in the adoption of the Stability and Growth Pact which, in fact, imposes absurd budgetary constraints on the Member States and clashes with the growth objectives laid down in the European Treaties.  This regulation sets as a medium-term objective for the Member States a budgetary situation involving a balance close to balance or in surplus. In practice, the possibility of indebtedness has been removed, which in crisis situations such as today's is the only viable option.  The Stability and Growth Pact, followed by its revision, six-pack and two-pack, ending with the fiscal compact, denied the possibility of growth and development for the Member States, with the sole objective of balancing the budget, which alone is by no means a guarantee of growth and development. All this, in addition, in complete contradiction to the provisions of the European Treaties, the maximum source of EU law, which clearly indicate the possibility for a state to be able to borrow for growth purposes within the limits provided for by the excessive deficit procedure.  I would therefore like to ask the Commission how it interprets this blatant contradiction and whether it intends to take any action to resolve this issue. What I understand very clearly, however, is that the rules can be interpreted according to the interests on the ground or the political will, because when these European rules were violated by France or Germany, they gladly turned a blind eye, if not two, as continues to be the case with the problem of overrunning Germany's trade surplus on GDP.  Unfortunately, the European Union is always weak with the strong and strong with the weak.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: Author. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the flexibility that the European Commission has been using in the implementation of the Stability and Growth Pact is not, contrary to what many want to suggest, a covert change in the rules of economic governance. On the contrary, this flexibility has long been inscribed in the rules, with the difference that the previous Commission, for ideological reasons, I think, never wanted to apply it. That is why the European Socialists fully support this Commission decision to adapt the Pact to the specific conditions of each country, avoiding the procyclical policies that have greatly contributed to the economic and social disaster in Europe in recent years.  The Berès report, which we have just discussed and prepared to vote on, confirms this greater transparency and clarity in the application of the current rules, in particular in terms of specifying and clarifying the scope of the investment clause and evaluating structural reforms.  In this context and with the aim of increasing transparency, the Socialist Group would like the Commission to clarify a number of points. First, what methodology does the Commission use to assess, when analysing the budgetary position of the Member States, the high put gap, the structural budget balance and the estimated potential gdp growth? Secondly, in the implementation of the Stability Pact, what methodology does the European Commission use to calculate the costs and added value of structural reforms? Thirdly, in the implementation of the Stability Pact, how does the European Commission estimate, how does it also estimate the impact of its recommendations on the process of convergence between Member States? I appreciate the answers.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Author. – Madam President, the Stability and Growth Pact, the famous SGP, was not enough for it to be absolutely devastating for the economy and for the well-being of citizens, it still had to be decided and imposed in an absolutely opaque, non-transparent and undemocratic way. Where the PEC was applied, what we saw was the debt increase. That was the general rule.  I would like to ask the Commission why there are any lessons they have learned or will once again make up arguments against facts. Secondly, is the Commission available to shift the focus, to recognise that austerity has completely failed and to stop using debt as an excuse, ignoring that in some cases, even in cases where adjustment programmes such as Ireland have been implemented, for example, it was not public debt but private debt that was at the root of the problem? In the SGP review, is the Commission available to start monitoring surpluses as well?  I must confess that I am absolutely outraged by the Commission's lack of rigour in applying the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact itself against excessive surpluses when it is then very strict in monitoring and punishing excessive deficits. Will the Commission continue to have double standards, turn a blind eye to rich countries that are in breach of the SGP and commit itself to punishing countries in difficulty, or will it finally remove sanctions that are absolutely unacceptable from the SGP? And the proof is that countries with surpluses in violation of the SGP have never accepted these sanctions. If the sanctions were not stupid, countries with surpluses would accept them.  So what I want to know is whether the Commission is also available to finally consider, as anyone of common sense considers, that investment is not the same as expenditure and that countries, like any company, cannot be accounted for in the same way, nor therefore be included in the deficit figures.

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner, I thank you for being here to address this delicate issue of the interpretation of the Stability and Growth Pact. These are complex texts. One of the reasons we asked this question is that, during the previous Commission's mandate, we had been fighting with Commissioner Olli Rehn to ensure that there would be a fair implementation of the Stability Pact and that the rules would be the same for everyone. Do you not believe that when the Commission accepts that reforms are announced and not implemented, we are embarking on a field where it is not at all certain that fairness between Member States is respected?

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent Commissioner, i would like to begin by thanking the Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. First of all, thank you for inviting me to speak on this important issue: transparency in the application of the Stability and Growth Pact.  The Stability and Growth Pact is essential for the functioning of the European Union. It forms a rules-based framework that promotes sound budgetary policies and the sustainability of public finances throughout the European Union. When assessing member states' budgets, these rules leave the European Commission and the Council sufficient discretion and the possibility to take account of the specific circumstances of each country, so that safe, independent and reliable assessments of the economic situation are essential for the functioning of the system. These important aspects are also mentioned in the report on economic governance by The Member, Mr Berès, who was discussed a short time ago.  In this context, I would like to highlight the significant improvements that have been made in economic policy coordination in recent years. I think it is safe to say that the new institutional framework set out in the Pact strengthens the Commission's role and right of initiative. The new rules also increase member states' accountability and transparency of processes. All process-related documents are publicly available on the European Commission's website, and the new approach also allows for a more robust and comprehensive assessment of the various possible economic factors in the Member States and in the European Union as a whole. The Council bases its discussions on an independent analysis of the economic situation prepared by the European Commission, for example in staff working documents and forecasts. We also use information provided by the Member States concerned in the Council, in particular on new or additional discretionary policy measures, if it implements such measures. The positions of the Member States are then discussed and, ultimately, an agreement is reached with a view to ensuring the necessary result, a stable and sustainable fiscal position. The same approach was also followed in assessing the situation and deciding on the application of the excessive budgetary procedure to France. Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. This year's economic policy coordination cycle, or three priorities of the European Semester, is, firstly, to encourage investment, secondly, to implement structural reforms and, thirdly, to develop responsible fiscal policies. In other words, although the importance of fiscal accountability is invaluable, it is nevertheless only one of the necessary elements. The importance of structural reforms and investments, alongside responsible fiscal policies, is also underlined in the Commission Communication on the application of the principle of flexibility in the Stability and Growth Pact.  The Council has exchanged views on this communication and found a common demper to make use of the flexibility provided for in the existing rules. The Council continues its work towards a common understanding of the application of the principle of flexibility. Finally, I would like to say a few words about the role of the Stability and Growth Pact in the wider context, its role in improving Europe's economic and monetary union. On 24 October 2014, the European Summit set the task of preparing the next steps for better economic governance in the euro area, and an early report by five presidents on the development of Europe's economic and monetary union was published on 22 June this year. It offers a gradual approach to strengthening Europe's economic and monetary union in the short term and to improving the long-term structure of European economic and monetary union. Tomorrow's European Council provides for the first exchange of views on the five Presidents' report, and the Council is ready to work constructively on the issues outlined in the report in all the appropriate formats.  As I said in today's debate on preparations for the European Council, it is essential to make every effort to promote convergence, because the differences currently existing between the Member States of the euro area may jeopardise the future of the Union as a whole. We are ready to work constructively to implement the proposals contained in the report, and the Guidelines of the European Council will play an important role in this process.  Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. I sincerely believe that we will be able to achieve a common vision of the future of Europe's economic and monetary union and will also be able to implement it. Thanks for the attention!

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, the Commission shares Parliament’s concern about transparency and the implementation of budgetary surveillance and agrees on the need for scrutiny on the part of the main stakeholders and of the public in general. Certainly things can be improved upon. But let me start by illustrating what is already in place. I will start by talking about transparency and then move to the scrutiny part. As you know, the work of budgetary surveillance by the Commission is based on its economic and fiscal forecasts. The Commission provides and publishes regular country-specific AA, EA and EU-level analysis of the economic perspectives. In addition the Commission produces, once a year, country reports that contain a comprehensive analysis of the economic situation, including in-depth reviews under the Macroeconomic Imbalances Procedure, where relevant, and an assessment of the main challenges. Concerning, in particular, fiscal surveillance, the assessments of the Commission are accompanied by detailed technical analysis prepared by the services, which are also made public. All the relevant results and documents are publicly available on the Commission’s website. Thus, all the elements needed to perform the Commission’s analysis and calculations are publicly available. We can certainly further improve and facilitate access to this amount of information, and I thank you for having brought the issue to our attention. In this connection I am glad to announce that we are planning a new version of a public Commission staff document on the rules of the Stability and Growth Package, the so-called Vademecum. In this document we will clarify even more the methodology that we use to assess whether the Member States, under the excessive deficit procedure, have taken the action required by the Council. This is the technical component of the analysis, which has then to be validated by the College. At the moment, all results and methodologies, including detailed information, top-down and bottom-up approaches, can be found in the relevant documents available on the Commission’s website. But we are aware of the need for further clarification and we will act decisively in this sense. When we are looking at Commission decision-making, the judgements and decisions taken by the College are certainly political, but they are based on independent analysis of the relevant facts and the applicable rules. In this respect the Commission cannot change the 3% deficit rule and the 60% debt rule of the Stability and Growth Pact, which are enshrined in the Treaty, of which the Commission remains the guardian. The Commission document on Flexibility is just an interpretative communication which provides additional guidance for the implementation of the Stability and Growth Pact, without ordering the rules themselves. Indeed, due to the complexity of the facts to be determined and of the economic analysis to be performed, the SGP provisions leave a substantial margin of appreciation to the Commission and to the Council. With the aim of providing transparency and predictability, it is therefore in the Commission’s remit to provide further interpretation of the Stability and Growth Pact provisions without changing or replacing them. Rules for sound public finances, of which the Stability and Growth Pact is an expression, are necessary for the existence of the monetary union and, more in general, for sustainable growth. They are even more important now that growth is coming back and we need to avoid repeating past errors. The Commission improved the surveillance cycle by presenting the economic analysis in country reports three months earlier than in the past. The Commission is also currently engaging in a dialogue with the European Parliament and the Council in the context of the so-called two- and six-pack review, and five presidents, including the European Parliament President, are discussing the future of EMU, including its governance mechanism. Honourable Members, as a conclusion, the Commission is committed to improving the surveillance framework. Our desire is to take this way all together.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the Stability and Growth Pact is an important instrument for ensuring fiscal discipline in the Member States. However, this whole discussion this evening demonstrates that neither Members of this House, nor the Member States in particular, are very happy with its application. I am very happy to hear Commissioner Katainen promise to improve the transparency and efficiency of the Stability and Growth Pact. One way, or one avenue, to improve the situation would perhaps be to consider adding to the existing main measure of fiscal discipline – which is, of course, the deficit – some other measures, such as for instance debt-to-GDP ratio. The deficit measure, be it in the form of a headline deficit or a structural deficit, suffers from important weaknesses. One of them is that the deficit gives us a short-term picture of the budgetary situation and actually is not a good measure of long-term sustainability in terms of fiscal policy. The other thing is that the deficit is very much dependent on cyclical factors, ad hoc measures and also discretionary policy measures taken by individual governments. The structural deficit is mostly a variable which is not directly observable and is also dependent on the potential output, which is again a concept that is difficult to measure and difficult to present in a convincing way. So maybe one possibility of improving the situation would be simply to shift to the debt-to-GDP ratio. This would give you at least a long-term measure of fiscal sustainability.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am somewhat astonished to have heard the speeches of the previous speakers, because from which the attitude seems to speak as if there are objective methods, as if economic analysis is something like exact science, where one can measure clearly and unambiguously. Ladies and gentlemen, that is simply not the case! I am speaking here as a former professor of economics: there is always a lot of discretion, a lot of different assumptions that can be based on the analyses, a lot of different numerical values that can be put into the calibration, very many different methods that are not a priori right or wrong. To assume that this can increase transparency is simply a fundamentally wrong approach. The application of the Stability and Growth Pact will always be opaque – we must face this up. The Stability and Growth Pact is simply non-transparent in the formulae in which it currently exists. The only way to arrive at rules that are easier to understand would be to return to its basic elements, to the basic elements of the Maastricht Treaty, namely the non-assistance clause.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Stability and Growth Pact is a real failure and should be renamed the Pact of Instability and Decline. Instability, because it has the effect, through the austerity policies implemented, of worsening the debt of the Member States, a debt which it is supposed to fight. Decrease, as it suffocates the economies of the Member States, thus preventing any resumption of economic activity. That is why the recommendations on transparency in the implementation of the Stability Pact will not change anything. The example of Greece showed us that. This pact is flawed in principle, because it is based on two erroneous assumptions. First, to think that economic recovery would depend exclusively on austerity policies. Secondly, the belief that these policies could be applied indiscriminately to the 28 Member States.  Rather than locking our nations into inept fiscal, monetary and accounting rules, the 28 Member States should be given a breathless space and sovereignty to see a credible exit scenario.  The return of growth in Europe will depend mainly on a radical change in economic and fiscal policies based on the... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Madam President, the Ecofin implements the Stability and Growth Pact by double standards. When it comes to Germany and France he turn a blind eye, gives forgiveness and tolerates violations of the rules. When it comes to small countries, such as Greece, then Ecofin imposes harsh austerity and violent fiscal adjustment measures that make people poor. Greece for five years has been under the suffocating control and supervision of the troika, which has become a mad dog of the Eurogroup and Ecofin. The Stability and Growth Pact is an undemocratic tool that imposes total control over the democratic functioning of the Member States.  In order for Greece to be exempted from enhanced financial supervision, it must include in its state budget Germany's debts to Greece, i.e. war reparations and forced occupation loans, arrears and interest payments amounting to one hundred and sixty-two billion euros plus interest. Because Greece is the lender and Germany is the debtor!

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I feel that I am at the bar rather than in an ASSEMBLY of the European Union.  I wanted to say, Mr President, despite this constant rumour, I wanted to say to Commissioner Katainen that if he worked in a private company he would already be dismissed, given the results he, Juncker but also, widening the scope a little, by Mogherini, even if it had nothing to do with this speech. The United States has developed its economy by trying to put in place fewer rules and give more opportunities for development. Europe is doing the exact opposite: my son, who is twelve years old, would also understand that perhaps we should do as the United States does and not as Europe does. We are a political and economic dwarf and we only favour multinationals.  Then I would say that the only stability pact that Europe could make is the Stability Pact for illegal immigrants. If we were to put 3% for illegal immigrants, we would probably have solved part of the problem, because this is a Europe that is not capable of solving anything.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for this very lively discussion. We heard all the different opinions from the latest speaker, who said basically that there should not be any rules in the economy, and then we heard somebody who said that our rules have been too loose and should be strengthened, or the rules should be a bit more strict. But the topic of the day was transparency of the application of the Stability and Growth Pact. This is a very important topic. Many people have said that the rules have not been transparent enough, and lots of questions have been raised about whether the interpretation of the rules is right. Some have been saying that the Commission’s interpretation has been too loose and we should have been stricter, and someone has said that we have been too strict and it should be been looser. That is why we have to pay attention to transparency, because everybody should understand what the rules mean. If there is a lack of clarity about what the rules mean, then the rules are under criticism from different directions. Of course, now, when we are concentrating on the Five Presidents’ report, we can also assess how to further develop our rule base. I would, as a personal opinion, say that most of it should concentrate on implementation of our rules. As I said earlier, the Commission has interpreted the current Stability and Growth Pact in a very flexible way, but one whereby we can still say clearly that we have stayed within the Stability and Growth Pact. One of the issues to which we have not paid that much attention in the past is the structural side of our economy. It is not only about deficit or debt level, but it is also about strengths or weaknesses of our structures. So I would like to turn our focus more to the structural side of our economies, because, when looking at the countries in trouble, their problems have been much more structural in nature than cyclical. That is why the Stability and Growth Pact should be seen as an entity, not only as a framework of rules which look at whether the deficit is 0.2% higher or lower; it also should focus more on the structural side of our economy. Madam President, I want to thank everyone once more for a very lively and very good discussion. I think this will not be the last time we will talk about the Stability and Growth Pact – and it should not be, because we have to further develop European integration and also our fiscal and structural economic growth.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, i would like to begin by thanking the Rapporteur for her excellent work. Commissioner, i would like to begin by thanking the Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. I thank you for this debate. Firstly, they showed how important it is for all of us to have a stable fiscal situation throughout the European Union, to ensure that conditions are sustainable and that contribute to the implementation of the Union's programme for jobs and growth.  After years of stagnation, Europe is in desperate need of growth and this can be ensured by the simultaneous implementation of all three priorities: fiscal responsibility, just as investments and structural reforms.  I cannot share the view that the Stability and Growth Pact has failed. The report by the five presidents, which we have already mentioned many times today, also confirms the importance of fiscal responsibility and financial sustainability and the central role of the Stability and Growth Pact in ensuring market credibility.  In the long term, this provides for the possibility of redistribution of public finance risks, but in order to achieve this objective, a number of preconditions must be met: firstly, significant economic convergence must be achieved, secondly, financial market integration must be ensured and, thirdly, fiscal rules must be respected. It is equally important that The Member States must express their determination to move towards closer integration.  As a last but not least, precondition, I would like to stress the need to promote and strengthen respect for political responsibility and legitimacy. To achieve all this, we will need closer involvement from national parliaments, the European Parliament and the social partners. This means that we all still have a lot of work to do together.  Honourable Members, i would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. To conclude this debate, which is indeed the last debate of the Latvian Presidency in the European Parliament, I would like to express my great gratitude for our very productive cooperation, for all the discussions that we have held here and for all the decisions that we have been able to take for the future of the European Union and for the benefit of our citizens. Thank you very much!

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. –  I am glad to note that the United Kingdom is outside the Eurozone; indeed, the phrase ‘there but for the grace of God go I’ springs to mind. Though it was not so much grace as common sense that caused Britain to remain outside the economic shackles of the euro. I believe in transparency, and any Pact should be applied in a transparent manner. But the project itself is fundamentally flawed, as a string of nations have found to their cost.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Stability and Growth Pact is an important instrument to guarantee fiscal discipline in the Member States. In 2011, thanks to the hard work of the European Parliament and the European Commission, the Pact was significantly deepened. At that time, the Commission took on a particularly high responsibility and now is the time to remind it of this. The Commission must play the role of an independent budgetary controller in order for our Economic and Monetary Union to be credible in the future. Ensuring the stability and sustainability of the European economic system is necessary and immediate in order to re-enter the path of growth and jobs. The rules of the Stability Pact should apply in all countries in the same way. An independent economic assessment must be carried out transparently and efficiently, and I am therefore pleased with the assurances given by Commissioner Katainen. We need to ensure a responsible fiscal policy and bring about convergence of our financial markets. It is also important to strengthen political legitimacy, which is why Parliament should show greater commitment. What methods are used by the European Commission to analyse the economic framework? What methodology does the Commission intend to use to assess the budgetary position of a Member State and the structural budget surplus and to estimate potential GDP growth? These questions should be answered first by the European Commission.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. We have called for the flexibility of budgetary rules loudly from the very beginning of our mandate. This is a subject that is close to the hearts of many of us and our governments, because numbers, decimals and percentages of budget regulations actually mean welfare, pension education. What is a 'zero comma' for Brussels very often means services, assistance and social protection for our citizens. Today's question is how to ensure that the famous 'structural reforms' really represent an opportunity for change and overcoming those backwardness situations that force our citizens to pay for decades of bad policies. We therefore ask the Commission what criteria it uses to evaluate these reforms, not only to avoid the mistakes of the past, but above all to see that long-awaited 'growth', but which at the moment is only the final word of a pact that must bear fruit.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – To achieve credibility of the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP), it is essential to apply its rules across the Member States in a transparent, fair and timely manner.  Admittedly, it is not advisable to resort to a one-size-fits-all approach across the EU when implementing the guidelines of the Pact. However, the Commission has to ensure that the balance between flexibility and the application of rules is maintained. Exceptions must be granted only when based on evident facts and their unbiased interpretation, and political bargaining must be avoided at all costs. We cannot accept political statements as a proof of genuine reform. The economic and monetary union – especially in the light of the Five Presidents Report – should thus avoid introducing further flexibility into the existing system, while focusing on successful implementation of the rules laid out in the Stability and Growth Pact instead. Furthermore, sufficient attention must be paid to the country-specific recommendations provided in the framework of the European Semester.  We need political will and clear guidelines in order to achieve the ambitious objectives we have set ourselves.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – The current crisis, almost two decades after the creation of the single currency, should motivate a serious and dispassionate reflection on the process of creating economic and monetary union, the fiscal treaty and the stability pact.  The euro was created by the great bankers to serve their interests and ensure their dominance over national states and over the sovereignty of peoples. The Stability Pact and economic governance are intended to strengthen this area by preventing the emergence of any alternative development project. The financial crisis of 2007 was thus used to deepen economic governance, i.e. to further strengthen the political stalls with which governments want to impose a single path, which is the way of maximising the profit of banks at the expense of citizens.  The current reality shows that the breaking of the bonds of the euro, the Budgetary Treaty and economic governance represents the first step towards the liberation of peoples and their self-determination in choosing their own development project.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next point is the vote. Request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos (A8-0191/2015) (Laura Ferrara) (vote)

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Mr Zarianopoulos, I would like to inform you that I am aware that you wished to comment in plenary, but according to the relevant rules, namely article 9(8) of the Code, I cannot speak to you. By the way, you have already been heard by the committee and you have had the opportunity to give your opinion on the subject.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Review of the economic governance framework: overview of the situation and challenges (A8-0190/2015) (Pervenche Berès) (vote)

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, on behalf of the ALDE Group, I would like to request that the report of Mrs Berès be referred back to the committee, according to Rule 188 of Parliament’s Rules of Procedure. The debate today and the release of the Five Presidents’ Report on Monday have clearly shown that the report is already outdated with regard to events going on outside this House.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Madam President, I would like to support this request made by the Liberal Group, not only because, as has been said, the Five Presidents' Report makes this report absolutely obsolete (it was to give parliament an answer to governments and not arrive in time, the five presidents arrived first), but above all on a political issue, because the inability to manage the Greek problem is proof that we need to profoundly review the framework of economic governance.  There are areas that are not in the Five Presidents' Report and which should be in this Parliament's economic governance report, which have to do with debt management or the stability mechanism.  So let us do serious work, respect the 500 million citizens we represent in this house and do a real job of reviewing the economic governance package.

name: Ashley FOX
text: – Madam President, my colleague is unable to be here, but on behalf of the ECR Group I would like to say that we do not want this matter postponed. This is a poor report; we should defeat it now.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Sylvie Goulard, on behalf of the ALDE Group, requests that the report be referred back to the Committee on the basis of Article 188(1) of the Rules of Procedure. Parliament rejects the request by electronic vote.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the Commission's statement on the decision adopted on the Action Plan on a fairer EU corporate tax system (2015/2675 (RSP)).

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission adopted its action plan for fairer and more efficient corporate taxation a week ago. That is why I am honoured to come and present to you our initiatives to upgrade corporate taxation in the internal market.  The package adopted in March dealt with tax transparency. Today, our scope of action is broader. We aim to fundamentally reform the corporate tax framework in Europe to make it fairer, more efficient and more conducive to growth and jobs. The inadequacy of EU rules on corporate taxation has made taxation an area for which the single market remains to be built. Today, the juxtaposition of twenty-eight different tax systems is ineffective and counterproductive. Ineffective, because in many cases Member States are not able to collect the tax that should be theirs, which dries up their revenues and affects their stability. Counterproductive because the proliferation, complexity and variety of standards that apply within the internal market often discourage companies from expanding beyond their national borders. We can no longer tolerate some companies, often the most successful, freeing themselves from their fair contribution to tax and that some tax systems encourage them to do so. Corporate taxation in Europe is unfair, because it amounts to a higher tax burden on citizens and other businesses. This is socially unacceptable. More fundamentally, unfair taxation jeopardizes consent to tax. Finally, this situation is contrary to our objectives, because abusive practices and the race for the lowest tax burden undermine pro-growth tax policies and create distortions within the single market. This last point is particularly important to me. Our fight against tax evasion is not a fight against business. On the contrary, the majority of European companies will benefit from our action, since it is both a question of preventing their less scrupulous competitors from gaining an unfair advantage and of refocusing tax policies on job creation and investment.  The framework in place today has aged terribly. We rely on rules developed in the 1930s to regulate the business environment of the twentieth century. At the international level, the OECD is working to update the international framework for corporate taxation. This is an extremely welcome initiative, actively supported by the Union. But we cannot rely solely on international standards, we must develop our own solutions for the single market in order to take into account its specificities.  The European Union needs a common and coherent approach to corporate tax reform, which raises a major obstacle along the way: the traditional reluctance of Member States to work together on this issue. Indeed, they often tackle tax challenges on their own. Many of them see Community action in this area as a threat to their sovereignty, in reality it is the other way around. It is when states exhaust themselves to prevent the erosion of their tax base in the face of elusive profits rather than to develop fiscal policies that meet their needs that sovereignty is compromised. Fortunately, we are witnessing an awareness in the Member States. They need to completely rethink their approach to corporate taxation if they want businesses to pay their fair share of taxes, if they want sustainable tax systems to be conducive to growth, if they want an attractive single market for business and investment. In these circumstances, if they want to restore their ability to democratically determine the amount of taxes to be paid, Member States have no choice but to cooperate. That is what we are proposing to them with the action plan adopted last week.  Ladies and gentlemen, Madam President, we will first relaunch the project of a consolidated common corporate tax base.  THE CCCTB can both make life a meaningful easier for businesses, thus encouraging investment and job creation, preventing tax evasion and protecting our single market. The idea is simple: in a single market, a single tax for companies that have a European dimension. This will be the end of a clutter of rules incompatible with each other and their procession of overlaps, differences in interpretation, legal loopholes, multiple, and sometimes contradictory, obligations, and ensuing challenges. Although discussions in the Council are deadlocked, this Parliament, Member States, businesses and other stakeholders are in favour of reviving this project. That is why the Commission will review its proposal and adjust it so that the discussions can get back on a good footing, and I hope to succeed. We intend to propose a mandatory ACCIS, at least for multinationals, because an optional system will not stop tax evasion. We will propose a step-by-step approach because the CSRAC, as proposed, was too ambitious for us to reach an immediate agreement. Preparatory work has already begun and the Commission intends to present you with an amended proposal as soon as possible next year.  But we cannot wait for the adoption of the ICSA by the Council to deal with the problems of corporate taxation, which is why our action plan includes a number of measures to be implemented immediately.  The effective taxation of profits within the single market is a burning issue. It is no longer acceptable for some multinationals that make large profits in the European Union to pay almost no tax. Businesses have to pay their fair share of taxes where they make a profit. To ensure this, some Member States have unilaterally adopted anti-abuse provisions. However, acting in scattered order on these issues risks creating more problems than solving them. That is why our action plan lays the groundwork for a common approach to effective taxation to ensure that profits generated in the Union are taxed there. This includes filling the legal loopholes, framing preferential regimes, reviewing the issue of transfer pricing, or coordinating anti-abuse provisions. Similarly, we are trying to put in place greater transparency. The tax transparency package, which we proposed last March, is progressing well. I am counting on you, I am counting on this Parliament to support it. Last week, we went even further by launching a public consultation on a country-by-country reporting system to make transparency about the activities of multinationals in different countries and the taxes they pay there. Transparency must also go beyond the European Union, particularly with regard to the least cooperative states and territories. Some Member States have established lists of tax havens, others have not. Some have retaliatory measures in place, others have not. This disorderly approach is not effective in discouraging tax predation by some countries outside the European Union.  By acting as a bloc, the European Union would have much more clout to fend off attacks on tax bases. To this end, the Commission has published a coordinated list of the 30 least cooperative states and territories, based on the national lists of Member States. The clarity provided by this coordinated list will enable work on a common approach of the European Union and will encourage the countries concerned to redouble their efforts to better cooperate.  Ladies and gentlemen, it is through this package of measures - the CGTA for the medium term, effective taxation, greater transparency and closer cooperation between Member States in the immediate future - that we intend to make corporate taxation an instrument of economic policy for growth and employment in Europe.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a big thank you to the informants and journalists. Thanks to them, all European citizens have learned that at the very moment when taxes are rising for many of them, some of the largest companies are able to evade a large part of their profits from taxation. The problem arises on two levels and in different ways. First of all, between us in the Union, I would say that it is a question of family solidarity. As you have said very well, Commissioner, in a unified economic space, 28 all moral but different laws lead to the height of immorality. We must ban any system that would allow some to steal the tax wealth of their neighbours. The solution is known. The laxity of the common definition of taxable profit, which you have mentioned and which you are familiar with, Commissioner, must be addressed, since you were rapporteur in this Parliament on the draft already presented in 2011.  Then there is the global level. The principles of transparency, loyalty and fairness must apply to tax competition as well as to all other types of competition. Faced with this situation, the elected representatives that we are have an obligation to achieve results. Parliament understood this by creating the special committee TAXE. The European Commission has understood this by presenting this first package of measures, which I would like to welcome, and which my group, Madam, will support. But it will all depend on the political will of the rulers.  I say it quite clearly, taxation is too important a subject to be left to the finance ministers alone. Left to their own devices, they will accept everything and apply nothing. It is at the summit level that action must be taken. The European Council must address this before the end of the year. In a few months, the popular emotion created by the LuxLeaks affair will be evaporated, and we would lose 20 years.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, this new tax transparency package presented by the European Commission is welcome. It's another step, still insufficient, but in the right direction in relation to the LuxLeaks scandal in response to the LuxLeaks scandal. In fact, it is not acceptable for some countries that violently control the budgets of others by imposing brutal spending cuts on them, to be the same as every day they steal tax revenues through aggressive and unfair practices.  This situation is unfair, it is politically unsustainable. For years, the Socialist Group has been calling for the establishment of ccctb, i.e. a common basis for calculating the consolidated and compulsory tax base for all companies in the Union. Without this common basis, tax rates cannot be compared.  We regret that the C of "consolidation" has been left out for now, apparently out of the proposals, because without certainty about transfer prices the fight against erosion of tax bases is weakened. We also regret that the obligation to report, country by country, of the accounts of companies, the so-called Country by Country Reporting, is postponed pending a feasibility study that was not at all necessary.  One question I ask: what can we do, as representatives of citizens overwhelmed by brutal tax burdens so that Europe can move faster on a tax justice agenda, where competition is done between businesses and not between states.  I am complied with by this proposal for the work it is doing, but can you assure, dear Commissioner Marianne Thyssen, that, following Juncker's political commitment, the whole college of Commissioners, not just a few Commissioners, will be united in a convergent, coherent and ambitious position, capable of moving the Council of Ministers, usually blocked by the unanimity rule?  As far as the TAXE Commission is concerned, I can assure you that the spirit that unites us is of commitment, demand and fair cooperation with an ambitious Commission tax agenda.  The citizens ask us to do that.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, playing a leading role on fair taxation does not mean legislating in isolation. I understand and share the concerns of EU citizens when it comes to large companies avoiding tax, but the EU should not delude itself that the multinational companies can be brought into a fair taxation framework via a single piece of EU legislation. It may be a sad reality, but it is a reality that people try to lower their tax contributions, and often that will mean locating activities in low-tax jurisdictions. That means companies may relocate outside of the EU to lower their tax contributions, and there is very little that the EU can do about it. There is a reason why the UK Government has led the tax reform agenda at the G7 and G20. If we want corporations to pay their fair share, we need to work collectively at the level of the OECD, so that as many countries as possible work together to solve this problem. If countries all legislate at a national level, wherever in the developed world a company may be located, our problem on tax is resolved. The Member States need to show leadership within the OECD and in particular press for stronger transfer pricing and permanent establishment rules to ensure companies pay the appropriate level of tax in the countries where they earn their profits. All Member States individually should now take the necessary steps for early adoption of the OECD country-by-country reporting, which will help tax authorities to spot avoidance and make sure that companies pay what they owe. Closer cooperation amongst EU tax authorities and their global partners will ensure that opportunities to avoid tax become fewer.  The EU legislative process on VAT took 10 years to negotiate and then a further 10 years to implement. A legislative route on the common corporate tax base is not an efficient way of solving the issue of corporate taxation. The easiest and fastest way to address the issue of corporate tax is to agree a solution at the OECD and then implement that solution urgently in national law.

name: Michael THEURER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The revelations surrounding the Luxleaks scandal have brought to light a dimension of aggressive tax avoidance by international corporations that many of us could not have imagined. We therefore had to act here, and I am glad that Parliament has now set up the special committee that I called for for the ALDE Group back in November. Our expert hearings and on-site visits clearly show a need for action. Firstly, there is a competition issue. Experts reckon that these aggressive tax avoidance schemes by large corporations are the disadvantage for small and medium-sized enterprises at 20-25%. It is not acceptable for large corporations to pay less than one percent tax on billions in sales. But what is the right answer to this situation? The Commission has put forward proposals that we welcome: on the one hand, the automatic exchange of information – a minimum requirement. And we learned from a visit to Switzerland, where there is tax competition between the cantons, that a common tax base is also important, because then there is competition over the different tax rates and no longer through an erosion of the tax base. But we also see that our tax models are coming under pressure in a globalised, digitised global economy as a whole. And here we say that we need an area of tax justice and fair tax competition within the European Union. We also need solutions for the so-called patent boxes, in other words for the deductibility of licences and interest. We need to take account of the economic substance, so that profits are not deducted, extracted, and then virtually non-taxed at all. In any event, double non-taxation is incompatible with the principle of fair tax competition.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Europe's taxpayers lose more than EUR 1 trillion a year from tax evasion and avoidance. The Commission is postponing consolidation in corporate taxes instead of taking advantage of pressure from Luxleaks until grass grows over Juncker money. In this way, corporations can continue to push profits and losses across borders and trick them. We finally need a public country-by-country reporting, as in the banking and raw materials sector, and also public exchange of information on tax rulings, because I do not trust the finance ministers. We need more, not fewer, tax investigators. They are increasing the value-added tax on the small people and at the same time cutting Varoufakis's tax investigators to a hundred men. That is a great hypocrisy! Journalists and whistleblowers are on trial in Luxembourg, and the European Commission wants to further weaken its protection through the Trade Secrets Directive. Which employee, which medium-sized company can already rely on his trade secret from the tax office? This is a disgrace: they punish the decent, not the tax thieves.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, last autumn, Europe was rocked by the LuxLeaks scandal. We discovered that Member States had been secretly agreeing deals with multinational corporations to allow them to avoid tax. Corporations were playing a game of divide and conquer with EU governments, and the losers were the people of Europe. It was only because of the actions of the brave whistleblower Antoine Deltour that we found out about this. The Commission had looked the other way. In spite of President Juncker’s promises to act, it was clear that this was through desperation rather than desire, and the outcomes have been disappointing. To explore the issue of Member State collusion in tax avoidance, a special committee was set up, and last week we visited London. I must confess I was shocked by the murky and elaborate system of relationships between my capital city and offshore secrecy jurisdictions, where money can be hidden and tax avoided. I think we all have to admit that our countries are involved in these activities that hurt us all and distort the single market. I welcome the Commission’s list of tax havens as a first step to map this hidden world, although there is much further to go. Two of the clear demands of the Green Group are that corporations should be required to make public how much economic substance is created in which country – so-called country-by-country reporting – and that there should be agreement about how and where corporations are taxed: the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base, or CCCTB. These are the minimum requirements we need to prevent countries shifting their profits in the interests of shareholders while depriving the public of the taxes that are necessary to pay for the roads and internet systems the companies use, the schools that educate their staff and the hospitals those staff use when they are ill. We already have country-by-country reporting for banks, so it is a simple matter to extend this to other sectors. So do we find this in the Commission’s tax package? I am afraid to say we do not. Instead, we have merely a viability study: a classic example of delaying tactics. Next time we meet as a Parliament in Strasbourg, we will have the chance to vote on this vital transparency proposal, and I sincerely hope we will pass it with a large majority. As for the CCCTB, the Commission is promising to relaunch its proposal, beginning with the common part, so that we all agree what should be taxed. But this means they are delaying the consolidation, the aspect of the proposal that would effectively control profit-shifting and the tax avoidance it facilitates. The people I represent are appalled that corporations are able to avoid their taxes, which gives them an unfair advantage over local businesses that cannot shift their profits abroad, as well as undermining the public services we depend on. The Commission’s action plan lacks determination and urgency and is a wholly inadequate response to this public outrage.

name: Diane JAMES
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, thank you very much for the opportunity to talk on this subject. What we heard tonight is a system of the future, one of EU Utopia. Much more though, we believe, is required. The devil is in the detail. That is a phrase much used in the UK. We are not there yet – and we probably will never get there, so I even take the ‘yet’ away. Required, though, is an EU-wide, USA-style IRS system in place and its approach to deliver, and I hold that up as a system that works and addresses the issues discussed tonight. It will have to address tax collection issues, so evident in the disparities between north and south Member States. And finally, I and my group believe it needs to be a global, not an EU, issue. G20 is the proper place to discuss and address this important matter, not here in Brussels.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is always suspicious to see the arsonist at work. Of course, he is in the best position to know how to put out the fire he started himself, but the question remains: does he really want it? The Commission has presented us with its action plan to put the LuxLeaks scandal to the fore. However, I recall that the President of the Commission is Jean-Claude Juncker, and he is the main architect of these practices of siphoning off the tax revenue of his European partners for the benefit of Luxembourg. This simple reminder should make us doubt the sincerity or the true purposes of this initiative.  On today's proposal, the aim is certainly laudable: to remove an incentive for aggressive tax optimisation, in line with the OECD's fifteen proposals. States would retain control of rates and profits would remain localized in the country where real economic activity is located.  There remains the question of localization criteria, particularly for the digital economy. But the proponents of federal Europe could take today's consensus as an alibi to give a boost to the fiscal union, which would go far beyond that. The AXIS project already plans to consolidate all profits and losses across the European Union. Secondly, when it comes to VAT, Brussels is already imposing a framework on rates on states. France knows something about catering and books.  What will be left of fiscal sovereignty in the long run? Will this logic of integration in progress lead the Union to raise its own tax? Will there be a gradual transfer of national budgets to THE Union's budgets so that the last lock, that of unanimity, can finally be skipped? If the ENF Group can only approve the fight against aggressive tax competition, we will remain very vigilant in the face of the processes and means that would undermine France's sovereignty.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, the Commission is proposing a package of measures on tax transparency. Let us first pass on the irony of the fact that the President of the Commission is Mr Juncker, former Prime Minister of Luxembourg, capital of tax avoidance in the Union. In fact, the package is nothing more than an air wish list, full of intelligent definitions with countless loopholes in which large companies aim to continue to avoid tax and to place more tax burdens on small and medium-sized enterprises, which are not networked like multinationals.  The Commission's view is ultimately doomed to fail, as have so many other regulations and provisions, which have achieved nothing more than to turn the Union into a labyrinth of bureaucracy hostile to both healthy and legitimate entrepreneurs and suffering workers. One could expect nothing more than a Union of protectors of Siemens and the other multinationals, who are proven to be illegal but continue to enjoy immunity.  One may be the solution to all this. A clear and secure investment environment that will remain stable for many years to come. As long as we have a single market with different tax rates in each Member State, the phenomenon of tax avoidance will never be eliminated. Since the introduction of common taxation throughout the Union would be an unacceptable assignment of national sovereignty, the solution is the abolition of a single market and the introduction of the obligation for companies to set up subsidiaries in the countries they want to operate, which will be taxed on the spot.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – I thank the Chairpers, I welcome the Commissioner and thank my colleague Lamassoure, President of the Special Committee on Taxes, who has launched a lot of initiatives in this short time to develop awareness of the importance of simplifying and harmonising tax systems in the European Union.  A stable and simple tax system is one of the key elements of a favourable business environment. This action plan is an important and big step towards creating fair, efficient, and developing directed corporate taxation. Tax should be paid where the work is done and profits are made. We can't allow business in one country and pay taxes in another. At the foundation of this plan is the preservation of the sovereignty of each Member State in terms of the tax system. We don't want harmonised tax rates. Each Member State has the right to independently design a set of measures that are favourable to its economy. However, it is important to work on strengthening cooperation between Member States' tax administrations to prevent tax avoidance and avoidance of double taxation and to apply rules aimed at preventing tax base erosion and profit shifting.  It is important to simplify and align tax procedures in the European Union in order to facilitate the work of entrepreneurs. Opaque, privileged tax treatments and the facilitation of profit shifting to avoid paying taxes in the country where added value has been created are procedures that undermine not only member states' tax bases but also the entire European Union single market. For this reason, I welcome this action plan and call for its swift and quality implementation, which will allow for increased transparency of the work of Member States' tax administrations and the prevention of tax fraud and tax avoidance.

name: Peter SIMON
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her After four months of work in the TAXE Special Investigation Committee, I think we can safely say that we are dealing here with state-organised tax dumping. If you look at the nature of corporate taxation in the European Union and the form of competition, it is quite cannibalistic. In this respect, it is important that the European Commission now takes a first major step forward with the Action Plan. It is important that we achieve a uniform tax base for corporation tax. However, it is very important that, in addition to the tax base, we also achieve consolidation within Europe, and we support the Commission in all its efforts to make progress in a timely manner. Country-by-country reporting so we know who pays taxes where is important. We therefore welcome the fact that the first steps have been taken here with a public consultation. Second and third steps must follow. At this point, however, I would like to strongly encourage the European Commission to go beyond what is contained in the plan and to take the sharpest weapon that remains of the European Commission, where it does not need the Member States, not even this House here, to implement it. The state aid law, which you now apply in six cases, is applied on a case-by-case basis. In other jurisdictions outside of taxation, the European Commission has demonstrated how it enforces competition law through guidelines applied in the Member States with clear, unambiguous rules on how not to release rules of the game that allow unfair competition in the Member States. The same is possible in the area of taxation: guidelines that clarify when there is inadmissible aid in the area of corporate taxation. We would also like to see such guidelines. The Commission has shown in other areas of law that it is capable of doing so. Please check here in the area of taxes.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done We are talking here about nothing more and nothing less than justice. This term has been used very little in the debate, but that is what is at stake. It is a question of every taxpayer being taxed according to his or her capacity and contributing to the tasks of the public authorities. It is simply scandalous that multinational companies are able to evade this taxation, this duty to also contribute to the good of the community. That is why we must indeed take decisive action here, we must combat this type of tax avoidance or tax evasion decisively. The proposals that have been made here are good proposals, and in some cases they are even too timid. Indeed, consolidation of the corporate tax base is a crucial element in ensuring that we can achieve tax justice. This must not be put off simply by saying that everything must be done globally. We must take a first step in the EU.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: We are very pleased with the Commission's action plan to tackle tax avoidance. The Commission proposes all kinds of instruments in this, and we believe that the most important weapon is transparency. Transparency about the rulings, transparency about where multinationals pay what taxes. In our view, it is not only the role of tax authorities and governments, but also of multinationals themselves. When we have this transparency, tax policy will naturally play a bigger role in the boardroom. The ethics in the boardroom are extremely important.  I think that in the tax debate we are actually at the same level as we were in the boardrooms 15 years ago with the environmental debate. Not everything that is legally allowed is also good. When there is more transparency, consumers can also choose with their feet, they can decide why they want to do their shopping at a particular company. That is why I believe that we should use that transparency as an important weapon against tax avoidance in every possible way.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: – Madam President, tax fraud and tax evasion are one of the most visible faces of injustice than is practised within the European Union; whether legal or illegal, is immoral and, as I said, unfair.  We know that in all countries these situations are going on. In the case of Portugal, 19 of the 20 companies classified in PSI 20, in the Portuguese stock exchange, pay their taxes in the Netherlands and do not do so with hurt, because one of these multinationals has the slogan "It feels good to pay so little". I don't know if it's irony or cynicism, but that's the slogan. Therefore, with the crisis we are still witnessing a more unequal distribution and a greater burden, passing the burden of taxes to the side of those who work and relieving large multinationals.  I think the Commission's proposal points in good directions, but there are still many holes. I do not fail to stress the need for the country-by-country report, but I also say that taxes must be paid where profits are made, because there are billions of euros that are lost in public accounts each year. The Commission's proposal has good principles, but it has many holes and, on the subject of LuxLeaks, I would even say that Caesar's wife is not enough to be honest should it seem: the Commission has to leave here above suspicion.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: Madam President, Mrs Thyssen, you and Mr Moscovici are finally very lucky. Thanks to LuxLeaks, you now have the opportunity to point the finger at the two major problems in the European Union: that of tax dumping and that of opacity. So we have the diagnosis and now we just have to try to solve the problems that arise. This has been said, as you have said yourself, on the issue of competition between states, we must of course move towards harmonisation, if not convergence, and try to have a consolidated European base and a rate framework. There is no difficulty in this area. On the issue of opacity, which must be stopped, it is a question of doing exactly as it has been done for banks, as is done in other countries, abroad. We need to have clear country-by-country reports on turnover, taxes paid and the number of employees. Unfortunately, if we know the answers, your second tax package - at least the one announced by Mr Moscovici on 17 June - does not yet meet those expectations. He's a long way from that!
