Nothing about tax transparency, except a request for public consultation, during which, of course, the large groups will explain to us how much we want to expect their competitiveness. Nothing about the consolidation of profits at European level, really, concretely, nothing about the convergence of rates. I want to tell you, Commissioner, lean on this Parliament! Have the political will to go and face the Council, make sure that this Commission, as you represent the symbolism of it, is the defender of the European general interest. Do it for the TPEs, do it for SMEs, do it for craftsmen, who can't relocate their taxes! Failing that, who will be grateful?

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the action plan presented by the European Commission last week is a very small step towards greater financial transparency. I believe, however, that transparency alone is not enough to ensure the restoration of tax justice in Europe. We need concrete action to counter the spill-over consequences in developing countries that do not have sufficient skilled work and technology to interact with multinationals. We must make illegal the schemes used to circumvent taxation so that everyone pays the right share of taxes and, above all, the country where the profits are made and the country of taxation coincide.  Taxation must serve as a tool for growth, so that revenue is reinvested in the real economy. It must not serve as an instrument of competition between Member States. I am thinking, for example, of the Luxleaks affair, of which someone on the upper floors of neighbouring Berlaymont is probably aware. The idea of the CCCTB, as well as the efforts to integrate new OECD actions at UNION level to combat base erosion and profit shifting, are certainly positive, but I have a strong doubt that the Member States do not accept this. We are once again faced with a fundamental problem: how can we ensure the free movement of capital within the EU without common rules on taxation?

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done According to calculations by the London School of Economics, profit shifting by international corporations leads to an annual tax loss of 150 billion euros in the countries of the European Union. The action plan under discussion today is intended to take this into account and to find a fair system to bring corporate taxation in the EU back to where it is, namely to the Member States, and to avoid aggressive tax planning. In this action plan, you have proposed a number of measures to avoid aggressive tax planning. Firstly, there is a common consolidated corporate tax base. Many are now happy because they believe that there will then be a harmonised tax. That will not be the case. I would like to quote Director-General Zourek of DG TAXUD, who was on the TAXE Committee and said that we are talking here about coordination and not about harmonising tax rates. That is very important to me to stress. The second point is effective taxation, and the third is more transparency. That is a good thing, because only in this way will we achieve fair tax systems and fair corporate taxes. But please in the Member States, and not at EU level.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Madam President, it is well known that in order for economic growth in a country, there must be investments in that country, facilitated by the existence of a legal tax system. The need for such a system also exists in the European Union, where, due to the free movement of products, many multinational companies are active at European and global level. That is why we have previously discussed the Commission's plan for a fair tax system to replace the existing one. With this plan, the European Union seeks to create a fair and secure business environment, distinguished by transparency and the ability to support companies that are consistent with their tax obligations.  However, the following question arises. How can a tax system be fair, which does not take into account the tax specificities and problems that companies in the crisis-affected countries have? How is it possible, for example, in Greece for institutions, or the troika as we used to say, to require Greek companies to pay 29% VAT while at the same time requiring them to be efficient and to make profits? On the other hand, the European Union does not want to intervene, and that is why we must accept that we must put aside hypocrisy and find and admit that unfortunately this tax system is not fair. Multinational companies will be subject to a scandalous tax exemption and unfortunately small and medium-sized companies will be taxed.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Tax competition is part of the European internal market, and no one is questioning the competition of tax systems. Taxes are levied differently, just as the Member States design their social systems differently. The Member States themselves know best who they are taxing, for what and how much. That is why the EU should not interfere with tax competences. Nevertheless, we in Europe need to act, namely when multinationals take advantage of the different systems of our taxes, when they undermine the tax base for tax collection, when they write invoices for so long within the group, until belgium, the Netherlands or the United Kingdom have hardly any tax to pay – to name but a few countries, where, unfortunately, this is a common place. The Commission is taking action against this, which I very much welcome. We therefore need a common tax base for corporation tax in the European Union, we need a much more binding exchange of information between the national tax authorities, we need country-by-country reporting. And we need – and I think this is very important – a stronger naming and shaming of the Member States that oppose it. Taxes must be paid where companies produce and where they provide their services. What is self-evident for the craftsman at home must become a duty for the large corporations in Europe. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to ask Mr Pieper – after it is said that EUR 150 billion in additional taxes could be collected from large companies – whether he then believes that this will enable us to reduce the burden on start-ups and small and medium-sized enterprises, micro-enterprises, in order to give them the opportunity to pay good wages and make investments again.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Not only that. If an additional 150 billion were available, we could also make tax relief available elsewhere, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. New start-up programmes could be launched, and more investment in infrastructure could be made. The European taxpayer, and therefore the European treasuries, are losing so much money that we could certainly do much for the competitiveness of the European Union in this direction. Thank you for the question.

name: Anneliese DODDS
text: – Madam President, colleagues, we can wait for the whole world to agree measures against tax fiddling, or we can take action now. Personally I am very pleased that the Commission has acted now and welcome much of what is within this package. Nonetheless, as many people have already said, the package does not go far enough to satisfy the public and the vast majority of tax-compliant businesses. The first big hole, as many have mentioned, is the lack of a commitment to public country-by-country reporting. Unfortunately this has been unnecessarily postponed. We must see it being enacted soon. There is also no mention of protections for whistle-blowers, and whilst a common list of tax havens is better than nothing at all, we surely need a common definition of tax havens to give that list credibility. Furthermore there must be consequences for those countries and firms which are classified as tax havens or which use tax havens. They should not be able to profit from EU funds. Finally, I am sorry to say that I do harbour some doubts about the Commission’s proposed loss adjustment mechanism. A 2011 OECD report indicated how, and I quote, ‘financial instruments are used to create artificial losses, i.e. losses which are only generated for tax purposes’. The Commission must ensure the loss adjustment mechanism does not perversely promote aggressive tax planning. Thank you again for your work on this and I look forward to much more over the months to come.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, I welcome the public debate in the EU on how to combat tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. Unfortunately, we have not found a solution to the challenges posed by the global economy, which will enable certain multinationals to achieve a tax rate close to zero, and this will also harm the right taxpayers. One solution has been to provide country-by-country reporting, i.e. a model that would oblige companies to disclose information about the taxes they pay to the tax authorities. Personally, I believe that country-by-country reporting would affect companies' willingness to pay taxes, as many companies want to protect their good reputation as honest and socially responsible operators. But I would like to stress that EU initiatives must follow international developments, otherwise we will be able to put European companies at a competitive disadvantage.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, recent events such as LuxLeaks have shown EU citizens that some corporations pay very little or indeed no tax. Such tax evasion is not acceptable, and therefore it is good to see that the Commission is relaunching its action plan for fair and efficient corporate taxation. I think one of the questions that we need to answer is: how much can the EU do on its own, and how much should we do in conjunction with the OECD, for example through its BEPS project, which needs to be fully implemented? The EU can and should take action. But I think it is crucial to remember that a global approach is also necessary in parallel with our own action plan. Transparency should be core to our efforts, and I hope this Parliament will vote for country-by-country reporting when it gets the opportunity to do so at the next Strasbourg part-session. Commissioner Thyssen, you said that the Commission is going back to the drawing board on CCCTB, and I think this is necessary due to the complexity of some of the earlier proposals. I think the crucial issue for small Member States in CCCTB will be how the formula is found to apportion the share of profits. Previous formulae were based on sales, employment and capital investment, and they favoured large countries over smaller countries. So I think that formula needs to be nuanced. I think in order to get everybody on board, the system must be fair for citizens and for Member States. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – I find it astonishing that you speak of action to be taken at European Union level against corporate tax avoidance and evasion, and you speak about action to be taken at global level – but nothing about the Member State, which surely is the most appropriate vehicle for any such action to be taken. Do you agree that that is rather a big omission?

name: Marian HARKIN
text: blue-card answer. – Actually I do not, because I think it is issues like transfer pricing which cause the problem when it comes to the fact that corporations avoid their tax. Member States can set their own tax levels – that is for Member States themselves to do – but it is the fact that money crosses borders, etc. which is the core of the issue. That is what leads to tax evasion. We do need to deal with it at European level, but I do not think we can neglect – and we should not neglect – the global issue as well.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Madam President, tax fraud and tax evasion are growing on the direct reason of the process of liberalising the economies of globalisation. To this extent, tax fraud and tax evasion are direct descendants of this process of European integration, based on the free movement of capital and the total supremacy of large economic and financial groups.  In the face of citizens' indignation, the Commission feels obliged to take action. It proposes more of the same: the harmonised tax base, the elaboration of a list of tax havens and vague principles aimed at avoiding the relocation of profits to tax havens.  What this process indicates to us is that tax evasion with the complicity of governments represents a widespread practice within the European Union and not outside. It is therefore the governments of the majority of the countries of the European Union, whose parties are present here in this House, who are largely responsible for this scandal.  For our part, we do not feed any illusions. The way out is the end of the supremacy of economic power over political power.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I wonder if you see an equate between tax avoidance and paying lower taxes in some Member States? The second question is whether you consider this Commission proposal to be sufficient? Do you, like me, lack more "tax-parenting" in the proposal?

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – (2) I am concerned precisely that these agreements which they are making make do not guarantee scrutiny on the part of the people and the Members themselves.  With regard to other measures, I continue to say that they do not touch the problem. The problem lies, as Commissioner Juncker knows, that there are multinationals that are in government and that they are in the parties. And that's really the problem.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission's proposal is certainly positive. But why did this proposal come about? Because the Luxleaks scandal has broken out, otherwise we would still be here sleeping and waiting for this kind of common sense proposal to come, because politics today lacks common sense.  We are with these multinationals that have turnover that is worth the GDP of G20 nations, that can take cheques of billions, that come in with red carpets into the institutions, into the ministries, as we are seeing in the TAXE Committee. We are welcomed into the basements because we cannot talk about these things, because these companies, by their behaviour, together with the Member States, by their irresponsible behaviour, distort competition. Small businesses close because of high taxation and we find ourselves in this situation, where we also lose the jobs of small businesses that suffer all this.  Politics must wake up, otherwise you will be woken up by the citizens.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, what are the Real Motivations of the Commission in this report? Well, nothing new. I think the Commission is essentially taking up the OECD proposals. But we must read between the lines and we can decipher that, under the pretext of unifying corporation tax in Europe, the Commission wants to create both a European tax and legitimise its function as a supranational state. In short, the finality must always be sought when analysing the Commission's proposals. Once again, Madam President, I think we must be skeptical of this proposal!

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, if this Commission could do one meaningful thing under REFIT and on better regulation, it would be this common corporate tax base and a reform of our taxation systems. This is indeed one of the big obstacles to our growth and internal markets. It is an administrative burden for our companies, which act in various Member States and need to comply with different taxation legislations. I am a bit bored of hearing all the blame about companies using aggressive tax avoidance and tax planning if we have offered it to them on a gold plate, even with private agreements, and then again with a system that encourages the use of a different kind of transfer pricing systems and different kinds of tax levels and tax accounting methods. Let us stop thinking that if we can compete within the family and beat other Member States with this kind of tax advantage, then it benefits those who think that it would be to their advantage, because we are all losing on this policy. We are losing up to EUR 1 000 billion every year because of bad tax systems, tax avoidance and non-taxation. Let us put an end to that. Madam Commissioner, I congratulate you on these proposals, which you know so well from your history, on the common corporate tax base. It is probably a wise idea to take things step by step, but I am a bit cautious about the time span being rather long, knowing that this Commission and this election period have their limits. I would want to see a faster timetable for the actions so that this Parliament gets access to all the necessary parts and different steps of this legislation. The same applies, on a basic level of timing, to transparency and country-by-country reporting, where I am quite convinced that the impact assessment could be done in a much shorter period of time. I do not want to start blaming and by-passing the Commission on this, as I know that the biggest part of the problem in this debate lies within the Member States. Last but not least, why should we not count tax crimes as money-laundering crimes and combine real automatic exchange of information, at all income levels, by the taxpayer to the tax officer of each and every Member State? If we did this we would already be going far. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: blue-card question. – I am very glad, Mrs Pietikäinen, that you have raised this issue of the time span. I completely agree, but I want to ask you whether you agree that not only the election time span, but also another thing – namely the need to go on very rapidly with the digital single market – is one of the factors which is pressing on the Commission, and also on us, to have more harmonisation of taxation in the EU.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: blue-card answer. – Indeed it is a pressing factor, as indeed are the international recommendations. Even though, obviously, those recommendations are never going to replace legislation, if we want to have a say in this area we have to act promptly and have our vision ready here within the EU.

name: Paul TANG
text: It is good that the European Commission wants to take a serious approach to tackling tax avoidance and this serious injustice. Only a common approach can prevent multinationals from playing countries apart. A European base for income taxes is therefore necessary. But the Commission must realise that the action plan is welcome, but far from sufficient.  Let me limit myself to three points. Firstly, the Commission is doing half the work by omwing the consolidation of profits and losses. If we want to guarantee that companies pay tax where they make a profit, that possibility must not disappear under the table. Secondly, the Commission is doing half the work in dealing with tax havens. Yes, the blacklist of tax havens is welcome, but the real question is how to deal with these tax havens. The Netherlands, my country, is a transit port of untaxed profits. I would therefore strongly advocate that a withholding tax on flows to these tax havens should be allowed under European directives. Thirdly, the European Union must also support the forthcoming OECD agreements by implementing them quickly. There is little to nothing about this in the action plan. But it's important to close the gaps that are already there.  Finally, half work does not mean a halved problem. The practice of tax avoidance shows that every hole will be looked up. In short, there is still a lot of work to be done by this Commission and by this Parliament.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The document presented by the Commission rightly states that many Member State governments, in order to compensate for the losses resulting from tax avoidance by large multinational companies, increase the tax burden on less mobile, mostly home-based companies and labour taxation. Consequently, small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens bear the disproportionate burden of participating in state running costs and public services, while large companies transfer profits abroad.  This phenomenon mainly affects the peripheral countries, whose development has taken place over the last 25 years mainly through external capital inflows and foreign direct investment, and it was not necessary for LuxLeaks to know about it at all. I'm surprised that only now has this been discovered. But It does not seem to me that harmonising the corporate tax base is the right way to combat this phenomenon.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: – Madam President, my first option coming in here was to speak English, then I thought I could as a second option speak in my native Swedish, but realising who is in the chair I have decided to speak Finnish. Mr President, it seems that we like tax competition, but for very different reasons. Some want more efficiency, others want to get rid of the state altogether. In this context, however, particular attention must be paid to one issue. Studies show that small countries fare worse in international economic competition. This may be because their domestic market is so small that it is not enough as a kind of stepping board in international competition. That's why they're trying to find their place through tax competition. This is a very dangerous and very bad development, and that is why we should understand how small and large countries compete with each other.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, the Commission calling for measures to create more transparency in corporate taxation within the EU is laudable. However, I have a fundamental disagreement with the Commission using the five-point action plan in order to recommend that Member States adopt the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base. In my opinion, it does not serve the interests of the ordinary citizens to have their countries’ sovereignty surrendered or relinquished through the harmonisation of taxation. It is absolutely and fundamentally the right of governments serving their people to legislate in the best interests of their citizens, including the setting of corporate tax rates. Of course we want transparency and of course we want the larger corporations to pay their fair share of taxation, and any measures taken by the European institutions to ensure that this is the case are to be welcomed. But all matters relating to corporate taxation and any other taxation are a matter of national competence, and the EU has no role in interfering or dictating national taxation policies.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! The action plan presented by the European Commission is very ambitious, but also much needed. Whether it is implemented will depend on the Member States and it will be their attitude that will determine the creation of a fairer corporate tax system in the Union.  The main problem in the current situation is, inter alia, the lack of a level playingmatch for economic operators. If multinationals pay on average 30% less tax than domestic companies, it is difficult to expect the latter to win competition. Therefore, the action plan presented can be seen as an instrument for rebalancing the single market. A number of initiatives aimed at combating tax avoidance, ensuring stable incomes and strengthening the single market for businesses deserve support. Taken together, these measures are intended to significantly improve the conditions for corporate taxation in the European Union, which will become fairer, more efficient and more growth-promoting.  I am convinced that if we succeed, albeit to some extent, in reducing the grey area and improving the enforcement of taxes on the budgets of the Member States, and thus of the European Union, there will be significant measures to make the investments necessary, even from the point of view of labour markets.  One of the most difficult tasks facing the European Parliament and the Council will be to work on a proposal to create a common consolidated corporate tax base. The previous attempt to adopt this instrument was not a complete success, thanks to a number of reservations from the Member States. If an agreement on this issue is to be successful, the European Commission will have to take into account the problems raised by the Members of the Union, but also by Parliament, and reach a satisfactory compromise for all.  It seems that the proposal to create a common tax base for companies without the need for consolidation is a solution going in the right direction. There is no doubt that, after a period of tightening the belt and a thrifty fiscal policy, it is time to support economic operators. We should do everything necessary to create a friendly business environment for our home businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, to encourage investment in the European economy.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I often can't hear the word tax competition, because it's almost always unfair competition. Employees pay their income tax, consumers pay VAT, and companies invoke tax competition and then simply pay the rates they want to pay – with the active support of the Member States. As you yourself said, this is a threat to national sovereignty. In this respect, it is good that this action plan is now before the Commission. However, I do not have a few elements. In the light of LuxLeaks, I also expect the Commission to take a strong position on minimum tax rates. I know you will say that there is unanimity here. However, right now the Commission should be particularly ambitious. Another instrument – where you cannot ultimately rely on unanimity – is state aid law. The Commission has a very strong instrument here, and it is therefore appropriate that you put together a corset of guidelines for states and for companies, so that they comply accordingly. That would be a very strong position that you could put forward. Finally, on country-by-country reporting, we need real, transparent country-by-country reporting, no narrow-gauge variant or a retract of the honourable and valuable work currently being done by the OECD.

name: Dawid Bohdan JACKIEWICZ
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The current rules on corporate taxation in the European Union are not adapted to the requirements of the modern economy. Some companies use the fact that national actions in this area differ in this area for tax avoidance. This results in significant revenue losses for Member States, higher tax burdens and distortions of competition in the markets. The action plan that we are talking about today paves the way for more effective tax enforcement in the Union. Under this concept, companies should pay a fair share of taxes in the country where they generate profits. And that's the right direction for change.  The Action Plan aims to increase tax transparency both in the European Union and in relation to third countries. It is necessary to strengthen the common system of protection against external threats to Member States' revenues. This will also be the right direction in tax policy, which we should develop and support with effective tools. This is what we should be calling for today.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Commissioner, with corporate taxation reform you have opened up one of the crucial issues of the present European Union, an institutional framework designed to promote the interests of large capital, with a fiscal structure that is regressive in both the Member States and the Union as a whole. The proposals you put forward are clearly insufficient, lacking clear commitments and dates that allow us to hope that progress will be made in the fight against tax evasion. Meanwhile, the Greek government has presented the institutions with viable plans to increase collection through the fight against tax evasion in their country. Instead of welcoming these proposals, his colleagues Juncker and Dijsselbloem, architects of tax havens such as Luxembourg and the Netherlands, have preferred to impose a reform of indirect charges that criminally increases the weight on the popular classes. Commissioner, with your Commission's policy we are closer than ever to a system that robs the poor to give to the rich. This is the story of Robón Hood.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Madam President, as we discuss the Commission’s action plan for fairer corporate taxation in the European Union, we can see that this is not some dry or technical matter. It is actually a very important day-to-day issue which we need to see from three different perspectives. These three different perspectives can be in terms of continuity, efficiency and competitiveness. Speaking of continuity, the action plan on corporate taxation is part and parcel of a growth agenda which President Juncker has been implementing with determination since November last year. It is no coincidence that taxation falls within plenary debates such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the Stability and Growth Pact. Looking at the bigger picture, it reminds us that taxation  rules can be combined and complemented by other initiatives at EU level to bring the best possible results. Importantly, initiatives such as the digital agenda and the use of new technologies can aid the transparent collection and control of tax contributions. Just to give a quick example: in Estonia, 95% of tax declarations are filled in electronically and the process takes about five minutes. It is so much easier for businesses and saves so much time which is not spent on queuing but actually on doing business. This brings me to efficiency, which requires clear uniform rules. As in most areas of taxation, it is best to keep things simple. The more exceptions and specific regulations there are, the more loopholes can be created. These loopholes can be exploited by the most skilled players and are often to the disadvantage of SMEs. This brings me to my last point: competitiveness. With continuity and efficiency, we can also support competitiveness for our companies, which will do business in a much more clearly-regulated environment. This is crucial for SMEs. Europe needs highly efficient and productive enterprises that can withstand global competition.

name: Olle LUDVIGSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for As I see it, the European Commission's action plan on business taxation is both good and bad. I think it is a good thing that the proposal for a common consolidated corporate tax base is now being relaunched in a pragmatic way. The step-by-step process before it is probably the only realistic way forward.  I also think it is good that the Commission is taking a proper line of reasoning on how to implement the OECD-led BEPS initiative at EU level. A well-thought-out strategy is needed here. I also think it is a good thing that the Commission is setting up a blacklist of tax havens. The list can be a useful tool in the fight against tax avoidance. On the other hand, I think it is totally bad that the Commission is burying the transparency requirement in a vague consultation. Instead, the Commission should have made a strong proposal to extend country-by-country reporting requirements for large cross-border companies to all sectors. Anyone who follows this issue is well known that the basis for such a proposal is already quite sufficient.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, good evening Commissioner and welcome. This subject, for a country such as my own country, Italy, takes on politically very important characteristics. As you know, the level of taxation, especially for businesses, in a developed country like mine has reached unbearable levels. We are talking about peaks of more than sixty%, given the whole of taxation. The subject of tax competition within the European Union for a country such as my own is therefore very sensitive. However, I remain convinced that this virtuous tax competition should be preserved provided that there is effective transparency, that is to say that the correct rules of the market are fully respected.  Let me give you an example: in my view, for example, compensation phenomena can be used. A useful example: an Italian entrepreneur legitimately decides to have an operating company in Bulgaria, because he will have tax advantages. Well, it seems to me that this cannot be prevented. However, I think it is appropriate to assume, for example, that the tax advantages obtained in this way should be partly reinvested by that Italian entrepreneur in his country of origin. This would be a good way of leaving the advantage that Bulgaria gains through a different tax regime from the Italian one, without at the same time totally taking value away from the country of origin.  These are systems that can be hypothesized. So my suggestion is also a quid pluris of imagination in creating the conditions for the future of this fiscal sovereignty within the Union. Or, through the tax credit, to solve the problem of the risk of double taxation or double non-taxation. In short, let us face those entrepreneurs who, small or medium-sized, respect the law, make sacrifices, generate value, but cannot afford the kind of tax tourism that some have sometimes been allowed and that small entrepreneurs must ultimately compensate by continuing to pay all taxes, as they have always done.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the Commission, through Commissioner Moscovici, tells us that this action plan will, in particular, tackle the introduction of a new legislative proposal on the consolidated common corporate tax base in the European Union. It is clear that, on the face of it, we may be pleased with this announcement in some respects. I believe that this measure would move towards a harmonisation of tax regimes in Europe. In the context of the TAXE committee, all the field visits show us how much more than useful it is.  It would also significantly reduce the administrative burden on corporations and, therefore, the costs associated with them. It would also greatly reduce legal uncertainty and, finally, I think it would really be a very effective weapon to combat tax evasion. I would also like to point out that this is one of the main recommendations that were made in the opinion on the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion in developing countries, which the ECON Committee recently adopted. I stress that this is just the beginning. I think we really need ambitious and faster reform if we are to really achieve the goal of making corporate taxation fairer, more efficient and more transparent in the European Union.  It seems to me, for this reason, that the Commission can go much further, notably on the blacklist of tax havens, on increasing transparency with regard to country reports, on possible conflicts of interest between the Big Four, etc. I think it is essential to change things and that everyone is involved in the exercise of tax, both taxpayers and multinationals. These are essential resources to invest in the services our citizens need, be it education, the economy, health, infrastructure, security or social protection. I am counting on you, Commissioner.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Madam President, I welcome the action plan for a fairer corporate tax system in the EU as it contains many positive steps, which shows the Commission’s commitment to fundamentally reform corporate taxation. Relaunching the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base, increasing transparency and improving EU coordination – all these steps point in the right direction. However, I must also emphasise the disappointment caused by the fact that the country-by-country reporting was not included in the action plan, although it would have provided desperately-needed transparency with which the EU could ensure that big corporations stop tax dodging. It is obvious to everyone that the current system is unfair and has a devastating effect on honest taxpayers, including small and medium-sized enterprises. Therefore, I cannot see any reason why we should not act in order to change the situation. As public consultation on the matter will not produce concrete and visible results in the future, I urge the Commission to take clear and swift action in this field and expand the country-by-country reporting system that already exists for banks to all sectors in the EU.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – I personally welcome this initiative of yours and this action plan, but I would not go down the path of penalised anyone and i would reverse it. That's why I brought you a solution called (speaker speaks in English) " and this is for translation, taxparency, not translated as transparency, taxparency. We solution is taxparency" This solution is actually a smart tax solution from the point of view of neuroeconomics. The thing is, we're not going to punish companies for not paying taxes, but we're going to motivate them to pay those taxes, i.e., we're going to make a tax base that's acceptable to corporate tax companies.  Just as I shop at companies that have the "Fair trade" brand, I'd like to spend my money with companies that have the "Taxparency" brand. I think that is the answer when the States criticise you for going into legislation that belongs to the Member States.  "Taxparency" is voluntary, and it's the only answer possible to "LuxLeaks" and other similar cases.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, at a time when the troika has imposed a new tax resalto on the backs of the impoverished Greek people, Mr Juncker's Luxembourg, the Netherlands and other Member States of the European Union operate on their territory tax havens for German and other multinational companies that have increased profitability from their activities in Greece. The same applies to well-known Greek oligarchs who escape tax through offshore companies.  Lux Leaks policies have left Greece with multibillion-euro tax revenues. Tax dumping must therefore be ended and multinationals taxed in the country where they make their profits. At the same time, money laundering and corruption must be hit. Therefore, Mr Weber, who was just waving his finger at Greece, should tell Mrs Merkel to give the Greek government the Christoforikos list containing the names of Greek politicians and other actors who took kickbacks from Siemens.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, it is almost unbelievable that we have no more problems in our European Union. I will say this because we have one single common currency for the vast majority of countries, and we have 28 tax systems. Many economists say that this is unsustainable, however, I believe and want our system to remain viable and that is why I am inclined to the variant of harmonisation of the tax system in the eurozone because it is the only possible right and proper way, and a stable way in the long term, to ensure the possibility of investment and everything we know about detecting tax havens and tax fraud.  Who will find it easier to make tax fraud big or small? Of course, large multinationals, not small and medium-sized enterprises. Who will be relieved to create various tax havens? The very people who want to create scams. And that is why I believe that this path taken by the Commission is a good path and I support such a path.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission – I think this debate tonight shows once again that, especially when it comes to tax reform, corporate tax reform, these reforms are often controversial. I think it is clear that there is a consensus that action needs to be taken, and I think this has also been made clear by the work of the special committee on taxation here in this House, Mr Lamassoure.  Some colleagues think that we are moving too fast, that we are going too far and that we are exaggerating and others are sorry that we are not braver, that we do not prescribe more things than we do. I would like to say, in the face of this double criticism, that this plan is well balanced in the Commission, that it is solid and balanced, balanced and also that it is realistic.  Ladies and gentlemen, I want to thank you. Most of you have supported the Commission's approach and I would like to thank you for this broad support for that action programme. In response to some of your interventions, I would like to make the following comments. Firstly, I would like to say something about consolidation. I can assure you that in the form we will give to the common basis for corporation tax, consolidation remains an important, fixed objective that the Commission is pursuing and that we will not lose our ambitions in this area. As far as tariffs are concerned, some of my fellow Members here have also called for a uniformity or harmonisation of those tariffs. Unfortunately, I have to disappoint those people, because it will not be about tariffs. The proposal concerns only the basis of corporation tax, not the rates. Thirdly, I would like to say something about country-by-country reporting. I can assure you - this has also been a question from one of the Members of Parliament - that the entire Commission is determined to take this seriously and to extend the rules to that effect as necessary.  Finally, I would like to point out that the Commission is working constructively with the OECD. I also said it in my introduction. But of course we do not do this without regard to the special features of the systems that are specific to the European Union. You know that the tax systems are very sensitive to abrupt shocks, that they have little resistance to them. In other words, all reforms must be very well documented, thoroughly prepared and also properly implemented. The approach presented today is the right, ambitious but at the same time realistic. A solid, but also flexible approach. We also need this flexibility to adapt to future developments. I am convinced that the Commission,with the proposal I had the honour of explaining here today, on behalf of the Commission, will ensure that there is more justice, that there can be more effective tax collection and that we can and will move towards a tax system that stimulates jobs and growth much more strongly. That's what people expect of us. That is also what the citizens can expect from us. And that is also what we are being asked to do by the business community, but also by small businesses.  It is now up to the Member States to launch themselves, to take control of that dossier.  Ladies and gentlemen, I am also counting on your support to support us in your capitals, but also here in this European Parliament. I think we have a common goal and if we do our best together and put our energy into it and do everything we can to get there, then I am sure that we will be able to take serious steps forward.  We look forward to the debate with you on the matter and thank you very much for this exchange of views.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed.  Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The Commission has presented an action plan to radically reform corporate taxation in the EU. This action plan sets out a series of initiatives to combat tax evasion, ensure sustainable revenues and strengthen the single market for businesses.  The guarantee of effective taxation that companies should pay a fair share of tax in the country where they make their profits is a good measure to combat tax evasion and dumping, but we will have to be very vigilant about how this measure will be implemented so that the Commission does not seek to increase its grip on states and encourages tax harmonisation.  In addition, it is proposed to revive the idea of the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (ACCIS) with a view to having a single business market and a common tax that thus overrides the sovereignty of states that will no longer be able to decide their taxation, which is intolerable.  Finally, the desire to strengthen transparency is obviously in the right direction, but I hope that it will indeed be achieved since the sincerity of the committee on this subject after the LuxLeaks case and the lack of a real decision by the Commission in the wake of this scandal can be doubted.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – The Commission will relaunch its proposal for a common consolidated corporate tax base (BICCIS), as a comprehensive solution for corporate tax reform. Negotiations on the BICCIS proposal submitted by the Commission in 2011 are currently halted. The Commission will immediately begin work on a new proposal to introduce a BICCIS on a mandatory level in accordance with a progressive approach. This will allow Member States to move faster to implement the common tax base. Consolidation would be introduced in a second stage, as this has so far been the most complex element in the negotiations. The Action Plan also addresses the issue of effective taxation in the EU, which is summed up by the idea that companies must pay their share of taxes in the country where they make their profits. According to the Commission, this can be achieved without harmonising corporate tax rates across the EU. In this sense, we must be more ambitious in the legislative field, launch a more comprehensive transparency strategy and aim for the initiative to include the 28 Member States.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. – The Commission will relaunch its proposal for a common consolidated corporate tax base (BICCIS), as a comprehensive solution for corporate tax reform. Negotiations on the BICCIS proposal submitted by the Commission in 2011 are currently halted. The Commission will immediately begin work on a new proposal to introduce a BICCIS on a mandatory level in accordance with a progressive approach. This will allow Member States to move faster to implement the common tax base. Consolidation would be introduced in a second stage, as this has so far been the most complex element in the negotiations. The Action Plan also addresses the issue of effective taxation in the EU, which is summed up by the idea that companies must pay their share of taxes in the country where they make their profits. According to the Commission, this can be achieved without harmonising corporate tax rates across the EU. In this sense, we must be more ambitious in the legislative field, launch a more comprehensive transparency strategy and aim for the initiative to include the 28 Member States.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. – I applaud the European Commission's initiative pursuing the objective of more equitable and effective taxation of EU businesses. It was urgent to present this plan of action for a long time, but it became indeferred after the LuxLeaks scandal. I agree with the fundamental principle that all companies must pay a fair share of taxes where they engage in real economic activity and where they produce their profits. I reiterate my conviction that in the future there should be greater harmonisation of taxation that puts an end to inequality between States, which undermines healthy competition in the Internal Market, because goods produced in European countries where they feel a higher tax burden do not compete on an equal footing with those where they benefit from lower rates.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. – The Commission will relaunch its proposal for a common consolidated corporate tax base (BICCIS), as a comprehensive solution for corporate tax reform. Negotiations on the BICCIS proposal submitted by the Commission in 2011 are currently halted. The Commission will immediately begin work on a new proposal to introduce a BICCIS on a mandatory level in accordance with a progressive approach. This will allow Member States to move faster to implement the common tax base. Consolidation would be introduced in a second stage, as this has so far been the most complex element in the negotiations. The Action Plan also addresses the issue of effective taxation in the EU, which is summed up by the idea that companies must pay their share of taxes in the country where they make their profits. According to the Commission, this can be achieved without harmonising corporate tax rates across the EU. In this sense, we must be more ambitious in the legislative field, launch a more comprehensive transparency strategy and aim for the initiative to include the 28 Member States.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. – Harmonisation of the corporate tax base, which the Commission intends to present within months, is an important step, which Parliament supports, but is far from meeting citizens' expectations and what is really necessary to put an end to tax dumping in the EU.  There has to be a shift in fiscal policy and consultation between Member States, placing an emphasis on transparency. First, you need to know who pays how much and where. We found that countries that wanted to control the budget balances of countries under financial bailouts by imposing harsh doses of punitive austerity on citizens are some of the same ones that for years have struggled to capture their tax revenues.  Almost all the largest companies in Portugal have their holding company in the Netherlands. This is a deeply unfair reality, inexplicable and politically unsustainable for those who, like me, defend and believe in the European project.  Commissioner, you have our support to meet the resistance of the Member States and to carry out a fundamental reform of corporate taxation in the EU.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. - This Action Plan provides a basis on which to build a fairer, more conducive corporate taxation framework for the European Union for growth. The proposed measures will contribute to achieving revenue stability, a stronger single (common) market, greater resilience and efficiency of companies and a fairer and more level playing field for businesses.  Aligning corporate tax rates for businesses is not part of this Action Plan. The aim is to coordinate Member States' tax systems so that they can better combat aggressive tax planning. This Action Plan will be the basis for the Commission's work on corporate taxation policy in the coming years. The key to reforming corporate taxation is ultimately in the hands of Member States, which must overcome differences between them in the name of fairness, competitiveness and efficiency.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. – The Commission will relaunch its proposal for a common consolidated corporate tax base (BICCIS), as a comprehensive solution for corporate tax reform. Negotiations on the BICCIS proposal submitted by the Commission in 2011 are currently halted. The Commission will immediately begin work on a new proposal to introduce a BICCIS on a mandatory level in accordance with a progressive approach. This will allow Member States to move faster to implement the common tax base. Consolidation would be introduced in a second stage, as this has so far been the most complex element in the negotiations. The Action Plan also addresses the issue of effective taxation in the EU, which is summed up by the idea that companies must pay their share of taxes in the country where they make their profits. According to the Commission, this can be achieved without harmonising corporate tax rates across the EU. In this sense, we must be more ambitious in the legislative field, launch a more comprehensive transparency strategy and aim for the initiative to include the 28 Member States.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – In the context of the current global economic situation, in which the European Union competes with strong states and regional structures, we need harmonisation of tax systems in order to benefit all from a coherent and unified environment within the Union that offers equal opportunities for development for all Member States.  Solidarity, which must return to the heart of the concerns of the European institutions, dictates a clear principle: fiscal fairness. Corporations need to give something back to the communities that exist. Therefore, we call for greater transparency of tax obligations for large companies. The fight against corporate tax evasion is a struggle for our medium- and long-term development. Europeans deserve to be informed and to know clearly the profit margin of companies operating in Europe. In this way, we can know very clearly what taxes are due to each Member State and the fact that those commercial entities pay taxes where they produce and profit.  It is basic to have a balance between Member States in terms of taxation for international companies. This balance is needed to provide more resources for the sustainable development of Member States and the prosperity of European citizens.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the one-minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 163).

name: József NAGY
text: – The motivation for migrants is also the imperfect social systems of the target countries in the European Union. Nevertheless, we are not pushing to eliminate the so-called pool effect. I therefore call on Vice-President Timmermans to address the elimination of tempting factors for economic migrants. Illiterate immigrants already know why they are all heading to selected countries of the European Union. The social system of several rich Member States is appealing and destructive as an emmental. They know the weaknesses beyond the EU's borders and are also a sign for those who could thrive at home. Without removing the attractions of a further increase in migration, neither high fences nor quotas nor the introduction of internal border controls between EU states will prevent them. I call on Commissioner Timmermans to prepare a report on the motivating factors on the part of the Member States, to map out their errors in the system and to call for an action plan. Otherwise, it is not the border guards of Frontex or the transit country that can stop the crowds once they have taken to the roads.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Madam President, Europe is today in the midst of a crisis of legitimacy, because it fails to defend its citizens and ensure equal treatment for all, regardless of country or nationality. In this situation are European citizens coming from my country, Romania. Romanians are under-represented at the level of the European institutions and, more specifically, Romania, although it is the seventh state in the European Union, ranks only 22nd in terms of representation in leadership positions in the European institutions.  Romanians are also, lately, stigmatized by several politicians in Europe. For example, the other day in Austria, the foreign minister decided to demand a reduction in social rights for Romanians living in that state.  When, fellow MEPs, are we going to say stop all these abuses? When will we realise that Europe means freedoms and rights for all its citizens? If we are talking today about the issue of the rights of European Romanians, I assure you that if we do not act, we will talk tomorrow about Poles, Greeks, Spaniards, maybe even Germans.  We must build a European society for all and Romanians, like all Europeans, are full EU members.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the troika and the loan lenders continue their blackmail policy against the poor Greek people. I have said this before in this Chamber, the memorandum has failed. The memorandum filled Greece with armies of the unemployed and millions of poor people. It slashed wages and pensions and caused a huge humanitarian crisis. The troika and the lenders got richer and the Greeks poorer. Of the two hundred and fourteen billion euros given as loans to Greece, ninety-six percent of these amounts went back into the pockets of lenders.  Madam President, the troika is continuing its blackmail policy even here at the moment. It tightens the noose around Greece, demands a further reduction in wages and pensions, demands a sell-off of public property instead of a lentil plate, imposes a new unpopular tax policy of eight billion euros, with an increase in VAT on basic food, intensifying the humanitarian crisis. But let the troika know that the Greek people will soon throw it out of our country.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – Despite the late hour, I was going to say a few words about the crisis in Macedonia, which has been waiting at the door of the European Union for 10 years to start the membership negotiations. It is this ai billion waits that are one of the reasons for the general frustration and accumulation of negative political energy, mistrust between the parties, illegality and anomalies of another kind. In the next few days, the flow of events can turn. We have a strong message from the Union's foreign ministers' meeting. We are waiting for the Council's position. On Monday, the presidents of the four most powerful parties will meet again in Skopje to agree on a political crisis solution... a political solution to the crisis. I hope so. I do not think there is an alternative to a political deal. The alternative is only to tighten up and destabilise the country and, perhaps, the regions. Today, the foreign minister of neighbouring Greece visited Skopje for the first time. They found that every problem can be found a solution. Even for the notorious name problem of the state. Together, they found that the two countries wanted stability with themselves and their neighbours. We've waited a long time for this expression of goodwill.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, last week I visited the Mediterranean to see the humanitarian crisis. I visited a centre for young migrants in Catania with accommodation for 36, but housing 64. I visited a reception centre in Pessalo holding hundreds of migrants in conditions worse than in prison. I held a two-month-old old baby called Falestine whose cot is a dirty mattress in a small box—room which also sleeps six women. I hugged a young girl called Happy. In Lampedusa, 400 migrants and refugees are living in overcrowded, cramped conditions. Sometimes there are 1 500; many of them are in the same clothes for two weeks.  The situation is sickening, but nobody puts their children on a boat unless the water is safer than land. We do not need more Frontex: we need more compassion. We need more search and rescue in the Mediterranean, and we need more safe and legal access to Member States.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Madam President, the Spanish Supreme Court said last May that the expansion works on the port of Valencia, one of the most important in the Mediterranean, were illegal. Work began on July 1, 2002, soon to be thirteen years after that disaster. More than a thousand owners of the La Punta area were expropriate, in the best productive orchard in all of Europe. Sixty people were expelled from their homes and centuries-old barracks and barracks were destroyed, a unique heritage already lost forever. The inhabitants of La Punta were harassed, left homeless and landless and all this was done to build a logistics activity area of 680 000 m2, which is completely empty, in which not a single company has been installed. And the European Union gave funds for this illegal, failed and unsustainable project. He is therefore responsible. That is why I am asking here to look for culprits and that the same funds that were given to destroy are now given to rehabilitate that single neighbourhood in Europe, in order to revert to the situation it was in before. It's a matter of elementary justice.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Madam President, in the preparation for the Paris climate conference, the European Parliament's commission sets more ambitious targets, going far beyond what has been achieved so far. A 50% reduction in CO2 emissions by 2030, a complete elimination by 2050, a 45% share of renewable energy by 2030 and a 40% increase in energy efficiency. These goals are unrealistic and are not a solution in themselves. They are unrealistic because they do not take into account the huge costs to the objectives, their impact on the economy and energy prices. They do not provide a solution because the EU is responsible for 9% of global emissions, while China and the US are responsible for 35%. The Paris Conference will be successful if they can finally be persuduced to make a legal commitment.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, the issue of real estate nationalised by the Communist power in Romania has been discussed several times, including in the form of a question addressed to the Commission. We pointed out that the restitution process in Romania had stalled, and even in the case of an important church property, the court decided to renationalisation, condemning the officials who carried out their duties as officials guilty. Despite the unacceptable situation, the European institutions have not spoken or called for account of the commitments made by a Member State.  On June 11, the U.S. Congressional Budget Committee unanimously put the issue of the return of church property in Romania into the Budget of the State Department in Washington, D.C., and within 90 days requested a report from the ministry on this issue. The United States therefore seems to believe that it is important to have human rights and minority rights in an EU Member State, while our own institutions are unable to formulate a coherent position and hold commitments to account in respect of a Member State's policy.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, I would like to refer to the latest report by the International Monetary Fund, which recalled the growing inequalities that europe and the world are going through today and alerted us that inequality today is not only a social problem, but is a serious stumbling block for economic growth. The International Monetary Fund has done so recently, in May, the OECD. Remember some data from my country, Spain. During the economic crisis, the rich in my country have grown by 40%, but at the same time today we have 29% of people – 29% – at risk of social excusion or poverty. Remember that inequalities are the great challenge of our time, which today are getting in the way, hindering economic growth, which are a social disaster; but above all, they are corroding our democracy, European democracy and that of our states, because without a just social model it is impossible to have long-term economic growth and sustainable democracy.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Colleagues, tensions in Bulgarian society have intensified in recent days, caused by the boom in ethnic domestic crime. Clashes and clashes caused by the arrogant and aggressive behaviour of some of their inhabitants are increasingly erupting along the borders of gypsy neighborhoods. Bulgaria faces the brink of social and ethnic clash. Part of the blame for not removing these illegal buildings in the neighborhoods is their protection from European institutions and colleagues who protect them and hinder the equal and uniform application of the laws to all Bulgarian citizens. This is blatant discrimination against the majority of Bulgarian citizens, especially taxpayers, and is an injustice that creates strong social tensions.  There are similar problems at the borders of illegal neighbourhoods in France, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Slovakia and other European countries, indicating that the European approach and model of integration is wrong, wrong and ineffective.  On the other hand, the authorities in Paris, Ghent and elsewhere categorically cannot cope with the integration of the inhabitants of the illegal Gypsy catuni in the way they recommend us, and then try to send them back to Bulgaria. I find this behaviour hypocritical, un-European and dishonest. They are European citizens within the meaning of the TEU, they have the right to free movement and I would very much like to see successful examples of integration at European level. I demand a review of the European Commission's policy on the so-called "no-fly zone". integration, decadi and so on failed endeavors, ending the indiscriminate financing of thieving foundations and NGOs and turning the model to personal responsibility, citizens' obligations and equal compliance with the law.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam Presidents, the European Union and member states need to create a new framework for European shipbuilding. We need a policy redefinition towards European shipbuilding by having vertical and horizontal support, especially to find a financial model for financing European shipbuilding.  Namely, we need to return to the logic that shipbuilding in Europe is a possible strategic industry. So many jobs, so many common products from European countries make up one ship and I am convinced that it is the ship that can become one of the common European products par excellence. Therefore, I propose that we find models of special financing of such common products. Also, we need to simplify many regulations concerning shipbuilding and we should also simply create guarantees that will allow both member states and European institutions to finance shipbuilding.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: – Madam President, we live in convulsive times, times with external and internal tensions.  Tensions arising from the failure of a global order that sought the transfer of all sovereignty. Tensions emerging from a fledgling multipolarity represented by emerging countries. Tensions over a design that punishes our nations from the south and east to indebtedness, deind industrialization and inequality. In this context, the European Union will define its future. You can remain the pawn and board where other people's Atlantic interests are played and defended. You can continue to push for free trade agreements that only guarantee the freedom of large corporations. It can continue to support regional inequality, the destruction of secular states and underpinning ethnic and religious apartheid regimes, or it can turn the course and ensure its presence with sovereignty and independence, with respect for our neighbors and fairly for our peoples and nations.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – The European Commission is currently engaged in the zoning of African swine fever and the introduction of strict restrictions on the territory of Lithuania. Nevertheless, African swine fever continues to spread among wild boars and has recently been found in new areas. Currently, more than half of the territory of Lithuania is infected with this particular disease. The fight against African swine fever urgently requires a unified strategy, which must include concrete actions to eradicate plague between wild boars and protection against the entry of plague wild boar into the territory of the European Union. In countries suffering from African swine fever, it is necessary to step up a citizens' information campaign on the dangers and preventive measures of African swine fever. It is clear that the measures taken so far have not brought the desired result or prevented the virus from entering the territory of the European Union.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the TEN-T project for a new tunnel on the Turin-Lyon line is useless: it destroys nature, it does not create jobs, it increases public debt and it creates opportunities for mafias. Twenty-six years of popular opposition have shown this.  It is false to say that there is a missing link. There is already a grand gabarit tunnel and a modernised and functioning railway line which allows goods to pass under the Alps seven times as much as they pass today and which is part of the Mediterranean freight corridor Number 6, the Rail Freight Corridor 6.  On 26 February 2015, Italy and France sent the European Commission a request for funding for this project. We would point out that the costs of the tunnel have been presented in such a way as to appear to be equivalent to the costs of other tunnels built in Switzerland, but are instead inconsistencies of billions of euros and there is a difference of 5 times between the costs per kilometre between the Italian and the French.  Cost certification should be guaranteed by a third party, while we detect a conflict of interest between TELT and GDF Suez, the certification company.  My colleagues in the 5-Star Movement, the Greens and the GUE have asked Commissioner Bulc to reject the request for funding, not least because of these irregularities. We await an answer.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today in the most important newspapers around the world there are the new wikileaks revelations, which show that three Presidents of the Republic French have been intercepted by the American NSA. What is Europe waiting for to make its voice heard by the Americans to make it clear once and for all whether we are being intercepted? So let us move the European Parliament! I would also appeal to the Commission to make its voice heard on this sensitive issue, which concerns not only privacy, but also security, and I would even say more generally relations between Europe and the United States.  I would also like to point out that in April a Resolution of the Council of Europe called for the establishment of a code du renseignement multilatéral. Well, I'd say it's time to do it, to move from good intentions to facts. We need to regulate seriously and, above all, we need to give a clear answer. Europe must give a clear answer: we do not want to be intercepted by the Americans.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – A jury composed of the President of Parliament, two of its former Presidents, four Vice-Presidents and two other members rejected Slovakia's only nomination for the European Citizen Prize. We have nominated a children's organisation that has been organising Christmas carols associated with a fundraiser for targeted development aid in Africa since 1996. Last year alone, these children raised almost a million euros. In its statutes, this children's Christian organisation shares the principles of the Evangelium Vitae encyclical on the value and intrusibility of human life. However, according to the jury, the encyclical is contrary to the Charter of Fundamental Rights. It is a gross attack on all European Catholics and, at the same time, a make-up of children who are changing lives and the world for the better. I therefore request the annulment of the jury's decision, which, moreover, was taken by only three of its nine members.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, I believe that fundamental rights and freedoms in a democratic society must be a reality. The European Union is considered a community of values based on human dignity, freedom, equality and solidarity.  The free movement of workers is provided for in the Treaty of the European Union and in Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. However, some Member States do not comply with this Regulation. As a Member of the European Parliament, I argue that the regulation of the European Union is necessary and I call on the Commission, the Council and all the European institutions to take the necessary measures to respect all Member States' rights of workers.  I cannot watch carelessly the discrimination made by some states against the citizens of my country and other countries, and I call for the respect of free movement to be pursued. I do not believe that some Member States should choose only what suits them from a treaty, but must comply with all the regulations of the European institutions if they are members of the European Union.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, four months ago my fellow Irish MEPs and I received a letter from Mario Draghi confirming the presence of the Vice-President of the ECB, Mr Vítor Constâncio, at an informal exchange of views with the relevant Irish committees. This was in the context of a letter from all Irish MEPs asking that a suitable representative from the ECB attend the Irish banking inquiry. However, to our dismay, we now hear that Mr Constâncio is withdrawing his offer. In recent weeks there has been seriously-conflicting evidence given to the Irish banking inquiry on decisions on the Irish guarantee and not burning bondholders. These conflicts arise between evidence given by former senior civil servants, one of whom is now a Member of the Court of Auditors, and Mr Jean-Claude Juncker, at an informal meeting in Dublin. So we, as Irish MEPs, are again writing to the ECB to request a meeting with President Draghi, or with Mr Vítor Constâncio, because the very least that Irish citizens can expect is that their elected representatives at European level can obtain all relevant information pertaining to the role of the ECB in the Irish banking crisis. We spent the last one-and-a-half hours in this Parliament talking about transparency. We need it at all levels.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, for so long the so-called institutions and some media have criticised the Greek Government for not putting forward proposals. It wasn't true, but the government made a new proposal the other day. At first everyone said very nicely, it's a very good suggestion, but suddenly they changed their minds and asked for things that are unacceptable. Because the real goal is not to have an agreement. It's this government either falling or being forced to change. Put people in, who are protégés and friends of Europe's great powers.  The question is: can a people respecting the framework of the agreement change the policy of previous governments a little, or not? Why, if not, why are we finally voting? Does the election make sense? They think they're murdering Tsipras and SYRIZA, they're actually murdering democracy.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: – Madam President, this scandal in the European Union, which was caused by the mandate of the company of former Socialist Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsány, Altus Zrt., is not unprecedented. Moreover, history repeats itself, since the case of the President of the Democratic Coalition is eerily similar to the case that took place in 2013 with the wife of the former Bulgarian Socialist Prime Minister Sergei Stanishev, whose PR firm won a €60,000 contract, who also stated that there was no conflict of interest. Of course, the scandal still erupted, with the former Socialist Prime Minister initially defending and fending off, but then repaying the money he had won from the Union. Well, Ferenc Gyurcsány's wife, as company director, also stated that there is no conflict of interest. You may have forgotten the husband of the party leader and his political statements.  As you can see, there is also a difference between socialist prime ministers: the Bulgarian acknowledged the existence of a conflict of interest and even invested the amount won. The Hungarian does not want to hear about his res away from the contract. Of course, maybe it's because the amount is much higher. The Commission's replies do not alter the facts, but only damage the image of the Institutions of the Union. It shouldn't get any worse. I want our constituents to trust me again. Ladies and gentlemen, it is time to investigate this matter.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Mr President, the conference of the parties will discuss in December in Paris how to combat and mitigate the effects of climate change. We all want effective decisions to be taken there.  On a global scale, the barometer for climate change is the Arctic Ocean. This ocean functions as a canary in the coal mine applied to planet Earth. For this reason, it is urgent that the European Union should be granted observer status in the Arctic Council and it is crucial to follow the provisions of the 2014 European Parliament Resolution on the European Union's Arctic strategy. This resolution stresses the importance of management being carried out on the basis of the ecosystem and the identification of marine areas with particular ecological and biological significance, recently recognized and identified under the Convention on Biological Diversity. It is now expected by the next step towards its recognition and this should be given at the level of the parties' conferences.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: – Madam President, it has also caused great consternation internationally that romania's parliament has complicily prevented the launch of criminal proceedings in the serious corruption cases of Prime Minister Victor Ponta. For a quarter of a century now, the Romanian state authorities, which have denied the independence of the judiciary, have made it impossible to bring to justice and hold to account the perpetrators of the december 1989 mass killings, the March 1990 Târgu Mureş carnage and the anti-human crimes of the Bucharest mining district in June 1990. We demand that the former perpetrators be held accountable under the decision of the Strasbourg Court of Human Rights, and that, like Victor Ponta, former President Ion Iliescu and former Director of The Secret Service Virgil Măgureanu are held accountable for their actions before the law.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – At present, the entire European Union is undergoing a very serious test that it is not up to. The migrants showed us our weaknesses. They set us a mirror of the truth about the failure of our democracy export policy. We are also failing the Schengen border system, and the shortcomings of the European Union's inconsistent asylum and migration policy are even more conubering. Readmission and return policy is failing. The uncontrolled arrival of migrants is causing movements promoting xenophobia, intolerance and racism to be activated. We have proposed many solutions, but the first thing that should have been, and we did not propose, was to adopt an embargo on arms exports to states where there are conflicts. The arms business is the evil that causes people to suffer. Therefore, the arms embargo could be the beginning of efforts to stabilise the situation in north Africa and the Middle East. Economic, humanitarian, health and social assistance to people in their native countries should then follow, so that they have no reason to migrate.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Another round of negotiations on migration awaits the European Council in the coming days. I would like to take this opportunity to call on the Heads of State to be really responsible. Millions of citizens in the European Union expect this negotiation to bring about a solution. A solution that is in solidarity but which will also mean greater security. I am glad that Europe has finally woken up, started to act.
