Unfortunately, our European Parliament resolution in April is often reduced by the media only to the issue of mandatory quotas, which I personally reject.  Not only the EU's executive institutions, but also the authorities of the Member States, are reacting too slowly. I would like to point out that, as early as December 2014, we passed a resolution here in the European Parliament calling for a comprehensive approach to migration, strengthening and border control, speeding up the processing of asylum applications and the return of those who are not entitled to it.  I want the Union to be actionable and more European where it is really important for our security. Then we will also take the arguments of the various extremists who are fueling themselves populistally on the current wave.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Madam President, it is a quarter to 11 at night and there is nobody here, but there are some people who are interested in some of the things that we do. I have had 10 000 e-mails in the last month about the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), which we were due to vote on a couple of weeks ago in Strasbourg – that is 10 000 interested constituents and millions of interested constituents all over the continent. We were due to vote here in the European Parliament. There you have some engagement – we are thinking about something and they are interested in it. You would think that would be good news. So what did we do? We cancelled the vote and the discussion because there had been too many amendments and we were not quite ready to do it. We will have had a month by July, so please can we have the vote and the discussion next month and not leave it – and leave these millions of interested people – until the autumn before we bring this back? That would be ridiculous.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – I would like to talk about something that is not much talked about in the European Parliament, and that is the so-called inquiry.  The European Union and its institutions are trying to save as much as possible on their expenditure, and I personally support this very much, but I would like to mention one problem where it really fails at all. I have been warned, repeatedly by several agencies, that the European Commission requires all agencies to translate their texts in a so-called translation centre. The idea seems very good, but according to cost calculations, translations can be doubly expensive through the European Translation Centre compared to if countries translate or agencies translate in those countries. Eurojust is an example. I would therefore ask the European Commission to start really addressing this problem and not to try to centralise everything to Brussels at all costs.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Statements by Foreign Minister Sebastian Kurz on allowances for Romanian children living legally in Austria, namely the intention to pay them at the level of the amount in Romania, demonstrate an unacceptable irresponsibility for a minister of a State that is part of the European Union. I want to believe that it was just a moment of profound intellectual silence for a person lacking the experience of public office. Just as I do not want to believe that Romanians are good for those in western Europe just to build their homes, clean their garbage or defend their borders. Child allowances are not only a right, but also an obligation of the State in which their parents live and work legally, and they must be paid the same, regardless of race or nationality. I warn the Austrian Government, from the rostrum of the European Parliament, that, in the second following such a decision, I will publicly request that all Austrian-owned companies operating in Romania pay taxes to the Romanian State, as well as employees, at the level of the amount in Austria.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The processing of the item is closed.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This is not a matter which was subject to a roll-call vote.  I note that Mr Zarianopoulos wished to address the chamber and explain his perspective on this case, but was not permitted to do so.  I understand that this is an application of Rule 9(8) of Parliament’s Rules of Procedure, and believe that this should be considered for a future rule change. The ‘accused’ should have the opportunity to present their case.  I further note that there was no debate. For the above reasons, on this occasion I decided to abstain rather than vote in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The report of the Committee on Legal Affairs states that the alleged offence has nothing to do with the status of Member of the European Parliament which Sotirios Zarianopoulos can now claim and that he was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time of the events. Therefore, Parliament decided to lift the Member's immunity so that the Greek justice system could judge the case on its merits.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report calls for the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, a non-registered member of the Greek Communist Party.  The report states that Sotirios Zarianopoulos is accused of illegally breaking into the headquarters of Greek public television ERT-3 on 4 March 2010 to interrupt the noon newspaper and read a press release. I voted for this report and the lifting of immunity, because I believe that the facts predate his election to the European Parliament and that he is not subject to political persecution.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the decision to suspend the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos in response to the request made by the Prosecutor's Office of the Supreme Court of Greece in the context of the investigation of an alleged offence committed by the MEP prior to the assumption of parliamentary functions, after illegally breaking into the headquarters of Greek public television ERT-3 on 4 March 2010 and having verified the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament that there is no reason to assume that the procedure is in the attempt to harm the political activity of the Member, especially in view of the that procedure was taken up years before the start of his term of office as such.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which is considering a request for waiver of the immunity of Sotirio Zarianopoulo, a Member of the European Parliament, which relates to a case pending before the Third Single Court of First Instance in Thessaloniki. Sotirios Zarianopoulos is accused of threatening physical violence and illegally entering the premises of the Greek public television channel ERT-3 on 3 and 4 March 2010 to break the midday news and overheat the report. This act is manifestly unrelated to the duties of Sotirio Zarianopoulo as a Member of the European Parliament, since it relates to the actions carried out by the Greek trade union PAME. Moreover, Sotirios Zarianopoulos was not a member of the European Parliament when these actions were carried out. After hearing a member of the European Parliament and examining the documents submitted by him, he decided to recommend the waiver of his immunity.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe that the fact committed by Mr Syderman is a good thing. Mr Zarianopoulos has no connection with his position as a Member of the European Parliament and, therefore, I believe that his immunity should be waived.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. A member of a Greek trade union, Sotirios Zarianopoulos is accused of breaking into a television set, interrupting the newscast using force to read a statement. On the one hand, the facts alleged against him have nothing to do with his work as a parliamentarian, since they predate his election as a Member of Parliament.  On the other hand, I reject the argument that the Member is the victim of any persecution insofar as the procedure began before the beginning of his mandate as an MEP.  That is why I voted to lift immunity.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained. The request for revocation relates to an incident relating to an attempted break-in at the headquarters of a Greek TV in order to interrupt the news and read a press release.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This particular case concerned the waiving of immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, a Member of the European Parliament, as part of an investigation concerning an alleged crime. Sotirios Zarianopoulos has been accused of threatening physical violence and illegally entering the premises of the Greek public television channel ERT-3 on 4 March 2010 to interrupt the midday news bulletin and read out a statement. However, it should be noted that the government at the time forced the closure of the television station. Moreover, Mr Zarianopoulos was a trade union activist at the time who was working with the employees of the television station. There is credible evidence to suggest that these charges are politically motivated and furthermore these charges are being vigorously contested, specifically the accusation that there was forced entry. While it is not up to Parliament to decide whether or not the Member of the European Parliament subject to legal proceedings is guilty, the suggestion of political persecution means that it is quite unlikely that Sotirios Zarianopoulos would receive a fair trial.  It was for these reasons that I voted against waiving immunity in this particular situation.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Supreme Court of Greece has requested the waiver of the immunity of the Member of the European Parliament Sotirios Zarianopoulos, as part of an investigation concerning an alleged crime. Although, during the parliamentary term, Members of Parliament may not be prosecuted, arrested, imprisoned or otherwise confined without prior leave granted by Parliament, the prosecution was initiated a number of years before the Member took up his post. I therefore voted in favour of the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Sotirios Zarianopoulos.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 MEP Sotirios Zarianopoulos is accused of illegally breaking into the headquarters of Greek public television ERT-3 on March 4, 2010 to read a statement. To this end, he interrupted the midday news by resorting to threats of physical violence. The alleged offence is linked to an action by the Greek trade union PAME and took place before the election of the honourable Member, factors which clearly demonstrate the absence of any connection with the position currently held by him. I therefore voted in favour of waiving immunity, so that justice can run its course.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the request to lift Mr Sotirios Zarianopoulos' parliamentary immunity. The facts alleged against him do not relate to his work as a parliamentarian. Mr Zarianopoulos was not yet a Member of Parliament at the time of the events: his use of physical violence to take over the premises of Greek public television took place as part of his participation in the Greek trade union PAME. It can thus be concluded that the proceedings against Mr. Zarianopoulos were not initiated with the aim of interfering with his mandate (fumus persecutionis).

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for waiver of the immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos. In 2014, the President announced, pursuant to Rule 9(1) of the Rules of Procedure, that he had received a letter from the Deputy Prosecutor of the Supreme Court of Greece requesting the waiver of Mr Styrendt's parliamentary immunity. Mr Zarianopoulos. Having examined the documents, the committee decided to ask the EP to decide to waive immunity, considering that the allegations clearly have no relation to the office of Member of the European Parliament of Mr Syp. Mr Zarianopoulos. At the time of the events, Mr De Clercq said that it was not a good example of this. Zarianopoulos, using threats of physical violence, illegally broke into the headquarters of Greek public television ERT-3 by interrupting the midday news and reading a statement. Furthermore, there is no reason to suppose that there is a fumus persecutionis.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the events that led to the Greek Government's request for the waiver of Zarianopoulos' parliamentary immunity pre-election as an MEP and that they have nothing to do with zarianopoulos' current position, I have decided to vote in favour of this request.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Sotirios Zarianopoulos is accused of illegally breaking into the headquarters of Greek public television ERT-3 on March 4, 2010 to interrupt the midday news and read a statement.  The alleged offence has no connection with the position of Sotirios Zarianopoulos as a Member of the European Parliament, given that the alleged crime is linked to an action by the Greek trade union PAME and that Sotirios Zarianopoulos was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time of the events.  According to Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union, an opinion expressed in the exercise of the mandate of a Member of the European Parliament is defined as a subjective assessment with a direct and obvious link with the exercise of parliamentary duties, but the alleged actions of Sotirios Zarianopoulos do not fall within this definition as the criminal proceedings do not concern any opinion or vote expressed in the exercise of the mandate of a Member. There is no reason to assume that the proceedings depend on the intention to prejudice the political activity of the Member (fumus persecutionis), also considering that the proceedings were initiated several years before the beginning of the Member's term of office.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour, initially because we are in favour of the abolition of parliamentary privileges as everyone should be equal in the face of the law. Moreover, this action is indicative of the mentality and authoritarian nature of the Communists.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Sotirios Zarianopoulos is accused of, on March 4, 2010, and resorting to threats of violence, having erupted illegally at the head of public television channel ERT-3, interrupting the midday news to read a statement. This alleged infringement does not relate directly to Sotirios Zarianopoulos' position as a Member of the European Parliament, but is related to an action by the Greek trade union PAME. At the time the facts occurred, Sotirios Zarianopoulos was not a Member of the European Parliament, nor did the legal action relate to any opinion or vote expressed in the exercise of his term as a Member of the European Parliament. I therefore agree with the lifting of parliamentary immunity.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted for this report because the alleged facts predate the beginning of the term of office as an MEP.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of the decision to waive the immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, which was submitted to Parliament by the Deputy Prosecutor of the Greek Supreme Court on 8 December 2014 in connection with the proceedings before the Third Criminal Court in Thessaloniki. The Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Greek Supreme Court has requested the waiver of the immunity of MEP Sotirios Zarianopoulos as part of an investigation into a suspected crime; The main reason in this regard is that the alleged offence is clearly not related to the mandate of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, a Member of the European Parliament, since it relates to the action of the Greek trade union PAME and, moreover, Sotirios Zarianopoulos was not an MEP at the time of the offence. These statements were made in the context of the judicial proceedings against Sotirios Zarianopoulos and it is not for the Committee on Legal Affairs to investigate the case or to decide whether or not the MEP who has been prosecuted is guilty. Therefore, on the basis of the information available to the Committee, there is no reason to believe that the procedure was in order to influence the member's political activities and that the proceedings were initiated many years before that person became an MEP.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the report to waive the immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, given the prosecution was initiated a number of years before Mr Zarianopoulos took up his mandate as MEP.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my colleagues in the Labour Party and the Socialist and Democrats Group, voted in favour of this report, following the recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs to waive the immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, and allow a criminal investigation to take place in his Member State into alleged crimes which took place before his election to Parliament. Waiving immunity will allow for due process to take place and the course of justice to run its path.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request to waive the immunity of Mr Sotirios Zarianopoulos. This parliamentarian is accused of threatening physical violence and illegally invading the Greek television ERT-3 building, seeking to invade the midday news and speak out publicly. Such an act by Zarianopoulos is not related to his parliamentary activities, so the Supreme Court of Greece has the right to request the waiver of his immunity and to initiate legal proceedings. I believe that both meps and other politicians must act ethically and with honour, regardless of the immunity they enjoy.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift Sotirios Zarianopoulos' immunity on charges of physical violence that cannot be linked to the performance of a MEMBER of the European Parliament. In addition, it can be concluded that Mr Zarianopoulos' conduct is not related to the vote or expression of opinions in the context of parliamentary activities. Therefore, since Mr. Zarianopoulos invokes so-called fumus persecutionis, I believe that the truth and Mr. Zarianopoulos's eventual innocence will prove before court instances.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Mr Zarianopoulous entered the building of the ERT-3 television channel under the threat of violence to read out a statement. This was done before the start of his mandate as an MEP. His actions are therefore unrelated to his role as a Member of the European Parliament, so that the possibility of waiving immunity can be exercised. In order to preserve the credibility of Parliament and its Members, I am voting in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons for the proposal to waive immunity.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. Sotirios Zarianopoulos is accused of illegally breaking into the headquarters of Greek public television ERT-3 on 4 March 2010 to interrupt the noon newspaper and read a press release by resorting to physical violence. I voted to lift his immunity, because this grievance predates his election to the European Parliament and has nothing to do with his duties as an MEP.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 MEP Sotirios Zarianopoulos is an independent member of the European Parliament and a member of the Economic and Monetary Policy Committee, the Special Committee on Tax Decisions and other measures of a similar nature or effect, and the Delegation to the Joint Parliamentary Committee of the Republic of Macedonia. Greece's Deputy Attorney General has applied for immunity to be lifted over a charge that on March 4, 2010, he entered the headquarters of greek public broadcaster ERT with threats of physical violence to stop the broadcast of the afternoon daily. I support MP Laura Ferrara's report and the decision based on the Opinion of the Legal Affairs Committee to lift MP Zarianopoulos' immunity. Zarianopoulos was not a member of the European Parliament at the time of the offence and there is no doubt that the proceedings will harm his political activity in Parliament.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. In the European Parliament, it has become fashionable to accept all requests for withdrawal of parliamentary immunity. Our group shares this view: the independent court will establish the truth. The competent committee recommended lifting immunity after evaluating all pros and cons. That is why I voted to withdraw immunity from Mr Sotirios Zarianopoulos.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, because the waiver of my colleague's immunity paves the way for the prosecution of a political nature aimed at criminalising his political activity.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. I expressed my opposition to the request for the waiver of the immunity of Mr Sotirios Zarianopoulos because I believe that parliamentary immunity is not a personal privilege of a Member but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament and its Members as a super partes institution. I remain convinced that a guarantee line must be followed in these cases, so I will continue to vote against this type of report in defence of the institutional role conferred by this Parliament.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I would have voted in favour of the request to waive Mr Zarianopoulos' immunity. In my view, the intention was not to affect the political activity of the honourable Member and the incident cannot be linked to his work in the European Parliament. The facts thus before us are the responsibility of the Greek courts, and the European Parliament should not stand in the way of the work of that very body.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report regarding the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos as the alleged offence and the ensuing prosecution have nothing to do with the position of Mr Zarianopoulos as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour on the report to waive the immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, Member of the European Parliament, who is accused of having threatened physical violence and illegally entered the premises of Greek public television channel ERT-3 on 4 March 2010 to interrupt the midday news bulletin and read out a statement.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In its investigation, the Committee on Legal Affairs found no reason to believe that the Greek authorities' proceedings were aimed at influencing the member's political activities, and that the proceedings were initiated much earlier than the election of Mr Zarianopoulos as a Member of the European Parliament. I therefore voted in favour of the request on the recommendation of the Legal Affairs Committee.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The lifting of a Member's parliamentary immunity must remain the exception, and be limited to cases of prosecution for crimes or misdemeanours of a certain gravity, which cannot amount to any form of political pressure or censorship. In this case, the prosecution of Mr. Zarianopoulos' action does not clearly exclude a form of politicization of prosecutions, so it is preferable to abstain on the claim against him.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of withgoing the application for immunity, as approved by the committee responsible in the European Parliament. The infringement in question dates back to 2010 and is not yet in the position of Member of the European Parliament. Therefore, the alleged infringement does not relate to the activity of an MEP, in accordance with the Rules of Procedure and the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The lifting of the immunity of Greek Communist Party MP Sotirios Zarianopoulos is requested following an outburst at the headquarters of the state television ERT that led to physical violence, in order to interrupt the lunchtime newscast and read a press release.  Considering that the alleged events took place in 2010, well before he took office as an MEP, that they are also foreign to his status as a Member of Parliament, and that the prosecutions are not on grounds that could hinder the Member's political action, I have decided to vote in favour of the lifting of immunity.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting sotirios Zarianopoulos' parliamentary immunity. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant parliamentary committee. I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 On 4 March 2010, Mr S.P. Sotirios Zarianopoulos has been accused of illegally breaking into the headquarters of Greek public television ERT-3, using threats of physical violence and interrupting the midday news conference to read out a personal statement.  In the light of the above, I supported Mrs Ferrara's request to waive her immunity because the alleged crime has no connection with the position of Member of the European Parliament. Furthermore, there is no reason to assume that the procedure depends on the intention to prejudice the political activity of the Member (fumus persecutionis), since it was initiated several years before the start of the European mandate.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report in accordance with the resolution and analysis of the report.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Sotirios Zarianopoulos is accused of illegally entering the studio of the Greek public television station ERT-3 on 4 March 2010 under the threat of physical violence, in order to interrupt the midday news and read out a message. The alleged offence appears to have no connection with the office of Sotirios Zarianopoulos as a Member of the European Parliament, since the alleged offence is linked to an action by the Greek trade union PAME and since Sotirios Zarianopoulos was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time of the incident. I voted in favour of the deprivation of liberty at the expense of Sotirios Zarianopoulos and Am in favour of waiving parliamentary immunity until this case is resolved and no more accusations are made.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 On the question of waiving Mr Zarianopoulos' immunity, I agree with the conclusion reached by the Committee on Legal Affairs. Since the legal process instituted against his colleague by the Hellenic Court is prior to the beginning of his term of office as a Member of the European Parliament, immunity does not exist.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation because, although prosecution is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EIA, it is not related to the opinion expressed or to vote in the performance of its duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, and the alleged offence is clearly in no relation to the performance of my colleague Uspaskich's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee is not competent to assess whether the prosecution was initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the Member Concerned (fumus persecutionis) because it was initiated before Mr Zarianopoulos became a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ In order for MEPs as representatives of EU citizens to be credible, it is important that parliamentary immunity serves only as an instrument to protect them from politically motivated persecution. The purpose of parliamentary immunity is never to place MPs above the law, but serves their smooth and independent action. In the case of Greek MEP Sotirios Zarianopoulos, the EP's Legal Affairs Committee argued that there are no grounds in the case to assume that the procedure is aimed at harming the political activity of lawmakers, as the proceedings were initiated several years before the start of the MPs' mandate. Except for this reason, I support this report because it can be concluded that the alleged unlawful conduct of Greek MEP Sotirios Zarianopoulos, who is accused of threatening physical violence, cannot in any way be linked to the performance of an honorable function as an MEP. In accordance with the presumption of innocence, and since Representative Zarianopoulos invokes the so-called fumus persecutionis, I believe that the truth and the eventual innocence of Mr. Zarianopoulos will be proven before the competent court instances.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The alleged offence for which the waiver of sotirios Zarianopoulos' immunity was requested does not relate to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament but to facts related to an action by the Greek trade union PAME of which he was a member when he was not yet a Member of the European Parliament. In the lack of fumus persecutionis, the request for revocation is perfectly valid in accordance with eu legislation.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 On 8 December 2014, the Attorney General of the Supreme Court of Justice of Greece requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Sotorios Zarianopoulos in the context of the investigation of proceedings for an alleged offence, related to the fact that that Member of the European Parliament had erupted illegally at the seat of the public television channel ERT-3, using threats of violence , and interrupted the midday news to read a statement. Under Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. According to the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, Article 8 of the Protocol does not apply in this case, since the alleged infringement does not relate to the position of Member of the European Parliament, but is related to an action by the Greek trade union PAME, and that, at the time of the events, Sotorios Zarianopoulos was not a Member of the European Parliament. On that basis and on the basis of that report, I voted in favour of this Decision to lift the immunity of Sotorios Zarianopoulos.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. With the adoption of the Ferrara report, MEPs followed the advice of the Legal Affairs Committee, which had recommended by a very large majority that Parliament lift the parliamentary immunity of Greek MEP Sotirios Zarianopoulos. The prosecutor of the Supreme Court of Greece accuses him of having, by resorting to physical violence, illegally broke into the headquarters of the Greek public television ERT-3 on 4 March 2010 to interrupt the noon newspaper and read a press release.  The lifting of a parliamentarian's immunity follows a very rigorous procedure. In the case of the MEP, immunity falls under Article 9 of the European Union's Privileges and Immunities Protocol and can, as a general rule, be lifted when the offence is absolutely not related to the exercise of the office of a Member of Parliament. The same article also stipulates that immunity cannot be invoked in the case of flagrante delict and cannot prevent the European Parliament from exercising its right to waive the immunity of one of its members. This derogation is most often justified either by the seriousness of the alleged facts or by the need to make the judicial decision quickly.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the decision to suspend the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos in response to the request made by the Prosecutor's Office of the Supreme Court of Greece in the context of the investigation of an alleged offence committed by the MEP prior to the assumption of parliamentary functions, after illegally breaking into the headquarters of Greek public television ERT-3 on 4 March 2010 and having verified the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament that there is no reason to assume that the procedure is in the attempt to harm the political activity of the Member, especially in view of the that procedure was taken up years before the start of his term of office as such.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Mr. Sotirios Zarianopoulos, so that the Greek justice system can continue its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, considering that the alleged facts - having broken into the headquarters of the Greek public television ERT-3 to interrupt the noon newspaper and read a press release - have nothing to do with the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament (the proceedings having been initiated several years before the start of the (mandate) and are not motivated by the desire to interfere with the MP's political action.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ There is no reason to assume that the intention underlying the criminal proceedings is to damage a Member’s political activity, given that the prosecution was initiated a number of years before the Member took up his post. For this reason, we voted to waive the immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the request to waive the immunity of a fellow MEP elected for Greece. The laws must apply to all EU citizens, and neither public officials nor politicians can have an exception. As the Deputy Prosecutor of the Supreme Court of Greece requested the waiver of the immunity of MEP Sotirios Zarianopoulos in connection with a criminal investigation, Parliament granted the prosecutor's request. Sotirios Zarianopoulos was supposed to have committed the crime back in 2010 when, under threat of physical violence, he illegally broke into the headquarters of Greek public television, disrupting the broadcasting process and reading his own statement. Although a Greek colleague claims that the charge is politically motivated, by waiving his immunity, he will have the opportunity to defend himself before law enforcement.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this Report because, as stated in the Report itself, the alleged offence is clearly not in any way linked to the function of a Member of the European Parliament and there are no grounds on which it can be assumed that the aim of the procedure is to damage the political activity of members, as the procedure itself was initiated before the term of office of the Member.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The criminalisation of political and trade union action on workers' rights is a practice affecting the Republic. During his hearing in the EP's Committee on Legal Affairs, MEP Zarianopoulos demonstrated the political nature of his prosecution by providing solid evidence that the protest performance for which he is accused and the reading of a short strike bulletin was made with the agreement of journalists, without in the least disrupting the smooth operation of the station. His prosecution is directed against the fight for the rights of workers, against the workers themselves, since it criminalizes their action, but ultimately also against the Republic itself.  Under no circumstances could we support such a practice. That is why we voted against the proposal to waive immunity in the belief that unsubstantiated accusations and prosecutions against the COMMUNIST Party MEP would fall into limbo.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 MEPs should be held to account in court when the need to investigate their activities is required, in accordance with existing legal procedures.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The person in charge of the case considered it clear that the alleged offence was unrelated to the status of Member of the European Parliament which Sotirios Zarianopoulos can now claim, as this alleged offence is part of an action by the Greek trade union PAME and sotirios Zarianopoulos was not a Member of the European Parliament at the time of the events. Therefore, in order for the Member to be able to explain himself freely before the courts of his country, a waiver of immunity was voted.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted to lift the immunity of MP Sotirious Zarianopoulos, who is accused of using threats of physical violence in March 2010 to illegally enter the headquarters of the 3rd programme of the greek public broadcaster ERT with the aim of interrupting the afternoon daily and reading the statement.  In my view, this High House should not induse the powers of judicial authorities and study the circumstances in which the offence of which the Member is charged, but after considering all relevant evidence, make the best decision that will not devalue the activity of the Member. I firmly believe that any form of violence in any context cannot be justified and therefore I support the decision that in this case Representative Zarianopoulos should reasonably face the offence of which he is charged and thus show responsibility, primarily to the viewers of greek public television and the citizens whose interests he represents.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report by the Committee on Legal Affairs concerning the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Sotirios Zarianopoulos, following the request by the Greek judicial authorities.  I believe that the charges against Zarianopoulos are not of a political nature, as he claims, but a part of the legal obligations that he, like any other civilian, has. The waiver of Mr Zarianopoulos’ immunity goes in the right direction and I hope that after the trial in Greece, the truth will prevail.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Sotirios Zarianopoulos (deputy of the Greek Communist Party) is accused of, on March 4, 2010, and resorting to threats of violence, having erupted illegally at the head of the public television channel ERT-3, interrupting the midday news to read a statement. At the time, Zarianopoulos was a trade union leader and the act he is accused of in Greece is related to an action by the Greek trade union PAME. Sotirios Zarianopoulos argues that his immunity should not be lifted because he did not exercise any action of violence. COMM JURI watched the video with the news footage and there is no sign of violence. On the other hand, journalists testified that no act of violence against them was perpetrated. He considers it political persecution. The shadow rapporteur, Kostas Chrysogonos (GUE/NGL), considers that persecutions against Sotiris Zarianopoulos are openly political and can undermine trade union activity in Greece, threatening the freedom of trade unionists in the country.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the request to waive Mr Zarianopoulos' immunity. In my view, the intention was not to affect the political activity of the honourable Member and the incident cannot be linked to his work in the European Parliament. The facts thus before us are the responsibility of the Greek courts, and the European Parliament should not stand in the way of the work of that very body.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. According to the report under consideration, Mr Sotirios Zarianopoulos - deputy of the Communist Party of Greece - is accused of illegally breaking into the public television channel ERT-3 on 4 March 2010, interrupting the midday news to read a statement. At the time, Zarianopoulos was a trade union leader and the act of which he is accused in Greece is related to an action by the Greek Trade Union PAME. It is clear that the persecutions against Zarianopoulos are openly political and an attack on trade union activity in Greece, threatening the freedom of trade unionists in the country. We voted against the lifting of parliamentary immunity.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of transparency I would like to confirm that I voted in favour of this waiver.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The lifting of immunity is requested for an ongoing legal proceeding in which Mr. Voigt is accused of inciting violence and insulting in a meeting in a national democratic party publication published at the time of the 2006 World Cup, for which he was responsible as party chairman. I approved this request to waive immunity.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report calls for the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Udo Voigt, a non-registered member of the German NDP. The report states that Udo Voigt is accused of a collective insult with incitement to racial hatred. At the 2006 World Cup, his party published a calendar of World Cup football matches with the inscription "Wei- nicht nur eine Trikotfarbe" ("White - not just a jersey colour") with a black player on the team. I voted for this report and for the lifting of immunity because I believe that the facts predate his election to the European Parliament and that he is not subject to political persecution.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the decision to suspend Udo Voigt's parliamentary immunity following the request made by the presiding judge of the Kammergericht in Berlin concerning a legal action concerning an alleged crime committed by the European parliamentarian, who is accused of instigation and collective slander in a publication of the National Democratic Party that came to light during the 2006 FIFA World Cup and for which he was responsible as a party president, facts unrelated to his role as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which is considering a request for waiver of the immunity of Mr Udo Voigt, a Member of the European Parliament. He is accused of inciting against any nation, race, ethnic, religious or other group of people and collective insults in a publication by the German National Democratic Party (German National Democratic Party). Nationaldemokratische Partei Deutschlands (NPD) spent the 2006 FIFA World Cup for which he was responsible as party chairman. Udo Voigt submits that the duration of the proceedings initiated in 2006 demonstrates a desire to prevent his parliamentary work, but since the current request for waiver of immunity is due to additional proceedings initiated as a result of the remedy used by Udo Voigt himself, the principle of that objection is nemo auditur propriam turpitudinem allegans (lot). "no one can rely on their own scourge"). The European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs recommends waiving the immunity of Udo Voigto and to refer that decision to the competent Supreme Court of the Land of Berlin for further consideration of the case of that parliamentarian.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe that the fact committed by Mr Syderman is a good thing. Voigt has no connection with his position as a Member of the European Parliament and, therefore, I believe that his immunity should be waived.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. Udo Voigt is accused of collective insult and incitement to racial hatred. The facts alleged against him are unrelated to his work as a parliamentarian as they predate his election as a Member of Parliament.  On the other hand, I reject the argument that the Member is the victim of any persecution insofar as the procedure began before the beginning of his mandate as an MEP. That is why I voted to lift immunity.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention. The request for revocation relates to attacks deemed offensive and published by the magazine of the National Democratic Party of which Voigt was president and referring to the Football World Cup.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This case concerned racist remarks made by Member of the European Parliament Udo Voigt in his position as chairman of the National Democratic Party. They relate to the FIFA World Cup in 2006 in which Udo Voigt spoke about a German national football player, saying that a ʽblack player wearing a white jersey does not make him part of a national German teamʼ, and some more general racist abuse. These remarks are unconnected to his position of MEP and it was for this reason that I voted in favour of waiving this immunity.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The presiding judge at the Kammergericht of Berlin has submitted a request for waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Udo Voigt in connection with legal action concerning an alleged offence. MEP Voigt has claimed that the length of the proceedings, which were initiated in 2006, demonstrates a desire to obstruct his parliamentary work, but this claim has been rebuked as the accusation relates to actions carried out in 2006, which is well before Udo Voigt was elected to the European Parliament in 2014.Therefore it was agreed to waive the parliamentary immunity of Udo Voigt. I voted in favour of this request.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 In this case, in voting on the request for waiver of immunity, I decided to follow the rapporteur's opinion.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the parliamentary immunity of Mr Udo Voigt, who must be able to be tried by the courts of his country for an offence which has nothing to do with his work as a Member of the European Parliament. Prosecuted for inciting racial hatred, Mr. Voigt has already been convicted by the trial court and the regional court, including publishing a calendar at the 2006 World Cup that stated "White, not just a jersey color". With Mr Voigt having lodged an appeal, the German justice system should be able to continue its course in line with the constitutional court's jurisprudence on freedom of expression issues.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for the waiver of Udo Voigt's immunity. In 2014, the President announced, pursuant to Rule 9(1) of the Rules of Procedure, that he had received a letter from the President of the Berlin Court of Appeal requesting the waiver of Mr Sn.'s parliamentary immunity. Voigt. Having examined the documents, the committee decided to ask the EP to decide to waive immunity, considering that the allegations clearly have no relation to the office of Member of the European Parliament of Mr Syp. Voigt. At the time of the events, Mr De Clercq said that it was not a good example of this. Voigt was accused of incitement and collective insults launched in a publication published by the National Democratic Party (NPD), at the time of the 2006 FIFA World Cup, for which he was responsible as party chairman. Furthermore, there is no reason to suppose that there is a fumus persecutionis.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the fact that the immunity provided for in Article 8 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union does not apply to this case, I have decided to vote in favour of this request for waiver.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The President of the Berlin Court of Appeal has submitted a request for the waiver of Udo Voigt's parliamentary immunity. Under Article 9 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament shall enjoy, on their national territory, the immunities accorded to members of their country's Parliament.  Udo Voigt is accused of incitement and collective insults launched in a publication published by the National Democratic Party at the time of the 2006 FIFA World Cup. The accusations are clearly alien to Udo Voigt's position as a Member of the European Parliament and are attributable to his position as Chairman of the National Democratic Party. In fact, the alleged actions do not relate to opinions or votes cast by the Member of the European Parliament in the performance of his duties, in accordance with Article 8 of Protocol 7, also taking into account the fact that the accusation relates to actions dating back to 2006, well before he was elected to the European Parliament in 2014.  There can be no suspicion of any attempt to obstruct the parliamentary activity of Udo Voigt (fumus persecutionis), having been initiated a few years before he took up his seat in the EP.  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against, despite the fact that we are against parliamentary privileges, as everyone should be equal before the law. In this particular case, however, the judiciary serves political interests, and it also accuses Mr Voigt of crimes of opinion by clearly violating his right to freedom of speech.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Udo Voigt is accused of incitement to hatred and collective injury in the context of a publication, released at the time of the 2006 FIFA World Cup by the National Democratic Party and for which he was responsible as Party President. Udo Voigt claims that the length of the process, which began in 2006, demonstrates a willingness to obstruct his parliamentary work. However, there is no relationship between the accusations and the functions of Udo Voigt as a Member of the European Parliament nor the alleged acts are related to opinions or votes cast by the Member of the European Parliament in the performance of his duties. I therefore agree with the lifting of parliamentary immunity.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, because the alleged facts predate the beginning of the term of office as an MEP.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of the request for the waiver of Udo Voigt's immunity and for Parliament to decide to waive Udo Voigt's immunity, which was submitted by the President of the Kammergericht Berlin on 9 February 2015 and notified in plenary on 25 March 2015. The President of the Kammergericht Berlin has requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Udo Voigt in connection with a legal procedure relating to a suspected crime. In my opinion, the fact that Udo Voigt is accused of incitement and collective defamation in connection with a publication published by the National Democratic Party during the FIFA World Cup in 2006, for which he was responsible as party chairman, is a serious charge which requires careful consideration and investigation. The allegations are clearly not related to Udo Voigt's position as a Member of the European Parliament and the alleged acts are not linked to the opinion expressed by a Member of the European Parliament in the performance of his duties, and in view of the fact that the prosecution relates to the acts of 2006, which is well ahead of Udo Voigt's election as a Member of the European Parliament in 2014, a waiver of immunity is justified.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report to waive the immunity of Udo Voigt who is accused of incitement and collective insults in a publication issued by the National Democratic Party at the time of the 2006 FIFA World Cup, given the proceedings were initiated a number of years before Mr Voigt took up his mandate in the European Parliament.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my colleagues in the Labour Party and the Socialist and Democrats Group, voted in favour of this report, following the recommendation by the Committee on Legal Affairs to waive the immunity of Udo Voigt, a German MEP, to allow for a criminal investigation to take place in his Member State into alleged crimes which took place prior to his election to the European Parliament. Waiving immunity will allow for due process to take place and the course of justice to run its path.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request to waive the immunity of Mr Idot. Udas Voigtas is accused of inciting discord and insults that were declared during the 2006 FIFA Cup by the National Democratic Party, because Voigtas, as party chairman, is responsible for party publications. This misconduct is not directly linked to Voiguto's activities in the European Parliament, so the Berlin court has the right to initiate legal proceedings. I believe that both meps and other politicians must act ethically and honorably.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's proposal to lift Udi Voigt's immunity, as the alleged offence in question was committed before Mr Voigt became a Member of the European Parliament, i.e. when he was president of the National Democratic Party. Moreover, this offence is not related to the expression of opinion or voting, but is a allegation of incitement to hatred and group insult. I therefore support the waiver of Mr Voigt's immunity, which is also the position of the ALDE group.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons for the proposal to waive immunity.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. Udo voigt of the German NPD is accused of collective insult with incitement to racial hatred. At the 2006 World Cup, he published a calendar of World Cup football matches with the inscription "Wei- nicht nur eine Trikotfarbe" ("White - not just a jersey color") with a black player on the team.  On 12 May 2014, the Berlin Regional Court (Landgericht) sentenced Udo Voigt who appealed. The appeal process has been served in the Court of Appeal since December 17, 2014. I voted to lift his immunity, because this grievance predates his election to the European Parliament and has nothing to do with his duties as an MEP. Marine Le Pen, to whom I personally exposed this matter, called on the entire FN delegation to vote like me.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Independent German MEP Udo Voigt is a member of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs and the Delegation for Relations with Iran. In his report, The Rapporteur of the Committee on Legal Affairs Tadeusz Zwiefka approved the waiver of the immunity of Voigt MEPs. The president of the Berlin regional appeals court has demanded the lifting of Udi Voigt's parliamentary immunity due to legal proceedings for the alleged offence of inciting hatred. During the 2006 FIFA World Cup, the National Democratic Party of Germany published a publication allegedly inciting hatred, with MP Voigt as party chairman at the time. I supported the lifting of the immunity of MEP Uda Voigt, as the allegations are not related to the performance of his duties in Parliament, with a purpose of continuing the investigation process.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. In the European Parliament, it has become fashionable to accept all requests for withdrawal of parliamentary immunity. Our group shares this view. That's why I voted to withdraw Deputy Udo Voigt's immunity.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the request for the waiver of Udo Voigt's parliamentary immunity, following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I would have abstained from voting on the request for the waiver of Mr Voigt's immunity, since the indictment against him and the related request are due to a restriction of his political activity and cannot be ruled out that this is a politically motivated action.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report regarding waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Udo Voigt as the alleged offence and the ensuing prosecution have nothing to do with Mr Voigtʼs position as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the report to waive the immunity of Udo Voigt, Member of the European Parliament, who is accused of incitement and collective insults in a publication issued by the National Democratic Party at the time of the 2006 FIFA World Cup, for which he was responsible as the party chair.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Legal Affairs concluded during its investigation that the allegations against Mr Voigt relate not to his position as MEP but to his position as Chairman of the National Democratic Party, and that the charge relates to an act which took place eight years before Mr Voigt was elected as an MEP. I therefore voted in favour of the request on the recommendation of the Legal Affairs Committee.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The lifting of a Member's parliamentary immunity must remain the exception, and be limited to cases of prosecution for crimes or misdemeanours of a certain gravity, which cannot amount to any form of political pressure or censorship. In this case, the prosecution of Mr. Voigt's action does not clearly exclude a form of politicization of prosecutions, so it is preferable to abstain on the claim against him.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 After evaluation by the committee responsible on the request for waiver of immunity, I voted in favour of this report. The alleged acts committed are not related to opinions or votes cast as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The lifting of the immunity of MP Ugo Voigt of the German NPD party is requested. He is accused of collectively insulting the German football team during the 2006 World Cup. Indeed, his party had then published a calendar with the inscription "White - not just a jersey color".  Mr. Voigt was already sentenced at trial on 12 May 2014, before he took office. However, he appealed this decision, so his immunity must be waived.  Considering that these facts predate his election to the European Parliament, and that these prosecutions show no political persecution, I have decided to vote in favour of this lifting of immunity.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Udo Voigt's parliamentary immunity. Any request made to the President of the European Parliament by the authorities of a Member State to waive a Member's immunity is heard by the relevant parliamentary committee. I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Udo Voigt is accused of incitement and collective insults launched in a publication published by the National Democratic Party at the time of the 2006 FIFA World Cup, for which he was responsible as party president.  Given that the alleged crime has no connection with Udo Voigt's position as a Member of the European Parliament, I have decided to support the request for waiver of immunity. Furthermore, there is no reason to assume that the procedure depends on the intention to prejudice the political activity of the Member (fumus persecutionis), since it was initiated a few years before he occupied his seat in the European Parliament.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report in accordance with the resolution and analysis of the report.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Udo Voigt was indicted for incitement and collective insult in a publication published by the National Democratic Party during the 2006 FIFA World Cup, for which he was responsible as party chairman. In this case, too, I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 As has already been said several times in such cases, I am in favour of not applying immunity in the case of proceedings or events that occurred before the election of a Member of Parliament to the highest European Assizes. From my point of view, therefore, I can only agree with the final result of the vote.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation because, although the prosecution is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EIA, it is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EEA. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, and the alleged offence is clearly in no relation to the performance of his duties as a member of the European Parliament, there is no reason to assume that the prosecution was brought with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis) because it was initiated before Mr Voigtu became a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ In order for MEPs as representatives of EU citizens to be credible, it is important that parliamentary immunity serves only as an instrument to protect them from politically motivated persecution. The purpose of parliamentary immunity is never to place MPs above the law, but serves their smooth and independent action.  The report on the request to lift Udi Voigt's immunity states that Voigt was accused of incitement to hatred and group insults in a publication published in 2006 by the National Democratic Party of Germany, when Voigt was at the helm. In the case of Voigt, the EP Legal Affairs Committee considers that there is no reasonable doubt in the case for attempting to disrupt the work of MEPs, so-called fumus persecutionis, and that the proceedings were initiated several years before Udo Voigt became an MEP. At the same time, it is clear that the charges voigt is charged with are neither linked to the performance of his or her duties as an MEP nor are they related to the expression of an opinion or the vote of Members of the European Parliament in the performance of his or her duties within the meaning of Article 8(1) of the EIA. Protocol No. 7 on EU privileges and immunies. Consequently, I supported the Report.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 In the case of Udo Voigt, too, the legal rules of the European Parliament must be applied. Immunity is normally waived where the offence falls within the scope of Article 9 of the Protocol provided that there is no fumus persecutionis, i.e. the sufficiently serious and precise suspicion that the case is brought before a court with the intention of politically harming the Member concerned. The hearing in the Committee on Legal Affairs did not show that there was fumus persecutionis, since the events had taken place before Voigt was a Member of the European Parliament. The alleged crime and subsequent legal action have nothing to do with Voigt's post as a Member of the European Parliament. The unanimous vote of the Committee on Legal Affairs also demonstrates this, hence my vote in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the waiver of immunity in the case of Mr Uda Voigt, because I believe that the German courts should be able to decide whether, as chairman of the NPD political party, he did not commit a breach of the law by publishing a publication at the time of the World Cup which may have contained racist attacks on players of the German national team. These activities and the opening of investigations took place long before he was elected to the European Parliament and therefore cannot in any way be regarded as a political obstruction of the exercise of his mandate as a Member of the European Parliament. In general, I believe that freedom of expression is our key value, but it cannot be thought that this freedom has no boundaries or that there may be statements spreading racial or class hatred within it.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 On 9 February 2015, the Presiding Judge of the Kaammergericht (Court of Appeal) of Berlin requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Udo Voigt in the context of a lawsuit, in which the alleged Member of the European Parliament is accused of incitement to hatred and injury because of a publication, published at the time of the FIFA World Cup 2006 by the German National Democratic Party , of which he was then President. Under Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. According to the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, Article 8 of the Protocol does not apply in this case, since there is no relationship between the accusations and the functions performed by Udo Voigt as an MEP, but is related to his position as President of the German National Democratic Party. Accordingly, and on the basis of the JURI report, I voted in favour of this Decision on the waiver of Udo Voigt's immunity.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. With the adoption of the Zwiefka report, the European Parliament lifts the parliamentary immunity of MEP Udo Voigt, as requested by the President of the Kammergericht in Berlin, and thus follows the advice of his Committee on Legal Affairs. Udo Voigt, often referred to as a "neo-Nazi" by the international press, is accused of inciting violence and collective insults in a 2006 publication of the National Democratic Party, the most radical party of the German far right, of which he held the presidency.   The lifting of a parliamentarian's immunity follows a very rigorous procedure. In the case of the MEP, immunity falls under Article 9 of the European Union's Privileges and Immunities Protocol and can, as a general rule, be lifted when the offence is absolutely not related to the exercise of the office of a Member of Parliament. The same article also stipulates that immunity cannot be invoked in the case of flagrante delict and cannot prevent the EP from exercising its right to waive the immunity of one of its members. This derogation is most often justified either by the seriousness of the alleged facts or by the need to make the judicial decision quickly.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the decision to suspend Udo Voigt's parliamentary immunity following the request made by the presiding judge of the Kammergericht in Berlin concerning a legal action concerning an alleged crime committed by the European parliamentarian, who is accused of instigation and collective slander in a publication of the National Democratic Party that came to light during the 2006 FIFA World Cup and for which he was responsible as a party president, facts unrelated to his role as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting Mr. Udo Voigt, so that the German justice system can continue its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, considering that the facts in question - incitement to violence and insults in meetings in a publication of the National Democratic Party published at the time of the 2006 FIFA World Cup - are clearly unrelated to the function of Udo Voigt as a Member of the European Parliament and are the result of president of the National Democratic Party.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ There can be no suspicion of any attempt to obstruct the parliamentary work of Udo Voigt behind the proceedings, as they were initiated a number of years before he assumed his seat in the European Parliament. We voted to waive the parliamentary immunity of Udo Voigt.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Report because as stated in the Report itself, there is no reasonable doubt for attempting to disrupt the work of members. The charge itself relates to acts committed in 2006, and the proceedings were initiated several years before the MPs' mandate. The offence is in no way linked to the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. In this respect, we are against parliamentary privileges, as everyone should be equal before the law. In this particular case, however, the judiciary serves political interests, not the administration of justice.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Udo Voigt is accused of inciting violence and insulting people in a meeting in a national democratic party publication published at the time of the 2006 FIFA World Cup, for which he was responsible as party president. The charges are clearly unrelated to the position of Member of the European Parliament occupied by Udo Voigt and are the result of his position as President of the National Democratic Party. In any event, it is acceptable that his immunity may be waived so that he can explain himself before the courts of his country.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted to lift the immunity of MP Voigt, who was accused of incitement to hatred and group insults in a publication published by the National Democratic Party of Germany during the 2006 FIFA World Cup, for which he was held accountable as the party's president at the time.  Since Mr Voigt did not hold his parliamentary office at the time and was not a Member of the European Parliament, I consider that the request for the waiver of immunity in this case is justified and that it is indisputable to assume responsibility relating to his duties as Party President.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of Udo Voigt's immunity as the charges presented are not related to his duties as an MEP.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report by the Committee on Legal Affairs concerning the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Udo Voigt. I strongly believe that all Europeans should enjoy equality before the law, so the justice system can decide about accusations of any kind. I do not think that our parliamentary immunity should exclude us from the legal procedures and obligations that our fellow citizens have to respect.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. During the 2006 FIFA World Cup, the Party newspaper published a calendar with the Party logo, with the following title - "Let's go the whites", which in the context of the time was considered incitement to hatred and collective violence. He later made public statements where he made it clear that, in his opinion, only white players should play for the German team. Udo Voigt was the President of his Party at the time of these events. We are voting in favour of the lifting of parliamentary immunity.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the request for the waiver of Mr Voigt's immunity, because the indictment against him and the related request are due to a restriction of his political activity and cannot be ruled out that this is a politically motivated action.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. This report deals with the request for the waiver of parliamentary immunity of Mr Udo Voigt, elected by the National Democratic Party of Germany, a far-right party. During the 2006 FIFA World Cup, his party's newspaper published a calendar with the party logo and the following title - "Let's go the whites", considered incitement to hatred and collective violence. He later made public statements, arguing that only white players should play for the German team. Udo Voigt was the President of the Party at the time of these events. We voted in favour of lifting parliamentary immunity.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, I am glad to welcome this European Fund for Strategic Investments that may help to kick start investment and, hopefully, produce growth within the EU over the coming years. The fund was launched last November and Parliament has played its role today in moving the process forward and in supporting the start-up of this fund. We have put in a number of positive changes, ensuring that more money goes to Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility, or – in truth – taking less from these. I am pleased to see that Ireland has already submitted a number of projects through the EU and European Investment Bank project pipeline. A project involving 14 primary care centres has already been submitted as one of the first projects with the potential to be supported by this fund. Some of these primary care centres are located in Kilcock in County Kildare, Tuam in Galway, Westport, Claremorris, Ballinrobe in County Mayo, Ballymote in Sligo and Boyle in County Roscommon. These will be very significant investments, not only in health infrastructure but also in people’s health.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – At this late time, I'd like to cut it a little short and lighten up a little bit.  I personally consider the proposal to be a great success, and not just for the European Parliament. It is important that the European Union is able to respond to the current situation and I would like to thank the Juncker Commission for this whole initiative.  I believe that drawing on this fund, as is currently legally set up, will not only benefit individual actors, but above all will show great added value for the European Union.  However, an important issue that remains unanswered for me is the level of private sector involvement in individual projects, so I firmly believe that Mr Juncker will give us a thorough answer in the coming days.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. \u2012 The EFSI has very broad support both among Member States and in the European Parliament. In Parliament, the proposal has been drawn in the right direction on crucial points: reducing the erosion of European research appropriations, the full inclusion of Member States' contributions in the budgetary rules of the Stability Pact and the fact that the ETUC should not be an excuse not to implement the necessary structural reforms. Unfortunately, in the negotiations with the Council of Ministers, the European Parliament has had to give in to several of these important demands. It is noteworthy that the Swedish Government in the Council of Ministers has supported taking money from research, injecting new money and loosening the budgetary rules in the Stability Pact. The EFSI does not solve the basic problem of a reduction in Europe's levels of investment. Europe has gradually become too over-regulated, sluggish and expensive to invest in. In order for Europe to become more attractive to invest in, it is necessary to implement reforms that strengthen countries' competitiveness and reduce financial deficits. Now it is crucial not to lose focus from what is really needed to increase the willingness to invest in Europe. Countries with great need for reform cannot hope for money from Brussels to take it out of the crisis, and therefore refrain from carrying out the necessary reforms. In such cases, the lower levels of investment are likely to be permanent.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) because I believe that the outcome achieved by the European Parliament following tough negotiations with the Council marks the concrete achievement of our priority of reorienting European economic policy towards growth and investment.  We have made FEIE an investment tool that promotes projects in line with our political priorities.    The agreement reached ensures the financing of quality investments, facilitates additional co-financing for all Member States, strengthens the governance of THE EIE within the European framework and proposes more appropriate and ambitious alternative funding from the Guarantee Fund to safeguard European R&D&I and transport programmes, Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Mechanism with an additional EUR 1 billion.  This is a good agreement which will give an urgent impetus to much-needed investments in the Union.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that this Fund will achieve its stated aims, and also have serious misgivings about the means by which capital is to be raised.  Public-private partnerships, as shown by the PFI schemes in the UK, combine not the best but the worst of public and private sectors.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. For the Juncker Plan to be a success and for investment to return to Europe, it is crucial both to achieve the single market, which is still too fragmented, to remove doubts about the future of Greece and the euro area, to closely involve SMEs and to prevent the EFSI from paving the way for a de-depresoliation of public spending. The European Parliament will therefore have to remain vigilant. Let us declare our confidence and meet the Member States for the revision of the multi-year financial framework, a great opportunity to restore payment credits for the Horizon 2020 and MIE programmes.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the European Investment Plan presented by the Commission, which aims to mobilise EUR 315 billion in aid. support for the recovery of the EU economy. It strengthens the supervision of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the role of the EP in appointing its management, and also clarifies the structure of the fund's funding. The new Fund will take over part of the new fund from Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility. However, in order to maintain successful programmes, it is ensured that the "cuts" of these programmes are reduced. I agree that the creation of quality jobs should become one of the criteria for selecting projects financed by the new fund.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The progress made between the final text and the initial announcement of the Recovery Plan should be noted. I am pleased that the social sector, education and health are finally among the possible areas of intervention. In addition, the Juncker plan will primarily benefit SMEs, the main source of economic recovery in many EU countries, including Belgium, and will encourage regional participation.  These advances achieved through the work of left-wing forces in the European Parliament fully justify full support, although it will be necessary to remain vigilant about the extent of effective job creation by the selected projects.  Thus, the public guarantee granted to private investment must have the imperative corollary to create growth and employment. The Fund's tracking scoreboard, another significant improvement, will be crucial in this regard in assessing job creation, the impact on growth, the volume of private investment and respect for leverage. Finally, while we can welcome the forthcoming implementation of the Juncker Plan, European decision-makers must be bold and courageous in abandoning the austerity in force in many countries, a policy that is humanly dramatic and economically ineffective.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing.
