The European Fund for Strategic Investments (FEIE), the cornerstone of the Juncker Plan, aims to increase investment in the European Union and promote economic recovery by supporting economically viable projects that are not currently being developed because private investors doubt their financing. The creation of this Fund gives us a unique opportunity to relaunch the Union's economy. However, we consider that such funding should not be detrimental to the budgets of other key European research projects, such as Horizon 2020 or the Connecting Europe Facility. From UPyD we consider it a breakthrough that the EIES Board of Directors is composed of representatives of the Commission and the European Investment Bank, and not by the States themselves. In addition, the selection of projects by an Investment Committee made up of independent experts will allow the selection of projects to be carried out on the basis of objective and solvency criteria that avoid political opportunism, friendliness and misuse of money for all Europeans. That is why we have decided to vote in favour of this Regulation.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. 'Growth in Europe is gradually picking up again. Yet too many Europeans are not seeing much of this resurgence in their daily lives. Unemployment is still unacceptably high in many Member States. To turn the tide, the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) is a very important and hopeful instrument. €315 billion in additional investment in the euro area; it should create a million new jobs over the next three years. One of the important dimensions and objectives of this fund is to restore confidence, the confidence to reinvest in ambitious projects. These projects will be submitted from a local level, in the Member States, preferably through a national investment platform. This is how they have to support the local economy.  Parliament's swift decision will help the European Investment Fund get off the ground. Now we also need a final and balanced agreement on Greece, at the EU summit, so that we can finally pry our way out of the valley and help our economy to achieve solid growth rates, so that there is finally justifiable hope and a concrete perspective for all fellow Europeans looking for a job.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The EFSI should be part of a comprehensive strategy to remove uncertainties that are holding back public and private investment and to reduce investment delays in the EU in order to boost competitiveness. It must also ensure better access to finance for companies with up to 3,000 employees, giving priority to SMEs and small mid-cap enterprises. The total envelope of this fund must be 21 billion euros. I remain convinced that the impact on investment will remain limited, because leverage is overestimated (X15!) and it is enough to see this with the 2012-13 2012-2013 Growth and Employment Pact. This plan will encourage the windfall effect for some companies that would have invested anyway and worse, it is worrying in several respects since it encourages public-private partnerships, requires structural reforms (labour market...) yet ineffective and will accentuate territorial disparities in favor of large urban areas and profitable projects at the expense of our countryside and medium-sized cities. SMEs are not likely to see money coming from Brussels, especially if the funding threshold is up to 3,000 employees, whereas I had proposed an amendment in committee to limit investment to companies with up to 500 employees; amendment, of course, rejected. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the aims that led to the creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) are acceptable, I cannot dispel my reservations about what the real functioning and impact of this instrument will be. I believe that it is a plan based on bold hypotheses to say the least, which only in theory should generate a leverage effect of as much as 1 500%, moreover using funds that are in fact subtracted from those already destined for Horizon 2020. For all these reasons, I did not support this report with my vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted against the report. The idea of an investment plan for Europe is a good one, but the current proposal is not a real investment plan, as it is not in fact real investment with real money. A key element of the current proposal is the desire for large private investment, the main motive of which will be the desire for profit and not to combat unemployment and growing social inequalities in europe. We know that there is enormous need for investment throughout europe; for example, to strengthen infrastructure, develop renewable energy, improve the public sector and welfare. Massive and real green investment in these sectors would boost the economy, create lots of new jobs and help solve many of the structural and social problems that EU countries face today. However, this requires a rethink from the EU, it requires leaving the market-liberal approach of austerity policy and recognising that massive public green investment is needed above all. I would support such an aggressive investment plan, but the current proposal is quite different. That is why I am voting against.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) because I believe that the outcome achieved by the European Parliament following tough negotiations with the Council marks the concrete achievement of our priority of reorienting European economic policy towards growth and investment.  We have made FEIE an investment tool that promotes projects in line with our political priorities.    The agreement reached ensures the financing of quality investments, facilitates additional co-financing for all Member States, strengthens the governance of THE EIE within the European framework and proposes more appropriate and ambitious alternative funding from the Guarantee Fund to safeguard European R&D&I and transport programmes, Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Mechanism with an additional EUR 1 billion.  This is a good agreement which will give an urgent impetus to much-needed investments in the Union.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because Europe urgently needs a new and complementary initiative aimed at growth and new jobs. In this context, we should welcome the proposal to establish a European Fund for Strategic Investments, which could ensure , while implementing other measures, immediate economic stimulus. It is to be hoped that this fund will increase much-needed medium and long-term employment, if well designed and managed. The fund is expected to mobilise EUR 315 billion over three years. This will create a direct and indirect amount of EUR 1,3 million. additional jobs. The potential impact of the Fund on employment will depend on a number of factors, in particular on the fund's ability to support projects with job creation potential, the extent of private capital raising, the compatibility of the Fund with other measures taken and timely access to funds and additional measures in labour markets. In order to make the European Fund for Strategic Investments more effective, the European Commission will also initiate and support additional measures to ensure greater regulatory predictability and remove barriers to investment, which will make Europe a more attractive place for investment.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcomed the decision to establish a European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), which is in line with the objectives of the Hungarian economy, as it will provide a new kind of financing opportunity for financial service providers and companies. I am convinced that the Fund will also support risk finance for SMEs and mid-caps across Europe. It will help to bridge the capital gap by means of larger direct capital investments and additional guarantees for high-quality securitisation of SME loans. Estimates that the investment package could increase the European Union's GDP by up to EUR 330-410 billion over the next three years and create between 1 and 1.3 million new jobs appear to be well founded.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a regulation we are voting on today on the European Fund for Strategic Investments is one of the central moments of this parliamentary term.  This is an important step, which I support and which identifies the ambitious path to be followed in order to restore confidence in the potential of the European economy and its policies.   The ability to deliver urgent action and the sharing of guarantees between Member States and the European Investment Bank will help to deploy the investment needed to modernise Europe and its infrastructure, as well as to stimulate the participation of private investors. I think it is important for the Fund to provide for a specific impetus of EUR 75 billion for the benefit of small and medium-sized enterprises. Parliament's role in drawing up the draft is also crucial, succeeding in strengthening the steps on flexibility for the contribution of the Member States and the additional nature of the projects to be approved. The action we will take in the implementation of the plan shows the internal CONSULTATION within the EU necessary for the implementation of the projects that must respond to the important challenges we face.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the amendment which called for the Commission proposal to be rejected in this resolution. Put simply, the Commission’s proposal is an unmitigated disaster with no redeeming features. The fact of the matter is that EUR 2.7 billion from Horizon 2020 and EUR 3 billion from the Connecting Europe Facility was going directly into the European Investment Bank (EIB) before there was any Juncker plan. Much of it is a sophisticated subterfuge in order to increase the powers of the European Investment Bank and create new structures within its framework. With regard to the legislative resolution I tabled a negative vote. While of course I welcome real investment, the European Fund for Strategic Investments (ESFI) does not go anywhere near real investment and more importantly it does not address the gaping hole we have in public investment as a result of continuous austerity policies. Critical engagement with the Plan is still fundamental but as it stands the resolution is inadequate and irresolute and it was for these reasons that I voted against this resolution.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the Union, having focused, for a long time, on austerity, must now take action to bring growth back to our continent and I am convinced that the European Fund for Strategic Investments is a key instrument for achieving this goal.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The activation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments is a victory not only for us progressives but for all citizens who want a Europe that is more attentive to the needs of workers, entrepreneurs and those who live in the territory and want to work to improve it.  The investment plan puts quality as well as quantity at the centre: it not only supports our economy but also helps to push it in the direction of more sustainable development. By focusing more investment on renewable energy sources, energy efficiency, intelligent interconnection networks, the circular economy, resource efficiency, it is possible to stimulate growth and work towards a new European green economy.  EFSI alone is not enough, but it is a very useful tool to overcome this moment of crisis, going beyond the dogmatism of austerity and austerity policy. Thanks to the European Fund, we can look at sustainable and intelligent development, while safeguarding the importance of the Horizon 2020 objectives, the European Research and Innovation Programme, and the Connecting Europe Facility, the European Infrastructure programme and the Digital Agenda, which should be strengthened and refinanced in the coming years.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), billed as the plan for a surge in European growth, confirms its smoky nature. Supposed to create a leverage of 315 billion euros from a guarantee of 21 billion, it still does not meet the expected public. More worryingly, the Member States called to pay to the Juncker plan are promised that the sums committed to the regulatory framework of the Stability and Growth Pact will not be taken into account. This proposal risks drying up the public financing channels of the State/Region Plan contracts and the European Structural Funds (FEDER - ESF). Under the Juncker plan, Member States will be reduced to the role of the European Union's back-up force and forced to pursue the austerity policies demanded by the European Commission. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the measure. EFSI is presented as functional to austerity and wage deflation. Instead, Europe needs investment and recovery.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the recent economic and financial crisis, European actors are supporting an increase in investment in the EU to cover the investment gap generated. This investment deficit has created a downward spiral of spending cuts, rising unemployment and a loss of confidence in future progress.  Introducing new incentives to increase investment, by supporting them with guarantees, can increase the confidence of investors, public authorities and the industrial sector. By unlocking new investments, the EFSI can become the cornerstone of an investment cycle that creates new jobs and opportunities. These new investments are not only needed to relaunch the Union economy, but also to transform it into a sustainable, innovative and circular economy.  It is also particularly important for the EFSI to strengthen these policies and contribute to their materialisation, with a focus also on the transformative investments needed for a sustainable and low-carbon transport infrastructure, for a digital and research infrastructure, for renewable energy creation, for energy efficiency and energy storage, and for the placing on the market of new products innovative services and technologies.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) because I believe that the outcome achieved by the European Parliament following tough negotiations with the Council marks the concrete achievement of our priority of reorienting European economic policy towards growth and investment.  We have made FEIE an investment tool that promotes projects in line with our political priorities.    The agreement reached ensures the financing of quality investments, facilitates additional co-financing for all Member States, strengthens the governance of THE EIE within the European framework and proposes more appropriate and ambitious alternative funding from the Guarantee Fund to safeguard European R&D&I and transport programmes, Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Mechanism with an additional EUR 1 billion.  This is a good agreement which will give an urgent impetus to much-needed investments in the Union.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European Fund for Strategic Investments aims to boost investment, supporting growth and creating new jobs. It will accompany the European Union in its economic recovery. Thanks to the European guarantee, investors will be able to invest in projects of a riskier and longer-term nature. It will also particularly encourage private initiatives. SMEs will be among the major beneficiaries of this project. Today, the resources for innovation and research are in sharp decline. This is a worrying situation which undermines the competitiveness of European products and services in the global market. This fund will give a boost to the fields of research and innovation. Implementation as soon as possible is essential. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). The economic crisis and the overly strict budgetary constraints imposed by the European Union on the Member States have led to a significant decline in investment in Europe. This situation is slowing down the economic recovery, with a negative impact on job creation, long-term growth prospects and competitiveness. Firm action by the European Union is therefore needed to break the vicious circle caused by the lack of investment and to remedy the growing disparities between regions. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the report on the European Investment Fund, which aims to address the endemic lack of investment, putting it back at the heart of the Union's policies in order to increase the competitiveness of the Member States.  In order to launch a lasting growth mechanism that will also lead to the creation of new jobs, effective and economically and socially sustainable structural reforms by the Member States remain necessary, as well as the promotion of initiatives such as training programmes and active labour market policies.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the amendment which called for the Commission proposal to be rejected in this resolution as, put simply, the Commission’s proposal is an unmitigated disaster with no redeeming features.  The fact of the matter is that EUR 2.7 billion from Horizon 2020 and EUR 3 billion from the Connecting Europe Facility was going directly into the European Investment Bank (EIB) before there was any Juncker plan. Much of it is a sophisticated subterfuge in order to increase the powers of the European Investment Bank and create new structures within its framework. With regards to the legislative resolution I tabled a negative vote. While of course I welcome real investment, the ESFI does not go anywhere near real investment and more importantly it does not address the gaping hole we have in public investment as a result of continuous austerity policies. Critical engagement with the Plan is still fundamental but as it stands, the resolution is inadequate and irresolute and it was for these reasons that I voted against this resolution.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) is at the heart of Commission President Juncker’s Investment Plan. It is the main channel to mobilise EUR 315 billion in new investment in the real economy over the next three years. The Fund will be established within the EIB, with which the Commission will work as strategic partner. It will finance projects with a higher risk profile, thereby maximising the impact of public spending and unlocking private investments. I fully agree with this Fund as a way to create more jobs and growth and voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 This agreement will be presented by Juncker Commission supporters as a success that can revive the economy, development and employment in Europe, also since the investments of this programme will not be included in the calculation for the deficit-to-GDP ratio of the Stability and Growth Pact. This measure can therefore be seen as a non-obvious admission of the unsustainability of the pact's rules, and then it should be noted and radically changed, not by granting this wretched contentment.  Apart from the questionable procedural issues highlighted, we still have a number of concerns, starting from the fact that it is open to companies with up to 3 000 employees (certainly not SMEs) to the point of considering that priority will be given to major infrastructures and energy projects that cannot really be defined as sustainable, and in this direction the main projects presented by Italy also go in this direction. The main focus on private investment is also very risky, because it is clear that in the event of bankruptcy the guarantees will serve to cover their losses in the first place, and there is a risk of bankruptcy situations similar to those that occurred through the Project Bond Initiative, of which the EFSI follows in practice the modalities.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this report on Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments. The Fund, created as part of the Juncker Plan, is supposed to boost European investment, with an investment volume of 315 billion euros or 2.2% of the EU's GDP. While I am obviously in favour of investment being stimulated and facilitated for European businesses, the Fund, as it is designed, does not seem to be promised concrete efficiency, particularly for SMEs. Priority is given to projects with high economic profitability. I am also sceptical about the real impact that such a fund will have on investment: we remember that the "growth and jobs" pact of 2012 promised to create 60 billion euros and actually ended at 20 billion. On the other hand, the promise of investment assistance is still accompanied by interference in national public policies, with counterparties required for structural reforms, for example, on the labour market: a step in the way of states that the IMF's research department has already deemed ineffective in terms of growth.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The new European Commission led by the President of Juncker, together with the hard work and intensive work of the European Parliament, led by the two rapporteurs, Jose Manuel Fernandes and Udo Bullmann, who deserve the congratulations of all of us, have managed in record time to draw up an investment plan aimed at EUR 315 billion. It is trying to create new economic data in Europe. A very ambitious project which, whether one agrees or disagrees, must all admit that for the first time the EU, through the European Commission, is responding with a concrete plan to the large growth deficit that Europe has been suffering from for several years. The Juncker Investment Plan aims to combat unemployment by creating thousands of new jobs and creating growth prospects. Without exaggeration, with cautious optimism and with confidence in the European Commission's new important investment initiative, we expect it to successfully achieve its goals for growth, employment and competitiveness, which are also our objectives, in our small country, Cyprus. That is why we have supported with all our might this important initiative by the European Parliament and the EU.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). The global economic and financial crisis has had a profound impact on investment in Europe, with a decrease of around 15% compared to 2007, or around EUR 430 billion. In some EU countries, including Italy, the decline was more pronounced. In order to respond quickly to this problem, the Juncker plan provided for the establishment of the EFSI.  The Fund will be financed through an EU guarantee of €16 billion and €5 billion allocated directly by the EIB and, thanks to the expected multiplier effect, will be able to mobilise €315 billion of investment, of which €75 billion will benefit SMEs. Investment will be concentrated in some key areas of the European economy (infrastructure, energy, research). Some bodies (steering committee, investment committee) will manage the Fund, while technical advice is entrusted to a European Investment Advisory Centre. Finally, a reserve list of investment projects is created in order to provide investors with transparent information on potential projects benefiting from the Fund.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I consider the European Fund for Strategic Investments to be an important and fundamental step towards reviving the European economy. Because of the economic and financial crisis, the European Union has been struggling to attract new investment for far too long, and this Fund aims to make it more attractive to invest in Europe by improving its infrastructure and economic competitiveness, with an eye to the regions that have been most affected by the crisis.  I believe that trying to mobilise EUR 315 billion is an ambitious but necessary objective to encourage public investment such as private investment and that, thanks to the EU Guarantee Fund and the strategic partnership with the European Investment Bank, this objective can be achieved. The main aim is to intervene in the real economy by reducing unemployment, promoting economically sustainable investment projects and reducing regional disparities. This release of liquidity will have to be accompanied by major structural reforms by the Member States, which will have to be economically and socially sustainable. For all these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour, because I believe that we must do everything possible to stimulate economic growth and to give new confidence to European entrepreneurs and workers.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I congratulate Mr José Manuel Fernandes for his excellent work as Rapporteur for the Juncker Plan. While I have some doubts about the success of this instrument, I agree that we must give priority to policies that stimulate growth and create jobs. I welcome the fact that of the total of 315 billion, 75 billion are earmarked, preferably, for projects that include Small and Medium-sized Enterprises. I particularly applaud that, on a proposal from the Rapporteur, it has been enshrined: - Strengthening investment in the countries that need it most - contributing to economic, social and territorial cohesion is a selection criterion; - the enhancement of the merits of projects, which cannot be harmed by the difficult economic situation of its Member State; - Support to investors by creating an Investment Advisory Platform; - Ensuring a transparent process - approvals will be public and disapprovals communicated to the European Parliament. I sincerely hope that this plan will contribute to portugal's economic recovery and job creation.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 There is no doubt that Europe is still suffering from a lack of investment, caused both by the negative economic and financial situation and by the budgetary constraints imposed on the Member States. In this context, the European Fund for Strategic Investments represents an important opportunity to stimulate economic recovery and to increase the competitiveness of European companies. This is necessary not only to foster future, sustainable and intelligent growth, but also to ensure that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy become achievable.        In the light of these considerations, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Written. \u2012 The EFSI has very broad support both among Member States and in the European Parliament. We Moderates have taken the proposal in the right direction and succeeded in getting the European Parliament with us on crucial points: reducing the erosion of European research appropriations, the full inclusion of Member States' contributions in the budgetary rules of the Stability Pact and the fact that the ETUC should not be an excuse not to implement the necessary structural reforms. Unfortunately, in the negotiations with the Council of Ministers, the European Parliament has had to give in to several of these important demands. It is noteworthy that the Swedish Government in the Council of Ministers has supported taking money from research, injecting new money and loosening the budgetary rules in the Stability Pact. The EFSI does not solve the basic problem of a reduction in Europe's levels of investment. Europe has gradually become too over-regulated, sluggish and expensive to invest in. In order for Europe to become more attractive to invest in, it is necessary to implement reforms that strengthen countries' competitiveness and reduce financial deficits. Now it is crucial not to lose focus from what is really needed to increase the willingness to invest in Europe. Countries with great need for reform cannot hope for money from Brussels to take it out of the crisis, and therefore refrain from carrying out the necessary reforms. In such cases, the lower levels of investment are likely to be permanent.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the "Juncker Plan", promised and promoted by the new Commission to revive the European economy. In committee, the M5S proposed an alternative vision to the original text, through some seventy amendments, which ranged from a true and 'restrictive' definition of SMEs, to a guarantee cover to be found, for example, within the pre-accession IPA funds, and finally to binding criteria for the choice of truly sustainable projects and better and more transparent governance.  I voted against this report because, apart perhaps from this last point, on which some progress has indeed been made, the rest has remained highly unsatisfactory for the M5S, the result of an armoured agreement between the People's Party and the Socialists who have not tried to protect this text in every matter without wanting substantial changes. Our vote was therefore against both the substance of the text and the method by which this whole process was handled.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today we are giving the green light to the initiative which, for the time being, at least in intention, marks the reversal of the trend towards a Europe of rigour and austerity that we have not only never loved, but which has, above all, proved inadequate to meet the challenges of the crisis, ultimately aggravating its social and economic consequences. The plan is not a cure-all, it is not a magic intervention that, on its own, can rekindle the engines of growth and can never be enough unless it is implemented in a synergistic and complementary way with the other resources that the Union makes available to the States. However, it has a high symbolic as well as economic value.  Parliament has significantly improved the initial proposal and, despite the general scepticism, has helped to dismiss a strengthened text, starting with the declaration on the exclusion of all contributions paid by the Member States from the calculation of the deficit. A victory for those who, like the S&D Group, have always fought to introduce flexibility mechanisms that favour investments. More needs to be done now, really involving local authorities in the development of EFSI projects, reconsidering the top-down approach, in order to bring it closer to the needs and needs of territories and citizens.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 It is to be welcomed that, in the case of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the investment package is completely separate from the resources of cohesion policy. €5 billion will be provided from the €8 billion needed to replenish the EU guarantee fund behind the package. The eur 5 billion redeployment concerns the CEF by EUR 2.8 billion and the H2020 programme by EUR 2.2 billion. From the horizon 2020 programme, it is a success that the reduction is reduced compared to the Commission's proposal. The good news is that the programme to broaden the participation of the new Member States will not be affected by the reduction.  The creation of EFSI will provide a new type of financing opportunity for domestic financial service providers and companies. The Fund will also support risk finance for SMEs and mid-caps across Europe. It will help to bridge the capital gap by means of larger direct capital investments and additional guarantees for high-quality securitisation of SME loans. SMEs will be able to benefit from pre-financing grants before efsi is fully set up. It is estimated that by 2020 the investment package could increase the EU's GDP by up to EUR 330-410 billion and create between 1 and 1.3 million new jobs. In line with the European People's Party, I supported the adoption of the proposal.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ As a rapporteur for the ENVI Committee on the EFSI, I focused mainly on the environmental criteria that projects which will be financed should fulfil. The EFSI criteria are an acknowledgment that economic growth and environment sustainability can go hand in hand and be complementary rather than contradictory to one another. The economic situation of the EU as it stands today needs a boost, but the investment should be channelled to those projects which can truly make a difference and provide the required boost to economic growth and job creation. The way EFSI has been negotiated is directed towards reorienting the European economic policy towards growth and investment. This is an opportunity that can help the EU’s economy to go back on track and give positive results which can be felt by our citizens. For these reasons I voted in favour of the EFSI.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted whole much in favour of the agreement reached with the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), the so-called 'Juncker Plan'. The adoption of this new instrument is a concrete and significant response to the need to reverse the course of European economic governance and confirms the commitments made a few months ago by the European institutions under the Italian Presidency, thanks to the action of our government.  Intelligent use of flexibility and a new focus on investment and growth policies have now been high on the European political agenda. The European Parliament, for its part, has, in recent months, made an important contribution to the definition of an instrument that is effective, transparent and democratic, and has also found an excellent compromise on the origin of the funding of the Juncker Plan.  It is also of great importance that operations supported by the Fund should have a higher risk profile than normal projects already financed by the European Investment Bank, thus ensuring effective additionality, and should focus on areas crucial to the economic and social development of the Union and its internal market, such as research and development, infrastructure, digital content and infrastructure and energy.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With this vote, we have reached an important milestone in the Juncker Investment Recovery Plan: the creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). This, with EUROPEAN Union guarantee funds, is expected to mobilise EUR 315 billion in public and private funding for investment projects in all Member States over the period 2015-2017. Announced in November 2014, the implementation of the EFSI demonstrates the willingness of the Commission led by Jean-Claude Juncker to keep its promises. It is now up to the Council to make a quick decision.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments is undoubtedly one of the most important measures of this year of the legislature, and has been one of the Commission's priorities.  The main objective of this fund is to overcome the lack of investment, which is particularly serious for those Member States most affected by the economic crisis. Furthermore, in order to strengthen confidence in the Union, it is necessary to encourage, above all, those investments which lead to an increase in jobs. Particular attention has been paid to financing that benefits small and medium-sized enterprises and encourages the creation of start-ups and enterprises in the social and solidarity economy. Finally, it was decided to reduce regional disparities in order to encourage competitiveness and innovation, while at the same time measures were supported for the energy-efficient transition to a sustainable circular economy. Therefore, I believe that the regulation goes in the direction we want: sustainable and intelligent growth that pay attention to the social dimension, succeeding in achieving the Europe 2020 objectives.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The Juncker Investment Package would mobilise EUR 315 billion in capital for European transport, energy, digital and social investment and, through venture capital loans, would help businesses with up to 3 000 employees, mainly SMEs, to raise funds. The three pillars of the investment package are, on the one hand, the setting up of a new fund, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, on the other hand, the creation of a list of feasible developments and the adoption of an internal market roadmap that removes administrative barriers. From a Hungarian point of view, the biggest success is that the investment package is completely separate from the resources of cohesion policy, and in the case of Horizon 2020, the basic research lines that are our priority are not affected by the redeployment, including the programme to broaden the participation of the new Member States.  Moreover, it is important to point out that the amounts withdrawn from the CEF transport, digital and energy network programme do not have a meaningful impact on activities (investments, projects) of Hungarian interest. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), which is in line with the objectives of the Hungarian economy, as it will provide a new kind of financing opportunity for domestic financial service providers and companies.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. \u2012 From a Hungarian point of view, the greatest success is that the investment package is completely separate from the resources of cohesion policy. €5 billion will be provided from the €8 billion needed to replenish the EU guarantee fund behind the package. The eur 5 billion redeployment concerns the CEF by EUR 2.8 billion and the H2020 programme by EUR 2.2 billion. From the horizon 2020 programme, it is a success that the reduction is reduced compared to the Commission's proposal. From a Hungarian point of view, it is important that, in the case of Horizon 2020, the programme that is our priority and which wants to broaden the participation of the new Member States is not affected by the reduction. The establishment of EFSI is in line with the objectives of the Hungarian economy: it will provide a new kind of financing opportunity for hungarian financial service providers and companies.  The Fund will also support risk finance for SMEs and mid-caps across Europe. It will help to bridge the capital gap by means of larger direct capital investments and additional guarantees for high-quality securitisation of SME loans. SMEs will be able to benefit from pre-financing grants before efsi is fully set up. It is estimated that by 2020 the investment package could increase the EU's GDP by up to EUR 330-410 billion and create between 1 and 1.3 million new jobs. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments and amending the regulations (EU) 1291/2013 and (EU) 1316/2013. This plan, beyond being insufficient, testifies once again to the nonsense of the Union's policy. Wouldn't it be wiser to put an end to austerity policies, rather than to develop investment plans to contradict them? The Union should stop its permanent interference in the policies of the Member States so that they can serve the interests of their citizens. To be in favour of a European-wide plan whose results are more than uncertain would be irresponsible.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ The final drafting protects the current multiannual financial framework (MFF), does not allow for politicisation of the guarantee, reduces redeployment from Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) by EUR 1 billion, as well as ensuring the protection of basic research funding and a continual assessment of the impact on affected budget lines. The fund is also limited to three years with the possibility of renewal subject to an independent assessment. For this reason I am happy to support it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for the establishment of a European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) as the Commission proposal was substantially amended in the interest of my country, Bulgaria.  I was very concerned by the Commission's initial text, as in its view the approval of the projects financed by this Fund would have depended entirely on their economic returns and support for economic growth without any geographical distribution. My concern was that with this type of criteria, EFSI-funded projects would concentrate in better developed REGIONS of the EU, which would further widen the gap with the least developed regions, such as those in Bulgaria. Thanks to the proposals made in the EP, it is of great importance to me that among the main objectives and indicators for measuring progress made under efsi should be to include the achievement of economic and social cohesion objectives, and that projects must contribute to ensuring inclusive and sustainable growth.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report proposes the creation of a new fund (European Fund for Strategic Investments), which will aim to finance EUR 60 billion in the form of a global loan for the financing of small and social cohesion projects. In the case of the Union's enterprises, the amount of the aid was EUR 1 million This could be made by the existing funds, following the necessary amendments to their regulation. (EIB, EIB)

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 In agreement with the position of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the adoption of the draft regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (juncker package). In my opinion, the Juncker package will also open up serious opportunities for private investment in agriculture with an EU bank guarantee. However, I remind colleagues that EU agricultural and cohesion policies are primarily based on subsidies, and hopefully this will not change in the future. It is in our interest that these current policies are maintained and not replaced, even in part, by a system of EU investment promotion instruments. Such an instrument can only complement the current system of cohesion policy and the CAP.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). Although it draws funding from other budgets, which I opposed, I welcome the signal of a shift towards investment after many years of cuts. It is an important step in the right direction. I will now be working to ensure that Wales gets the maximum benefit from EFSI.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the agreement, which will contribute to growth and job creation in Europe. We have managed to reduce the overall cuts in Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility by EUR 1 billion. The "Juncker plan" aims to mobilise €315 billion of public and private investment over the next three years. We will have €240 billion for investments and €75 billion for businesses, including small and medium-sized enterprises. This fund translates into another opportunity that can be wasted. It is complementary, allowing to finance what the current funds and the market do not support or finance. To reduce the impact of the planned funding of Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility to finance the "Juncker plan" guarantee fund, an additional €1 billion has been achieved from unused budget margins. The cuts to the two COMMUNITY programmes will be €2.8 billion in Horizon 2020 (the EU programme for research and innovation) and €2.2 billion in the Connecting Europe Facility (investments to improve Europe's transport, energy and digital technology networks).

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) because I believe that the outcome achieved by the European Parliament following tough negotiations with the Council marks the concrete achievement of our priority of reorienting European economic policy towards growth and investment.  We have made FEIE an investment tool that promotes projects in line with our political priorities.    The agreement reached ensures the financing of quality investments, facilitates additional co-financing for all Member States, strengthens the governance of THE EIE within the European framework and proposes more appropriate and ambitious alternative funding from the Guarantee Fund to safeguard European R&D&I and transport programmes, Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Mechanism with an additional EUR 1 billion.  This is a good agreement which will give an urgent impetus to much-needed investments in the Union.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because the proposed plan ignores national strategic imperatives and will accelerate territorial disparts.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Written. \u2012 The EFSI has very broad support both among Member States and in the European Parliament. We Moderates have taken the proposal in the right direction and succeeded in getting the European Parliament with us on crucial points: reducing the erosion of European research appropriations, the full inclusion of Member States' contributions in the budgetary rules of the Stability Pact and the fact that the ETUC should not be an excuse not to implement the necessary structural reforms. Unfortunately, in the negotiations with the Council of Ministers, the European Parliament has had to give in to several of these important demands. It is noteworthy that the Swedish Government in the Council of Ministers has supported taking money from research, injecting new money and loosening the budgetary rules in the Stability Pact. The EFSI does not solve the basic problem of a reduction in Europe's levels of investment. Europe has gradually become too over-regulated, sluggish and expensive to invest in. In order for Europe to become more attractive to invest in, it is necessary to implement reforms that strengthen countries' competitiveness and reduce financial deficits. Now it is crucial not to lose focus from what is really needed to increase the willingness to invest in Europe. Countries with great need for reform cannot hope for money from Brussels to take it out of the crisis, and therefore refrain from carrying out the necessary reforms. In such cases, the lower levels of investment are likely to be permanent.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Strategic investments are of great importance to all regions of Europe at the moment, when the European Union is combating high youth unemployment and the economic and economic crisis. The European Parliament and the Council reached agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments at the end of May. This agreement will allow EFSI to start operating very quickly and efficiently. The outcome of the negotiations is a great success, as it leads to a reorientation of European economic policy towards growth and investment. Efsi will only be able to support high-quality investments, strengthen the governance scheme and increase investment in efsi through greater co-financing by Member States. It is very important that Member States continue to adopt economic and structural reforms in order to maximise the impact of EFSI on employment and the improvement of the social situation of european Union citizens.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 EFSI is an instrument that in principle finds our support but by analyzing it and understanding its true scope, it is not based on its own funds (but takes them away in particular from Horizon); Member States, even if they participate in EFSI with their own contributions, are completely excluded from governance, etc. The text can therefore only have our vote against.

name: Vicky FORD
text: in writing. ‒ I could not quite bring myself to vote for the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). Europe needs investment. Commissioner Katainen and colleagues are working hard to encourage investors and public/private partnerships can help. Knowing the European Investment Bank (EIB) has ʽskin in the gameʼ may reassure investors, especially in less secure parts of Europe.  But EFSI does take money from the Horizon 2020 science and research budget. Parliament amendments have managed to reduce the hit and to ring-fence frontier research. We have saved the precious ERC grants. The Commission has stated they will not cut basic science. They have said that more money will come into research through EFSI than before. This is extremely helpful. But I know that many individuals in our research organisations are still worried, as are our universities. Horizon 2020 was not perfect – but it was negotiated through five years of consultation with front-line researchers from organisations large and small from all across Europe. It did have the confidence and support of scientists, so changing the rules has put a dent in their confidence. Sometimes policy does need to change, and EFSI may be better than Horizon 2020 but we must involve those on the front line much earlier on to keep their trust.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) because I believe that the outcome achieved by the European Parliament following tough negotiations with the Council marks the concrete achievement of our priority of reorienting European economic policy towards growth and investment.  We have made FEIE an investment tool that promotes projects in line with our political priorities.    The agreement reached ensures the financing of quality investments, facilitates additional co-financing for all Member States, strengthens the governance of THE EIE within the European framework and proposes more appropriate and ambitious alternative funding from the Guarantee Fund to safeguard European R&D&I and transport programmes, Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Mechanism with an additional EUR 1 billion.  This is a good agreement which will give an urgent impetus to much-needed investments in the Union.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) because I believe that the outcome achieved by the European Parliament following tough negotiations with the Council marks the concrete achievement of our priority of reorienting European economic policy towards growth and investment.  We have made FEIE an investment tool that promotes projects in line with our political priorities.    The agreement reached ensures the financing of quality investments, facilitates additional co-financing for all Member States, strengthens the governance of THE EIE within the European framework and proposes more appropriate and ambitious alternative funding from the Guarantee Fund to safeguard European R&D&I and transport programmes, Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Mechanism with an additional EUR 1 billion.  This is a good agreement which will give an urgent impetus to much-needed investments in the Union.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 After months of hard work, the European Fund for Strategic Investments finally becomes a reality. It is an instrument which represents the turning point from the point of view of European economic cohesion at social and territorial level. Today we all hope that EFSI can really become the key to finally enabling all the peoples of Europe to emerge from this interminable and gruesome crisis that still oppresses our economies. We hope that the Member States will now live up to the task and make the most of the full potential of this innovative instrument.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the regulation for a European Fund for Strategic Investments given it is an important opportunity to boost investment in the EU. It should focus on long-term investment in infrastructure that is geared up for the future. Therefore it is crucial that the right projects are selected in areas such as renewable energy and the digital market. Furthermore, I welcome the fact that the fund will also focus on investment in the creative industry.  On the financing side of the Fund however, I am still concerned that an important part will be taken out of Horizon 2020, cutting into the EU budget for research and development. I am also concerned about the fact that the Fund will be limited in time, and I hope this will not affect its effectiveness.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the European Fund for Strategic Investments is a sign of a Europe that is changing direction. Europe certainly did not have much choice: the failure of austerity policies was certified by the facts, by the dramatic levels of unemployment, by the closure of thousands of companies, by the collapse of consumption, by the deterioration of the welfare state and, last but not least, by the growth of anti-democratic forces in many countries.  Europe needs to look forward, but above all to 'do' today.   We now have a framework that allows us to make manoeuvres to revive the economy, but above all to grow our territories, the well-being of our citizens.   The Juncker plan, the communication on flexibility and the Structural Funds, these three instruments together do not allow us to fail. The real challenge is to ensure efficient use of the instruments available; That is why I hope for a strong and fruitful synergy between the resources of cohesion policy and those of EFSI.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. The European Fund for Strategic Investments is based on leverage: with a capital of 21 billion euros, abounded by the European Investment Bank (5 billion) and the European Union (16 billion), this envelope will be mobilized to raise more resources in the form of bonds. The expected leverage is 315 billion euros (x15), but the sincerity of these claims is questionable. On the one hand, the previous arrangement of the same kind, the "Pact for Growth and Jobs" of 2012-2013, which was to create 60 billion euros, with a leverage of 6, actually resulted in 20 billion, with a leverage of 2.  On the other hand, this fund will generate windfall effects. It will mainly benefit companies that would have invested with other financing methods anyway. Finally, the plan will be subject to structural reforms (labour market reforms and fiscal consolidation), i.e. a policy of austerity that is already hampering growth. That is why the steering committee only has members of the Commission and the EIB, to supposedly guarantee its independence. States have been excluded, which does not bode well for the future.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against the Commission's proposal because, although the outcome of the tripartite dialogue improved the Commission's intolerable proposal, this Fund does not in any way constitute – neither because of its size nor its forms of administration – the countercyclical commitment that Europe needs.  If the Union budget represents less than 1% of the GNI of EU Member States (in fact, it represents 0.98% in 2015%), the EIE represents less than 1% of the EU's annual budget, a clearly insufficient amount to reverse the consequences of the procyclical policies promoted so far by the EU and carried out by its Member States.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my colleagues in the Labour Party and the Socialist and Democrats Group, voted in favour of this report to help implement the EU’s EUR 315 billion plan to overcome the crisis-induced shortage of investment in the European economy. This initiative should entail no extra financial burden for taxpayers. The aim of the European Fund for Strategic Investment (EFSI), to be run by the European Investment Bank, is to provide public support for projects that are economically viable, but would not otherwise happen because private investors are hesitant to finance them due to the uncertain economic situation and the higher risk involved. EFSI will assume part of that risk, thus encouraging private investors to get on board.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) because I believe that the outcome achieved by the European Parliament following tough negotiations with the Council marks the concrete achievement of our priority of reorienting European economic policy towards growth and investment.  We have made FEIE an investment tool that promotes projects in line with our political priorities.    The agreement reached ensures the financing of quality investments, facilitates additional co-financing for all Member States, strengthens the governance of THE EIE within the European framework and proposes more appropriate and ambitious alternative funding from the Guarantee Fund to safeguard European R&D&I and transport programmes, Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Mechanism with an additional EUR 1 billion.  This is a good agreement which will give an urgent impetus to much-needed investments in the Union.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal for a European Fund for Strategic Investments. With this proposal, the Commission aims to lift the European economy out of recession by creating new jobs, increasing employment, attracting private investment and capital. In order to compete with the world leaders in the US and China, we need to ensure that the European economy grows united and that the Member States take all possible measures to achieve future growth.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as this plan will give small and medium-sized businesses the kick-start that is needed to strengthen the economy and deliver more jobs. It will lead to significant growth particularly in the areas of research and development, innovation, education and infrastructure. It is a hugely important measure that will help Europe recover in a strong way after the financial crisis.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 From a Hungarian point of view, the greatest success is that the investment package is completely separate from the resources of cohesion policy. €5 billion will be provided from the €8 billion needed to replenish the EU guarantee fund behind the package. The eur 5 billion redeployment concerns the CEF by EUR 2.8 billion and the H2020 programme by EUR 2.2 billion. From the horizon 2020 programme, it is a success that the reduction is reduced compared to the Commission's proposal. From a Hungarian point of view, it is important that, in the case of Horizon 2020, the programme to broaden the participation of the new Member States is not affected by the reduction. The establishment of EFSI is in line with the objectives of the Hungarian economy: it will provide a new kind of financing opportunity for hungarian financial service providers and companies.  The Fund will also support risk finance for SMEs and mid-caps across Europe. It will help to bridge the capital gap by means of larger direct capital investments and additional guarantees for high-quality securitisation of SME loans. SMEs will be able to benefit from pre-financing grants before efsi is fully set up. It is estimated that by 2020 the investment package could increase the EU's GDP by up to EUR 330-410 billion and create between 1 and 1.3 million new jobs. On the basis of the above, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) as it marks the beginning of a positive project aimed at boosting much needed capital investment across Europe. Key to this investment plan must be the funding of small, locally based projects in Member States. We need a strong economic recovery with its foundations in towns and cities boosting employment and capital investment. I would urge that the strategy going forward gives stronger credence to the positives of economic investment at a local and regional level.  In January 2015, the Commission had proposed trimming EUR 2.7 billion from Horizon 2020’s budget, including EUR 221.2 million from the European Research Council to feed EFSI. I deeply regret this proposal and continue to call for the protection of this essential research funding.  As a result of ongoing pressure from European Parliamentarians, the Horizon 2020 funding will now be cut by EUR 2.2 billion instead of EUR 2.7billion. Although I welcome this improvement, I remain of the opinion that any further attempt to plunder the Horizon 2020 fund should be avoided.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against the Commission's proposal because, although the outcome of the tripartite dialogue improved the Commission's intolerable proposal, this Fund does not in any way constitute – neither because of its size nor its forms of administration – the countercyclical commitment that Europe needs.  If the Union budget represents less than 1% of the GNI of EU Member States (in fact, it represents 0.98% in 2015%), the EIE represents less than 1% of the EU's annual budget, a clearly insufficient amount to reverse the consequences of the procyclical policies promoted so far by the EU and carried out by its Member States.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments and on amending the Regulation (EU) No 2012/2013. 1291/2013 and (EU) No. 1316/2013 because it is essential and necessary to boost the economic recovery and competitiveness of the European Union, especially in those Member States most affected by the financial crisis. It is therefore important to ensure the financing of quality projects that contribute to job creation, infrastructure improvement, research and innovation, etc. in the form of achieving long-term growth and raising competitiveness. In this context, particular attention should be paid to the needs of local and regional authorities in order to launch additional investments to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. However, it is necessary that all procedures are carried out in a transparent and responsible manner in order to minimize fraud and improve reporting.  Therefore, I strongly support the establishment of this Fund that will mark the work of our mandate, with special emphasis on risky investments and public private partnerships, without forgetting traditional European industries such as tourism and shipbuilding.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution of 24 June 2015 on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Faced with a 15% reduction from the record level of 2007, it is important to boost investment in Europe. This fund, in addition to other tools, will help boost employment, competitiveness and long-term growth. It will also encourage investment for SMEs and PMIs.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The European Fund for Strategic Investments will never reach the promised volume of EUR 315 billion, as the return prospects that private investors want to see can still not be specified. In addition, parts of the fund's volume are already reserved for projects with specific objectives, which runs counter to the market character that the Fund should ensure. I am also opposed to part of Horizon 2020's budget being used to finance the EFSI. For these reasons, I am voting against the proposal.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Fund for Strategic Investments regulation at the European Parliament plenary session because fresh investment is needed in the European Union to restore economic growth. The newly created fund will generate around €315 billion in investment in EU economies. The fund will be administered by the European Investment Bank (EIB), which will invest EUR 5 billion in it, while the European Union will serve as a guarantee to reduce risk to private investors, thereby significantly increasing the attractiveness of projects to investors. The projects will be developed by the operators and will be assessed by the EIB and decided on the granting of the guarantee. According to the European Commission's estimates, the fund will create around 1-1.3 million new jobs. Investment projects can also be applied for by Latvian entrepreneurs.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the creation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the Juncker investment plan. This plan foresees EUR 315 billion in investments over the next three years to boost European economy and innovation. This is an original and practical solution in a situation where no extra funds can be expected from the Member States. In total EUR 240 billion are foreseen to be used for investments, and EUR 75 billion will be made available for SMEs, the backbone of the European economy.   The negotiations between Parliament and the Council have led to more democratic scrutiny from the Parliament side – stronger reporting and an increased accountability. I welcome also that Parliament gained the right to approve the appointment of the managing director and deputy managing director of the investment fund.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for a renegotiated investment deal on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), a new tool to boost growth and job creation in Europe. Billions of pounds from EFSI could now be used for British infrastructure, SMEs, and green growth.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) aims to promote economic growth, employment and recovery in Europe. The new initiative promises to allow for new investments of EUR 315 billion over a three-year period, most of which will be financed by the private sector. What is not so clearly stated, however, is the fact that the European Investment Bank is liable for defaults. In concrete terms, this means that the taxpayer should be liable for the default risks of private entrepreneurs. Irrespective of these considerations, EFSI will fail anyway. It is inconceivable that a new authority could make better decisions than thousands of company bosses. If this task were to be taken seriously, thousands of civil servants would have to be recruited.  This is a step towards a planned economy on the part of the EU. Knowing what planned economic policy has done, particularly in Eastern Europe, the EFSI must be rejected.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 From a Hungarian point of view, the greatest success is that the investment package is completely separate from the resources of cohesion policy. €5 billion will be provided from the €8 billion needed to replenish the EU guarantee fund behind the package. The eur 5 billion redeployment concerns the CEF by EUR 2.8 billion and the H2020 programme by EUR 2.2 billion. From the horizon 2020 programme, it is a success that the reduction is reduced compared to the Commission's proposal. From a Hungarian point of view, it is important that, in the case of Horizon 2020, the programme that is our priority and which wants to broaden the participation of the new Member States is not affected by the reduction. The establishment of EFSI is in line with the objectives of the Hungarian economy: it will provide a new kind of financing opportunity for hungarian financial service providers and companies.  The Fund will also support risk finance for SMEs and mid-caps across Europe. It will help to bridge the capital gap by means of larger direct capital investments and additional guarantees for high-quality securitisation of SME loans. SMEs will be able to benefit from pre-financing grants before efsi is fully set up. It is estimated that by 2020 the investment package could increase the EU's GDP by up to EUR 330-410 billion and create between 1 and 1.3 million new jobs. On the basis of the above, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. – I voted against this report because this plan not only does not represent a proper investment plan as it brings no fresh money, but it does not bring a much needed and urgent change of policies, nor does it contribute to an enlarged trend in increased public investment. Furthermore, I agree that what was needed would be to develop a true plan of public investment through the emission of new money, with the ECB and the EIB involved. But there is nothing of the sort. The EFSI, while facilitating and easing access to credit for micro, small, medium-sized and even social enterprises, keeps the logic of the ʽinnovative financial instrumentsʼ: aggravating the transfer of risk to the public sector and ensuring a high return for private investors, with a medium/long-term transfer of costs to European citizens. The absence of a true public investment plan will have as an impact that this plan will entail the aggravation of the privatisation of public strategic and fundamental sectors, in particular in the peripheral and poorer regions and Member States, at the cost of the public interest, while its impact on the European economy remains highly questionable.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – A report full of contradictions, which would, so to speak, improve the opportunities for SMEs but maximize the eligible size of the company by 3000 people, project five times the leverage within 3 years, transfer funds elsewhere from already running research. While additional public investment is needed to reduce unemployment and adequate resources need to be created, the report is unsustainable, but some amendments may bring us closer to working out an acceptable solution. Time is ticking, since 2008, investment has fallen by EUR 400-500 billion per year, and there should be no such unnecessary laps.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: in writing. ‒ Following the economic crisis, the level of investment in the EU has dropped and has never come back to its ordinary level since. SMEs within the EU are still facing the consequences of the financial crisis and incentives are needed in order to motivate businesses to come back to various risky fields. An Investment Plan for Europe together with the establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments does exactly that by aiming to address gaps in the market and mobilising private investment. The plan will have strong positive implications on sectors connected to education, research and innovation, which will consequently lead to economic growth and job creation. Therefore, I invite everyone to support this plan and contribute to further implementation of the plan domestically and throughout the EU.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: Writing. \u2012 The EFSI Agreement is a good example of effective interinstitutional cooperation. The start-up of the Fund will provide an important boost for small and medium-sized enterprises, research and development and the creation of new jobs.  A major victory for the European Parliament is that Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility will be cut at a much smaller scale than planned. The European Commission has also pledged to review the budgetary options for these funds on an annual basis.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report by Mr Fernandes and Mr Bullmann on EFSI (European Fund for Strategic Investments). The Juncker Plan, strongly desired by the EPP, is the main vehicle for mobilising at least EUR 315 billion of additional investment in the real economy over the next three years. It will finance projects with a higher risk profile, so as to maximise the impact of public spending and unlock private investment. The Fund will be set up within the framework of the European Investment Bank (EIB), with which the Commission will cooperate in a strategic partnership. I am sure that it will be a driving force for work and opportunity, which will make the European economy competitive, innovative and circular, not neglecting fundamental aspects, such as sustainable development and green growth.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report on the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which is intended to become the backbone of the 'Investment Plan for Europe' (The Juncker Plan). The fund will be set up by the Commission and the European Investment Bank. Its capital will consist of a contribution of 5 billion euros from the EIB and a guarantee of 16 billion financed by the EU budget. Several aspects are of concern: 1) The counterparties required are always the same: namely structural reforms (in the labour market ...) while the IMF research department has just shown their inefficiency on potential growth.  2) Although it wants to combat them, this plan will accelerate territorial disparities by retaining only the most profitable projects, to the benefit of a few major metropolises and conurbations. 3) It encourages the use of public-private partnerships to defer the cost of infrastructure to future generations. 4) It undermines the state level, which is no longer just a back-up force of the Union, and encourages direct cooperation with the 'regional authorities'.  5) It recommends the continuation of "fiscal consolidation", i.e. austerity.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Written. \u2012 The economic engine in Europe is sputtering. The EFSI investment plan can provide additional investment. But to make our economy healthy again, that will not be enough. A real recovery policy with structural reforms is essential for this. The N-VA had some basic red lines. We are pleased that they can also be found in the final text to a large extent. For example, not politicians but independent experts will decide which projects are funded. That is a good thing because politicisation would have deterred private investors. However, N-VA is not satisfied with the financing of EFSI. It is disappointing that horizon 2020 and CEF, EU programmes are already being cut, creating additional growth and jobs. These programmes are also very important for Flanders, not least for our research institutions. It is positive that the European Parliament has succeeded in safeguarding some of the basic research programmes, but unfortunately this is not enough.  With this abstention, we want to send a very clear message: the resources cut in the successful Horizon 2020 and CEF programmes should be offset as soon as possible by adjustments in the European budget.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The report contains many positive points, such as: -Only high-quality investments will be financed by THE EAI Eligibility criteria have been defined based on quality job creation capacity, smart, sustainable and inclusive growth promotion, and economic, social and territorial cohesion. -Strengthening the governance scheme within the EU framework The day-to-day management will be carried out by a Director-General and an Deputy Director-General whose appointment will be approved by the EP after the parliamentary control session established for this purpose has passed.  -A solution to finance the FEIE Guarantee Fund, which reduces the effects on Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility, in accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) aims to promote economic growth, employment and recovery in Europe. The new initiative promises to allow for new investments of EUR 315 billion over a three-year period, most of which will be financed by the private sector. What is not so clearly stated, however, is the fact that the European Investment Bank is liable for defaults. In concrete terms, this means that the taxpayer should be liable for the default risks of private entrepreneurs. Irrespective of these considerations, the EFSI will fail anyway. It is inconceivable that a new authority could make better decisions than thousands of company bosses. If this task were to be taken seriously, thousands of civil servants would have to be recruited. This is a step towards a planned economy on the part of the EU. Knowing what planned economic policy has done, particularly in Eastern Europe, the EFSI must be rejected.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I supported the report on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). All initiatives to contribute to strengthening economic growth and creating new jobs deserve our support. Furthermore, the EFSI is to focus on projects of high social importance, including education, training and research and innovation projects. It is therefore all the more important to support its effective implementation and ensure proper management and funding. We must also take into account the appropriate time perspective for the implementation of investments in specific sectors and adapt to it the monitoring and evaluation of individual projects, as well as their impact on growth and employment. At the same time, we must bear in mind that the EFSI is not a substitute for national action. For example, in terms of educational objectives, we cannot cut national spending on research or science and hope that the investment plan will fill this gap. Only combined actions and strengthened funding will achieve the critical mass needed to stimulate further growth. Therefore m.in. also funding for the EFSI should be independent of the Horizon 2020 budget. These two programmes must complement each other on a substantive basis and strengthen each other, while their funding must be independent.  Finally, I stress the great importance of supporting education projects under the EFSI. High-quality education and the development of skills and competences are the foundations for increasing growth, employment, competitiveness and innovation development in the EU.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am against the EU managing "investment" to rebuild the economy. This money had to be collected from taxpayers first. Such redistribution of money will not restore economic growth, but will weaken it.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. - I support the establishment of a European Fund for Strategic Investments set up in cooperation with the European Investment Bank with a view to mobilising funding.
