The purpose of the Fund is to mitigate the consequences of the financial and economic crisis by investing in riskier projects in the fields of research, innovation, energy, transport and social infrastructure, education and science.  European Commission Vice-President Jyrki Katainen stressed that the implementation phase is now starting and that it is very important to convey messages to Member States. The European Union cannot implement EFSI alone, this is the task of the Member States. It takes intermediaries for SMEs, government activity to set up national and regional investment platforms and we need to send a message to entrepreneurs that they can contact the European Investment Bank on their own today. Only in this way will the European Fund for Strategic Investments boost growth, development and enable job creation.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. The European Fund for Strategic Investments has an important role to play - using this mechanism now, after the crisis in the European Union, the economy could be launched and us branches that need special, future-oriented investments developed. I voted for it.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed regulation responds to reduced investment growth in the European Union, which decreased by 15% compared to 2007 as a result of the financial and economic crisis. This negatively affects economic growth, employment and competitiveness. The proposed Regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments aims at creating a legal framework and providing appropriations to support investments and then taking measures to increase the regulatory environment and remove obstacles to investment. In particular, small and medium-sized enterprises will be beneficiaries of the support, which, by drawing efsi funding, will be able to create new jobs and revitalise the economic market. At the same time, a European Investment Advisory Hub will be created, acting as a single technical advisory hub for the financing of European Union projects. Investments must support the development of infrastructure, education, health, research, development, information and communication technologies and innovation, the expansion of renewable energy and energy efficiency, infrastructure projects in the fields of the environment, natural resources, urban development and the social sphere.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Writing. The creation of growth and sustainable jobs is the primary objective and guiding principle of the ambitious Juncker Plan. At its heart is the European Fund for Strategic Investments. It is desperately needed because, despite the appreciable recovery in many Member States following the economic and financial crisis, there is still a significant investment gap. The EFSI is an essential element in increasing the level of investment and thus in stimulating the european economy. In combination with other financial instruments, it has the potential to provide the right impulses. The planned EUR 345 billion could create or safeguard 1.3 million jobs. The quality of the Recommendations of the Investment Committee depends on the success of attracting large-scale private capital. Particular attention must be paid to supporting small and medium-sized enterprises. They are the backbone of our European economy and have enormous employment potential. This must be released. For example, the EFSI should make an effective contribution: in the short term to stabilising the labour market, in the long term to the necessary growth throughout the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the amendment of Regulations (EU) Nos 1493/1999 and (EC) No 1493/1999. 1291/2013 and (EU) No 1291/2013. 1316/2013, for the reasons I mention in the relevant written statement I submitted in accordance with Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament concerning the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The strategic investment plan, EFSI, devised by the Juncker Commission, aims to shift EU policies from austerity to growth by focusing on investment. The main aim is therefore to promote and facilitate access to finance in Member States and regions with high levels of unemployment. I am particularly in favour of EFSI because it is again designed to restore confidence at European level by stimulating a multiplier effect on the market by providing liquidity with a total investment of EUR 315 billion. These investments will have to, over the next 3 years, maximise the impact of public resources and unlock private investment in order to boost the real economy without producing new public debt. The proposed measures, if implemented in the best possible way, could go even further than expected by adding between EUR 330 billion and EUR 410 billion to European GDP over the next three years and create 1 million and 300 thousand new jobs.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. U2012 The investment of EUR 315 billion in Europe in the coming years will allow, I am convinced, to boost the economy and, therefore, employment, as demanded by citizens. I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution which allows this plan to be finally approved, which envisages some improvements that we have made from the European Parliament and which, I am sure, will be a real aid for the EU's recovery.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The bipartisan legislative resolution on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) has definitively validated the European Commission's 315 billion euro investment plan, known as the Juncker Plan. The European Socialist Group, and with it the French Socialist delegation, had mobilized very strongly to impose this recovery plan which Europe sorely needs after several years of austerity. In this regard, I am pleased that a large part of this fund is directed primarily to the countries of southern Europe, which have been doubly affected by the crisis and austerity measures. It is also to be welcomed that additional contributions from Member States will be encouraged, as they are considered budgetaryly neutral. I regret, however, that the plan, which is largely artificial, does not mobilize almost any fresh money: it actually relies on a very random multiplier effect. Moreover, it only insufficiently directs funds towards innovative green or digital projects. Finally, it greatly cuts existing research funding programmes or European transport networks. Considering that the Juncker plan should be seen as a first step towards more investment in Europe, I nevertheless voted in favour of the report.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I would have refused to support the report on the European Fund for Strategic Investments, because I believe that the European Fund for Strategic Investments cannot achieve the leverage effect of EUR 315 billion provided for in the report. In addition, a large part of the money would have to be taken from special funds, which in turn would secure the financing of other projects, but which do not correspond to the market character of the fund.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report regarding Parliament’s position on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), which is an integral part of the Juncker Commission’s investment plan. A number of Parliamentary committees contributed amendments to the Commission’s text to ensure that the measures taken to overcome the investment gap are in the best interests of the public. I support Parliament’s efforts to guarantee that the EFSI is in sync with the European Union’s strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which proposes new incentives to boost investments by backing them with EU guarantees, which can create trust again amongst investors, public authorities and industries in tomorrow’s growth. By unlocking new investments, EFSI can become the flywheel of a new investment cycle that creates new jobs and opportunities. These new investments are not only needed to relaunch the EU economy, but also to transform it into a resilient, innovative, inclusive, low-carbon and circular economy

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ After years of painful austerity and structural reforms, Europe is still in a process of recovery, while growth remains sluggish. Compared to pre-crisis years, we must realise that we find ourselves in an ʽinvestment holeʼ, as Commission President Juncker himself put it. Investor sentiment remains rather low and our economy needs a rapidly deployable booster. Hopefully this will be the role of the famous Juncker Plan, made fact in the European Fund for Strategic Investments, for which I voted today. Of course, Parliament left its mark on the original plan. Ultimately, this resulted in it having oversight over some of the Fund’s governance aspects, project selection has become more transparent and EUR 1 billion less will be taken from the EU’s flagship research and infrastructure programmes. All in all, I hope I will not regret having shared in the optimism of the Fund’s supporters.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal is of the utmost importance: it proposes a joint regulation of the Parliament and of the Council on a very ambitious plan to regulate the functioning of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which is at the heart of the Juncker Commission concept, with at least EUR 315 billion of investment and 1.3 million new jobs over three years. The proposal has been discussed by all the relevant committees, including the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, of which I am a member, and has tabled amendments to it. On the basis of the opinions of these committees, the Committee on Budgets and the Economic and Financial Affairs committees drafted the amended proposal before Parliament at first reading, which I voted in favour of accordingly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The Investment Plan presented by Jean-Claude Juncker aims to create a new European Fund for Strategic Investments, which will be managed by the European Investment Bank. The European Commission therefore intends to mobilise EUR 16 billion from the European budget with a view to mobilising overall investment of around EUR 315 billion.  I am voting in favour of this report on the European Strategic Investment Fund because I believe that this may be the necessary step to boost economic growth between EUR 330 billion and EUR 410 billion and create around 1.3 million job vacancies. I believe that it is time for the European Union to raise private awareness of strategic investments in key areas for improving energy, transport or telecommunications links.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The European Fund for Strategic Investments is the backbone of the Juncker plan.  Noting for the umpteenth time the dramatic fall in private investment, which is only the result of the disastrous austerity policies demanded by Brussels, the Commission, through this plan, is making us look forward to a great deal of communication 315 billion euros of investments, created from a guarantee of 21 billion euros. This deliberately overestimated leverage will suffer the same fate as the "pact for growth and jobs" which is supposed to bring in 60 billion euros of additional investment to actually reach 20. But the counterparties demanded are still the same: the smoky structural reforms that can no longer even find thanks to the eyes of IMF economists who recently confessed that they bring no additional growth.  In reality, this plan will accelerate territorial disparities by retaining only the most profitable projects, to the benefit of a few major metropolises and conurbations. Finally, it will strengthen the backs and downs of infrastructure privatization through public-private partnerships whose adverse cost effects for future generations are known to be known.  So I voted against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (Juncker Investment Plan), which is expected to mobilise EUR 315 billion for new investments in the real economy. The aim is for the Union to create leverage through a 16 billion euro guarantee to support public and private investment in the transport, telecommunications and energy infrastructure sectors (including interconnections of transport and energy networks), as well as digital infrastructure. Strategic investments will also include projects of common interest in urban and rural development, the environment, natural resources, industry, research and innovation, culture and health.  A consultancy structure at European level will be created to help identify projects, but also to prepare and develop them. Its expertise will be made available to small and medium-sized enterprises at a capped cost (one third of the costs of technical assistance they will receive) and free of charge for public structures. This fund aims to revitalise the EU economy without further delay by facilitating access to finance and promoting the competitiveness of businesses.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 In Europe, the lack of investment caused by the recent economic and financial crisis has ended up creating a dangerous downward spiral of spending reduction, rising unemployment and loss of confidence.  Our group immediately asked Mr Juncker to take new initiatives in this regard, so we welcome the success achieved, very much welcoming the launch of this new fund, which will be set up in close partnership with the EIB, and which, thanks to the EP's commitment, will enter into force as early as the next few months with a view to reviving the demand and confidence of private investors.  By unlocking new investments, by incorporating the principle of real additionality, EFSI will be able to become the driving force for innovative projects that create new jobs and opportunities. We are convinced that it will serve not only to revive the EU economy, but also to transform it into a resilient, innovative, inclusive, low-carbon economy. We will therefore support truly transformative services and infrastructures that can meet the 'new' challenges, such as our loss of competitiveness, dangerous climate change, our dependence on scarce and critical natural resources from third countries and the volatility and unpredictability of energy and resource prices.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I obviously voted for this text, because it will eventually make the Juncker plan a reality, namely the mobilization of some EUR 315 billion for the benefit of the investment. The European Union, through this initiative, makes a blatant denial to the view that it is only seeking austerity in Europe.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic and financial crisis has led to a decline in investment in the Union, which has fallen by around 15% since its peak in 2007. The lack of investment in the EU is due in particular to budgetary constraints imposed on Member States and stagnant growth, which in turn lead to uncertainty in the markets about the future of the economy. This shortcoming, which has been particularly serious in the Member States most affected by the crisis, slows down economic recovery and has a negative impact on job creation, long-term growth prospects and competitiveness, potentially hampering the achievement of the Europe 2020 strategy objectives.  Comprehensive action is therefore needed to break this vicious circle and EFSI could be one of the backs of a comprehensive strategy to overcome the uncertainty surrounding public and private investment activity and to reduce investment shortfalls in the Union. The strategy is based on three main axes: mobilising funds for investment, the ability of investment to achieve the real economy and improving the investment environment in the Union.  In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the report.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the European Fund for Strategic Investments is a solution to the final recovery from the economic crisis. Our main objective must be to turn the European Union back into a competitive economy, where investment contributes to the creation of new jobs, thereby reducing unemployment, increasing GDP and a positive future outlook for national economies. At the same time, I stress that investment in research plays a huge role in creating a competitive market, as only through innovation can we develop and take advantage of our competitors and thus ensure our competitiveness, thus retaining our leading economic position at the forefront of the world. Furthermore, I consider it very important to support micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, as these organisations make up 99% of the European market, thereby taking a lion's share of the future healthy functioning of the European market.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) was designed to boost the Economic growth and long-term competitiveness of the European Union. I voted on this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Strategic Investment Fund and amending Regulations (EU) No 1493/1999 and (EC) No 1493/1999. 1291/2013 and (EU) No 1291/2013. 1316/2013 because the final proposal included several amendments that we have initiated to allow all States and beneficiaries access to these funds.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I believe that the European Fund for Strategic Investments must be used fairly and geographically balanced to reach as many European citizens as possible.  Through a concentration of resources in already highly developed areas and a lack of funding in the poorer ones, the differences not only between Member States but also their regions become larger.   With this in view of this, I very much hope: firstly, that there will be a geographical balance in the allocation of projects; secondly, to provide for financial resources for rural, remote and non-privileged areas; thirdly, the funds should also be used to tackle high unemployment, especially in rural and remote areas where it is a very acute problem; fourth, prioritise projects that create long-term quality jobs; I believe that this fund should help solve worrying trends such as depopulation and isolation, in which unprivileged regions and areas, most of which are also rural, fall.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the Regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) because I believe that setting up a fund can be a much-needed boost for the European economy. By being willing to take higher risks than commercial banks or the European Investment Bank, the Fund could make investments that would not otherwise occur. At the same time, I welcome the fact that the EP has managed to ensure the maintenance of EUR 1 billion in the important Horizon 2020 and CEF programmes. I would like to call on the Czech Government to better consider its refusal to contribute to the EFSI budget and to be inspired by the example of Poland, which was the first non-euro area country to contribute, or Slovakia, which contributed very recently as the last.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The creation of growth and sustainable jobs is the primary objective and guiding principle of this report. Despite the recovery from the economic and financial crisis, further investment is urgently needed. The EFSI is an essential element in increasing investment levels and can stimulate the european economy. The basic idea is actually very good and sensible. Personally, however, I do not have a clear plan behind the idea. A transparent strategy is needed, in particular on how to use financial resources and what benefits can be derived from them. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. The European Fund for Strategic Investments (FEIE), the cornerstone of the Juncker Plan, aims to increase investment in the European Union and promote economic recovery by supporting economically viable projects that are not currently being developed because private investors doubt their financing. The creation of this Fund gives us a unique opportunity to relaunch the Union's economy. However, we consider that such funding should not be detrimental to the budgets of other key European research projects, such as Horizon 2020 or the Connecting Europe Facility. From UPyD we consider it a breakthrough that the EIES Board of Directors is composed of representatives of the Commission and the European Investment Bank, and not by the States themselves. In addition, the selection of projects by an Investment Committee made up of independent experts will allow the selection of projects to be carried out on the basis of objective and solvency criteria that avoid political opportunism, friendliness and misuse of money for all Europeans. That is why we have decided to vote in favour of this Regulation.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 European Investment Plan, which aims to mobilise EUR 315 billion in aid. This will support the recovery of the EU economy, boost investment in Europe, while contributing to growth and jobs in Europe. This is an innovative instrument and it is very important that all uncertainties regarding the funding scheme for this fund are removed. In particular, this Fund must not be financed at the expense of Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility. We need to invest in projects, services and infrastructure that can help to solve emerging new challenges that threaten prosperity and prosperity. It is to be welcomed that the financing structure of this fund has been agreed and clarified, to strengthen its supervision and to increase the role of the European Parliament in the allocation of the management of the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Fund for Strategic Investments because I believe that Parliament has managed to achieve important compromise results in this negotiation with the Commission, which will give new impetus to the European economy through investment and the creation of new quality jobs and lead to greater economic, social and territorial cohesion. This programme will facilitate investment in the territory, which will be assessed in its real effectiveness and taking due account of the level of social and territorial cohesion they bring.  Investment projects should be in line with the Union's objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The added value of the investments and their effective additionality will have to be demonstrated. Funding will be modelled on the specificities of each country and sector taking into account market conditions. The prices applicable to EFSI operations should stimulate additional investment in order to prevent and effectively combat problems related to financial fragmentation, market failures and a lower than optimal level of investment. This ambitious plan is a sign of a Europe that is starting to invest again in order to get out of the austerity squeeze.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 As a member of Parliament's Industry Committee, I particularly appreciate the EU's commitment (even in this particular period of crisis) by seeking to focus efforts and energies on strategic investments for the Union. I am therefore in favour of supporting Parliament's position at first reading because I believe that this regulation could unblock the investment situation in many Member States - such as my own - and relaunch European employment and industrial leadership.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ It is worrying that the exit from the economic crisis that began in 2007 has never been slower in the history of world crises than the recovery we are witnessing today. The current level of investment and investment in the EU is insufficient and decisive action needs to be taken immediately. The establishment of EFSI is only one of these measures, the coordination of which must be applied in order to achieve maximum synergistic impact of all measures taken. Mobilising funding and investment in a fair and transparent manner, improving the investment climate and supporting projects of public interest, through the mobilisation of EFSI€315 trillion, as proposed, is a good basis for a new economic upsurge. Job creation and greater investment by the EU should be based on investments in renewable energy sources, investments in the agriculture sector, development of rural areas, and self-sustaining projects such as organic production and ecotourism.  In particular, I consider it important to make the necessary efforts to make sure that the effects of this fund are felt to the level of SMEs, startups and the self-employed, as they represent the source of jobs for the largest number of European citizens, have the greatest growth potential locally and globally, and I strongly advocate that they be both the largest beneficiaries of secured funds and guarantors of the long-term growth of the EU economy.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ It is not often that leaders of all EU member states reach consensus relatively easily and support a proposal politically as recently happened with the Juncker Investment Plan. A broader consensus is in place between the leaders of the Union and the various political groups in the European Parliament on the necessity of such a plan after years of recession and stagnation in the EU caused by, inter alia, a lack of investment.  I support Juncker's investment plan as one of the fulfilled promises made to the Socialists and Democrats ahead of the no-confidence vote. Given that the energy sector, transport connectivity and research are mentioned as areas of investment, I do not think it should be underestimated the possibilities of this Plan for Croatia. On the other hand, it remains an open question which of the 77 projects submitted can be accepted. Nevertheless, the backbone of the whole project is that the Juncker Investment Plan, as well as everywhere in the EU, should encourage the renewal of the economic initiative with us. In the meantime, we have significant EU funds at our disposal that can serve as a platform for the economic recovery and development process.  So the Juncker Plan, if fully implemented, is a welcome contribution to this process that is worth accepting and for that I support it. In particular, I would like to stress that in addition to the preparedness of projects, the impact of member states in the financial crisis should also be taken into account as a criterion when allocating this fund.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The global economic and financial crisis has had a profound impact on investment in Europe, which after peaking in 2007 by around 15%, affecting all European regions – especially less developed ones.  The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) is a key element of economic growth, i.e. its primary purpose should be to help address difficulties in financing and implementing strategic investments of economic and social importance in the Union in order to strengthen a sustainable economy and create quality jobs and to ensure better access to finance especially in regions where it is structurally restricted. €315 billion in additional investment in the eurozone should provide 1 million new jobs over the next three years. It is necessary that the money used from the Fund be used for projects that will bring general benefit to all members, including Croatia and which will hopefully play a big role in its economic recovery. At the same time, I think that citizens need to get closer to the whole project as well as present the opportunities it provides.  I therefore supported the report as I believe it is our duty to take all steps to stop the vicious cycle that has emerged from insufficient investment and to stimulate economic growth and regain the trust of entrepreneurs.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Fund for Strategic Investments must be seen as a priority for current European policy, which is why I voted in favour of this instrument. As the financial backbone of the Juncker Investment Package, the Fund is necessary to break economic stagnation and promote sustainable and inclusive investment. It is clear that we need a strong economy, new, quality jobs and Member States that will not have their hands tied by the Stability and Growth Pact to support structural investment more than it is healthy. I supported a more democratic governance structure for this fund, which means a greater vote for the European Parliament in electing the Director of the Governing Board responsible for the day-to-day running of the Fund. In view of the amount of funding that the Fund and the European Investment Bank will operate with, I have also supported a greater level of reporting and hearings to ensure more effective democratic control. I would like to point out that I voted in favour of an alternative proposal to finance this instrument, mitigating the negative financial impact that the creation of the Fund has on Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility. It would be very unwise to move funds from budget lines where there is more than needed, while there is another and far more appropriate budgetary area.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years, due to the severe economic crisis, there has been no major investment in the European Union. As a result, this lack of investment has slowed down competitiveness, growth and employment in the EU. I am optimistic about the European Commission's proposal for the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), which I voted in favour of, the aim of which is to stimulate the EU's economic activity with an association of public and private partners in the use of resources and projects. It is, of course, important to emphasise that, in the selection of projects, priority must be given to those that have a clear European value, that are sustainable and that can give added value in reviving growth.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of today's report on the European Fund for Strategic Investments, I would like to reiterate, in particular, that it is a good thing that the amounts that will be transferred to the Fund from the science and research funds in Horizon 2020 and from the energy, transport and digital infrastructure funds in the CEF programme have been reduced. In general, I believe that the best tool for moving economies is to reduce the tax burden, which is more effective than investing public funds.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The economic and financial crisis has resulted in a low level of investment within the European Union (EU) and, as a result, the European Parliament considers that a comprehensive action plan needs to be carried out in order to reverse the vicious circle created by the lack of investment that has fuelled a growing disparity between EU regions.  To this end, and without prejudice to the indispensable structural reforms that ensure the financial and social sustainability of the States of the Union, the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), reinforced with member states' financial contributions, should complement the competitiveness and investment strategy.  The implementation of this fund will allow the cofinancing of projects, in partnership with private investors who, leveraged by EFSI, will enable the implementation of investments with productive and strategic capacity, capable of generating return and ensuring the indispensable boost to the European economy.  In the light of the present, and in view of the indispensability and provisionality of the project, I voted in favour of the provisions establishing the EFSI as a distinct mechanism, identifiable and transparent, with its own specificity and instruments.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. The European Parliament yesterday adopted in plenary the agreement reached with the Council on the regulation establishing a European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) which reflects the Juncker plan to boost investment in Europe.  I voted in favour of this agreement, which echoes Parliament's demands to ensure democratic control and transparency of the EFSI. The agreement will also allow Member States' contributions to the EFSI and investment platforms (which can include public banks and local authorities) to be excluded from the calculation of budget deficits. This is a strong signal to revive public investment in Europe and in our territories.    With the commitment of MEPs in the Committee on Transport, we have secured to limit the contribution to the EFSI of the Interconnection Mechanism in Europe, which funds trans-European transport networks. Therefore, the agreement makes it possible to clearly integrate a reference to transport projects, with a view to allocating EFSI funds.  Finally, this agreement will allow the EFSI to be operational quickly to respond to the urgent need to revive investment. We will have to closely monitor the implementation of the Juncker plan, which aims to create more than EUR 315 billion in investment.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. By adopting the Fernandes-Bullmann report today, MEPs have sent a clear signal in favour of the Juncker plan and the resumption of investment in Europe. I also voted in favour of this agreement reached with the Council on the Strategic Investment Fund, which, if not perfect, preserves the essentials by reducing the participation of the Horizon 2020 programmes and the mechanism for interconnection in Europe to the financing of the European guarantee: it goes from 6 to 5 billion euros. The Juncker plan is therefore in the process of being launched with a starting stake of 21 billion: 16 for the European Union and 5 from the BCI. A sum that may seem considerable, but it will not be too much to attract private investors who need a stable environment. The latter would commit in practice to co-financing major infrastructure projects (energy and transport, telecommunications, environment) expected in vain since the Delors era. This means that It is in Europe's interest to find solutions quickly, not only to the Greek crisis, but also to the stabilisation of the euro area as a whole and to the completion of economic and monetary union.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the creation of the European Strategic Investment Fund. This investment plan, initiated by Juncker, provides 315 billion euros to encourage the financing of viable investments in Europe, especially in the energy and digital sector: 240 billion euros should be spent on investments and 75 billion on businesses, mainly SMEs. The aim is to make an additional contribution to the EIB's investments, on the basis of mainly private investments, by supporting more ambitious and risky projects.  This plan represents an extraordinary opportunity for Europe to demonstrate more than ever to citizens its ability to emerge from the crisis. Some prerequisites for the success of this fund are necessary, including the reduction of obstacles to the achievement of the European single market, the implementation of structural reforms in some countries and the mobilization of all the actors involved.  We must also ensure greater transparency in the implementation of this plan, and the European Parliament has ensured that responsibilities are clearly assigned in the governance of the Fund, and has also ensured that it improves its working arrangements and democratic accountability.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) because I believe that the outcome achieved by the European Parliament following tough negotiations with the Council marks the concrete achievement of our priority of reorienting European economic policy towards growth and investment.  We have made FEIE an investment tool that promotes projects in line with our political priorities.    The agreement reached ensures the financing of quality investments, facilitates additional co-financing for all Member States, strengthens the governance of THE EIE within the European framework and proposes more appropriate and ambitious alternative funding from the Guarantee Fund to safeguard European R&D&I and transport programmes, Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Mechanism with an additional EUR 1 billion.  This is a good agreement which will give an urgent impetus to much-needed investments in the Union.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Parliament today approved the European Fund for Strategic Investments. This vote - of which I welcome - marks the end of a legislative process that demonstrates Parliament's commitment to this plan. Parliament sought to improve the funding structure of the Plan Guarantee Fund, the Fund's governance rules, its working arrangements and its democratic accountability. The main successes are the reduction of cuts in the European research and innovation programme Horizon 2020 and in the mechanism for interconnection in Europe of one billion euros. Horizon 2020 and the MIE, two of the three sources of EU guarantee funding supporting the plan, will now contribute EUR 2.2 billion and EUR 2.8 billion respectively, each 500 million euros less than originally proposed; guarantee that the EUR 1 billion recovered for the programmes will be paid by levying on the unused budgetary margins of 2014 and 2015; the list of approved projects will be public. In the Council of Ministers to do the same now. The Juncker Plan regulation will then come into force at the beginning of July, and its fund is expected to be fully operational by September 2015.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the European Fund for Strategic Investments - the so-called Juncker Plan, congratulating the rapporteurs on the excellent work done in recent months, with a special greeting to my colleague in the national delegation José Manuel Fernandes. As a very comprehensive matter and with some complexity, I would just like to highlight two ideas: the first is that this new Fund should be complementary and additional to the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF), as advocated in this report and in other documents adopted by the European Parliament, and that of the total of EUR 315 billion foreseen for the plan, EUR 75 billion is allocated to the , preferably, projects aimed at small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 In line with the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats and the majority of the European Parliament, I voted in favour of the report presented by Mr Fernandes and Mr Bullmann. The subject of the proposal for a regulation is one of the most interesting innovations proposed by the new Juncker Commission. The EFSI (European Fund for Strategic Investments), at the heart of the Juncker Investment Plan, plans to leverage private investment to reach a total investment of €315 billion over three years. New investments will therefore be released which will create jobs and growth, thus relaunching the Union's economy.  However, as a member of the TRAN and ITRE committees, I note that there will be an inevitable reduction in investment in certain specific sectors which are by their nature less attractive to private investors; In fact, even if investments in railways and inland waterways bring important socio-economic and environmental benefits, they are less profitable and require grants for them. Coordination is therefore needed to ensure that these high-level European projects can be reintroduced through the Juncker Plan.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against the Commission's proposal because, although the outcome of the tripartite dialogue improved the Commission's intolerable proposal, this Fund does not in any way constitute – neither because of its size nor its forms of administration – the countercyclical commitment that Europe needs.  If the Union budget represents less than 1% of the GNI of EU Member States (in fact, it represents 0.98% in 2015%), the EIE represents less than 1% of the EU's annual budget, a clearly insufficient amount to reverse the consequences of the procyclical policies promoted so far by the EU and carried out by its Member States.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am pleased that a rapid agreement has been reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). Since 2007, investment for SMEs has fallen by 15% across the EU. In order to counter this negative trend and to stimulate growth, employment and competitiveness, resources from the European budget and the European Investment Bank of 21 billion have been made available to EFSI. These funds are expected to have a leverage effect that can mobilise €315 billion between 2015 and 2017. The main objective of EFSI should be to help overcome the difficulties of financing and investing in strategic fields such as sustainable urban mobility, energy infrastructure, digital technologies, research, training and e-health.  Despite optimistic expectations, however, we cannot hope that this measure alone will solve the EU's structural and economic problems. I hope that this instrument will help to encourage new investment in the EU, but I hope that it will also be accompanied by proposals for deeper and more incisive reform of the European economic system.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments, known as the "Juncker Fund", in the version that resulted from a demanding negotiation between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, because the adoption of this fund is the recognition of a demand from the European Socialists that the European economy needs an investment boost that will make the European Union resume the path of economic growth and employment.  Despite the vote in favour, I have doubts about the expected financial leverage and I regret that this fund does not provide for positive discrimination in favour of convergence, in particular for the promotion of investment in the countries most affected by the crisis, including Portugal.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – In order to maximise the employment impact of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), Member States should continue to undertake structural reforms that are effective and economically and socially sustainable, as well as other initiatives such as training programmes and active labour market policies, the support of conditions for the creation of quality and sustainable jobs, and investment in targeted social policies. Member States should also undertake additional activities such as customised training programmes to match the skills of workers to the needs of sectors benefiting from the EFSI, tailor-made business services for enterprises to prepare them to expand and create more jobs, as well as support for start-ups and self-employed individuals. For these reasons, I voted in support of the EFSI report.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The European Union has still failed to kick-start the economy since the financial crisis in 2008 and also after the 2012 euro area crisis. I see the European Fund for Strategic Investments as an attempt at growth. At the same time, I appreciate that this fund will be coordinated at transnational level, thereby increasing the transparency of funding.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed European Fund for Strategic Investments is not perfect in design: I remain sceptical over the decision to strip Horizon 2020 of EUR 2.5 billion, particularly from collaborative research and societal challenges, and it would have been preferable to source the guarantee from the margins of the EU budget. The development of the plan also needs to be scrutinised to ensure that the Commission’s promises of a leverage multiplier of 15 with private money comes to fruition. Nevertheless, the plan provides the opportunity to front-load important spending on renewable energy projects, energy efficiency, electricity and transport networks, and seed capital for SMEs, at a time when Europe is crying out for investment capital: under this plan many projects which otherwise would have been tied up in red tape for years can be brought forward now. In addition, Parliament has improved the Commission’s original proposal, such as through the governance of the Fund and the criteria for project selection. Scotland can benefit significantly, from North Sea marine energy grids to electric car infrastructure to renovation of buildings for energy savings. Therefore I voted in favour.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 One year has passed since the idea of creating a European Fund for Strategic Investments to praising it. During this time, we have discussed and supplemented the amendments in committees so that the final result of implementation is as effective as possible. The ESIF had its opponents but also its supporters from the outset. I personally believe in this fund, and I expect that the projects implemented will bring the expected leverage in the growth of the economy and in the creation of new jobs. I consider it important that private capital is part of the investments under this fund, because with such investment there is a greater chance of investing effectively, eliminating unnecessary bureaucracy and delays from plans to implementation. I share the opinion of the REGI committee that the European Fund for Strategic Investments should also take into account geographical balance, thereby contributing to strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this proposal for a regulation. The emerging fund promises to stimulate long-term economic growth. The EU will guarantee public funds, thereby enabling loans for selected projects. Within 3 years, this plan should mobilise new investments up to an estimated EUR 315 billion. This fund is also an opportunity to implement projects that would not (due to their higher risk iness) for investments made in the classical way. Approximately 1/4 of the Fund's funds will be provided for projects for SMEs and mid-caps. However, I think it is right that these projects will be selected according to certain criteria. In particular, these will be economically and technically feasible projects, with a focus on infrastructure development, research, innovation, education or energy. It is with the last mentioned that I see an important element for the Czech Republic, namely the possibility of reducing dependence on russian gas imports in connection with projects focusing on the interconnection of energy systems. Last but not least, I would also like to emphasise the fact that the EFSI is expected to create up to 2 million new jobs (and probably 1-2 million more by 2030), which represents an important contribution in the fight against unemployment in the EU.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The Guarantee Fund for the growth of the European economy and the creation of new sustainable jobs is estimated to create between 1 and 1.3 million new jobs and mobilise at least 315 billion investment funds between 2015 and 2017. As this is an important novelty in the capital market, this raises many questions. Above all, it is clear that we have the right to demand the best possible and maximum transparency over resources. The important question is therefore whether this fund should become a financial instrument which will be subject to greater scrutiny by the European Court of Auditors, thus giving greater emphasis on assessing the efficiency of the use of funds and the achievement of the objectives. In addition, it can also become the subject of discharge in the European Parliament, and in this way the concrete role of parliament towards this fund is strengthened. I would also like to point out that the regulation clearly provides for the use of indicators to assess the impact of projects before and after the investment is approved. Before adopting the indicator act, we must therefore not forget the requirement to place greater emphasis on the priority selection of sustainable projects that provide long-term and quality jobs. I voted in favour of the RESOLUTION on the EFSI as a whole, as I believe that this fund, with proper interinstitutional cooperation, is a good step towards reviving economic growth in Europe.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Small and medium-sized enterprises form the backs of the European economy and have been hardest hit by the crisis. The Investment Mechanism is an opportunity to help them and thus increase employment and economic growth across the Union. However, it will depend on our government whether it uses its instruments to fulfil its purpose.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒I support this Report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments and on the amendment of regulations. Member States most affected by the crisis see a lack of investment, which has a negative impact on job creation and long-term growth. The consequence is also growing inequality between regions, and creating an investment-friendly environment would strengthen the economic progress needed to achieve the Europe 2020 objectives for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Investment financing, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility would contribute to improving the union's competitiveness and attract investment.  Effective structural reforms, which will be both economically and socially sustainable, as well as support the conditions for creating quality and sustainable jobs and investing in social policies under the Social Investment Package, need to continue to increase the impact of the EFSI. In addition, it is necessary to harmonise the skills of workers benefiting from EFSI and to adapt business services.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The European Fund for Strategic Investments is at the heart of President Juncker's investment plan. I support this fund, which is a great opportunity for all Member States of the European Union, and primarily for countries where the economy is stagnating or growing at very small rates. The decline in investments after the beginning of the economic crisis has further exacerbated the recession and this plan is a great opportunity to stimulate new growth and create jobs, especially in new members such as Croatia, whom the decline in investments has further made cohesion more difficult. In Croatia, GDP has been falling continuously since the end of 2011 with minimal growth in the last two quarters (0.2% IV/2014; 0.5% I/2015) and this fund is an additional opportunity to change trends and increase economic activity. I consider it necessary to point out that, in addition to public ones, it is very important to mobilize private investments in order to maximaist the impact of public investments and to realize riskier projects. I hereby invite private investors from all countries and croatia to engage and apply. I must mention the project of reconstruction and upgrading of Dubrovnik Airport, which is one of the accepted projects for co-financing from this initiative. In addition, I hope that the construction of the Pelješac Bridge, a capital project that would finally territorially connect Croatia and the European Union, will find a place in this plan.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Since the beginning of the economic crisis, however, we have seen a decline in investment, which is causing uncertainty in the financial markets. The European Union must respond to the current situation. I therefore support the European Fund for Strategic Investments, as the funds from the Fund will be beneficial not only for individuals, but also for the whole of the European Union. In this context, I would like to stress that member states must also do their homework and create a friendly investment environment through appropriate structural and economic reforms.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), which is an important element of the Investment Plan for Europe to stimulate long-term economic growth and competitiveness. This fund will help to draw on public funds, including from the EU budget, in order to activate private investment. It is to bring in up to EUR 315 billion in new investment across the EU over three years. In particular, the Juncker Investment Plan will aim to ensure the interconnection of broadband, energy and transport networks, support education, research and innovation, the provision of renewable energy sources and energy efficiency.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Fund for Strategic Investments is an incomplete project, which, instead of promoting growth and public investment in the real economy, transfers the risk of investment to the already austere Member States and taxpayers, leveraged profits for private capital. 'So while guarantees and losses will be socialised, profit will be privatised. Even these scarce public investments will be used by cuts from other projects, such as €3.3bn (£3.3bn) in funding. from the Connecting Europe programme and €2.7 billion from the European Investment Bank (EIB) and €2.7 billion from the European Investment Bank (EIB). Horizon 2020.  For these reasons we have decided to vote against.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Tackling poverty and unemployment is not achieved by setting up funds, which are more a means of manipulating public opinion than solving the problem.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the fund behind the investment plan, as I believe that an effective compromise has been reached. The vote was preceded by a long and meaningful debate, the primary result of which, from a social point of view, is that social utility is finally put before purely economic considerations. I believe that investment promotion and quality and long-term sustainable job creation are a new milestone in the life of the European Union, whose socialist roots are unquestionable. The amount itself is not enough to solve all problems, but the approach can be a good tool, unlike previous austerity policies.  A number of parliamentary committees contributed to the joint report of the Committees on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Committees on Budgets by forming so-called opinions. So, for example, the EP Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on which I was given the task of coordinating the proposals of the Socialists and Democrats' group. My primary objective in drafting this opinion was to ensure growth and job creation in rural areas for both Community and private investment, with no increase in administrative burdens. The most important elements of this have also been included in the final report.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Given S&D's contribution to the final form of this programme, I reiterate that we will not agree to the reduction of research funding. The Horizon 2020 Strategy and the Connecting Europe Facility now benefit from a budgetary solution for maintaining financial strength and continuing the investment started. We must bear in mind that Programmes dedicated to European research and innovation must not be a source of emergency funds for other programmes and must remain functional, because they produce jobs and clear results in the economy.  I am taking advantage of the political consensus on a programme that will give us opportunities for sustainable development to draw attention to the fact that the application of the EFSI must be fair to all Member States, but especially to regions that have to catch up with substantial development gaps, both in terms of infrastructure and in other socio-economic aspects. I believe that we must take advantage of every opportunity we have to ensure European solidarity, including at the economic level. The EFSI now represents a chance to develop the EU's border infrastructure, to reduce economic and social cleavages in Europe and to increase competitiveness in all European regions, including the least rich.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the european Parliament and the Council's proposed regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments. After peaking in 2007, the level of investment in the European Union has fallen by about 15% and is now well below its historical trend. This situation is the result of, among other things, the economic and financial crisis, and hinders economic recovery, job creation, long-term growth and competitiveness. With the recovery expected in the coming years only partial, further measures are needed to address this investment deficit. It was therefore normal for the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development to support the European Commission's policy guidelines for 2014-2019, which have made this issue a major political challenge.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the vote in favour of the report on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). This Fund, if correctly implemented and if the Commission and Member States deliver on their promise that it will attract additional investment in the fields of research, innovation, energy and transport, can then have a real added value and boost investments to enhance European competitiveness.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments is certainly good news for Europe.  The adoption of this initiative represents a fundamental step in a necessary path for the recovery of the economy and for the change in our economic strategies which, with this text, relaunch a macroeconomic strategy for development and growth. I welcome the significant improvements introduced by Parliament, in particular with regard to governance, the setting of targets for investment guidelines, the evaluation system, the scoreboard. I would also like to stress that this fund will make it possible to invest additional resources to help overcome market failures, financial fragmentation, alongside traditional instruments of support for research, innovation and energy efficiency.   I hope that this Fund will also help to strengthen public and private investment capacities, especially in the most difficult geographical areas.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ In the report, I recognise the possibility of quality action that will allow funds from the Fund for Strategic Investments to be distributed towards alleviing macroeconomic imbalances, both in the Republic of Croatia and in other Member States with a low GDP rate.  I find it extremely useful to have increased access to finance that intends to allocate funds so that funding benefits SMEs, which must be at the heart of supporting investment in the Union.  In doing so, it is important that the projects to be financed by the Funds provided by the Fund are selected on the basis of their effectiveness and not by political criteria, which is unfortunately not the case in this proposal. We must not forget that the Fund will be financed with taxpayers' money, which is why the selected projects must have the optimal rate of return and be of greatest benefit to the citizens who finance these projects.  The appointment of three of the four members of the Management Board of the Fund by the European Commission and the main role assigned to the Commission in the work of the Fund indicate that the policy will have a major impact in the selection of the project; but let us hope that the European Parliament, through the control it will carry out, will ensure that the economic benefits will be the main criteria that govern the structure governing the Fund.  So I voted abstention.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the European Fund for Strategic Investments. As a result of the economic and financial crisis, the level of investment in the EU has decreased by around 15 % since the peak of 2007. There's plenty of liquidity. However, the uncertain economic outlook and high public and private debt are holding back investment in some parts of the EU. President Juncker's Investment Plan for Europe will help by linking projects to existing liquidity and directing money where it is needed. The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) is at the heart of this plan. It is the main tool for mobilising €315 billion in new investment in the real sector of the economy over the next three years. The Fund will be set up within the EIB (European Investment Bank) to act as a strategic partner for the Commission. It will finance projects with a higher risk profile, which will increase the impact of public spending and the relaxation of private investment. A guarantee fund will also be set up to cover the risks of efsi guarantees.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I fundamentally disagree with the EU's contribution to the Fund at the expense of the cuts in Horizon 2020 and CEF that we have negotiated intricately. On the other hand, we have now managed to save at least basic research under Horizon 2020. I also think we should give the fund a chance. In the end, I therefore decided to abstain.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) aims to promote economic growth, employment and recovery in Europe. The new initiative promises to allow for new investments of EUR 315 billion over a three-year period, most of which will be financed by the private sector. What is not so clearly stated, however, is the fact that the European Investment Bank is liable for defaults. In concrete terms, this means that the taxpayer should be liable for the default risks of private entrepreneurs. Irrespective of these considerations, EFSI will fail anyway. It is inconceivable that a new authority could make better decisions than thousands of company bosses. If this task were to be taken seriously, thousands of civil servants would have to be recruited. This is a step towards a planned economy on the part of the EU. Knowing what planned economic policy has done, particularly in Eastern Europe, the EFSI must be rejected.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I think that the agreement reached during the trilogues was the best possible one taking into account the position of the Council and the Commission, which was many times completely united against Parliament. I do not think that the Juncker Plan is the cure for all our economic problems, nor do I think it is perfect, but I do think it can be useful and goes in the right direction. The Juncker Plan can help to build those European infrastructures still needed to enhance our growth and deepen the single market. Moreover, a personal objective was from the beginning that provisions be included that ensure that the EFSI will not be used to build airports without planes or trains without passengers. Only those projects with capacity to attract private investors will be able to be part of the fund. Maybe EFSI will work as it is intended to. Maybe it will not, but in any case I really think we have to give it a chance, as its potential benefits far outstrip its funding mistakes.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against the Commission's proposal because, although the outcome of the tripartite dialogue improved the Commission's intolerable proposal, this Fund does not in any way constitute – neither because of its size nor its forms of administration – the countercyclical commitment that Europe needs.  If the Union budget represents less than 1% of the GNI of EU Member States (in fact, it represents 0.98% in 2015%), the EIE represents less than 1% of the EU's annual budget, a clearly insufficient amount to reverse the consequences of the procyclical policies promoted so far by the EU and carried out by its Member States.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted against this report because the European Fund for Strategic Investments is far from the investment plan needed for Europe. This simple readjustment of the budgetary resources already available, without new money or liquidity, cutting in environmental matters, is a missed opportunity.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the Juncker Plan. In my opinion, this is a very important project, which is also relevant for Lithuania. It should be noted that this is a big step forward. I hope that this project will be implemented. I would encourage more development.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments, as I believe that the European economy urgently needs the establishment of a new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), which will  bridge the EU investment gap. ‘The Juncker Plan’ as we MEPs also call it, is a flagship which could create a multiplier effect that could mobilise additional investments over the next years.  Furthermore, the EFSI could act as a guarantee which could unlock billions of euros in investment in projects, infrastructure and small businesses – a necessary step to get out of the current economic crisis.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. Following the conclusion of a trilog agreement within the prescribed time limits, the start-up of the new instrument will be possible from June/July. The agreed text will make it possible to define more precisely what this European fund will do and how it will do so, as well as to balance governance. It is therefore necessary to vote in the affirmative on this report in order to promote the implementation of one of the pillars of this legislature.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE) because I believe that the result achieved by the European Parliament following tough negotiations with the Council will specify our priority of reorienting European economic policy towards growth and investment.  We have made FEIE an investment tool that promotes projects in line with our political priorities.    The agreement reached ensures the financing of quality investments, facilitates additional co-financing for all Member States, strengthens the governance of THE EIE within the European framework and proposes more appropriate and ambitious alternative funding from the Guarantee Fund to safeguard European R&D&I and transport programmes, Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Facility with an additional EUR 1 billion.  This is a good agreement which will give an urgent impetus to much-needed investments in the Union.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. During the debate in plenary, Mr Weber said that voting against the Juncker Fund is not common sense. I wonder, then, whether it is common sense to vote in favour of a fund that takes billions away from research to finance major unsustainable works or infrastructures such as relifiers and gas stockings; if it is common sense to insist on short-term clientele finance to find solutions for the real economy; if it is common sense to vote today on a proposal for a regulation when the EIB has already identified and announced for months the projects it intends to finance, thus going beyond the parliamentary process and the EFSI regulation.  Experience in recent years has taught us that project financing provides profits for individuals and lobbies by making risks fall on the public guarantee. The examples are many, starting from my region, Lombardy, which is full of financial black holes, as demonstrated by the Brebemi and Teem projects.  The EFSI is therefore yet another tool that will allow private individuals to maximise profits at the expense of the community, financing projects with little added value and with a high risk of exposure to mafia infiltration and corruption in subcontracting. That is why the 5 Star Movement had the good sense to vote against this initiative.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: Written. \u2012 The economic engine in Europe is sputtering. The EFSI investment plan can provide additional investment. But to make our economy healthy again, that will not be enough. A real recovery policy with structural reforms is essential for this. The N-VA had some basic red lines. We are pleased that they can also be found in the final text to a large extent. For example, not politicians but independent experts will decide which projects are funded. That is a good thing because politicisation would have deterred private investors. However, N-VA is not satisfied with the financing of EFSI. It is disappointing that horizon 2020 and CEF, EU programmes are already being cut, creating additional growth and jobs. These programmes are also very important for Flanders, not least for our research institutions. It is positive that the European Parliament has succeeded in safeguarding some of the basic research programmes, but unfortunately this is not enough.  With this abstention, we want to send a very clear message: the resources cut in the successful Horizon 2020 and CEF programmes should be offset as soon as possible by adjustments in the European budget.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This fund is a fundamental bet of this European Commission. It is not the desirable public investment plan that would be necessary. It represents, first of all, a financial engineering exercise of dubious results. Bet on ppp, of bad memory, which today represent a sweatof public resources. It gives no guarantee of a fair geographical distribution of the investment. It is not understandable to the average citizen that the ECB has €60 billion to spend every month to buy debt securities and other assets, but at the same time there is no EU capacity to finance a genuine public investment programme capable of relaunching economic growth.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I have refused to endorse the report on the European Fund for Strategic Investments, because I believe that the European Fund for Strategic Investments cannot achieve the leverage effect of EUR 315 billion provided for in the report. In addition, a large part of the money would have to be taken from special funds, which in turn would secure the financing of other projects, but which do not correspond to the market character of the fund.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the regulation because I believe that EFSI is the first concrete step towards moving from a Europe of austerity to a Europe of growth and jobs. The text from the trialogue is much stronger than the Commission's initial proposal. We will now have to work to ensure that the Fund funds high-risk projects that stimulate growth and deal in particular with new forms of the economy.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. Little concrete, a lot of leverage, a lot of hope – that is the EFSI. A €315 billion investment fund is designed to boost the economy in the EU Member States. There is no question that economic performance can be improved in many Member States, and it is the task of national governments and national parliaments to launch national programmes tailored to their own infrastructure. The EFSI is to be financed only from rescheduled funds from the EU budget and a capital injection from the European Investment Bank. To this end, the EU budget will be reallocated at the expense of the current horizon 2020 research investment programme. This is haphazard. In addition, the EFSI only provides guarantees and serves as "EU insurance" for investment projects for which professional lenders do not want to put their hand on fire. The EU Commission now wants to mobilise private capital for risk investments. However, Commission President Juncker cannot credibly explain the projected leverage effect of "1 euro of invested tax money = 15 euros of private investment". The EFSI is the wrong way to go and a lot of eye-washing, so I reject it.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the amendments by Parliament to the Commission Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). As a crucial element in the European Union’s growth strategy, employment remains a priority for the European Union. The EFSI offers an invaluable resource for many small and mid-size companies, including start-ups and spinoffs, which struggle to attract investment. The higher risk portfolio of the EFSI will encourage small-business owners and rising entrepreneurs to once again trust in Europe. The criteria stipulated for the selection of projects will ensure that our goals for smart, sustainable growth in Europe happen, by encouraging projects focused on social, economic, and territorial cohesion and job creation. I congratulate the Committees on the Budget and on Economic and Monetary Affairs for their work in amending the proposal by the Commission. I look forward to the implementation of the EFSI through our continued cooperation with the Commission.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the European Strategic Investment Fund (EFSI). I welcome the perspective of the rapporteurs, who have shown that the EFSI should support projects that promote quality job creation, growth and competitiveness in the short, medium and long term, research, education and training at an early age, infrastructure and energy transition and efficiency. The report adopted by the EP also stresses that investments supported by the EFSI should contribute to the achievement of existing Union programmes and policies and to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The EFSI aims to mobilise at least EUR 315 billion in private and public investment across the European Union. The Commission proposal also establishes a European investment advisory platform.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: In writing. The investment plan voted today is of great importance to the European Union and I have been keen to give my full support to it. More than ever, the Union needs to open up major strategic projects that will enable it to rise to the challenges of the 21st century, and that is precisely what the Juncker plan is responding to. Furthermore, I am pleased that the European Parliament has weighed in on the definition of the Rules of the Fund and would like to congratulate Mr Fernandes on his work as rapporteur on such a complex and important issue for the future of the European Union.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the draft regulation on the establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), as it can contribute to boosting economic growth and falling unemployment in the European Union. Additional funding for investment in transport and strategic infrastructures (digital technologies and energy), research and innovation centres, as well as investment spurring employment (especially for young people) will not only improve macro-economic indicators, but will also change in favour of the situation of individual regions in the Union. This also applies to the Kujawsko-Pomeranian Voivodeship in Poland, which is out of step with the average standard of living in the EU. Over the next three years, the EFSI is projected to mobilise investments of at least EUR 315 billion, the main beneficiary of which will be small and medium-sized enterprises. They play a key role in the economy, particularly in terms of job creation. Given the scale of the resources that are intended to be spent under the Fund, I believe that particular account should be taken of the prevention of fraud and irregularities that may occur in the process of their distribution. To this end, it is necessary not only to establish closer and effective cooperation between OLAF and the European Investment Bank, but also to intensify the ongoing work in the Council on a regulation on the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the reform of Eurojust.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the European Fund for Strategic Investments is a project worth giving a chance to implement. The dramatic fall in investment in the European Union in recent years is a problem for all Member States. Unlocking the investment potential of the private sector and effective cooperation between private companies and public institutions can be key to restoring many jobs in the European Union that have disappeared as a result of the economic crisis. Of course, the European Parliament cannot dispense with its audit tasks in the case of the EFSI and should keep a close eye on all the EC's activities in this regard. We cannot allow the creation of the EFSI to have a negative impact on other programmes that already support investment in Member States, including, in particular, the CEF and Horizon 2020 instruments. Investments in the transport sector and increasing the infrastructure capacity of less developed regions of the European Union should play a particular role in projects adopted for implementation by efsi. I believe that the support for this project opens up many new opportunities and creates many opportunities, including for Polish, which needs to free up new resources to rebuild industry and huge investment in other areas.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. \u2012 Although more could be done, the Juncker plan is certainly a great step towards a Europe that ultimately decides to turn its back on austerity and look forward with confidence to a future of growth and investment. This grand investment plan of 315 billion is the best response we could give to all the Eurosceptics who continue to bring Parliament's work into disrepute. Now, however, we must ensure that this plan does not become a half-failure like the Youth Guarantee, which failed to deliver the results we expected.  I am proud of the work done by the S&D Group, which has ensured that national contributions to EFSI, but also to national promotional banks and national platforms linked to the Fund, are considered one-off measures without consequences for the tax position of countries.
