It has also achieved a Fund governance structure that ensures greater independence from the EIB and greater democratic control, as well as an EFSI EU financing system that reduces funds taken from the already pro-growth and innovation programmes and Horizon 2020 and CEF infrastructure by 1 billion, while using the margins allowed from the EU budget.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today we voted on financial contributions from the so-called Globalisation Fund. The fund is designed to help people who have become unemployed following the closure of European companies. I consistently vote against payments from this fund for two reasons: firstly, labour market policies and financial support for the unemployed should be decided on, and financed, at national level – not at European level. Secondly, the basic idea of the Fund is based on the fact that globalisation is something negative – which is not true. Globalisation and free trade lead to growth and peace.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. For the general budget of the EU for the financial year 2015, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund shall be mobilised to provide the sum of EUR 630 000 in commitment and payment appropriations.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has already helped many workers across Europe who have lost their jobs as a result of the collective redundancies caused by the effects of the financial and liberal crisis. In Wallonia, several hundred dismissed workers from CARSID, Caterpillar, Duferco NMLK, Saint Gobain Sekurit and ArcelorMittal have already benefited, while a file concerning AGC Roux and Saint Gobain Glass is being prepared. This dossier, which I have approved, provides for the funding of technical assistance to the Commission, which will enable the Commission to carry out the evaluation of the projects implemented, the creation of a knowledge base and the networking of Member States developing EGF projects.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The annual budget available for the EGF in 2015 is EUR 150 million and, in accordance with Article 11, paragraph 1 of the WEF Regulation, 0.5% of this amount (EUR 811,825 in 2015) can be allocated, on the Commission's initiative, to technical assistance to finance a number of monitoring, training and information activities on the WEF. The report follows a request from the Commission to mobilise EUR 630,000, or 0.39%. The EGF, which must support workers who are victims of redundancies and the consequences of globalisation, could appear to be a good measure if it did not in fact close the loopholes that the EU itself has opened by its liberal policy and its desire to open up borders completely, leaving European companies to face unfair competition from many countries outside Europe in particular. The report proposes, as it stands, to allocate this funding but also to raise awareness of the EGF, to improve the monitoring and evaluation of aid granted and to estimate the effectiveness of the fund over the long term, or to allow for more flexibility in the intervention of member states. I have decided to abstain on this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Deprez report. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a concrete and indispensable instrument for supporting companies and workers affected by the crisis; The report we are voting on is balanced and also offers indications that we can support in improving its operation, but much still needs to be done in this respect.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to assist laid-off workers and self-employed people who have had to end their activities as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns caused by globalization, the continuation of the global financial and economic crisis or a new global economic and financial crisis, and help them rejoin the labour market. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 630 000 from the EGF for technical assistance to improve the functioning and implementation of the fund. This technical assistance will improve the monitoring and collection of data on EGF requests, general knowledge, information and visibility through the improvement of its website, a knowledge base/application interface will be created to standardise, simplify and speed up the processing of application and management procedures, administrative and technical support to FEAG Member States will be strengthened and an intermediate assessment will be financed with a view to concluding the assessment by 30 June 2017, as required by Article 20(1)(a) of the EAGF Regulation.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the Commission's proposal to finance technical assistance for the management of the European Globalisation Fund from the Fund's own budget in order to ensure better visibility and operational efficiency of the EGF as a union solidarity instrument for redundant workers. This measure, as provided for in the EGF Regulation itself, proposes to be used to increase the effectiveness of the Commission's egf applications and to reduce the time taken by Parliament and the Council for the evaluation and approval of applications, to extend the list of eligible actions and beneficiaries to include self-employed and young people, and to provide incentives for the establishment of own businesses.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. Since the use of the EGF so far has, in my view, proved effective, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to support this report with my vote because I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a very important instrument for countering the effects of the crisis and that the Commission and the Member States must work to make it as efficient as possible.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The report aims to allocate EUR 630,000 to technical assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (FEAM) to finance the preparation, monitoring, data collection and creation of a knowledge base to better assess the conditions necessary for the implementation of the FEAM regulation. As a reminder, the FEAM's reason is to assist workers who have been dismissed justified by a change in the structure of international trade, in order to ensure their professional transition. In other words, the FEAM is only responding to the terrible consequences of the Commission's austerity policies. Like the common agricultural policy, the Union gives with one hand what it takes with the other.  That is why I abstained on this report.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The report also contains indications that we can support on how to improve the functioning of the EGF.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to provide assistance to people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in international trade, or due to a global economic crisis. It provides workers with additional assistance and accompanies them in their reintegration into the labour market. The report proposes to mobilise EUR 630,000 in funds to provide technical assistance to the Commission's services. The goal is to create a database to ensure better management and increased monitoring of the information transmitted. The aim is to ensure the transparency of the information and data exchanged. The report also stresses the importance of good budget management and calls on Member States to monitor the use of these funds. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and sound financial management (application EGF/2015/000 TA – Technical assistance on the Commission's initiative). The Commission's proposal concerns the mobilisation of resources to cover technical assistance on the Commission's initiative, with the aim of financing monitoring and information, in creating a knowledge/interface base and in advising Member States on the use, continuity and evaluation of the EGF. I therefore voted in favour of this measure, which I hope will help to increase knowledge of this instrument between Italian companies and national and local institutions.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report is concerned with providing provisions which would enable the Commission to progress with its role as a facilitator and coordinator of European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) applications and the results of such applications.  The EGF was established to support workers who have been made redundant in EU Member States as a result of the adverse effects of globalisation This Fund plays a vital role in ameliorating what is a very distressing situation for workers who have found their whole livelihoods placed into disarray. In what is often a very harrowing situation, it is important to focus on positive and constructive options which are available. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this report.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ This concerns the mobilisation of EUR 630 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), covering technical assistance for the Commission to finance monitoring, information, create a knowledge base interface and to advise Member States on using, following up and evaluating the EGF. The report also calls on the Commission to present Parliament with a complete analysis and report on the EGF funds already implemented and progress on integration into the System for Fund Management in the European Union from the beginning of 2011 until 2014. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am generally in favour of mobilising the EGF, although I am aware that it is certainly not the instrument that can best help workers who are victims of company crises. In this case, however, it is not a question of mobilising funding to support specific actions, but for information and technical assistance purposes. For these priorities, in my opinion, the European Commission could use other budget lines and resources already available and concentrate the entire amount of the EGF on cases of concrete business crises and support for workers. Because of these concerns, I preferred to abstain.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on Mr Deprez's report on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) and technical assistance on the Commission's initiative. Of course, the principle of the EGF can be supported since it was put in place to help workers who are victims of offshoring movements and the destructive effects of globalization. European employees, who are the first to suffer from the consequences of social dumping created by uncontrolled migration flows and by the economy's introduction of politics, deserve nothing less than this aid. However, the WEF seems to be part of a real hypocritical process on the part of the Union, since it is the comprehensive rules imposed by the World Trade Organisation and scrupulously followed by the Union that have led to the deindustrialisation of Europe and the dramatic employment consequences that ensue.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is certainly one of the main and important instruments of solidarity with those workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the economic crisis. In this first year of parliamentary activity, the Member States' requests for access to the Fund have already been numerous, a clear sign of the economic difficulties faced by companies. There is no doubt that the European Commission has been faced with an increasing number of requests and there is also no doubt that the procedures for simplifying applications so that they can be dealt with quickly must be streamlined and standardised. I voted in favour of the Commission's request for an increase in the budget, which is also intended to support Member States in preparing requests to respond more quickly to the needs of workers.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I believe that it is necessary to support the Commission's proposal on mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to provide technical assistance of 630,000. It is well known that under the EGF operating regulation, the maximum annual budget available is EUR 150 million per year. Some 0.5% of this amount, amounting to around EUR 800 000, must be made available for technical assistance. Bearing in mind that the Commission is proposing only EUR 630 000, i.e. only 0.39% of the total amount, below the permitted 0.5%, and also bearing in mind that the European Parliament has repeatedly pointed out the need for greater visibility of the ERDF as an EU instrument of solidarity with redundant workers, we consider technical assistance to be extremely important. We note that this amount will be allocated to financial instruments for preparation, monitoring, data collection and the creation of a knowledge base. It will also be channeled for administrative and technical support and information and communication activities as well as control, inspection and evaluation activities necessary for the implementation of the Regulation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). The Fund was set up to provide support to workers affected by the consequences of major trade changes. Under the provisions of Regulations (EU) Nos 1311/2013 and No 1309/2013, the Fund may not exceed the ceiling of EUR 150 million. With this proposal, the European Commission is calling for the mobilisation of EUR 630 000 to cover technical assistance with the objective of monitoring, collecting data and providing administrative and technical support to the Fund.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to technically improve the quality of support offered to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade.  With the adoption of this measure, EUR 630 000 can be mobilised in order to support the Technical Assistance of the Fund, which consists in financing monitoring and information, i.e. collecting data on applications received, contributions made and measures proposed and implemented, to create a common knowledge base that can lead to the adoption of standardised procedures for EGF applications for intervention and management and to advise Member States on the use of , continuity and evaluation of the Fund.  If the strengthening of these aspects is successful, the Union's financial support for workers made redundant will be managed dynamically and efficiently as possible, so that they can be successfully assisted in the procedures for reintegration into the labour market. It will be of paramount importance to strengthen networking and the exchange of EGF-related information, so that the impact of support provided on the basis of this Fund can be assessed.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide complementary support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns and to help their reintegration into the labour market. Regulation (EC) No 1927/2006 provides that 0.5 % of the maximum annual amount of the EGF may be made available annually for technical assistance on the initiative of the European Commission (EC). I agree with the proposal to mobilise EUR 630 000 to cover technical assistance costs to the European Commission. The aim is to finance monitoring and information in order to create a knowledge base/interface for applications and to advise Member States on the usefulness, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF. With this funding, we will contribute to the simplification of the application processes, which will allow better access to relevant data, the sharing of knowledge and information, leading to a more efficient future implementation of this Fund.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because this instrument is an important and effective measure to continuously address the consequences of the global financial and economic crisis for workers and the self-employed who have been made redundant or have had to cease their activities. It is our duty to make it possible and easier for everyone and those affected to move back into the labour market. The EGF is also an effective tool in the fight against youth unemployment – this is a particularly important issue for me.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has for several years been providing legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to all those workers who have unfortunately been suffering from the negative consequences of changing the structure of world trade for years. By voting in favour of Mr Deprez's report, I wanted to express my appreciation for the Commission's proposal of 15 April to mobilise an amount of EUR 630 000 from the Fund to cover technical assistance, that is to say, the financing of certain actions such as monitoring and information and the creation of a knowledge base and advisory activity to the Member States on the use, application and evaluation of the benefits/effects of the EGF. I would like to stress that access to the EGF should also apply to all those regions with a high rate of youth unemployment, especially all those young people up to the age of 25 who are unemployed, who are not studying or who are no longer undergoing training.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 On 15 April 2015, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision on the use of the EGF. The proposal aims to use EUR 630 000 from the Fund for technical assistance to the Commission. The purpose of technical assistance is to finance the establishment of supervision, information and knowledge base interfaces and to advise Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF. The Commission proposes that in 2015 the amount requested will be used to finance the following activities: monitoring and data collection, information, creation of a knowledge base interface, administrative and technical support, evaluation. In line with the European People's Party, I supported the adoption of the proposal.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilising money to simplify the application procedure of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund as well as to encourage general awareness of the Fund and its visibility. I believe in both the importance of the existence of this fund and the continuous development of its operation.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes that the European Parliament authorize the mobilization of EUR 630,000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to finance technical assistance on the Commission's initiative. The aim of technical assistance is to fund monitoring and information to Member States on the mobilization, implementation and evaluation of this fund and to create an interface to advise Member States on their request. Considering that it is essential for the proper use of the EGF that Member States know the modalities of its mobilisation and that they have data on the impact and implementation of this solidarity support on the part of the European Union towards European employees who have lost their jobs and are seeking retraining, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) has an annual budget of 150 million euros to financially support people who find themselves unemployed as a result of the crisis or globalisation. This can help be used for retraining, starting a business, or mobility. In this case, we have approved the release of EUR 630,000 to the Commission, in charge of the management of the Fund. This includes improving information and communication tools on the WEF and creating an application to streamline funding applications.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. \u2012 On 15 April 2015, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision on the use of the EGF. The proposal aims to use EUR 630 000 from the Fund for technical assistance to the Commission. The purpose of technical assistance is to finance the establishment of supervision, information and knowledge base interfaces and to advise Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF. The Commission proposes that in 2015 the amount requested will be used to finance the following activities: 1. Monitoring and data collection 2. Information 3. Create knowledge base /application submission interface 4. Administrative and technical support 5. Evaluation On the basis of the above, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: EGF/2015/000 TA 2015 - Technical assistance on the Commission's initiative. The latter helps employees severely affected by the financial crisis that has crossed Europe. However, it should be noted that the difficulties faced by these workers can also be attributed to EU policy, which is obsessed with globalism and gigantism. The gradual and already well-under-started lifting of national borders puts French workers in competition with European or non-European workers. However, it is clear that the treatment of the latter weighs heavily on the working conditions of French employees. That is why, behind an appearance of goodwill, this report highlights above all the hypocrisy of the Union.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ Conservatives believe that it is essential that EU expenditure is closely scrutinised on the basis of value for money and in line with this approach, we do not believe the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an efficient tool that offers value for money in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the gallery exists to support short-term redundant employees working in large companies. We believe that its allocations are already being mis-promoted to the dismissed in order to support third-party companies. We believe that the disbursement of EUR 630 000 in technical assistance to the Commission, conferences and briefings can be used to genuinely support the unemployed.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 On 15 April 2015, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). The proposal aims to use EUR 630 000 from the Fund for technical assistance to the Commission. The purpose of technical assistance is to finance the establishment of supervision, information and knowledge base interfaces and to advise Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF.  The Commission proposes that in 2015 the amount requested will be used to finance the following activities: 1. Monitoring and data collection 2. Information 3. Create knowledge base /application submission interface 4. Administrative and technical support 5. Evaluation On the basis of the above, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support for workers who have lost their jobs in large-scale closures. This report will improve monitoring and the functioning of the Fund, as well as creating a network for sharing best practice. Wales has suffered from large-scale job losses and could qualify for use of the Fund. However, despite repeated requests, the government refuses to apply. I will continue to work to get the same benefits for Welsh workers as those in other countries of Europe.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The EGF was created to provide additional support to redundant workers following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or the financial crisis, and to help them find new jobs. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training.  In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take steps to get their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. The proposal concerns the mobilisation of EUR 630 000 from the Fund to cover the Commission's technical assistance expenditure. The purpose of the technical assistance is to finance the monitoring and information in order to create a knowledge base/interface for applications and to advise Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I abstained on this resolution, because the WEF is only a shambles in relation to the ravages of globalisation.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 This report contains a decision to release funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This is technical assistance at the initiative of the European Commission. The expected contribution is EUR 630 000. This amount shall be used for monitoring and data collection, information activities, administrative and technical support for the organisation of meetings, seminars and evaluations. The main objective of all these measures is to simplify the application procedure as well as to promote general awareness and visibility of the EFG.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This is a useful initiative by the Commission to make it easier for entrepreneurs in difficulty to identify and assess the possibility of obtaining European Union support. It also protects the labour market in the Member States of the European Union. The initiative will speed up assistance to people losing their jobs, streamline procedures and improve the rationality and expediency of spending, with an emphasis on a more comprehensible cost-benefit assessment. Importantly, it also draws attention to giving Member States more flexibility in offering additional resources. I therefore support the rapporteur in his assessment of the proposal.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively in favour of this report, on the basis of the understanding that the measures proposed by the Commission should be financed as technical assistance in accordance with Articles 11(1) and 4 and Article 12(2), (3) and (4) of the EGF Regulation. I welcome the ongoing work on the standardised procedure for EGF applications and the use of the electronic data exchange system by managing bodies, which will make it possible to simplify and process applications more quickly and to improve reporting. The integration of the EGF into the electronic data exchange system has been going on for many years and the related costs to the EGF budget will remain relatively high over the next two to three years until the installation process is complete. I call on the Commission to present the progress of its integration into SFC2014 from the beginning of 2011 to 2014, and I urge the Commission to invite Parliament to the meetings and seminars of the expert group in accordance with the relevant provisions of the Framework Agreement between the European Parliament and the European Commission. I would also like to stress the importance of liaising with all actors involved in EGF applications, including the social partners.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the EGF, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and sound financial management. The allocation to the European Commission of a contribution of EUR 630 000 corresponds to the provisions of Articles 11 and 12 of the EGF Regulation. The financing of technical assistance activities provided by the Commission benefits the Member States benefiting from the Fund, which benefit from important support in the management of applications, workers, who can find the necessary information more easily, and the Fund itself, whose visibility is increased. Through this contribution, the Commission will carry out monitoring and data collection activities concerning the Fund, improve the Fund's website by making it available in all EU languages and work on an important technological simplification of procedures that will speed up and make more accessible requests for Fund assistance. Important measures to strengthen this important European instrument.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given I believe it is important that the application procedure of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is simplified and general awareness of the Fund and its visibility are increased.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. The report approves the mobilisation of a small part of the Commission's budget (EUR 630 000) to assist in the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This fund is used, for example, in the case of closure of the Company Delphi in the Bay of Cadiz, although the management of this item by the Junta de Andalucía did not give the promised results. The report includes an amendment tabled by rapporteur Liadh which aims to ensure that the number of laid-off workers needed to mobilisation the Fund can be revised down. This is an important point for the future revision of the EGF.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management (application EGF/2015/000 TA — technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission). The EGF was created to provide assistance to workers suffering from major structural changes in world trade trends, and by funding technical support for the management of this fund from the fund's own budget, the EU will contribute to better visibility and operational efficiency of the EGF. It is essential to ensure that institutions, organisations and foundations set up in the EU make the right use of Member States' funds and work as efficiently and efficiently as possible.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 On 15 April 2015, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision on the use of the EGF. The proposal aims to use EUR 630 000 from the Fund for technical assistance to the Commission. The purpose of technical assistance is to finance the establishment of supervision, information and knowledge base interfaces and to advise Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF. The Commission proposes that in 2015 the amount requested will be used to finance the following activities: monitoring and data collection, information, creation of a knowledge base/application interface, administrative and technical support, evaluation On the basis of the above, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it points out the importance of increasing general awareness about the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) and its visibility. It reminds applicant Member States of their role in publicising actions funded by the EGF to the targeted beneficiaries, authorities, social partners, the media and the general public. These are all worthwhile positions that should be supported.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 On 15 April 2015, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision on the use of the EGF. The proposal aims to use EUR 630 000 from the Fund for technical assistance to the Commission. The purpose of technical assistance is to finance the establishment of supervision, information and knowledge base interfaces and to advise Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF.  The Commission proposes that in 2015 the amount requested will be used to finance the following activities: 1. Monitoring and data collection 2. Information 3. Create knowledge base /application submission interface 4. Administrative and technical support 5. Evaluation On the basis of the above, having regard to the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, in accordance with the European People's Party, I supported the adoption of the proposal.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. The report approves the mobilisation of a small part of the Commission's budget (EUR 630 000) to assist in the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This fund is used, for example, in the case of closure of the Company Delphi in the Bay of Cadiz, although the management of this item by the Junta de Andalucía did not give the promised results. The report includes an amendment tabled by rapporteur Liadh which aims to ensure that the number of laid-off workers needed to mobilisation the Fund can be revised down. This is an important point for the future revision of the EGF.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Proposal of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 12. The Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation on budgetary issues and on good financial management, as I consider that the recognition of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is important in the general public, and even more important is the overall awareness and information of targeted beneficiaries, authorities, social partners, media, as well as constant communication with stakeholders at local and regional level.  Furthermore, the Commission and the Member States should work even harder to improve the monitoring and evaluation of the impact of EGF support, allow for greater flexibility during the disbursement period, improve budgetary measures to accelerate the mobilisation of the EGF, provide access to support for young people up to 25 years of age in regions with high unemployment, and certainly emphasise the importance of networking and exchanging egf information on new regulations.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I think it is essential to provide EUR 630,000 for technical assistance to enable the fund to function properly. Indeed, networking and exchange of information on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund improves its effectiveness.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The Fund should divert EUR 630 000 from the Commission's technical assistance to review and obtain information on the measures taken so far, with the aim of making the Adaptation Fund more efficient in the future. The amount requested is less than the maximum limit of EUR 750 000 available for such purposes. I am therefore voting in favour of this motion.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as it covers technical assistance to finance monitoring, for information, to create a knowledge base interface and to advise Member States on using, following up and evaluating the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, a fund that gives assistance to reintegrate into the labour market workers made redundant owing to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to help support workers who lose their jobs as a result of global economic changes in the event of major waves of redundancies. As important as the social cushioning of market-based developments is, it must be noted that this fund is a misconstruction. In doing so, the EU is taking on tasks which, in the sense of subsidiarity, are a matter for the nation states. However, we do not want a European superstate in which Brussels intervenes in all areas of life. The EGF is a step towards a European unemployment insurance scheme. This cannot work well in the EU. For this reason, the EGF, and consequently projects to be financed from this fund, must be rejected.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 On 15 April 2015, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision on the use of the EGF. The proposal aims to use EUR 630 000 from the Fund for technical assistance to the Commission. The purpose of technical assistance is to finance the establishment of supervision, information and knowledge base interfaces and to advise Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF.  The Commission proposes that in 2015 the amount requested will be used to finance the following activities: 1. Monitoring and data collection 2. Information 3. Create knowledge base /application submission interface 4. Administrative and technical support 5. Evaluation On the basis of the above, in view of the interinstitutional agreement concluded on 2 December 2015, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in accordance with the European People's Party.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The result of the ongoing global crisis has resulted in many workers not only losing their jobs, but also having difficulty reintegrating into the former social-economic environment. By voting in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I am defending assistance to workers in quick and effective ways, and in particular the strengthening of youth participation and employment in the labour market, which will be a substantial response to the global economic crisis.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which was set up to support the reintegration of workers and self-employed persons made redundant in the labour market as a result of major structural changes in world trade, the continuing global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis, is not used to being given to the needy of peripheral countries. The report is eligible because this envelope is being used to support information through the creation of a website, the creation of an application interface, the education of EGF professionals, etc., thus creating hope for a fairer use of the fund for the future.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. With a positive vote, I voted in favour of Mr Deprez's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Under the latter, it has been proposed to allocate EUR 630 000 as technical cover, on the Commission's initiative. This coverage will be useful for financing monitoring and information and for advising Member States, with continuity in the evaluation of member states' projects.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I abstained because this report attempts to improve the effectiveness of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which in itself is not bad. But this Fund is a hide-and-seek that fails to mask the ravages of the ultraliberal globalisation desired by the European Union.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This is a technical report which refers to the EUR 630 000 mobilisation of the Fund to cover technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission. Technical assistance is intended to finance control and information, create a knowledge base/application interface and advise Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF. In accordance with Article 11(1) of the EAGF Regulation, up to 0.5% of the Fund's maximum available resources (i.e. EUR 750 000 at 2011 prices) can be used each year for technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission. In accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to help support workers who lose their jobs as a result of global economic changes in the event of major waves of redundancies. As important as the social cushioning of market-based developments is, it must be noted that this fund is a misconstruction. In doing so, the EU is taking on tasks which, in the sense of subsidiarity, are a matter for the nation states. However, we do not want a European superstate in which Brussels intervenes in all areas of life. The EGF is a step towards a European unemployment insurance scheme. This cannot work well in the EU. For this reason, the EGF, and consequently projects to be financed from this fund, must be rejected.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the increase in expenditure associated with the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The European Union should not interfere with the natural development that firms can best cope with on their own, unless the market is crooked by regulations and subsidies.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been created to help former employees find a new job, education or self-employment, who have lost their jobs as a result of globalisation and the financial and economic crisis. Financed from the general budget of the European Union, the Fund has €150 million per year available to the Fund from 2014 to 2020.  The European Commission has requested the mobilisation of the 630,000 euro EGF for the technical improvement of the Fund itself. The amount would be used to collect data, create a knowledge base, inform and other technical and administrative assistance with a view to better informing about the Fund and its practical implementation and evaluating the measures already implemented.  I supported MEP Gérard Deprez's report, as it approves the request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the purpose of its more effective use and proposes additional activities in more detail. It calls for the standardisation and simplification of the procedure so that Member States can more easily access information on the Fund, apply and implement measures more efficiently to combat unemployment and mitigate the effects of the crisis.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report which requires the Commission to examine the reasons why the approval or implementation of many important projects for the EU is delayed. It is the European Commission's obligation to publicly explain to the citizens of Europe why this delay. The report also underlines the importance of social dialogue, which is essential today more than ever in my country, Latvia. Today, the participants of social dialogue are the weak point, the bodies of power do not listen to them. This report can turn the situation around at European level, lead it and get it on track. The EU Globalisation Fund is a relevant mechanism for social dialogue. It aims to help job seekers, paid workers, disadvantaged by major structural changes. Latvia's economy has a vital dependence on changes and fluctuations in the global economy. Our goal is to strengthen this mechanism. I voted for it.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes to transfer EUR 630 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund reserve to technical assistance aimed at financing activities related to monitoring, informing and advising Member States and monitoring the use of EFG resources. The Commission may request an annual allocation of EUR 750 000 to finance this activity. The Commission must use these funds in such a way as to increase the awareness and efficiency of efg assistance to globalisation-affected workers, while at the same time creating sufficient control over the actual use of these resources.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013, between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, because it is comprehensive and documented.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal concerns the mobilisation of an amount of EUR 630 000 for technical assistance in financing monitoring and information and in advising Member States on the use and evaluation of the EGF.  Given that the European Parliament has often highlighted the need for greater visibility of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund as an instrument of union solidarity with regard to the new deterioration of the world economy, I felt it was right to approve the Commission's proposal.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. "U2012 My support for the motion for a Resolution submitted by the European Parliament on the functioning and mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in which, I would like to stress, we have called for access to EGF aid for young people under the age of 25 who are not employed in regions with a high unemployment rate to expand, under certain conditions, access to EGF aid for young people under the age of 25 who are out of employment , education or training.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The resolution put to the plenary vote was intended to ensure additional technical assistance to EU institutions and Member States to make more effective use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF). Already operated in the case of the dismissal of employees of Mory Ducros in particular, this fund was created to financially support and facilitate the reintegration of workers who have become inactive due to an upheaval in international trade or the occurrence of a global economic crisis. In this, it helps to mitigate the effects of wild globalization. The resolution proposes that this instrument be further enhanced vis-à-vis the public and governments, and that technical assistance be provided to potential beneficiaries so that the potential of the WEF is fully exploited. The text also expresses an idea that I very much welcome: that the aid granted by the EGF can be extended to young people aged 25 and under who are not working, not studying or training. Even if it only acts on the margins, I consider the WEF to be an indispensable instrument in the current context. I voted for the report.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I would have voted in favour of the request for technical assistance to be used by the EGF, as I believe that the funds made available here will be used wisely and purposefully. I also consider the fact that the full capacity of the funds is not being used up to be positive. Better evaluation and data collection will ensure a more targeted use of EGF funding in the future.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the proposals contained therein will improve the work of the countries of the European Union, their ministries, municipalities and public bodies, making it easier for them to absorb the funds allocated to the EGF. This will make access to the Fund easier, more understandable for employees of EU countries and public bodies following these improvements.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it highlights the importance of increasing general awareness about the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in order to reach those who most need it. I also support increasing the Commission’s technical capabilities to monitor the funds and advise Member States on using and evaluating the efficacy of the EGF.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on  the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which aims to provide support for workers made redundant and self-employed persons whose activities have ceased as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, as a result of a continuation of the global financial and economic crisis, or as a result of a new global financial and economic crisis, and to assist them with their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. The Commission has now proposed to use EUR 630 000 from the Fund for technical assistance. In the framework of technical assistance, the Commission intends to finance the establishment of a monitoring, information and knowledge base interface and to advise Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF. The amount requested is within the 0.5% limit that can be used by the Fund for this purpose, the proposal is agreed by the Committee on Social Affairs and Employment and its adoption is supported by the Committee on Budgets responsible for competence. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Regulation No 1927/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 December 2006 established the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with the aim of supporting workers who have lost their jobs due to structural changes in the context of the global economy.  I am voting in favour of this report, which notes the importance of networking and the exchange of information on the EGF, in particular in relation to the provisions of the new EGF Regulation, thereby supporting the funding of the EGF contact expert group and the seminars on networking on the implementation of the EGF.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report follows a request from the Commission to allocate EUR 630,000 to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for technical assistance, to finance preparation, monitoring, data collection, the creation of a knowledge base, and to monitor and evaluate the activities necessary to implement the EGF Regulation.  The WEF was set up to provide assistance to workers suffering the consequences of a crisis in a given sector or affected by changes in the economic structures of Member States caused by globalisation and free trade.  While this Globalization Adjustment Fund is a step forward, it is still important to help devastated sectors and ensure the best possible economic transition.  In this sense, the Deprez report proposes to raise awareness of the EGF, to improve the monitoring and evaluation of aid granted and to estimate the effectiveness of the fund over the long term or to allow more flexibility in the intervention of Member States by allowing it to provide additional measures, to speed up the budgetary procedure for a faster mobilization of the EGF... So I decided to abstain.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF). It is a purely technical procedure that aims to validate the annual amount spent on technical assistance provided by the Commission to carry out all the tasks necessary for the proper functioning of this fund: monitoring and gathering of information, operation of the website, creation of a standard knowledge base and procedures, administrative and technical support, networking, evaluation, etc. In 2015, EUR 630,000 will be mobilised by the Commission, or 0.39% of the maximum annual budget of EUR 150 million allocated to the EGF.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of changes in the structure of world trade or the global economic and financial crisis, as well as to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market.  The EP has always stressed the need for greater visibility of the Fund as an instrument of solidarity with redundant workers. We are convinced of the need to strengthen contacts between all those involved in EGF applications, in particular the social partners and stakeholders at regional and local level, so as to create all possible synergies. In regions with a high rate of youth unemployment, access to EGF support should be extended to young people up to 25 years of age who are unemployed and outside each cycle of education and training.  We therefore welcome the Commission's proposal to mobilise an amount of EUR 630 000 to cover all technical assistance initiatives necessary to improve information, monitoring and data collection. The EGF's website will need to be regularly updated and every new element translated into all EU languages, in order to contribute to increasing the visibility of its activities.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 On 15 April 2015, the European Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). The proposal concerns the mobilisation of an amount of EUR 630 000 from the Fund to cover technical assistance, i.e. to finance monitoring and information, to create a knowledge/interface base and to advise Member States on the use, continuity and evaluation of the EGF.  Given that the EGF was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade and that the European Parliament has often stressed the need for greater visibility of the Fund as an instrument of union solidarity with these workers, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) provides support to people who lose their jobs due to major changes in the structure of world trade with globalisation or the economic and financial crisis. As shadow rapporteur, I voted on this report to amend the regulation to better implement EGF projects.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is helping workers who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade patterns, such as the closure of a large company. Our European companies, which respect the social rights for workers that have been created and acquired over decades, are lagging behind because of the higher costs that this entails. Imports into the EU of products that have not been produced under certain minimum social standards must be banned as soon as possible. Until that is the case, we can only mitigate the damage caused by globalisation in the countries concerned. I therefore voted in favour of releasing the funds from the Fund.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal tabled to mobilise the Fund in order to finance technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission. It is essential to ensure that support is used in a targeted and targeted manner. In particular, monitoring and data collection must be funded as well as information. This will allow for more efficient collection of data on applications received and publication on a website. In addition, measures to raise awareness and visibility of the EGF will be promoted. Investments in the development of a database and application interface are necessary to alleviate the administrative burden on Member States and to simplify the submission of applications. This is essential in order to provide advice more effectively to Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). I believe it is essential to provide support to redundant workers and the self-employed, whose activities have ceased as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, due to the continuing global economic and financial crisis, in order to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market.  Since its inception in 2007, the EGF has proven to be an effective and efficient tool for those who have lost their jobs. It is to be considered a concrete expression of European solidarity and a practical tool that helps people recover from large-scale redundancies. In particular, the EGF allows Member States to support targeted measures adapted to the circumstances of the workers in question. Since its inception, it has helped and continues to help some 91 000 redundant workers by providing them with assistance in training, finding a new job or other forms of support. It is necessary to ensure that the EGF continues to play a crucial role in the fight against unemployment.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 On the issue of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, given that it was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade, I can only agree with the initiative proposed by my colleagues and hope that it will be an important breakthrough in assisting workers in their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Over the last year, we have voted for many decisions to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. These decisions have helped workers who have found themselves in an unenviable position as a result of major structural changes in global trade flows and global financial and economic crises, in order to more easily wither the crisis and reintegrate into the labour market as painlessly as possible. Today's decision is somewhat different, but almost as important for workers who find themselves in an unenviable position due to global developments. The Commission's initiative focuses on the process of including the EGF in the electronic data exchange system (SFC2014) which has been going on for several years and is financially demanding and will result in an acceleration of the application processing process and adequate assistance to workers. I therefore support the Decision awarding the amount of EUR 630,000 precisely for the above purposes and I hope that the Fund will continue to justify the role it plays today and increase its recognition as a Union solidarity instrument with workers who have lost their jobs. This can be achieved through an analysis and report on EGF funds and an evaluation of its work between 2007 and 2013. I hope that the Commission will submit such a report to Parliament in due course.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Since the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support redundancy workers and the self-employed who ceased their activity due to major structural changes in globalisation-in-the-world trade flows, due to the protracted global financial and economic crisis mentioned in Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013; 546/2009(3) or the new global financial and economic crisis and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, I support the decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund under the General Budget of the European Union for the 2015 financial year in order to provide €630 000 in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations. Member States should show solidarity with each other when necessary and the Commission must assist them in doing so in order to spend the funds in the most equest and transparent way.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EFG) was created to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in global trade flows. The annual budget available for the EGF in 2015 is €150 million and in accordance with Article 11(1) of the EEA. The EGF Regulation 0.5% of this amount (EUR 811,825 in 2015) can, at the initiative of the Commission, be made available for technical assistance in order to finance a range of activities, from preparation, monitoring, data collection and development of basic knowledge to audit activities and the control and evaluation necessary for the implementation of the EGF Regulation.  The report proposes to mobilise €630,000, representing around 0.39% of the maximum annual budget available for the EGF in 2015, to fund an expert group of EGF contact persons and a seminar on the implementation of the EGF. It is important to increase overall awareness of the EGF and its recognition, as well as to strengthen the communication of all parties involved in applying for the mobilisation of the EGF, in particular social partners and stakeholders at regional and local level, with a view to attaining as many synergistic effects as possible. Consequently, I supported colleague Deprez's report on the proposal for an EP-Council decision to mobilise the EGF on cooperation on budgetary issues and on good financial governance.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. As we have seen, it has been of great use in the last period. I therefore support the proposal – and I voted for it – to mobilise an amount of EUR 630 000 from the Fund to cover technical assistance on the Commission's initiative. The objective of technical assistance is to finance monitoring and information and to advise Member States on the use, continuity and evaluation of the EGF. The scope of the Fund is also important, which is intended to finance the following activities: monitoring and collection of data, information and the EGF website, the creation of a knowledge base to develop standardised procedures for applications for assistance and the management of the EGF, administrative and technical support and the creation of networks between Member States.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the Deprez report, although I am one of those who have long had some reservations about the European Globalisation Fund. I believe that the funds from it should be channeled as evenly as possible to all Member States. Unfortunately, this is not happening yet, in my opinion. With the Deprez report under discussion today, I would like to note that I believe that the funds provided for technical assistance will be as low as possible, because the maximum amount of funds should be used for the main purpose of the European Globalisation Fund.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 On 15 April 2015, the Commission adopted a new proposal for a Decision on the mobilisation of the EGF. The proposal concerns the mobilisation of EUR 630 000 from the Fund to cover the Commission's technical assistance expenditure. The purpose of the technical assistance is to finance the monitoring and information in order to create a knowledge base/interface for applications and to advise Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF.  In accordance with Article 11(1) of the EGF Regulation, 0.5 % of the maximum annual amount of the EGF may be made available annually, on the Commission's initiative, for technical assistance expenditure. Since the proposed amount falls within that limit, I voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision to mobilise the EGF, in the above terms.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to assist laid-off workers and self-employed people who have had to end their activities as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns caused by globalization, the continuation of the global financial and economic crisis or a new global economic and financial crisis, and help them rejoin the labour market. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 630 000 from the EGF for technical assistance to improve the functioning and implementation of the fund. This technical assistance will improve the monitoring and collection of data on EGF requests, general knowledge, information and visibility through the improvement of its website, a knowledge base/application interface will be created to standardise, simplify and speed up the processing of application and management procedures, administrative and technical support to FEAG Member States will be strengthened and an intermediate assessment will be financed with a view to concluding the assessment by 30 June 2017, as required by Article 20(1)(a) of the EAGF Regulation.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) as part of the technical assistance presented at the commission's initiative. This technical assistance, which will be funded to the tune of EUR 630,000, or 0.39% of the maximum annual budget available for FEAM, is to finance a number of monitoring, training and information activities on feAM.  Through this report, the European Parliament recommends that the Commission's and Member States' networking activities include improving monitoring and assessing the impact of FEAM support on the various participants. I think it is necessary to be able to measure the long-term benefits on the beneficiaries of the EMF in the most precise way possible. The European Parliament also recommends greater flexibility in implementing the measures so that states can provide additional measures if opportunities arise. Indeed, while it is important to respect the established rules, I also think it is appropriate to give Member States some leeway in order to maximise the results of each FEAM intervention.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Having regard to the purposes of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I am in favour of the proposal to mobilise EUR 630 000 to cover technical assistance expenditure to the European Commission, in accordance with those laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1927/2006.  With this mobilisation, it will be possible, inter alia, to finance the creation of a database of advice and information to Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF. Through this instrument, there will be a simplification of the application procedures, thus contributing to a better implementation of this Fund.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) offers support to those who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation, for example in the event of a company being closed down or a production relocated to a non-EU country, or as a result of the global economic and financial crisis. The EGF can finance up to 60% of the cost of projects to help redundant workers find another job or start their own businesses. For all these reasons, I have decided to vote in favour of mobilising an amount of EUR 630 000 to cover technical assistance from the Fund. The objective of technical assistance is to finance monitoring and information, to create a knowledge/interface base and to advise Member States on the use, continuity and evaluation of the EGF.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour, believing that the report contains indications that we can support on how to improve the functioning of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. The report approves the mobilisation of a small part of the Commission's budget (EUR 630 000) to assist in the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This fund is used, for example, in the case of closure of the Company Delphi in the Bay of Cadiz, although the management of this item by the Junta de Andalucía did not give the promised results. The report includes an amendment tabled by rapporteur Liadh which aims to ensure that the number of laid-off workers needed to mobilisation the Fund can be revised down. This is an important point for the future revision of the EGF.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal to allow the European Commission to cover the technical and administrative assistance costs of the year 2015 concerning the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF/2015/000 TA 2015) amounting to EUR 630 000. These costs correspond to approximately 0.39% of the maximum annual budget available to the EGF. These appropriations relate in particular to the costs of monitoring and data collection, website management, the creation of standardised procedures for the management of the fund, the organisation of networks between Member States and the development of new evaluation systems. I hope that these amounts will be used rationally and efficiently for the intended purposes.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ MEPs today voted in support of the Commission proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). It concerns the mobilisation of EUR 630 000 from the Fund, covering technical assistance for the Commission. The objective of the technical assistance is to finance monitoring, information, to create a knowledge base interface and to advise Member States on using, following up and evaluating the EGF.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. My vote is therefore in line with the position of the ECR Group, which, while supporting measures to create growth and new jobs, does not consider the European Globalisation Fund to be the right instrument to achieve these objectives. This fund does not offer enough efficiency and value for money spent. Moreover, this is not about state aid, but only about funds for the administrative background for the fund.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund serves to support workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns or the global financial and economic crisis and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market. The 2015 budget is EUR 150 million. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund can use 0.5% of this amount for technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission to finance the preparation, monitoring, data collection and establishment of a knowledge base, administrative and technical support, information and communication activities, as well as audit and control activities necessary for the implementation of the EGF Regulation. In line with this, on the basis of the Commission's proposal, we have approved an amount of EUR 630 000, equivalent to 0.39% for technical assistance. This technical assistance should, inter alia, simplify the application procedures, which would immediately start the process of providing assistance to redundant workers without waiting for applications to be approved, while ensuring greater flexibility during the period of assistance.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is one of the budgetary instruments put in place by the European Union to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows or the consequences of the global financial and economic crisis, and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. The maximum annual budget available for the EGF in 2015 is €150 million, and the EGF Regulation states that, at the Commission's initiative, no more than 0,5 % of this amount is used to finance the activities necessary for the implementation of the EGF Regulation. For 2015, eur 630 000 should therefore be mobilised to provide technical assistance at the Initiative of the Commission, including in particular the monitoring and collection of data, the updating and development of the website, including translation to raise awareness and visibility of the EGF, the establishment of a user interface to simplify and speed up the processing of applications, the establishment of an expert group of contact persons for the EGF and the networking of Member States. Since union financial assistance for redundant workers must be dynamic and available as quickly and as efficiently as possible, and the above activities will certainly make a significant contribution to this, I was happy to support the report on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the vote.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support the Report of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support workers and assist them in reintegration into the labour market. As a general rule, EGF funds can only be used if more than 500 workers have become redundant in one company (including its suppliers and further producers) or a large number of workers have been laid off in a particular sector in one or more neighbourly regions.  As all the preconditions for achieving them are met, I support the proposed amount of EUR 630 000 representing approximately 0.39 % of the maximum annual budget available for the EGF in 2015. For the best possible functioning and implementation of measures, the exchange of information on the EGF, the work on standardising procedures for applying for EGF mobilisation is important, and it is important to allow for greater flexibility during the disbursement period.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on the proposal for a decision by the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in accordance with point 13. Interinstitutional agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation on budgetary issues and on good financial management (EGF/2015/000 TA request - Technical assistance at the initiative of the Commission).  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from major structural changes in global trade patterns. The Fund must not exceed the maximum annual amount of EUR 150 million. On 15 April 2015 The Commission adopted a new proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF. This refers to the mobilisation of €630,000 from the fund, covering technical assistance for the Commission. The goal of technical assistance is to finance monitoring, information and create a knowledge base. The Commission will collect data on the requests received and on proposing and implementing measures, and will also regularly update and extend the websites to the EGF set by the Commission in terms of employment and social issues. In addition, the Commission will organise networking between Member States through two seminars organised by the implementing authorities of this Fund from the Member States.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The proposed amount of EUR 630 000, out of a total of EUR 811 825 per year, will be used for the preparation, monitoring and collection of data, which will allow for simplification and faster processing of applications and improved reporting. I support the Commission's intentions to increase the visibility of the EGF, which provides additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes during the financial and economic crisis.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Money of the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed, and not to conferences and briefings.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it helps workers affected by structural changes in world trade and has been made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis and supports their reintegration into the labour market. I agree with the report that financial support for redundant workers must be dynamic and that these instruments should be made available as quickly and efficiently as possible. The Regulation broadens the range of eligible measures and beneficiaries, involving the self-employed and young people, and supports initiatives to create new businesses. With these and with a higher contribution from the Fund, I believe that the EU instrument of solidarity for workers will be a more effective and visible instrument.  Together with the report, I am in favour of continuous work on the standardised procedure for applications and the use of the electronic data exchange system (SFC2014) by managing bodies, which will make it possible to simplify and process applications more quickly. I trust that, along the lines set by the EP, we can really provide useful assistance to workers through much more effective implementation by the Commission and the Member States.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Globalization is a complex phenomenon that can sometimes pose a number of problems for even the most developed countries of the world.
