The changes involved in the dynamics of the workforce can take international governments and institutions by surprise. To this end, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created, which can help some of those who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in globalisation to reintegrate into the labour market. The European Union's budgetary effort for this programme is not very great, but its effects can be considerable to achieve effective employment available. This is a programme contributing to social cohesion measures within the Union, in particular the reintegration of young people, one of the most vulnerable categories, into the labour market.  For these reasons, I believe that the draft resolution on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a useful document for European citizens, which must be supported by the European Parliament.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr Deprez's text. It is important to remember the importance of networking and exchanging information on the EGF, particularly with regard to the provisions of the new WEF regulation. Through this vote, we show our support for the funding of the WEF Contact Expert Group and networking seminars on the implementation of the WEF.  Nevertheless, I stress the need to strengthen contacts between all stakeholders involved in EGF applications, including social partners and other actors at the regional or local level, in order to produce maximum synergies. Interactions between the contact person at the national level and the partners responsible for implementation at the regional or local level should be strengthened. Support and communication arrangements and information flows should be explicit and agreed upon by all relevant partners.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ While I fully support measures to enable job creation and provide an incentive for economic growth and investment; as in the observations made so far regarding the mobilisation of EGF funds, I take the same position. I believe that this allocation of funds cannot achieve the ultimate goal of reintegration of workers into the labour market and provide effective support to those affected by the consequences of structural changes in trade flows. The mobilisation of the Fund and the envisaged costs, in which only for additional administrative and technical assistance in the implementation of the programme provides for funds of EUR 70 000, I hold unnecessary strengthening of the bureaucratic apparatus and I fear that this would produce only sluggishness in assisting redundant workers, and the effects of solidarity action would completely disappear. I say again that all measures to reduce unemployment, especially in terms of youth unemployment, but I say no to their application at the expense of long-term effects.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report on the mobilisation of the EGF. The EGF is an instrument to support workers who have lost their jobs and provide career advice, job-seeking assistance and so on. In this case, it involves the transfer of €630,000 from the Fund, which includes technical assistance to the Commission. The purpose of technical assistance is to finance monitoring, information and knowledge base and to assist Member States in the mobilising, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to help support workers who lose their jobs as a result of global economic changes in the event of major waves of redundancies. As important as the social cushioning of market-based developments is, it must be noted that this fund is a misconstruction. In doing so, the EU is taking on tasks which, in the sense of subsidiarity, are a matter for the nation states. However, we do not want a European superstate in which Brussels intervenes in all areas of life. The EGF is a step towards a European unemployment insurance scheme. This cannot work well in the EU. For this reason, the EGF, and consequently projects to be financed from this fund, must be rejected.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. The report approves the mobilisation of a small part of the Commission's budget (EUR 630 000) to assist in the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This fund is used, for example, in the case of closure of the Company Delphi in the Bay of Cadiz, although the management of this item by the Junta de Andalucía did not give the promised results. The report includes an amendment tabled by rapporteur Liadh which aims to ensure that the number of laid-off workers needed to mobilisation the Fund can be revised down. This is an important point for the future revision of the EGF.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund supports people who lose their jobs as a result of changes in global trade as a result of globalisation. This fund is intended to help, for example, workers from companies relocating their production outside the EU or from companies that must close as a result of a global economic crisis.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). That this report provides support for workers and self-employed people whose activities have been severely influenced as a result of the current financial crisis is very positive. I believe it is very valuable that these people will be assisted to reintegrate into the labour market, which is not only a very challenging part but also the most vital one.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a fund that is dedicated to processing transfers of funds to pay compensation for maximum redundancies for the cessation of different business activities of the Member States. In this case we are facing a technical adjustment by the Commission on the substance on which the Council has already given its approval. It is therefore appropriate to vote in favour of that report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report agrees with the measures proposed by the European Commission to finance technical assistance. In particular, it endorses the mobilisation of EUR 811 825 in 2015, as its Regulation points to up to 0.5 % of the maximum annual amount of the EGF, which in 2015 is EUR 150 million, to finance the preparation, monitoring, collection of data and the creation of a knowledge base, administrative and technical support, information and communication activities , as well as the audit, control and evaluation activities necessary for the implementation of the Regulation. We agree to the proposal. However, we reaffirm our criticism of the fund, as unemployment prevention measures need to be ensured, including the reversal of the neoliberal course of EU policies leading to outcomes such as this. The destruction of jobs, the absence of work, is inherent in the capitalist system and its structural crisis, which leads every day to the closure and relocations of companies.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I have received my support for the request for the EGF for technical assistance, as I believe that the funds made available here will be used wisely and purposefully. I also consider the fact that the full capacity of the funds is not being used up to be positive. Better evaluation and data collection will ensure a more targeted use of EGF funding in the future.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. The Globalisation Fund was set up to help with short-term emergencies caused by mismanagement, globalisation or the financial and moral crisis in the Member States. Support includes training, business start-up grants, coaching and outplacement of redundant workers. The Globalisation Fund co-finances these job creation measures at 50% or 65%, with the balance being provided by the Member State concerned. This will make the European Commission a gigantic labour market agency. Nevertheless, the European Court of Auditors said in a special audit report that this "Globalisation Fund" provides only limited EU added value and should be replaced by a more efficient regime. It was explicitly stated that this Globalisation Fund is not the best way to provide much-needed specific support. And yet the EU is continuing the policy, which has been shown to be inefficient. I cannot agree with that.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). The EGF has provided necessary resources to redundant workers since its creation in 2006. Though the EU employment rate for people aged 20-64 rose in 2014 by 0.8 pps to 69.2%, it is still well below the target rate of 75% (Europe 2020 Strategy) by 2020. Through increased integration and the creation of a new knowledge base and application interface, the EGF will become more transparent and therefore more user-friendly to those who need it. The transfer of funds to the Commission for technical support will allow the EGF to further its mission to re-integrate those EU citizens who are on the fringes of the labour market. I urge Member States to recall their obligations to promote EGF projects in order to extend the reach and visibility of the EGF. I look forward to the integration of the EGF into the System for Fund Management.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the creation of a technical assistance system within the Commission for the Member States that will aim to benefit from amounts from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). The EGF was created to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in international trade practices. The Commission proposal concerns the mobilisation of EUR 630 000 from the EGF reserve for technical assistance on the initiative of the Commission. The objective of technical assistance is to finance monitoring, information activities, to create a knowledge base interface and to provide advice to Member States on the use, monitoring and evaluation of the EGF. According to the report adopted in the EP, the Commission will organise networking activities between Member States through two seminars dedicated to EGF implementing bodies in the Member States, which will take place around the same data and focus on issues related to the practical implementation of the EGF Regulation at the basic level.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund allows financial support to be allocated to redundant workers, due to the so-called effects of structural changes in world trade patterns or the global economic and financial crisis, which is necessary but always insufficient in the face of the loss of a job.  This report agrees with the measures proposed by the European Commission to finance technical assistance, in particular on the mobilisation of EUR 811 825 in 2015, as its Regulation points to up to 0.5 % of the maximum annual amount of the EGF, which in 2015 is EUR 150 million, to finance the preparation, monitoring, collection of data and the creation of a knowledge base , administrative and technical support, information and communication activities, as well as audit, control and evaluation activities necessary for the implementation of the Regulation. However, we reaffirm our criticism of the Fund, as unemployment prevention measures need to be ensured, in particular the reversal of the neoliberal course of EU policies leading to outcomes such as this. The destruction of jobs, the absence of work, is inherent in the capitalist system and its structural crisis, which leads every day to the closure and relocations of companies.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, I voted for this report because I support the idea that the flexibility contained within the Stability and Growth Pact should be used by the Commission. In this context, I was pleased to read the Commission’s initial communication on flexibility within the pact. I and some of my Irish colleagues were the only Members of this Parliament to actively work and canvas the Irish people to actually vote for the fiscal compact in our last EU referendum. Therefore, the rules we voted for should be enforced and the flexibility they contain should be honoured. Hence I support the idea in the report that the Commission should clarify where the room for flexibility exists because, above all on this issue, we need clarity and predictability.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Madam President, in October 2008, French President Nicolas Sarkozy proposed the creation of an EU economic government. The proposal was so open about the intention to create a superstate that the name was changed. Since then, it has been an economic governance, not an independent body. However, the result is the same: the withdrawal of the economic and budgetary self-determination of the Member States. The report states that, before the adoption of draft budgets in the Member States, the financial committees of the national parliaments invite the EU Commissioners responsible for economic governance to their parliaments. This is how the EU Commissioner, the Commissioner, becomes the commie commie that executes the central will. And all this, of course, in the spirit of democracy. That is why I did not support the adoption of this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent Today, colleagues, we voted in favour of the report by my colleague, Pervenche Berès, and what is happening now in Greece, and the crisis in the governance of the euro area. This is what my country – Latvia – went through in 2009.\u201201. At that time, the huge crisis raged throughout Eastern Europe, including Latvia. But the crisis has not been overcome, and the fact that Latvia supposedly left it is thanks not to the government or the European Commission, but only to the people of Latvia.  The Latvian government at the time cruelly closed hospitals, reduced salaries for police officers, teachers, deprived 10% of pension pensioners. The Greeks simply do not allow it to be handled by themselves, as a southern nation, but that does not mean that we , the European Parliament, do not need to look for new and better models of the municipality. Another road is not just a compromise between all the parties involved. That is why I supported my colleague Berès's report because it is a compromise product, and that is why I voted in favour. Thank you!

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the revision of the economic governance framework because it is urgent and necessary to complete the turn of European economic policy, and in particular to fill the gaps in Economic and Monetary Union (EMU).  This report raises possibilities to improve the use of flexibility contained in existing rules, strengthen economic coordination and simplify procedures, as well as improve democratic control of structural reforms.  In particular, the following elements should be highlighted: - Adoption of common structural or convergence policy objectives through codecision (i.e. with the participation of the European Parliament). - Adoption of an Interinstitutional Agreement for the participation of the European Parliament in a simplified European Semester. - Fiscal capacity of the eurozone to deal with asymmetric shocks. - Convergence of tax policies. - European-level fight against tax evasion and avoidance. - Initiatives to reduce the eurozone's public debt stock. - Strengthening the social dimension, including the establishment of a European minimum wage. I also consider it important to complement the vertical strengthening of EMU with its horizontal consolidation so that, by 2020, Member States that already fulfil economic conditions join it.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Written. The Berès report is a contradictory confluence of well-intentioned intentions which, if you add them up, make no economic sense.  Can anyone explain how to implement both structural reforms, large-scale public investment, reduce public debt and engage in social dialogue with local populations in countries, and also involve supranational technocrats from the OECD and THE IMF? Debt, savings, investments, the future of the euro... it is all addressed in this report. Whereas, worryingly, this same report on page 21 admits that there is not even clarity on the definition of one of the basic concepts of the economy, namely the 'output gap'. Perhaps the Commission must agree on basic concepts before it starts to withdraw money from European citizens by hundreds of billions at a time.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report has little to commend it, and much applies only to the Eurozone.  It was consistent with UKIP principles for me to vote against.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted against this report for two main reasons: 1) it does not go far enough and is below the report of the five presidents (notably the proposal of the Euro Area Parliament is not included); 2) the final version of this report has lost the clarity and breath of the original version (lack of Eurobonds and fiscal union, the President of the Eurogroup is no longer Vice-President of the Commission).

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. On this technical and complex report, I abstained, because while some parts of this file call for progress, others are unacceptable. Indeed, one point is particularly problematic, because we welcome the implementation of the 2/6 pack when we want to adapt these mechanisms.  The author also welcomes the Commission's communication on flexibility. We approved this point because it can help some countries in great difficulty. However, for us, this is not enough, because this definition of flexibility will not allow Belgium to make more investments. The chapter on the future of EMU comes too late, as it was supposed to influence the report of the five presidents who, for the time being, have already come out. I can, however, welcome part of this report which calls for the replacement of the troika, more tax transparency, a minimum wage and also a change in the European semester.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. The report on the economic governance framework seeks to establish the Euro-Camera's position in the debate on Economic and Monetary Union for greater integration and cooperation in economic matters. What could have become a unique opportunity for the European Parliament to set an ambitious position in establishing a strong framework for crisis management and to advance the economic and political governance of the Union has been left in a decaffeinated text which does not even provide for the basis of the European Commission's own proposal. From UPyD we regret that fundamental aspects such as the revision of country-specific recommendations, the review of macroeconomic imbalances or a mechanism of insolvency for States are not included. Nor does the text refer to the role of the European Court of Justice or the need for an external representative of the eurozone. In short, the report lacks analysis, concrete proposals and efficient solutions. For all of the above we have decided to vote against the report.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. The financial and economic crisis has exposed a number of shortcomings of economic and monetary union (EMU). In recent years, of course, we have already intervened in response to this, for example through an adapted Stability and Growth Pact, the Fiscal Pact and the European Stability Mechanism. Now is the time for new steps to give the economic revival plenty of opportunity, in particular by deepening the framework for economic governance while at the same time developing social protection to broaden the European social market economy. This can be achieved by streamlining the European Semester in particular and by using the flexibility provided for it effectively. At the same time, we must now work towards a convergence of social standards in the euro area and to further strengthen the role of the social partners. Their input is essential for a sustainable revival. This should lead to a strengthened social market economy, with a more accurate balance between competitiveness and social justice.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The report gives the European Parliament's opinion on the evolution of the economic and budgetary governance of the euro area and the Union. In fact, this report ultimately encourages a future economic government of Europe whose vocation is obviously the adoption of the euro by as many EU countries as possible. For good economic governance, states must respect ever more stringent rules of convergence, after the Maastricht criteria, the golden rule, the two-pack and the six-pack and finally the TSCG, which really subject our economies and governments to the dictates of Brussels even if these criteria are very little respected by the Member States. Of course, this report calls for stronger economic governance and reforms that states need to put in place. Attached to the sovereignty of States, I strongly challenge this method of governance and a supranational body such as the European Union must not dictate to states their budgetary, economic or social choices. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Bères report addresses the analysis of European economic governance in a totally uncritical and partisan manner.  All too often, the text points out that the failure of the current system is due to the inability of States to apply European rules rather than to their inefficiency. This is yet another short-sighted and partisan interpretation of a situation that costs our businesses and our citizens great suffering. For all these reasons, I voted against the measure.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the revision of the economic governance framework because it is urgent and necessary to complete the turn of European economic policy, and in particular to fill the gaps in Economic and Monetary Union (EMU).  This report raises possibilities to improve the use of flexibility contained in existing rules, strengthen economic coordination and simplify procedures, as well as improve democratic control of structural reforms.  In particular, the following elements should be highlighted: - Adoption of common structural or convergence policy objectives through codecision (i.e. with the participation of the European Parliament). - Adoption of an Interinstitutional Agreement for the participation of the European Parliament in a simplified European Semester. - Fiscal capacity of the eurozone to deal with asymmetric shocks. - Convergence of tax policies. - European-level fight against tax evasion and avoidance. - Initiatives to reduce the eurozone's public debt stock. - Strengthening the social dimension, including the establishment of a European minimum wage. I also consider it important to complement the vertical strengthening of EMU with its horizontal consolidation so that, by 2020, Member States that already fulfil economic conditions join it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it gives the Commission its recommendations on future euro area governance. In the report, Parliament acknowledges the need for drastic action in the face of the crisis, but not all of them were correct, and therefore there is now a need to agree on a review of euro area governance. Parliament welcomed the Commission's proposed framework of the three pillars of euro area governance, based on investment attraction, fiscal consolidation and structural reforms, but called on the Commission to take greater account of each country's situation when assessing national budget projects and making recommendations to countries. Parliament also welcomed the Commission's envisaged limited fiscal flexibility, allowing Member States to go beyond the 3% deficit threshold for a certain period of time, if necessary to encourage strategic investment in the country, in addition to the automatic application of the so-called excessive budgetary procedure.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The crisis has shown that Europe needs to take steps to improve its economic model and restore its competitiveness. This requires both public funding and targeted investment. At present, however, the potential of economic governance is not unfolding. Effective economic coordination aims to kick-start Europe's growth and employment engine and ultimately also to increase citizens' opportunities. The coordination of economic and employment policies will be complete if a significant part of this coordination covers all possible means of stimulating the real economy, which would otherwise be excluded from the broader coordination of the European Semester.  I voted in favour of Mrs Beres's report, because I believe that economic policy management needs to be strengthened in order to be an engine for the Union to stimulate and promote growth and job creation. This requires re-creating the highest level of political oversight, avoiding any artificial discrimination between actions at EU and Member State level, and at the same time developing more effective tools to ensure that the EU's single market really benefits citizens and businesses.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on the 'Verification of the economic governance framework: budget and challenges', which I support, comes at a crucial time, following the publication of the five Presidents' report, with a view to the European Council meeting over the next two days, and is at the same time as the debate on the European Fund for Strategic Investments. The economic crisis, the reduction in investment in the EU, the current levels of unemployment and growth show the limitations and difficulties of the current Economic and Monetary Union and the need to return to discussing it with appropriate instruments. The current state of economic governance suffers too much from the bureaucratic complexities that go with it, which weaken its effectiveness also in terms of transparency and democracy. It is therefore a good thing that Parliament should play an active role in this process. As Commissioner Katainen also pointed out, we need a system that can stem any future crises by ensuring a higher level of stability for the euro area and Europe. However, I would add that stability must not be our end, but the condition for finally arriving at forward-looking economic and budgetary policies.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ As the name suggests this Report is concerned with economic governance and is the parliament's review of the 6-pack and 2-pack. Economic Governance is a matter of crucial importance particularly in Ireland where such governance has proved to be a dismal failure.  We are all familiar with the lack of accountability and oversight in the Irish political system and we are also aware that the banks were too lightly regulated. Therefore, it is essential that any such review would substantially address the underlying structural and economic problems that have dominated the financial crisis. Unfortunately, this report goes nowhere near addressing these critical concerns. The reforms proposed in the report are primarily concerned with ensuring that Member States don’t deviate from the economic neo-liberal ideology that it is advocating for. It does not leave Member States with any flexibility to implement alternative policies, which would be pro-investment, pro-growth, pro-jobs.  If we are serious about addressing economic boom and bust cycles and restoring economic growth to the EU and Ireland then there needs to be a focus on equitable growth, public investment and poverty reduction. As none of these matters were tackled in any authentic manner, I voted against this Report.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree with its conclusions. In particular, I believe that the eu's economic governance structure must be completed as soon as possible and that a higher level of democracy must be ensured.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report recommends strengthening the governance of the monetary union to move towards harmonisation of economic and fiscal policies among euro area member states.  Indeed, macroeconomic divergences in EMU threaten the stability of the currency area and confirm that the euro area is a non-optimal monetary area, as Paul Krugman, the Nobel laureate in us economics, explained. That is why the harmonisation of the structural policies of the States, desired by the Commission, means nothing more than a levelling down of wages and the social protection system of the French. This anti-democratic project once again violates France's sovereignty.  Only a concerted and anticipated exit from the euro single currency would allow states to regain their monetary sovereignty. Adjusting parities between national currencies would thus eliminate differences in competitiveness. Exchange rates could even fluctuate between two terminals as part of a semi-fixed exchange rate system to avoid a currency war.  So I voted against it.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. The text places too much justification for the non-functioning of the instruments that would have been intended for development and growth, but which did not achieve any objectives. The results of European policies are clear to everyone: long-term unemployment, social hardship and Member States that cannot make ends meet.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 More than 7 years after the beginning of the crisis, the euro has been supported by measures such as the revision of the Stability and Growth Pact (SPP), the Budget Pact, the creation of a European Stability Mechanism (ESM), the establishment of the Banking Union and the establishment of the essential role of the European Central Bank (BEC). However, the prognosis for lowering the unemployment and inflation rate has not been achieved. In the light of the present situation, there has been a controversy over the policies adopted in the wake of the crisis, given that the euro area has encountered difficulties with its counterparts. The new provisions were not sufficient to counter the cumulative effects, throughout the Union, on the budgetary situation of the Member States and therefore problems such as the threat of deflation, low economic growth or high unemployment have not been resolved. I voted in favour of the report as I want the EMU to function better and to adopt a symmetrical approach to contributions to co-financing projects under the EFSI.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the revision of the economic governance framework because it is urgent and necessary to complete the turn of European economic policy, and in particular to fill the gaps in Economic and Monetary Union (EMU).  This report raises possibilities to improve the use of flexibility contained in existing rules, strengthen economic coordination and simplify procedures, as well as improve democratic control of structural reforms.  In particular, it is worth noting the following elements: - Adoption of common structural or convergence policy objectives through codecision (i.e. with the participation of the European Parliament) - Adoption of an Interinstitutional Agreement for the participation of the European Parliament in a simplified European Semester. - Fiscal capacity of the eurozone to deal with asymmetric shocks. - Convergence of tax policies. - European-level fight against tax evasion and avoidance. - Initiatives to reduce the eurozone's public debt stock. - Strengthening the social dimension, including the establishment of a European minimum wage. I also consider it important to complement the vertical strengthening of EMU with its horizontal consolidation so that, by 2020, Member States that already fulfil economic conditions join it.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the verification of the economic governance framework: budget and challenges. The report pointed out that, although progress has been made to correct the macroeconomic imbalances in Europe and to improve the current economic situation, characterised by weak growth and high unemployment, it is necessary for Member States to implement structural reforms and work to relaunch investment with the aim of restoring the Union's competitiveness. The call for greater economic coordination that takes account of the euro area as a whole is also important: only through greater coherence and organisation at European level can the effectiveness of the economic governance framework really be improved and coherent and equitable implementation of the framework in all Member States can be guaranteed, just as the different economic and fiscal situations of the Member States can be tackled on a real level playing field.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ As the name suggests this Report is concerned with economic governance and is the parliament's review of the 6-pack and 2-pack. Economic Governance is a matter of crucial importance particularly in Ireland where such governance has proved to be a dismal failure. We are all familiar with the lack of accountability and oversight in the Irish political system and we are also aware that the banks were too lightly regulated. Therefore, it is essential that any such review would substantially address the underlying structural and economic problems that have dominated the financial crisis.  Unfortunately, this report goes nowhere near addressing these critical concerns. The reforms proposed in the report are primarily concerned with ensuring that Member States don’t deviate from the economic neo-liberal ideology that it is advocating for. It does not leave Member States with any flexibility to implement alternative policies, which would be pro-investment, pro-growth, pro-jobs. If we are serious about addressing economic boom and bust cycles and restoring economic growth to the EU and Ireland then there needs to be a focus on equitable growth, public investment and poverty reduction. As none of these matters were tackled in any authentic manner, I voted against this Report.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ This Report has been prepared as a contribution to assess and analyse the effectiveness of the first years of the implementation of the economic governance framework to the economic crisis. The recent Commission review of the “Six Pack” and the “Two Pack” legislation that makes up the EU’s economic governance rules shows that overall the reformed fiscal rules have worked well so far and that future work should build within the framework of existing rules without the need to reopen the governance framework. On the other hand, this Report also proposed to harmonise tax structures. This is a very sensitive matter for my country. The moves in the direction of tax harmonisation could set off a trend that could result in serious consequences for the Maltese economy. Tax harmonisation would reduce the flexibility of those economies, like Malta’s, which given its limited endowments and peripheral status only a sovereign fiscal policy can help to partially offset these difficulties in order to boost its competitiveness and performance. Due to these reasons I have voted against this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the report supported by the Socialist-People's Axis in no way reflects our reading of the situation and goes in the direction of further strengthening a wrong and counterproductive governance framework, we have tabled an alternative motion for a resolution on behalf of the EFDD Group.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Charanzová (ALDE), in writing. – I voted against the Beres report as I do not believe we should weaken the economic tools needed to ensure minimum responsibility between governments and their budget planning. Today, Europe is in crisis exactly because governments did not respect budget discipline or the growth and stability pact. I do not believe that if we weaken the current rules, as this report calls for, we will be helping to move ourselves away from the crisis, nor will it help us prevent the next one. We need actions to help growth and job creation, but uncontrolled spending is not the answer.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which clearly goes in the direction of closer economic integration of the Member States of the Union, in complete disregard of the principle of subsidiarity and the sovereignty of European nations. It should be remembered that the convergence rules are accompanied by a power given to the Commission to sanction any country that does not comply with the austerity requirements dictated by Brussels. MEPs therefore persist in forcing the dictation of the uniformity of member states, even though, from an economic and budgetary point of view, as in so many other respects, the differences between countries are too great. Moreover, the requirements imposed are unrealistic: from the creation of the euro, two founding members of the Union, Belgium and Italy, did not meet the Maastricht criteria (a deficit of no more than 3% of GDP and a public debt of no more than 60% of GDP).

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We must recognise that at the heart of the economic governance system is the prevention of excessively high levels of deficit and debt, as well as macroeconomic imbalances and the coordination of economic policies. For us, the question is whether EMU is ultimately so armored and effective as to prevent Member States from being derailed by excessive debt and deficit. Moreover, the success or failure of EMU on the key issue of convergence of Member States' finances is an important element. We consider the economic governance framework to be a key political initiative that underpins the foundations of the Europe 2020 objectives. We support initiatives that enhance the full exploitation of the untapped activities of the single market. We support all the measures proposed by the European Commission to finance the new European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to revise the economic governance framework. The document aims to analyse the effectiveness of the regulatory framework under the TFEU, in particular the economic policies and achievements of EU Member States. More than seven years after the start of the crisis, the euro has been saved through measures such as the revision of the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP), the Budgetary Pact, the establishment of the European Stability Mechanism (ESF), the Banking Union and the leading role of the European Central Bank (ECB).  However, the two communications on the subject published by the Commission highlight a number of critical issues. Indeed, the eurozone lacks an effective assessment of the global economic situation, and the growing complexity of economic governance has highlighted its lack of democracy and transparency. Looking ahead, the four Presidents (European Parliament, European Commission, Council and ECB) decided to discuss deepening economic and monetary union (EMU), also in the light of the results of the recent European elections and general elections in some Member States, in particular those held in Greece in January 2015.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the verification of the economic governance framework. The introduction of the 6-Pack and the 2-Pack has expanded the application of the Stability and Growth Pact, seeking to prevent a deeper crisis and at the same time ensuring flexibility for structural reforms and investment. I am aware of the need to improve the economic governance framework, through simple and transparent procedures, in order to increase budgetary availability and allow for economic rapprochement and convergence in the euro area, strengthening national ownership, democratic accountability for the implementation of rules and the systematic application of rules issued at European level. In order for there to be a return to growth and a reduction in unemployment, it is important to accept the governance framework by the public and to try to help SMEs in particular in their phase of expansion, access to credit and reduction of bureaucracy in order to achieve levels of competitiveness appropriate to the international market.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I applaud The Report of Mrs Pervenche Berés on the necessary changes in the field of economic governance. It is indisputable that recent events, both from the point of view of the euro crisis and the pressure of the need to stimulate economic recovery and job creation, reinforce the timeliness of this debate. The Presidents' Report, the Commission Communication on the Analysis of Economic Governance and the document on flexibility in the application of sgp rules provide a good basis for reflection, which justifies the EP's opinion. I agree with the rapporteur that we need to think about the economic governance of an emu in depth on the post-crisis horizon, and that this reflection is not only on the results but also on combating the recognised democratic deficit that it feels today. I recognise that the complexity of economic governance is the enemy of desirable transparency and that an economic assessment and a common diagnosis are urgently needed in an area where the same currency is shared.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because the review of the economic governance framework, together with the review of the overarching Europe 2020 strategy and the European Semester, is urgently needed. The current difficulties in Greece show that we need better economic policy coordination. With the Stability and Growth Pact, we have a set of rules at our hands that must be applied consistently. However, we must also consider whether and where necessary improvements need to be made.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome mrs Berès' report, which seeks to assess the effectiveness of the regulatory framework for economic governance. In particular, the report seeks to establish whether the provisions concerning decision-making processes have been sufficiently incisive and whether progress has been made in terms of closer coordination of economic policies and lasting convergence of Member States' economic performance under the TFEI. Although the regulatory framework has proved to be good, there is still a lack of an adequate assessment of the overall economic situation. Nowadays, economic governance, due to a lack of confidence, has reached a level of complexity that is detrimental to democracy and transparency. That is why the Member States must be allowed to undertake reforms on the ground of a common understanding of the situation. Finally, in order to give European citizens the maximum benefit from the single currency, the debate on EMU should be deepened. In this respect, it is Parliament's task to ensure that the elements necessary to strengthen EMU such as budgetary capacity, renewed assistance mechanisms and the social dimension are present in these negotiations.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to assess the effectiveness of the current economic governance framework and outline future challenges. The report, from which German taxation is clear, appears to be completely divorced from reality as it focuses on compliance with budgetary constraints, the failure and insufficient enforcement of the rules and the inadequate implementation of reforms, due to the lack of 'ambition' on the part of the various Member States in implementing the measures 'agreed' with the institutions. Even when it comes to margins for flexibility, the report never fails to emphasise that any deviation from budgetary constraints must be only temporary and cannot lead to a 3% increase in GDP.  Furthermore, the report completely lacks a systemic and analytical reading of the reality, causes of the crisis and the devastating impact that the current governance framework and the strategy adopted by the Commission have had on the eurozone economies. There is also a lack of criticism of the need to take corrective measures to manage excessive trade surpluses that cause huge macroeconomic imbalances within the eurozone. The conclusion drawn from the report is that there is no need to call into question the rules in force, let alone to amend the Treaties.  For the reasons set out, I am voting against.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report provided an opportunity to see how much, even today, there may be distances on the future of economic governance between those who merely preach against the Europe of austerity, but on the substance continue to be convinced that it is the only possible alternative, and those who are fighting and put on the table different solutions for a Europe that complements its Union and knows how to become added value in terms of growth , development and jobs. The same dividing line divides those who say that the austerity measures imposed have not been properly implemented and we in the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D), who, in reality, think that they were wrong or inadequate in practice. We must put a stop to this, leave behind the initiatives and solutions promoted to stem the acute crisis and launch a coherent European plan capable of ensuring the long-term completion of economic and monetary union. We firmly believe that we must start again, on the one hand, from the use of maximum flexibility to fill the investment gap that penalises us, and, on the other hand, from greater involvement of the European Parliament and national parliaments, which restores democracy to the decisions taken in economic and monetary matters.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The crisis has shown that Europe needs to take steps to improve its economic model and restore its competitiveness. This requires both public funding and targeted investment. At present, however, the potential of economic governance is not unfolding. Effective economic coordination aims to kick-start Europe's growth and employment engine and ultimately also to increase citizens' opportunities. The coordination of economic and employment policies will be complete if a significant part of this coordination covers all possible means of stimulating the real economy, which would otherwise be excluded from the broader coordination of the European Semester. I voted in favour of the Beres report because I see the need to strengthen economic policy governance in order to be the Union's engine for stimulating and promoting growth and job creation. This requires re-creating the highest level of political oversight, avoiding any artificial discrimination between actions at EU and Member State level, and at the same time developing more effective tools to ensure that the EU single market really benefits citizens and businesses.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I did not support this report because I have serious reservations related to the power to raise revenue which currently rests on national parliaments, that is, taxation. Furthermore I cannot support the proposed fourth pillar on taxation and a taxation union. I cannot support proposals that propose to harmonise tax structures and reduce the flexibility of those economies which are extremely limited. I believe that taxation should remain a Member State competence. The power to raise revenue and authorisation of debt issuance currently reside exclusively with national Parliaments taking into account their accountability and democratic legitimacy.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted strongly in favour of the own-initiative report on the review of European economic governance. In recent months, reforms have been launched which will finally put growth and development in Europe back at the centre. The watchwords have changed: no more austerity, but growth. We must now continue even more strongly along this path in order to promote a new competitiveness of the European Union and to regain employment, including by making the most of the new opportunities offered by the investment clause defined by the European Commission in its recent communication on flexibility. Only by directly linking the new and reformed economic governance to the real economy, the completion of the single market and the creation of a genuine digital market will the measures taken in recent months really help to achieve sustainable and sustainable growth in our countries. It is precisely the deepening of the single market, a new focus on SMEs and quality European manufacturing and a definitive enhancement of intellectual property rights that will be the main driving forces for new growth and employment in Europe.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. At the December 2014 EU summit, the Heads of State and Government mandated Presidents Juncker, Tusk, Dijsselbloem and Draghi to decide on the state and future of eurozone convergence. Through this vote, we wanted to join in this analysis. We support the Commission's strategy, which is based on three pillars: investment, fiscal consolidation and structural reforms. However, it is a matter of better implementing it when issuing macroeconomic recommendations on the basis of draft national budgets. In addition, the European Stability Mechanism and the Stability, Coordination and Governance Treaty should be fully enshrined in the euro area's economic governance framework.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – I have voted against the report as it fails to reflect the ambition outlined in the 5 Presidents’ Paper on how to complete Europe’s Economic and Monetary Union. The report clearly undermines what the European Parliament and our group ALDE have been advocating for the last 5 years. The rapporteur has resisted forward-looking proposals to improve Europe’s economic governance model. It has become a watered-down compromise between the socialists and conservatives on the flexibility mechanism. It lacks in clear direction and has no added value. The Berès report does not contain innovative ideas, nor references to a debt redemption fund, no detailed plan for the external representation of the euro area and no plans to give the European Court of Justice full oversight on the respect of the rules. I cannot support a report which does not respond to the challenges concerning the future of the EMU.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the verification of the economic governance framework highlights the balance sheet and prospects for European macroeconomic governance. This is a fundamental report in order to understand the main dynamics in which the Economic and Monetary Policy Decisions of the European Union have been incorporated and will be incorporated.  One of the main problems that has arisen is the lack of investment in Europe, which leads to a high level of unemployment and a lack of growth in the European economy. In recent years, a number of developments have been continued, including the revision of the Stability and Growth Pact, the establishment of the European Stability Mechanism and the banking union. In particular, the European Central Bank has taken on a key role in maintaining political and macroeconomic stability within the euro area. From an institutional point of view, one of the main problems that has arisen concerns the incompleteness of economic and monetary union, which has failed to ensure coherence within the policy mix in the Union.  For this reason, the European Parliament has taken decisive action in this context, laying the foundations not only but also by building a new policy regime in which priority is given to the European vision.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The crisis has shown that Europe needs to take steps to improve its economic model and restore its competitiveness. This requires both public funding and targeted investment. At present, however, the potential of economic governance is not unfolding. Effective economic coordination aims to kick-start Europe's growth and employment engine and ultimately also to increase citizens' opportunities. The coordination of economic and employment policies will be complete if a significant part of this coordination covers all possible means of stimulating the real economy, which would otherwise be excluded from the broader coordination of the European Semester. I voted in favour of Mrs Beres's report because I believe that economic policy governance needs to be strengthened in order to be an engine for the Union to stimulate and promote growth and job creation. This requires re-creating the highest level of political oversight, avoiding any artificial discrimination between actions at EU and Member State level, and at the same time developing more effective tools to ensure that the EU's single market really benefits citizens and businesses.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. \u2012 The crisis has shown that Europe needs to take steps to improve its economic model and restore its competitiveness. This requires both public funding and targeted investment. At present, however, the potential of economic governance is not unfolding. Effective economic coordination aims to kick-start Europe's growth and employment engine and ultimately also to increase citizens' opportunities. The coordination of economic and employment policies will be complete if a significant part of this coordination covers all possible means of stimulating the real economy, which would otherwise be excluded from the broader coordination of the European Semester. I voted in favour of Mrs Beres's report because I believe that economic policy governance needs to be strengthened in order to be an engine for the Union to stimulate and promote growth and job creation. This requires re-creating the highest level of political oversight, avoiding any artificial discrimination between actions at EU and Member State level, and at the same time developing more effective tools to ensure that the EU's single market really benefits citizens and businesses.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the review of the economic governance framework: balance sheet and issues. This text is clearly built on a pro-European ideology, repeating the out-of-phase need to move towards governance that would overhang states. Once again, this report therefore promotes EU interference in state budgetary policies. However, I have always opposed the Union's encroachment on national sovereignty. At a time when the euro is being challenged across many Member States, the members of the majority are doing everything they can to save it. No, the euro has never been a solution and we would like to be led to believe, in the face of the growing discontents of the peoples of Europe, that it is the saving currency.

name: Ian DUNCAN
text: in writing. ‒ There is not much stocktaking in the report and the proposals made do not correspond to ECR’s position. There are calls for the next steps to deepen the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) to be explored, which would include euro area fiscal capacity based on specific own-resources, a common deposit guarantee scheme, the inclusion of the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) in Union law, a minimum wage or income mechanism, a euro area mechanism to allow debt reduction and upgrading euro area external representations.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against, because the report does nothing more than promote and continue the failed model of economic governance that led to the current crisis. Moreover, it undermines the sovereignty of the Member States, effectively establishing the economic dictatorship of Brussels.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The crisis has shown that Europe needs to take steps to improve its economic model and restore its competitiveness. This requires both public funding and targeted investment. At present, however, the potential of economic governance is not unfolding. Effective economic coordination aims to kick-start Europe's growth and employment engine and ultimately also to increase citizens' opportunities. The coordination of economic and employment policies will be complete if a significant part of this coordination covers all possible means of stimulating the real economy, which would otherwise be excluded from the broader coordination of the European Semester.  I voted in favour of Mrs Beres's report because I believe that economic policy governance needs to be strengthened in order to be an engine for the Union to stimulate and promote growth and job creation. This requires re-creating the highest level of political oversight, avoiding any artificial discrimination between actions at EU and Member State level, and at the same time developing more effective tools to ensure that the EU's single market really benefits citizens and businesses.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Berès report, which was already weak in its original form, came to the vote in plenary as the result of an unacceptable compromise between the large groups and with a clear German approach. My vote against the text is due to the very nature of the underlying idea: there is no need to review the economic governance framework or, therefore, to examine in a specific way what causes the crisis, the problem would, in fact, be only in the member states' failure to implement the reforms. Moreover, although there is a reference to margins of flexibility, it is specified that these can only be temporary and in any case never lead to an overrun of 3% of GDP. As a group, we have therefore tabled an alternative motion for a resolution reflecting the idea that the effects of the austerity measures imposed on member states are at the base of this historic eurozone crisis. Our proposal, which is a long way from the approach of the text we are voting on, states that in order to reverse the negative trend, it is necessary to think about introducing measures such as citizenship income, to guarantee more fiscal autonomy for the Member States and to give them the opportunity to leave the eurozone.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the revision of the economic governance framework because it is urgent and necessary to complete the turn of European economic policy, and in particular to fill the gaps in Economic and Monetary Union (EMU).  This report raises possibilities to improve the use of flexibility contained in existing rules, strengthen economic coordination and simplify procedures, as well as improve democratic control of structural reforms.  In particular, it is worth noting the following elements: - Adoption of common structural or convergence policy objectives through codecision (i.e. with the participation of the European Parliament) - Adoption of an Interinstitutional Agreement for the participation of the European Parliament in a simplified European Semester. - Fiscal capacity of the eurozone to deal with asymmetric shocks. - Convergence of tax policies. - European-level fight against tax evasion and avoidance. - Initiatives to reduce the eurozone's public debt stock. - Strengthening the social dimension, including the establishment of a European minimum wage. I also consider it important to complement the vertical strengthening of EMU with its horizontal consolidation so that, by 2020, Member States that already fulfil economic conditions join it.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it gives exclusive credit to European economic governance, which is now responsible for the Greek crisis.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is still unable to cope with its consequences 7 years after the financial and economic crisis. It must be acknowledged that, on the one hand, the common European currency, the euro, has been saved by the creation and modification of the Stability and Growth Pact, the fiscal agreement, the establishment of the European Stability Mechanism, the Banking Union and the strengthening of the competences of the European Central Bank. On the other hand, however, we must look critically at the fact that, even with enormously high financial investments, the European Union is not able to combat unemployment quickly, efficiently and flexibly, which is still at 11.5%. Youth unemployment, in particular, is indeed alarming in some Member States of the European Union. This is also one of the reasons why The Citizens of Europe are increasingly believing in the European institutions and their ability to solve their problems.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this text which, with regard to the issue of eu economic governance, gives too much mitigating factors to the instruments put in place that have not worked (in their opinion often due to the fault of the Ms). The truth is different: it is a failure across the board and not admitting it and persisting in error will make the situation worse.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The crisis has shown that Europe needs to take steps to improve its economic model and restore its competitiveness. This requires both public funding and targeted investment. At present, however, the potential of economic governance is not unfolding. Effective economic coordination aims to kick-start Europe's growth and employment engine and ultimately also to increase citizens' opportunities. The coordination of economic and employment policies will be complete if a significant part of this coordination covers all possible means of stimulating the real economy, which would otherwise be excluded from the broader coordination of the European Semester. I voted in favour of Mrs Beres's report because I believe that economic policy governance needs to be strengthened in order to be an engine for the Union to stimulate and promote growth and job creation. This requires re-creating the highest level of political oversight, avoiding any artificial discrimination between actions at EU and Member State level, and at the same time developing more effective tools to ensure that the EU's single market really benefits citizens and businesses.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the revision of the economic governance framework because it is urgent and necessary to complete the turn of European economic policy, and in particular to fill the gaps in Economic and Monetary Union (EMU).  This report raises possibilities to improve the use of flexibility contained in existing rules, strengthen economic coordination and simplify procedures, as well as improve democratic control of structural reforms.  In particular, it is worth noting the following elements: - Adoption of common structural or convergence policy objectives through codecision (i.e. with the participation of the European Parliament) - Adoption of an Interinstitutional Agreement for the participation of the European Parliament in a simplified European Semester. - Fiscal capacity of the eurozone to deal with asymmetric shocks. - Convergence of tax policies. - European-level fight against tax evasion and avoidance. - Initiatives to reduce the eurozone's public debt stock. - Strengthening the social dimension, including the establishment of a European minimum wage. I also consider it important to complement the vertical strengthening of EMU with its horizontal consolidation so that, by 2020, Member States that already fulfil economic conditions join it.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the revision of the economic governance framework because it is urgent and necessary to complete the turn of European economic policy, and in particular to fill the gaps in Economic and Monetary Union (EMU).  This report raises possibilities to improve the use of flexibility contained in existing rules, strengthen economic coordination and simplify procedures, as well as improve democratic control of structural reforms.  In particular, it is worth noting the following elements: - Adoption of common structural or convergence policy objectives through codecision (i.e. with the participation of the European Parliament) - Adoption of an Interinstitutional Agreement for the participation of the European Parliament in a simplified European Semester. - Fiscal capacity of the eurozone to deal with asymmetric shocks. - Convergence of tax policies. - European-level fight against tax evasion and avoidance. - Initiatives to reduce the eurozone's public debt stock. - Strengthening the social dimension, including the establishment of a European minimum wage. I also consider it important to complement the vertical strengthening of EMU with its horizontal consolidation so that, by 2020, Member States that already fulfil economic conditions join it.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 In today's report we have addressed the important issue of economic governance. We have heard a great deal about economic and financial recovery, and it is right that this issue should be given great importance because it is an essential element in our economic and monetary policy. However, it must be strongly emphasised that this pillar collapses if it is not flanked by the other pillar, which is support for the real economy. Helping the real economy means rebalancing imbalances, reducing debt and, above all, helping citizens. That is why we welcome the fact that this report talks about flexibility and that Commissioner Katainen himself has spoken more strongly about this than in the past. Let us continue on this step and help rebuild the real economy in order to be closer to the citizens.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the verification of the eurozone's economic governance framework, because I agree with the need for new solutions to complete the economic and monetary union project. For the first time since the outbreak of the crisis, the EP, which had called for the adoption of mechanisms for correcting macroeconomic imbalances (due to high levels of deficits and public debt in many countries), carried out an important analysis of the decision-making processes with a view to closer coordination of economic policies and greater convergence of European economies in order to make EMU more solid.  EMU must have a strong social dimension, based on strong coordination of social policies and the introduction of a minimum wage/income across the EU. Since the beginning of the crisis, the euro has shown that it can withstand severe turbulence through the creation of new arrangements: from the Banking Union, the link between sovereign debt and banks, to which the EP has made a major contribution, to the European Stability Mechanism, designed to help the countries under the programme, to the very important action of the ECB with its unconventional policies, including quantitative easing, and finally to greater flexibility in the interpretation of the PS&C, to increase investment.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe it contributes in a significant way to the debate on the review of the economic governance framework, as it acknowledges the need to address the lack of investment and the long-lasting low inflation situation within the euro area, and to improve the current economic framework. Furthermore, it stresses to improve use of flexibility within the Stability and Growth Pact, requiring added value of flexibility to bridge the investment gaps and ensuring better implementation of the rules regarding growth. I welcome the underlining of macro-economic imbalances that should be tackled with greater vision and support strengthening the role of national and European parliaments. Furthermore, we should reinforce the Five Presidents’ report on the future of the economic Union forthwith.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report. With it, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs sought to make an assessment of the two-pack which the European Union has adopted in recent years for its review, improvement and/or consolidation. The initial report prepared by MEP Pervenche Beres (French PS), which contained some critical elements, has been amended and chopped into a very long process of negotiations which jeopardized the very integrity of the report. The end result is a text with multiple ambiguities, accommodating the current Framework, which in many cases attributes the economic disaster that has resulted from austerity to which it has not been fully implemented.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my colleagues in the Labour Party and the Socialist and Democrats group, voted in favour of this report as this report aims to assess the effectiveness of the legal framework, particularly whether the provisions governing decision-making have proved sufficiently robust and whether the progress in ensuring closer coordination of economic policies and sustained convergence of economic performances of the Member States is in accordance with the TFEU. The report is based on this background and on the analysis of the first years of the implementation of the economic governance framework as it was modified during the crisis. The report observes that the new provisions have not allowed to take adequately into account the cumulative, Europe-wide effect of policies pursued at national level, in particular of the aggregate fiscal stance, and therefore have not addressed the risks stemming from growing divergences among euro area economies, the threat of deflation, low growth and high unemployment.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the revision of the economic governance framework because it is urgent and necessary to complete the turn of European economic policy, and in particular to fill the gaps in Economic and Monetary Union (EMU).  This report raises possibilities to improve the use of flexibility contained in existing rules, strengthen economic coordination and simplify procedures, as well as improve democratic control of structural reforms.  In particular, it is worth noting the following elements: - Adoption of common structural or convergence policy objectives through codecision (i.e. with the participation of the European Parliament) - Adoption of an Interinstitutional Agreement for the participation of the European Parliament in a simplified European Semester. - Fiscal capacity of the eurozone to deal with asymmetric shocks. - Convergence of tax policies. - European-level fight against tax evasion and avoidance. - Initiatives to reduce the eurozone's public debt stock. - Strengthening the social dimension, including the establishment of a European minimum wage. I also consider it important to complement the vertical strengthening of EMU with its horizontal consolidation so that, by 2020, Member States that already fulfil economic conditions join it.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the report "Review of the economic governance framework: evaluation and objectives" was adopted, I voted against it because it is not ready to finish. In particular, the EU is not yet able to properly summarise and evaluate the six-point and two-point packages, which have made the previous changes to the rules very important. Secondly, the structure of the economic governance framework has yet to be strengthened, especially in the area of the implementation of structural reforms. Thirdly, this report does not guarantee a democratic level of decision-making in the future. It is a pity that we have not been able to convince my colleagues in Parliament that this report should be returned and amended. During the vote, I voted in favour of many of the amendments to the report, which bring it at least somewhat closer to the quality and level that the ALDE Group expected.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. "We Swedish Social Democrats state that there is a need to develop economic governance within the euro area. As long as the process does not damage the internal market or strike at the interests of non-euro countries, we generally have no objection to the fact that a renewed reform process for the euro area has now been launched.  The report contains significant ambiguities on several specific points. These include how 'convergence guidelines' would work, how the ESM and the Fiscal Compact would be 'integrated into the Community framework', how a 'European financial authority' would be constructed and how a 'fiscal capacity' for the euro area would relate to the EU budget. The ambiguities have made it difficult to take a definitive position on these points.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The crisis has shown that Europe needs to take steps to improve its economic model and restore its competitiveness. This requires both public funding and targeted investment. At present, however, the potential of economic governance is not unfolding. Effective economic coordination aims to kick-start Europe's growth and employment engine and ultimately also to increase citizens' opportunities. The coordination of economic and employment policies will be complete if a significant part of this coordination covers all possible means of stimulating the real economy, which would otherwise be excluded from the broader coordination of the European Semester. I voted in favour of Mrs Beres's report, in accordance with the position of the Hungarian Delegation to the People's Party, because I believe that economic policy management needs to be strengthened in order to be an engine for the Union to stimulate and promote growth and job creation. This requires re-creating the highest level of political oversight, avoiding any artificial discrimination between actions at EU and Member State level, and at the same time developing more effective tools to ensure that the EU single market really benefits citizens and businesses.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I think we need to look back at the economic governance framework that was put in place primarily during the financial crisis. I think the focus of this report, particularly on sound and sustainable public finances and structural reforms in order to increase competitiveness, is very welcome. But we do need to acknowledge that the 2-pack and 6-pack rules have worked well so far but it is too early to fully assess the regulations at this point in time.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The crisis has shown that Europe needs to take steps to improve its economic model and restore its competitiveness. This requires both public funding and targeted investment. At present, however, the potential of economic governance is not unfolding. Effective economic coordination aims to kick-start Europe's growth and employment engine and ultimately also to increase citizens' opportunities. The coordination of economic and employment policies will be complete if a significant part of this coordination covers all possible means of stimulating the real economy, which would otherwise be excluded from the broader coordination of the European Semester. I voted in favour of Mrs Beres's report because I believe that economic policy governance needs to be strengthened in order to be an engine for the Union to stimulate and promote growth and job creation. This requires re-creating the highest level of political oversight, avoiding any artificial discrimination between actions at EU and Member State level, and at the same time developing more effective tools to ensure that the EU single market really benefits citizens and businesses.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report. This report was authorized by the Conference of Presidents at the very beginning of the new term with the ultimate view of providing an input on the way forward for the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU). As the negotiation process on the report became longer than planned the report has not been adopted in time to contribute to the completion of the President’s report on EMU. The ongoing impact of the economic crisis and the austerity-driven response across Europe has underlined the need for a more equal, self-sufficient view on economic governance. I reject the report’s whole-hearted endorsement of austerity in reducing excessive imbalances in deficit countries and I would rather see a focus on investment in capital projects alongside a proper account of the social aspects of the EMU. The report as a whole is a bad recipe which lacks vision for ensuring the long-term sustainable future of the EMU.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report. With it, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs sought to make an assessment of the two-pack which the European Union has adopted in recent years for its review, improvement and/or consolidation. The initial report prepared by MEP Pervenche Beres (French PS), which contained some critical elements, has been amended and chopped into a very long process of negotiations which jeopardized the very integrity of the report. The end result is a text with multiple ambiguities, accommodating the current Framework, which in many cases attributes the economic disaster that has resulted from austerity to which it has not been fully implemented.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the revision of the economic governance framework: scoreboard and challenges, primarily because this report is already outdated in relation to the current political situation. In particular, following a recent statement by the five Presidents, who speak clearly of the need to deepen Europe's monetary and overall Economic Union, it is clear that ambitions are far greater than the report in particular contains.  As I am convinced that only "more Europe" can contribute to a more stable monetary system and guarantee a prosperous European economy, with my vote against it, I wanted to express this ambition of creating a stronger Europe.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ The 2008 financial crisis and the ensuing recession have prompted the European Union to start overhauling its economic governance system. The EU established three authorities to better supervise the financial markets, improved mechanisms to oversee and coordinate fiscal policies, created procedures to correct economic imbalances, and launched a Banking Union. While the reform process is still ongoing, it is crucial that the EU evaluates the current economic governance framework and works on the next steps to follow to improve it.
