This was supposed to be the aim of this key report which, in my view, failed to reflect the economic realities facing Europe today and to address the ongoing euro crisis. Among other things, the report calls for a weakening of the Stability and Growth Pact, which would be a backwards step for Europe. With such watered-down compromise report, the Parliament proved unable to match the ambition of the Five Presidents’ report released last week.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report, the vote of which has been constantly postponed for four months and which has made it difficult to find compromises, aims at the creation of a transfer union, based on a unified fiscal policy. The growing inequality between states is a problem that cannot be solved sustainably through transfer payments, but rather through structural reforms in the respective Member States. I reject this report.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the revision of the economic governance system at the Plenary Session of the European Parliament. This report assesses the governance of the EU's economic policies, which includes closer coordination of economic policies between EU Member States, legislation limiting the creation of national excessive deficits and the strengthening of economic and monetary union in general. With this report, the European Parliament stresses the need for a functioning economic and monetary union, which means closer economic relations between the countries of the euro area, greater coordination of structural reforms, possibly even the shifting of some tax to a new budget of the euro area. The rapprochement of the countries of the euro area will be a process that will bring significant benefits to Latvia and its citizens; one of the benefits will be the dismantling of existing barriers in the single market, thus creating additional opportunities for Latvian entrepreneurs.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The crisis has shown that Europe needs to take steps to improve its economic model and restore its competitiveness. This requires both public funding and targeted investment. At present, however, the potential of economic governance is not unfolding. Effective economic coordination aims to kick-start Europe's growth and employment engine and ultimately also to increase citizens' opportunities. The coordination of economic and employment policies will be complete if a significant part of this coordination covers all possible means of stimulating the real economy, which would otherwise be excluded from the broader coordination of the European Semester. I voted in favour of Mrs Beres's report because I believe that economic policy governance needs to be strengthened in order to be an engine for the Union to stimulate and promote growth and job creation. This requires re-creating the highest level of political oversight, avoiding any artificial discrimination between actions at EU and Member State level, and at the same time developing more effective tools to ensure that the EU's single market really benefits citizens and businesses.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This economic governance framework has failed. Any modification or improvement would result in the maintenance of the "ancient régime". I voted against the report on the review of the economic governance framework, because I believe that only replacing it with a new legal framework for economic governance can be a constructive solution for the future.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – The aim is to better the euro area economic governance system by means of economic policy instruments. However, the system itself is fundamentally flawed, so all efforts are doomed to failure, so the report is unsupvocated. It is almost unbelievable that, despite a series of bankruptcies and the growth of unsustainable social conflicts, there is still no question of rebuilding a different type of cooperation system from the foundations instead of dead-end solutions.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Berès' report on the review of the economic governance framework, aware of its importance in assessing the effectiveness of the European regulatory framework on economic management. The aim is to verify that the policies undertaken by the Member States under the TFEI have been quite incisive in seeking greater coordination of their economic policies.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is supposed to give the Opinion of the European Parliament on the evolution of the economic and budgetary governance of the euro area and the Union. In reality, it is more of a roadmap for a future economic government of Europe, which is clearly de straying from the principle of subsidiarity, in order to impose ever more restrictive recommendations. The Berès report is very talkative and leads to a strengthening of European governance, that is to say, further interference by the European Union in budgetary policies, but also in the wage and social policies of the Member States. In doing so, he advocates the strengthening of technocratic bodies such as the Eurogroup. However, I am opposed to the loss, even partial, of the sovereignty implied by the rules of European governance. It is not for the European Union to dictate to France the great balances of its budget or its economic policies.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The report deals with strengthening the euro area's economic governance framework since the start of the crisis. In this context, given the slow growth, large differences in situation between Member States, high unemployment, low inflation and low investment levels, the report considers that decisive action is urgently needed. Among the topics highlighted in the report are: support for the Commission Communication on flexibility in the interpretation of the Stability and Growth Pact, the adoption of common structural or convergence policy objectives through codecision (i.e. with the participation of the European Parliament), the adoption of an Interinstitutional Agreement for the participation of the European Parliament in a simplified European Semester , the elimination of the Troika, the convergence of tax policies, the European-level fight against tax evasion and avoidance and the strengthening of the social dimension, including the minimum wage. Agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The report's task was to take stock of the current state of fiscal governance, in particular to assess the functioning of the regulatory framework and to describe challenges ahead. The report does not do justice to this task because it does not require a systematic analysis of the status quo. Instead, it calls for the centralisation of economic policy and the communitarisation of liability in the euro area. As a result, expenditure responsibility and liability continue to diverge and existing European law, in particular the non-assistance clause (Article 125 TFEU), is disregarded.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against it because I do not agree with any calls that could lead to greater centralisation of economies towards the EU in the future. The economic crisis cannot be solved by centralisation, but rather by respecting the sovereignty of nation states and allowing tax competition.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported Berès MP's report on the revision of the economic governance framework. We want a Europe that inspires and leads, and without good economic governance, togetherness and partnership, we cannot achieve this. Good economic governance is the cornerstone of growth, development and employment. Without good economic governance, neither the new European Fund for Strategic Investments, nor cohesion or agricultural policy can succeed in the long term.  Success and development require a combination of measures: investment, structural reforms and smart fiscal consolidation. We need to strengthen the current economic governance framework, stronger inclusion of national parliaments and more decisive implementation of recommendations is needed.  Europe is heading in the right direction, the new Commission is making positive changes, work is firmly being done to strengthen the single market and the monetary, economic, financial and fiscal Union. Sharing knowledge and experience will help everyone, less developed Member States to converate more quickly and develop them to become even more innovative, creative and competitive on the global market.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I absolutely cannot accept the populism expressed by the far right during the consultation. The difficulty of using the Greek people to raise their rating is absolutely unacceptable. My colleague Berès' report is weighted and is the result of a political compromise. I voted in favour.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The report assessed the effectiveness of the legal framework, the budgetary policy management situation and progress in ensuring the coordination of economic policies and convergence of economic performance of the Member States in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The report reflects the economic and financial crisis and the measures taken to mitigate it. It is necessary to highlight the importance and necessity of taking timely measures and decisions in the management of economic affairs so that they can eliminate the negative impacts on the EU economy and its Member States.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Writing. Solidarity is not a one-way street – we also need solidity! This is what the triad stands for, of a consistent course of reform, the will for real structural changes and strict budgetary discipline. On this basis, European taxpayers are prepared to help the people of other Member States. It may be tempting for politicians to make lavish election promises. Ultimately, this populism is irresponsible, because the next generation will have to foot the bill. And investors are mercilessly punishing unsound budgeting and debt-making. This results in capital flight, unstable markets and significant financial problems, for example for the promotion of social policies. I have successfully tabled amendments both in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. You pointed to positive developments, including the increase in full-time contracts and improvements in the labour market situation in some, but not all, Member States. Austerity with measure and aim has strengthened confidence in the euro area. Ireland and Portugal are considered to be rehabilitated; Cyprus and Spain are on the right track. And the new banking union offers sufficient protection. So let us remain undeterred on this path of stability! But let's also leave room for re-adjustment and fine-tuning without changing the overall course.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: in writing. The role of co-legislator condemns the European Parliament to go far behind the Commission, which could become positive only if Parliament took advantage of the revision of the past to guide the future. This is not the case with the Beres report, which we vote against, where instead of a critical look the policies with which the EU has dealt with the economic crisis are highlighted, ignoring the fact that they have divided the continent between creditors and debtors, and have led to colossal unemployment and poverty. While the five presidents of the European institutions are declaring earlier this week that the economic governance of the eurozone needs to be strengthened, the EP approves a motion that there would be almost nothing to touch. Not only is it a mistake, but it is the resignation of this Parliament to go ahead and propose solutions for the future.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the review of the economic governance framework: review and challenges, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 24 June 2015.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The review of the economic governance framework concerns the effective application of the "6 pack" and "2 pack" packages. A review of the governance framework is therefore understood to mean an analysis of the effectiveness of legislation and, consequently, the recognition of the crisis situation in a Member State as soon as possible, calling for corrective action through structural reforms. I voted in favour of supporting the Commission's 3 strategic pillars: investment growth, fiscal consolidation, structural reforms and flexibility. In addition, the Commission communication welcoming the '6 pack' and '2 pack' have worked well so far, but it is still too early to fully assess its effectiveness. The report calls for the European Semester to be rationalised in the structure of the existing rules.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The governance of the euro area, which is always difficult, has been particularly complex during the period of economic crisis, with decisions that may not always have been the right ones, but which I believe have been the right ones as a whole to deal with this difficult situation. However, we need to reflect on economic governance and that is why I support the European Parliament's resolution, which calls for issues such as more account of national circumstances when implementing the measures or ensuring control over the indirect effects that are caused.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I reject the report 'Review of the economic governance framework' because of the demands on the European Parliament's participation and the implementation of the rules in economic governance and on structural reforms and more economic coordination.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ This report included specific references to convergence of taxation policies of the Member States and a commitment to a common consolidated corporate tax base, which I could not support. Issues involving taxation, such as these, are matters of national competence and are best dealt with at a Member State level.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst appreciating and supporting the positive aspects of the report on the review of the economic governance framework, I have serious concerns and express my reservations with some of the articles of the report, such as the proposal for the creation of a fourth pillar on taxation and taxation union, including changing the powers to raise revenues, which are an exclusive national competence based on the EU Treaties. Moreover, harmonisation of the tax structure at this stage might further reduce the flexibility of those economies, which in order to boost their competitiveness and performance, given their limited endowments, will need to differentiate their tax profiles, naturally under conditions of full transparency. For these reasons, I voted against those provisions and against the final report.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs pushes for a review of the framework for economic governance. Two German MEPs, Bernd Lucke and Beatrix von Storch, commented on the report. According to this, the "report supports the centralisation of economic policy and the sharing of accountability within the euro area" and "concrete proposals relating to European economic governance include the establishment of an EU central budget and a European unemployment insurance, the issue of Eurobonds and the institutional strengthening of the Eurogroup." That's how I see it myself. According to this report, the report is on the trail of a joint article published in the Guardian by German Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel and French Economy Minister Emanuel Macron, proposing a broader, stronger Union and closer cooperation. While minority opinions reject the report for this reason, that is why I supported it.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The Berès report presents the desired evolution of the EU's economic and budgetary governance framework. It clearly takes a stand in favour of greater integration through enhanced policy coordination and specific recommendation mechanisms. The federalist logic at work leads to the european Union's further interference in fiscal policies, but also in substantive reforms, wage and social policies of the Member States.  In order to do so, it advocates the strengthening of bodies such as the Eurogroup.  Since the 2008 crisis, states have been pressed to give up some of their fiscal sovereignty, have accepted a ruinous redistributive mechanism for the rescue of failed states (the European Stability Mechanism) and abandoned supervision of banks (the first pillar of the banking union). The complexity of the procedures and the lack of transparency in the Eurogroup's decisions are additional elements against these European convergence policies. The FN wants states to retain the choice of their economic and fiscal policy on their own and challenge the legitimacy of the single currency, and thus the convergence it implies. Therefore, it votes against this report.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The evaluation of the implementation of the Six-Pack and Two-Pack legislative packages is still partial at this stage and cannot be isolated from the European Semester, the TFEU and the Fiscal Compact. Furthermore, I believe that the prevention of excessive deficit and debt levels, as well as excessive macroeconomic imbalances, is central ly in the European economic governance system. I am voting in favour of this economic governance report, which aims to underline the importance of the fact that budgetary rules should be interpreted to close the investment gap in the European Union and facilitate structural reforms that favour growth and are sustainable and socially balanced.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report once again calls for a utopian economic governance of the euro area based on convergence criteria (respect for a certain level of deficit and public debt) that are not based on any macroeconomic basis. Indeed, according to the bank JP Morgan, the countries of the euro area are even more economically dissimilar than the countries of the world starting with the letter Mr. Moreover, to obtain an optimal monetary zone, the solution lies in a significant mobility of factors of production, including work. However, different barriers, such as language or different cultures, make this option quite impossible. It also requires large budget transfers between the heart of the area and the periphery which are unimaginable as the Greek case can show.  Moreover, these different solutions are an intolerable attack on sovereignty and democracy, since they feed a supranational super-state that does not meet the expectations of the peoples. Such a direction would reflect the assertion that European integration is an "enlightened despotism" whose effectiveness leaves us wondering when one sees the economic disaster that has led to austerity.  So I voted against this report.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock and sets out the issues of the euro area's economic governance framework, the central elements of which are the prevention of deficits, debt levels and excessive macroeconomic imbalances and the coordination of economic policies. It is important to recognise the meagre results in this area and, like the EPP Group of which I am a member, I regret that, from the moment the euro was launched, remediation efforts to implement the stability rules have been relaxed. This lack of compliance with the rules is one of the root causes of the sovereign debt crisis that several euro area states have experienced since 2009. That is why I am in favour of sustainable fiscal consolidation and structural reforms that will increase competitiveness and invest in improving growth.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this report, which is the result of lengthy negotiation work between the various political groups, in order to assess the effectiveness of the existing regulatory framework on economic governance. In particular, we have had to analyse whether the provisions on decision-making processes have been sufficiently incisive and whether progress has been made in terms of closer coordination of the economic policies of the Member States. The negative effect on growth prospects, due to the introduction of a simultaneous contraction of budgetary policies in Europe, has been significantly underestimated, and the flexibility clauses provided for in the Stability and Growth Pact have not been fully used, partly because of too restrictive an interpretation.  We are convinced that any framework of economic governance cannot be judged solely on the basis of results, but must also be assessed in terms of political and democratic accountability.  For this reason, the European Parliament must be able to contribute to the debate on the better functioning of EMU in order to achieve the objectives of democracy, transparency and ownership. It is therefore necessary to put an end to purely intergovernmental agreements and to involve this House, whenever necessary, in order to increase the democratic legitimacy of any decision on economic governance.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 This report attempts to assess the efficiency of the regulatory framework for economic governance, specifically whether the provisions on decision-making processes have proved sufficiently incisive and whether progress has been made in terms of closer coordination of economic policies and lasting convergence of Member States' performance. I therefore voted in favour of this text because it calls on the Commission to present an ambitious roadmap for achieving an in-depth economic and monetary union, taking into account the proposals made in it, on the basis of the mandate given to it by the euro area summit and confirmed by the European Council, in order to prepare the next measures aimed at improving economic governance.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the 2007 financial crisis, the shortcomings of the economic governance framework established for the euro area in 1990 have revealed, which is unable to take into account the complexity of macroeconomic political challenges for a monetary union. I voted for this report on the evaluation of the economic governance framework for the implementation of new elements with a view to achieving stricter coordination, economic convergence and rationalisation of the European Semester.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report, which I consider to be a reasonable compromise. In particular, I appreciate that the report does not create scope for relaxing the existing EU economic governance rules as regards the legal framework for six-pack and two-pack. The key point of the report, which talks about strengthening and simplifying the European Semester without changing the current legal framework, remained in the report and should thus constitute a safeguard against possible attempts to break or relax the rules of fiscal discipline. The flexibility already in place deserves a reserved and cautious attitude, much less, in my opinion, it is necessary or desirable that this flexibility should be even more so. Excessive flexibility and little respect for the rules was largely behind the DEBT crisis in the EU, which many countries have been affected by.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. This report promises a great deal of good. The objectives set are to coordinate the relevant objectives and to promote the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy for smart and inclusive growth. A review of effectiveness would also be necessary in this case. Unfortunately, the report does not highlight the instruments used to review the framework. Because of this ambiguity, I voted against this report.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. The report on the economic governance framework seeks to establish the Euro-Camera's position in the debate on Economic and Monetary Union for greater integration and cooperation in economic matters. What could have become a unique opportunity for the European Parliament to set an ambitious position in establishing a strong framework for crisis management and to advance the economic and political governance of the Union has been left in a decaffeinated text which does not even provide for the basis of the European Commission's own proposal. From UPyD we regret that fundamental aspects such as the revision of country-specific recommendations, the review of macroeconomic imbalances or a mechanism of insolvency for States are not included. Nor does the text refer to the role of the European Court of Justice or the need for an external representative of the eurozone. In short, the report lacks analysis, concrete proposals and efficient solutions. For all of the above we have decided to vote against it.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the solutions proposed will not reduce social inequalities, long-term unemployment and increasing poverty. The independence of community members on economic and financial matters must not be allowed to be further restricted while at the same time further reducing the autonomy of the Member States. It should be noted that the reduction of public expenditure under the fiscal consolidation plans did not help to reduce social exclusion and economic growth, but rather led to a weakening of social protection. The economic situation in EU countries is not good, and there is indeed a need for solutions that lead to job growth and the reduction of social exclusion. The current system of economic governance has failed economically, socially and politically. This system must therefore be substantially reviewed, restoring the fiscal and monetary autonomy of the Member States. In this context, urgent, comprehensive and decisive measures are needed to address problems such as high unemployment, rising poverty and excessive inequalities.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 The action plan approved by Parliament contains important guidelines for the development of European governance, which is why I voted in favour. The current system of rules is complex and unsatisfactory, and the case of Greece shows that we are still a long way from achieving a genuine economic and monetary union. The path started in 2008 must therefore be continued, improving current governance measures to better protect the European system from external shocks. The introduction of a new legal framework to replace the troika is crucial to achieving more investment and sustainable growth. In this context, I believe it is particularly important to strengthen parliament's role as an institution with democratic accountability and to ensure greater transparency in procedures.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The JRC voted against the report because it promotes measures to strengthen the ECONOMIC governance of the EU and deepen EMU, intensifying the harsh attack of EU and civil governments against the peoples in all its Member States, hitting labour rights and further reducing the price of labour, to ensure the competitiveness and profitability of European monopolistic groups , to become more powerful in the field of imperialist competition for market sharing.  The JRC does not enter the debate on individual measures and proposals, because it does not legitimise the debate on the ways and forms in which the exploitation, poverty and misery of workers will grow and deepen. EMU with whatever "architecture" it is set up, "economic governance", the Stability Pact, the Euro Pact, the Financial Pact, the ESM, is an "iron" mechanism for imposing unpopular measures. He's not getting a fix. Those who claim that the EU can change for the benefit of the people are consciously deceiving workers into keeping them in the chariot of their exploiters. The only way to popular prosperity is to break with the EU, its capital and power, to disengage from the EU, to socialise monopolies with Labour-People's power.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to begin by thanking my colleague and the Commission for their hard work and for seeking a point of convergence on such an important prospective budget. As far as I am concerned, I am in favour of the motion for a resolution because it is necessary to become aware of the weaknesses that are undermining the euro and the European Union and to adopt effective solutions to emerge from the economic crisis.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. \u2012 Convergence is by normal definition a process, or a certain circumstance of gradually approaching a point in space or time. Common EU policies (such as the Common Agricultural Policy) should lead to this desired rapprochement.  However, today we are aware of the exact opposite process – divergence, but not between policies and economies, but between people, citizens of the European Union, and those poor and rich, whereby the poor get poorer, while the rich get richer.  The report said the crisis highlighted the existence of fundamental problems and unsustainable economic developments in many European countries and unequivocally showed that EU economies depend on each other. Member States' economies depend on each other and there is also interest from each other to help each other, in order to achieve the desired goal together, to retain Europe's status as the best place to live in the world.  Although this report relates to the eurozone and Croatia is outside the eurozone, with a clearly expressed desire and intention to become a member of the Eurozone and has tied its currency to the euro and implements austerity measures, I expect this desired convergence at all levels to contribute to a better life for the citizens of my country, who are today among the poorest in Europe. This poverty is sometimes actively contributed by some European policies, along with the disinterest and incompetence of the current government.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ It is obvious for the signatories of the Report "euro more than currency", but to remain successful and stable as a political and economic project needs a stronger, fairer and more democratic legitimacy basis. The crisis over the repayment of Greece's debt and its future (inside or outside the eurozone and the EU) is the best evidence that the work taken in 2008 when the crisis was just heating up is not nearly complete. I agree with the view that we need to simplify, improve, complement and fix the existing set of rules to boost investment and achieve sustainable development. I am pleased that Parliament's new guidelines go further and advocate maintaining the social dimension by defining the minimum wage, encouraging a more effective fight against tax evasion, but what is particularly interesting is that they propose the abolition of the notorious Troika and its replacement with a more efficient model. It is interesting to note how different Cameron's is from the Juncker calendar for, apparently, the inevitable treaty changes. The British Prime Minister would like a new deal before the announced referendum in 2017, while the President of the Commission announces the possibility of such a thing only after that year. I think, too, dilemmas can grow about the future relationship between the eurozone and the single market. All in all, completing Europe's Economic and Monetary Union will not be possible without a new generation of far-reaching policy decisions on the future of the EU in the 21st century.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒I support peer Pervenche Berès' report on the revision of the economic governance framework to assess whether the Commission and the Member States of the Union apply governance rules in an effective and uniform manner. This audit was a good opportunity to exchange views, in particular with the competent committees of the European Parliament, on the operational rules of the framework and on how the efficiency and democracy of the framework can be increased and its social dimension, in particular as regards the achievement of the Objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy. The fact is that the total debt of the 28 Member States of the Union has decreased from 4.5 % of GDP in 2011 to the projected 3% of GDP in 2014, but the economic balance across the cycle should more effectively foster a smart , sustainable and inclusive growth, which has been modest or stagnant in recent years and is estimated to keep Union GDP growth below 1.5%. In achieving this goal, Member States should implement the Commission's recommendations to support sustainable growth by creating better, sustainable jobs and social cohesion and to make progress towards the Objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy. Of particular concern is the number (21%) unemployed young people in the Union. The Republic of Croatia is among the leading countries in this ranking with 45% and therefore needs a more efficient implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative throughout the Union.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union, and in particular the euro area, have reached the point where the reform of the economic system needs to begin. It is no longer possible to accept 28 different policies of individual Member States if their coordination does not work effectively. There is a need to create a Union whose economy is resilient and able to safeguard growth and social protection for its citizens. That is why I voted in favour of the report on the review of the economic governance framework. I supported the proposal encouraging better coordination of member states' social policies, including, inter alia, the minimum wage and the fight against long-term unemployment. With my vote, I also called on the European Commission to be extremely careful when evaluating the budgetary situation in the Member States. The practical consequences of unconsioned, economically restrictive decisions may be enormous in the context of the current fragile growth. That is why I also supported stronger involvement of the European Parliament in the European Semester process, which must ultimately create a fairer economic, tax and social environment. I am deeply convinced that if we can make the current, very cluttered procedures a simpler and more transparent system, not only the responsibility of the Member States and the European institutions will improve, but also the necessary trust of citizens.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it crucial in the present report on the review of the economic governance framework that there should be no attempts to relax existing economic governance rules, such as the excessive deficit procedure or the macroeconomic imbalances procedure, and to weaken the emphasis on budgetary discipline and structural reforms in favour of public investment. Maintaining budgetary discipline is one of the state's main economic roles, and its implementation has a key economic impact on the state of the economy. On the contrary, I consider the idea that public investment is more important than budgetary discipline to be wrong, and I am not afraid to say that it is harmful.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The recent economic and financial crisis has required the adoption of measures such as the creation of the Banking Union, the ESM, the Six-Pack and the Two-Pack, the TECG and the European Semester. This report aims to assess the effectiveness of this economic governance framework by proposing to take stock of its implementation and to identify challenges and prospects for future developments.  In this regard, it advocates the adoption of a holistic approach, based on fiscal sustainability, structural reforms that promote growth and strengthening investment, supports the strategy of the three pillars (investments likely to promote growth, fiscal consolidation and structural reforms), presented at the 2015 Annual Growth Survey, and welcomes the interpretative communication on flexibility recently published by the Commission. On the other hand, with a view to deepening EMU, it advocates, among other measures, simplification and strengthening of the European Semester, greater effectiveness in implementing the macroeconomic imbalances procedure, the completion of the Banking Union, a budgetary capacity for the euro area, the integration of the ESM and the ESM into the EU legal framework and the strengthening of democratic accountability mechanisms , both at European and national level. I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. As speculation mounts about a possible Greek exit from the eurozone and even the European Union, Parliament must take an ambitious position on the future of Europe's economic governance. Unfortunately, the report approved today does not meet this expectation. On the contrary, we find ourselves in an incredible situation where the document published recently by the five presidents, with concrete proposals to get out of the euro crisis, goes much further than this Berès report does. However, we had proposed innovative solutions for effective, democratic and rules-based European economic governance applied to all countries. It is regrettable that the demands of the ALDE group were not taken into account by the Socialist rapporteur. Worse, this report takes a step backwards from Parliament's previous proposals. It only weakens the position of the European Parliament in the forthcoming negotiations on economic governance. Therefore, I voted against this report which does not address the challenges regarding the future of the single currency.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the revision of the economic governance framework because it is urgent and necessary to complete the turn of European economic policy, and in particular to fill the gaps in Economic and Monetary Union (EMU).  This report raises possibilities to improve the use of flexibility contained in existing rules, strengthen economic coordination and simplify procedures, as well as improve democratic control of structural reforms.  In particular, it is worth noting the following elements: - Adoption of common structural or convergence policy objectives through codecision (i.e. with the participation of the European Parliament) - Adoption of an Interinstitutional Agreement for the participation of the European Parliament in a simplified European Semester. - Fiscal capacity of the eurozone to deal with asymmetric shocks. - Convergence of tax policies. - European-level fight against tax evasion and avoidance. - Initiatives to reduce the eurozone's public debt stock. - Strengthening the social dimension, including the establishment of a European minimum wage. I also consider it important to complement the vertical strengthening of EMU with its horizontal consolidation so that, by 2020, Member States that already fulfil economic conditions join it.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament has set out its vision for a strengthened Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) by taking up and voting on this report, which focuses on economic convergence and the importance of investment to stimulate growth in Europe.  In order to reform EMU in the longer term, the text of the report stresses the importance of promoting the "convergence" of euro area economies, through setting targets for the euro area as a whole and correcting macroeconomic imbalances between Member States. On structural reforms, the text calls for their impact to be assessed over time, "not only in terms of labour costs but also in terms of social, environmental and economic criteria." Last but not least, it should be noted that to complete EMU, it will take the same political will as demonstrated to complete the banking union. Case to follow...

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. This report draws attention to the review of the current economic governance framework, presenting a diagnosis of the situation and looking at those that are the main challenges in the future. Bearing in mind the current financial crisis scenario in the euro area, it is of particular importance to improve the current economic governance framework with a view to ensuring better fiscal stability, greater economic convergence of the euro area and equivalent treatment for the different economic and budgetary situations of the Member States. I also endorse the rapporteur's position on the need for simplification and transparency of the processes for good economic governance, better application of flexibility, within the existing rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, and further rationalisation and strengthening of the European Semester, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution tabled by Mrs Berès, which seeks to assess the effectiveness of the regulatory framework for economic governance. In line with the PPE's position, I am satisfied with the governance framework, although the poor results of both excessive deficit procedures (EAPs) and macroeconomic imbalances (MIPs) due to insufficient application should be highlighted.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote against because the report, while presenting some just criticism of the work of the European Commission, maintains an overall approach that is too optimistic and positive towards the line taken by the European institutions, although this line has proved to be completely unsuccessful and inconclusive in the face of the current social and economic crisis.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this report. With it, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs sought to make an assessment of the two-pack which the European Union has adopted in recent years for its review, improvement and/or consolidation. The initial report prepared by MEP Pervenche Beres (French PS), which contained some critical elements, has been amended and chopped into a very long process of negotiations which jeopardized the very integrity of the report. The end result is a text with multiple ambiguities, accommodating the current Framework, which in many cases attributes the economic disaster that has resulted from austerity to which it has not been fully implemented.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Berès report on the 'Review of the economic governance framework: assessment and challenges', because it is essential that the European Parliament has a clear and ambitious position in the debate on the future of economic and monetary union (EMU).  This report, which, together with the 5 Presidents' document, should be the basis for the discussion of the reform of EMU, incorporates key demands of the Socialists, such as support for the flexibility of budgetary rules and investment, a more progressive view of the concept of structural reforms and the requirement to assess their economic and social impact, strengthen the prevention of macroeconomic imbalances and a strong defence of convergence between Member States , a call for strengthening the control and democratic legitimacy of economic and monetary decisions and the budgetary capacity of the euro area, as well as affirming the social dimension of EMU, through the coordination of social policies and the fight against poverty and social exclusion.  These proposals are a valuable contribution to a decisive debate for Europe and the future of European citizens.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. – Labour MEPs voted in favour of the report on the review of the economic governance framework. The euro area lacks a proper evaluation of its global economic situation, as one sharing the same currency needs to have. This has been made obvious by the appearance of strong divergences that the current crisis and the intervention of the Troika have even increased and by the historical fall of investment in the EU. The rapporteur proposes to upgrade the euro area recommendation prepared by the Commission, thus to make it compulsory and to adopt it earlier during the Spring Council.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the Berès report. It should be noted that the report is aimed at conferring greater EU competence on economic and monetary union. I believe that moving in this direction, and therefore trying to introduce elements of fiscal and monetary federalism, is a step in the wrong direction. Respect for subsidiarity and the principle of international cooperation should be at the heart of every part of EU policy, and I therefore agree with the ECR Group's position against this report.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the report, which aimed to assess the effectiveness of the legal framework, in particular whether the provisions governing decision-making have proved sufficiently reliable and whether progress in ensuring closer coordination of economic policies and a lasting convergence of the economic performance of the Member States is in line with the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. The report points to certain critical points. The euro area lacks a proper assessment of its global economic situation, a common diagnosis that those who use the common currency must have. The Economic and Monetary Union clearly lacks adequate tools to properly discuss the dynamics that different Member States should follow – in relation to their fiscal position. The report came at a time when, more than seven years after the start of the crisis, the euro has been saved through measures including the modification of the Stability and Growth Pact, the fiscal agreement, the establishment of the European Stability Mechanism, the Banking Union and the governing role of the European Central Bank.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The financial crisis has exposed fundamental problems in many European countries and shown the need for structural reforms. However, the emphasis on consolidation in recent years has at times been detrimental to their financing, led to a halt in the economic growth of EU countries, an increase in unemployment and sparked debates about the democratic legitimacy of the Union. A new way to take into account the costs of implementing structural reforms by Member States when assessing a Member State's fiscal situation could improve the implementation of reforms by Member States, increase their sense of responsibility and kick-start the European economy. On the other hand, closer integration and stronger involvement of the European Parliament at European level are essential conditions for increasing the EU's democratic legitimacy.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report by my Social Democrat colleague Pervenche Berés. The report is a good and honest inventory of the current European economic governance capacity. In doing so, it clearly shows where we urgently need improvements. The aim should be to improve the harmonisation of the 28 national economic policies. This requires a central European collection of economic data. So far, Europe has had to rely on the analyses of the nation states in its economic policy. There is an urgent need to adapt the budgetary rules to economic policy realities. Pure austerity cannot lead to the goal in difficult economic times. Nation states must be given the opportunity to invest in future industries. The unilateral austerity policies pursued so far have further increased public debt in some European nation states. I also supported the reform policies presented in the report, which are based on the interests of workers and not just on the interests of business associations. Too often in Europe, under the guise of structural reforms, the dismantling of workers' rights has been practised. This must stop once and for all.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ According to commission forecasts, the economy should grow in 2015 after negative growth in the past two years. While the economy is recovering, the output gap remains large and there are large differences between the Member States itself in the debt ratio, unemployment level, current account situation. Adverse effects on the entire Economic and Monetary Union should be avoided. Investment also decreased by 3.4% in 2012, by 2.4% in 2013 and by 17% since the period before the crisis, and the expected growth rates are very low, which is a burden on future generations.  Nevertheless, the introduction of a European Investment Plan to stimulate new investments worth €315 billion should prevent the damage of the investment gap. In accordance with all of the above, I support the Economic Governance Framework Review Report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I support this Report, as the Commission's autumn forecasts are expected to grow by 0.8% in 2014 and 1.1% in 2015, which would mean that the growth rate will not reach pre-crisis levels this year. Also, following the Troika's intervention, there will still be huge differences between Member States and the projected GDP growth rates in 2014 will range from -2.8% in Cyprus to +4.6% in Ireland, reflecting increasingly problematic and growing internal disparities. The current economic situation requires urgent, comprehensive and decisive measures in response to the risk of deflation or very low inflation, weak growth and high unemployment. I believe that economic governance has a great need for less complexity, better accountability, greater transparency and democracy, and that a path to stronger integration cannot be achieved by adding a set of new rules in addition to the pre-existing ones. Furthermore, a reassessment of the eurogroup decision-making process should be carried out to ensure adequate democratic accountability and transparency.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the review of the economic governance framework. Economies in the EU are closely intertwined, especially for the euro area with a single monetary policy. In a shared boat it certainly doesn't help if one side paddles forward and the other back. That is also why we have economic governance. To help and support each other in the EU in creating the jobs we have lost through the crisis, in strengthening the economic recovery and investment. This requires compliance with the agreements and clear, simple and transparent rules and procedures, and we also have a role and responsibility for the European institutions in ensuring them.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. Unfortunately, the report insists on the continuation of the neoliberal policies of harsh austerity, even though, as has been shown in practice, they are increasingly exacerbating the economic crisis, increasing inequalities and leading peoples to unemployment, poverty and poverty.  In the same context, economic integration, the deepening of the Stability and Growth Pact and the fiscal union proposed in the report will be disastrous for the people. We believe that each country should implement its own policy, which takes into account the particular circumstances of the individual country, taking into account the needs of society and peoples. The concept developed in the report of social reform limited to the need to harmonise working conditions for the benefit of mobility, i.e. non-stable forms of employment, poses a significant threat to labour rights in the EU. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The failed model of economic governance that led to the current crisis must not continue. It undermines the sovereignty of the Member States by effectively establishing the economic dictatorship of Brussels than by solving the real problems of the citizens.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 The crisis has shown that Europe needs to take steps to improve its economic model and restore its competitiveness. This requires both public funding and targeted investment. At present, however, the potential of economic governance is not unfolding. Effective economic coordination aims to kick-start Europe's growth and employment engine and ultimately also to increase citizens' opportunities. The coordination of economic and employment policies will be complete if a significant part of this coordination covers all possible means of stimulating the real economy, which would otherwise be excluded from the broader coordination of the European Semester.   I voted in favour of Mrs Beres's report because I believe that economic policy governance needs to be strengthened in order to be an engine for the Union to stimulate and promote growth and job creation. This requires re-creating the highest level of political oversight, avoiding any artificial discrimination between actions at EU and Member State level, and at the same time developing more effective tools to ensure that the EU's single market really benefits citizens and businesses.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. ‒ I congratulate Ms Berès on the report on economic governance. It has been a very complex process and the rapporteur managed to give an excellent overview and made valuable comments. I especially agree with the observation that economic governance has become so complex that it has started to work against us. It has indeed a detrimental effect on transparency and democracy. I welcome the fact that the report calls for less complexity, more transparency and identifies a European-wide measure against tax fraud and evasion and aggressive corporate tax planning as a tool to achieve it.  The country-by-country reporting for corporates was also mentioned in the report, which was unfortunately not introduced by the Commission’s Action Plan for a fairer corporate tax system. I urge the stakeholders to take note of the recommendations of the report and aim for a less complicated economic governance system that could stabilise the current fragile economic situation.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is, from the very beginning, a project aimed at strengthening solidarity between European states and citizens. The first of the areas where this has been true is the economic sector. Today, the European Union's economy is one of the best performing in the world, allowing a high standard of living for our citizens. With the crisis, however, the viability of our development model has been called into question, especially due to the problems faced by some Member States.  The response mechanisms created at European Union level to solve these problems suffer from an inherent lack of legitimacy, which can only be removed through the involvement of the European Parliament, the representative forum of European citizens. Only in this forum can we decide whether the rules by which economic and monetary union operate can be changed or not, only here can we choose one model or another of development, a greater or lesser degree of convergence. In the current context, I believe that the solution is an increase in European integration and solidarity by achieving a fiscal union, a banking union and the introduction of a European minimum wage. The meaning of the continuation of the European project can only be to strengthen economic integration, in order to ensure the prosperity of all our citizens.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I did not vote against it, but abstained. Indeed, I continue to wonder if the magic will work and bring out these 300 billion euros. In many ways, I cannot understand that, in one of the paragraphs, some people are happy with the "two-pack" and the "six-pack"! I cannot accept the text.  However, I must highlight the work done by the ECON Committee, in particular by my colleagues Berès and Bayet. The progress made between the final text and the initial announcement of the stimulus package should be highlighted. I am pleased that the social sector, education and health are finally among the possible areas of intervention. In addition, the Juncker plan will primarily benefit SMEs, the main source of economic recovery in many EU countries, including Belgium, and promote regional participation. In this regard, I agree with the colleagues of the aforementioned group that the public guarantee granted to private investment must have the imperative of creating growth and jobs.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this report as it fails to reflect and respond to Europe’s ongoing financial crisis and to propose appropriate measures for the future of the economic governance. By this vote, I also wanted to express my concern after it called for a weakening of the Stability and Growth Pact. Finally by adopting such a report the Parliament proved to be unable to match the ambition of the Five Presidents’ report released last week.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU and the euro area need simple and effective governance to prevent a repeat of insufficient and late action in the future and to ensure that European citizens can reap the full benefits of the single currency and the internal market. Unfortunately, most observers, but also the Commission, recognise that economic governance has reached a level of complexity that is detrimental to democracy and transparency; It is therefore essential to go down an ambitious and credible path of reform. A forward-looking reform programme that will boost the real economy and competitiveness and support advanced social standards: we need new investment and a strengthening of fiscal union. We need proper economic coordination of our policies in order to reduce the macroeconomic imbalances that are undermining the growth of our continent. All these points are taken up in the Berès report, which I voted for and supported with conviction.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. I agree that the current economic situation requires urgent and comprehensive measures, but I believe that the provisions that call on stakeholders to strengthen the Economic and Monetary Union through the strengthening of the tax union will not achieve better economic governance and adding a set of rules in addition to the existing ones will only burden the large administration.  The legislative activity of the European institutions so far shows that by amassing regulation, bureaucracy seems only sluggest and more inefficient. In my view, giving the Commission greater powers to create and channel fiscal flexibility creates an additional burden and prevents Member States from fully taking responsibility and accepting recommendations that can boost economic growth in a country as well as building a single market. We must be aware that the widening internal differences in GDP growth rates between Member States also require completely different approaches, which the current complex economic governance framework does not allow, and thus does not allow for different reactions to different fiscal situations. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the review of the economic governance framework: an assessment of the situation and challenges. Both I and the EES political group regret the lack of compliance with the rules seen in several Member States, as well as the weak implementation of the rules by the institutions, which we believe is the root cause of the national debt crisis that many countries have faced since 2009. However, to increase competitiveness, I support stable and sustainable public finances.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The report's task was to take stock of the current state of fiscal governance, in particular to assess the functioning of the regulatory framework and to describe challenges ahead. The report does not do justice to this task because it dispenses with a systematic analysis of the status quo. Instead, it calls for the centralisation of economic policy and the communitarisation of liability in the euro area. As a result, expenditure responsibility and liability continue to diverge and existing European law, in particular the non-assistance clause (Article 125 TFEU), is disregarded.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ It is my understanding that just after a few years of being brought into existence, it is still premature to decide over how to modify the rules and what are its real flaws. Moreover, I don’t think that the mere announcement of a reform without its implementation should grant extra time for governments to balance their books.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against this report. With it, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs sought to make an assessment of the two-pack which the European Union has adopted in recent years for its review, improvement and/or consolidation. The initial report prepared by MEP Pervenche Beres (French PS), which contained some critical elements, has been amended and chopped into a very long process of negotiations which jeopardized the very integrity of the report. The end result is a text with multiple ambiguities, accommodating the current Framework, which in many cases attributes the economic disaster that has resulted from austerity to which it has not been fully implemented.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted against this report of which I have been shadow rapporteur. The report endorses the macroeconomic policies followed by the EU. In addition, it enshrines the austerity binomial + structural reforms without social and environmental sensitivity as the only recipe against the crisis no matter how inefficient and unfair.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report on the review of the economic governance framework: stocktaking and challenges, as I believe that the report does not address a series of key issues of great importance. There is no inclusion of a merger of the country-specific recommendations, the excessive deficit procedure and the macroeconomic imbalance procedure in a single document of legally binding nature; there is no inclusion of a role to be played by the ECJ; there is no inclusion of an insolvency procedure for sovereigns and no inclusion of a debt redemption fund, on which the report actually rolls back on standing EP positions. These are just a few of the shortcomings of the report which led me to vote against it, in the hope of a better re-formulation that would adequately tackle all the outstanding issues.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a very important report in order to strengthen the framework of the economic government of the euro area. Reports of this kind that contribute to discussing and trying to obtain an analysis that will help improve the economic governance framework are always positive. That is why I consider it appropriate to vote in favour of this report.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the revision of the economic governance framework because it is urgent and necessary to complete the turn of European economic policy, and in particular to fill the gaps in Economic and Monetary Union (EMU).  This report raises possibilities to improve the use of flexibility contained in existing rules, strengthen economic coordination and simplify procedures, as well as improve democratic control of structural reforms.  In particular, it is worth noting the following elements: - Adoption of common structural or convergence policy objectives through codecision (i.e. with the participation of the European Parliament) - Adoption of an Interinstitutional Agreement for the participation of the European Parliament in a simplified European Semester. - Fiscal capacity of the eurozone to deal with asymmetric shocks. - Convergence of tax policies. - European-level fight against tax evasion and avoidance. - Initiatives to reduce the eurozone's public debt stock. - Strengthening the social dimension, including the establishment of a European minimum wage. I also consider it important to complement the vertical strengthening of EMU with its horizontal consolidation so that, by 2020, Member States that already fulfil economic conditions join it.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it sends out an unacceptable political message, namely that Europe today needs to further strengthen the rules and enforce them, rather than change them. According to the report, the real cause of the crisis would be the failure to respect the current framework of economic governance, and not the devastating repercussions that austerity policies and the obsession with budgetary constraints have had on the economy and citizens.  Presented as a fundamental contribution by Parliament to the process of reforming economic governance, this text simply proposes the same wrong recipe, based on austerity and absurd budgetary constraints, which has dragged Europe into the most serious economic and social crisis in the history of European integration and condemned Greece to a real humanitarian emergency. For these reasons, I voted against the Berès report and tabled on behalf of the EFDD Group an alternative motion for a resolution calling for a radical revision of the budgetary rules and austerity policies, including through the revision of the Treaties, and we reiterate the need to give Member States greater fiscal autonomy to finance productive public investment and social measures. , such as citizenship income, and the right to leave the eurozone and then democratically choose your own currency.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The current crisis, almost two decades after the creation of the single currency, should motivate serious and dispassionate reflection on the process of creating the economic and monetary union of the fiscal treaty. The euro was created by the great bankers to serve their interests and ensure their dominance over national states and over the sovereignty of peoples. Economic governance is intended to strengthen this area by preventing the emergence of any alternative development project. The financial crisis of 2007 was thus used to deepen economic governance, i.e. to further strengthen the political stalls, with which it is intended to impose on governments a single path, which is the way of maximising the profit of banks at the expense of citizens. The current reality shows that the breaking of the bonds of the euro, the budgetary treaty and economic governance represents the first step towards the liberation of peoples and their self-determination in choosing their own development project.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I reject the report 'Review of the economic governance framework' because of the demands on the European Parliament's participation and the implementation of the rules in economic governance and on structural reforms and more economic coordination.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it is important to start a debate on the institutional future of the European Union as soon as possible. Parliament's position, together with the report of the five presidents, is an excellent basis for discussion and will, I hope, lead us to a more efficient Union future capable of facing up to the challenges of the modern world.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. Since 1999, European economic governance has become increasingly complicated and has not produced any significant results. The financial, economic and confidence crisis has created more and more new EU laws over the past five years without alternatives than ever before. The name is a programme: 'European economic governance' inevitably leads to the loss of national autonomy in the economic, financial, social and fiscal decision-making areas of the Member States. There have long been well-founded doubts about the constitutionality of European economic governance. However, this own-initiative report ignores this. Through the 'European economic governance' steering element, the EU intends to intervene to a large extent in the national budgets of the Member States in the future and to have a say in national tax legislation, wage developments or social benefits. Binding country-specific recommendations are a direct attack on the principle of subsidiarity. Concrete proposals for European economic governance also include the establishment of a central EU budget, a European unemployment insurance scheme, the issuance of euro bonds, an institutional strengthening of the Eurogroup. I reject that.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The JRC voted against the report because it promotes measures to strengthen the ECONOMIC governance of the EU and deepen EMU, intensifying the harsh attack of EU and civil governments against the peoples in all its Member States, hitting labour rights and further reducing the price of labour, to ensure the competitiveness and profitability of European monopolistic groups , to become more powerful in the field of imperialist competition for market sharing.  The JRC does not enter the debate on individual measures and proposals because it does not legitimise the debate on the ways and forms in which the exploitation, poverty and misery of workers will grow and deepen. EMU with whatever "architecture" they are based on, "economic governance", the Stability Pact, the Euro Pact, the Financial Pact, are "iron" mechanisms for imposing unpopular measures. They're not getting a fix. Those who claim that the EU can change for the benefit of the people are consciously deceiving workers into keeping them in the chariot of their exploiters. The only way to popular prosperity is to break with the EU, its capital and power, to disengage from the EU, to socialise monopolies with Labour-People's power.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjoined. (The sitting was closed at 10.50 p.m.)
